Question
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. On arrival, he is alert and oriented with a Glasgow Coma Scale rating of 14. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows multiple abrasions over his anterior abdomen and extremities. There is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. There are decreased breath sounds over the left base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. Bowel sounds are normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. A chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient, who has just been in a car accident, is in respiratory distress and has chest pain, decreased breath sounds over his left lung, and a chest x-ray that is typical for this condition.

A. Diaphragmatic rupture
B. Esophageal perforation
C. Flail chest
D. Pneumothorax
E. Phrenic nerve palsy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of progressive fatigue. During this time, she has had increasing shortness of breath and difficulty walking up the stairs. Medical history is noncontributory. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She takes a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. Cardiac examination shows jugular venous distention but no murmurs. Auscultation of the lungs shows bilateral basilar rales. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. The uterine fundus is palpated at the costal arch. Laboratory studies show:Urinalysis shows 1+ protein. ECG shows no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.35. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This previously healthy patient presents with features of systolic heart failure (dyspnea, peripheral edema, bibasilar rales, jugular venous distention, reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF)) during late pregnancy.

A. Amniotic fluid embolism
B. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
C. Severe preeclampsia
D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: D

Question
One year after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery, the patient comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She feels well. Her current medications include enalapril and metoprolol. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.4. She is currently considering another pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) < 0.5 indicates persistent LV dysfunction.

A. Initiate folic acid therapy and preconception screening
B. Replace enalapril with nifedipine therapy
C. Perform cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
D. Initiate loop diuretic therapy
E. Advise the patient against pregnancy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headache, cough, runny nose, and a low-grade fever since waking up that morning. He has been healthy except for a urinary tract infection 1 week ago that has resolved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy. Both parents have a history of allergic rhinitis. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). Physical examination shows rhinorrhea and tenderness to palpation over the frontal and maxillary sinuses. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's findings? This patient has isolated moderate neutropenia (low leukocyte count and a low percentage of neutrophils) in the absence of anemia or thrombocytopenia. Since the absolute number of other leukocytes (e.g., lymphocytes) remain normal, their overall concentration increases.

A. Primary autoimmune neutropenia
B. Folate deficiency
C. Medication side effect
D. Acute lymphocytic leukemia
E. Cytomegalovirus infection
F. Epstein-Barr virus infection
G. Acute myelogenous leukemia

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling of her left leg over the past 24 hours. The pain is worse while walking and improves when resting. Seven months ago, she was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism and was started on warfarin. Anticoagulant therapy was discontinued 1 month ago. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient does not smoke. She currently takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. On physical examination, the left calf is diffusely erythematous, swollen, and tender. Dorsal flexion of the left foot elicits pain. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. On duplex ultrasonography, the left popliteal vein is not compressible. Laboratory studies show an elevated serum concentration of D-dimer and insensitivity to activated protein C. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? This patient's history of pulmonary embolism, warfarin use, and clinical features of calf tenderness, swelling, erythema, elevated D-dimer, and noncompressible popliteal vein indicate a diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis. Her laboratory studies implicate insensitivity to activated protein C as the underlying cause.

A. Deficiency of antithrombin III
B. Deficiency of protein S
C. Antiphospholipid antibodies
D. Mutation of coagulation factor V
E. Mutation of prothrombin
F. Elevated levels of homocysteine
G. Deficiency of protein C

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 74-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and hip pain. During this period, he has also had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. He has not noticed any blood in his urine. He has a history of major depressive disorder and hypertension. His medications are fluoxetine and amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears tired. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Range of motion of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows multiple lytic lesions in the right ilium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Patients with this condition typically have an overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulins (typically IgG and IgA) and/or immunoglobulin fragments.

A. Primary hyperparathyroidism
B. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance
C. Multiple myeloma
D. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
E. Chondrosarcoma
F. Metastatic renal cell carcinoma

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty concentrating at work and generalized fatigue for the past 5 months. During this period, he has often fallen asleep while watching his favorite TV show. His wife reports that he snores loudly and often stops breathing for a few seconds while asleep. He has hypertension treated with metoprolol. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Daytime arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:A nighttime arterial blood gas analysis on room air would most likely show which of the following sets of findings? Daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and snoring with apneic episodes suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), for which obesity is a risk factor.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. He has been taking over-the-counter supplements for constipation for the past 5 years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His current medications include metformin. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg. Examination of the abdomen shows no masses. Palpation of the left lower abdomen elicits tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen with oral contrast is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the patient's condition? The patient's CT scan shows segmental thickening and enhancement of the colonic wall with air-filled pouches in the surrounding segments.

A. Focal weakness of the colonic muscularis layer
B. Infiltrative growth in the descending colon
C. Dysregulated immune response in the intestinal mucosa
D. Twisting of the sigmoid colon around its mesentery
E. Thrombosis of the inferior mesenteric vein

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with fever, dyspnea, and impaired consciousness. His wife reports that he has also had an episode of dark urine today. Two weeks ago, he returned from a trip to the Republic of Congo. His temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 114/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Decreased breath sounds and expiratory crackles are heard on auscultation of the lungs bilaterally. His hemoglobin concentration is 6.3 g/dL. A blood smear shows red blood cells with normal morphology and ring-shaped inclusions. Further laboratory testing shows normal rates of NADPH production. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient? This patient presents with features of severe malaria (shock, jaundice, pulmonary edema, impaired consciousness, and significant anemia), which is most commonly caused by Plasmodium falciparum (falciparum malaria).

A. Proguanil
B. Primaquine
C. Chloroquine
D. Atovaquone
E. Dapsone
F. Artesunate

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 68-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of worsening fatigue and swelling of his legs. He has had occasional exertional chest pain and shortness of breath over the past year but has not seen a physician. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years but currently smokes only four to five cigarettes daily. His medications include inhaled daily budesonide, formoterol, and tiotropium. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air discloses an oxygen saturation of 87%. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, mild cyanosis, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Lung auscultation shows a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Cardiac examination shows a loud P2 and a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard in the fourth intercostal space at the left sternal border. In addition to smoking cessation, which of the following is most effective to improve this patient’s life expectancy? This patient's hypoxemia, signs and symptoms of right heart failure (i.e., jugular venous distension, peripheral edema, loud P2,, tricuspid regurgitation), and history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) are highly suggestive of pulmonary hypertension (PH) and cor pulmonale.

A. Long-term oxygen therapy
B. Pneumococcal vaccination
C. Sildenafil therapy
D. Respiratory physiotherapy
E. Positive airway pressure therapy at night

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 39 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital after a spontaneous rupture of membranes and the onset of contractions. She noticed the fluid leak about an hour ago and has no associated bleeding. Contractions have been about 20 minutes apart. On admission, the cervix is 50% effaced and 2 cm dilated; the vertex is at -2 station. The patient is monitored using an external tocodynamometer. After 2 hours, the cervix is 70% effaced, 7 cm dilated, and the vertex is at -1 station. Four hours later, pelvic examination shows no changes. An intrauterine pressure catheter shows that contractions occur every 2 minutes, last 1 minute, and are 55 mm Hg in amplitude (275 Montevideo units). The fetal heart rate is 120/min, with moderate accelerations and no decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In a patient with ruptured membranes and cervical dilation ≥ 6 cm, no further cervical dilation after ≥ 4 hours of adequate uterine contractions (i.e., ≥ 200 Montevideo units) indicates an arrested active phase of labor.

A. Cesarean delivery
B. Assisted vaginal delivery
C. Oxytocin infusion
D. Amnioinfusion
E. Reassurance and close follow-up

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of multiple swellings in both axillae. She says they are generally painless but are sometimes painful on the weekends. She also has increased fatigue, recurring low-grade fever, and generalized pruritus. She does not smoke. She drinks five to six beers on the weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple firm, nontender axillary lymph nodes. A lymph node biopsy shows multinucleated giant lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli that resemble eosinophilic inclusions. Which of the following additional findings would be the strongest predictor of a good prognosis in this patient? This patient's presentation of cyclical fever, pruritus, and axillary lymphadenopathy that become painful upon alcohol intake is suspicious for Hodgkin lymphoma. Biopsy findings consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells confirm the diagnosis.

A. Mediastinal tumor occupying 45% of the chest width
B. Axillary tumor measuring 15 cm across
C. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/hour
D. Leukocyte count of 22,000/mm
E. Lymphocyte-rich classical type tumor

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue, poor appetite, and an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. The patient also reports several episodes of nausea and two episodes of non-bloody vomiting. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband, but states that she has lost desire in sexual intercourse lately. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 96/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with features of hypoaldosteronism (hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis), hypocortisolism (weight loss, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, hypotension), and hypoandrogenism (loss of libido). Deficiency in all three hormone classes produced by the adrenal cortex should raise concern for primary adrenal insufficiency (i.e., Addison disease).

A. Urine aldosterone level measurement
B. 24-hour urine cortisol measurement
C. Hydrocortisone administration
D. Adrenal imaging
E. Cosyntropin administration

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in her lower back. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity and radiates down her legs. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and major depressive disorder. Her current medications include sertraline, insulin, and enalapril. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/94 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple excoriation marks on the upper extremities and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. There is severe tenderness to palpation over the L2 vertebra; range of motion is limited. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the spine shows decreased bone density and a wedge compression fracture of the L2 vertebra. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's susceptibility to fractures? This patient's peripheral edema, pruritus (indicated by excoriation marks), anemia, increased BUN, increased creatinine, and hyperkalemia raise concern for chronic kidney disease (CKD). CKD can be complicated by renal osteodystrophy, a common cause of metabolic bone disease.

A. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
B. Secondary hyperparathyroidism
C. Hypoestrogenism
D. Pseudohypoparathyroidism
E. Primary hyperparathyroidism

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports that she has had frequent headaches and dizziness recently. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 170/100 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. Fetal heart rate is 155/min.Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? This pregnant patient has severe hypertension (systolic blood pressure > 160 mm Hg) and thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000/mm3), indicating preeclampsia with severe features.

A. Magnesium sulfate and labetalol therapy
B. Platelet transfusion
C. Induction of labor
D. Lisinopril therapy
E. ICU admission
F. Cesarean delivery

Correct Answer: A

Question
The patient is given prophylactic labetalol and magnesium sulfate. Examination shows absent deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? Consider the side effects!

A. Discontinue magnesium sulfate and administer calcium gluconate
B. Discontinue labetalol
C. Discontinue magnesium sulfate and administer lorazepam
D. Perform nerve conduction studies
E. Perform emergency cesarean section
F. Increase magnesium sulfate dose

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 22-year-old man who is on active duty in the US army sustains a stab wound to his chest during a military attack. He is brought to the combat medic by his unit for a primary survey. The soldier reports shortness of breath. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. His pulse is 99/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound at the left fourth intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Bubbling of blood is seen with each respiration at the wound site. There is no jugular venous distention. There is hyperresonance to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the left side. The trachea is at the midline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The presence of dyspnea and tachypnea with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance to percussion after a penetrating chest wound with bubbling of blood indicates an open pneumothorax. The absence of hemodynamic instability, tracheal deviation, and jugular venous distension make a tension pneumothorax unlikely.

A. Emergency thoracotomy
B. Partially occlusive dressing
C. Emergency pericardiocentesis
D. Emergency echocardiography
E. Needle thoracostomy

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 12-week history of persistent cough. The cough is nonproductive and worse at night. She otherwise feels well. She has not had any changes in appetite or exercise tolerance. For the past year, she has smoked cigarettes occasionally when with friends. Use of herbal cough medications has not provided any symptom relief. She has no history of serious illness but reports getting a runny nose every morning during winter. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Her FEV1 is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Chronic cough (> 8 weeks), a history of vasomotor rhinitis, and no signs of lower respiratory involvement (e.g., dyspnea, crackles, stridor) in young, immunocompetent patients are compatible with upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), the most common cause of chronic cough.

A. Smoking cessation
B. Prednisone therapy
C. Inhaled salmeterol
D. Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate
E. Oral pantoprazole
F. Codeine syrup
G. Oral acetylcysteine
H. Oral diphenhydramine

Correct Answer: H

Question

A. A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a 3-day history of fever, sore throat, and refusal to eat. He has not had a cough. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. He has no known allergies. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (108 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F). Examination of the oral cavity discloses erythema and edema of the oropharynx with grayish exudates overlying the palatine tonsils. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. Rapid antigen detection test for group A streptococci is positive. The physician prescribes penicillin V oral tablets. Which of the following is the most appropriate way to write the prescription? Physicians should prescribe medications as precisely and simply as possible in order to prevent errors and maximize patient safety.Penicillin V, 500 mg, orally, twice a day, for 10 days
B. Pen-V, 500.00 mg, orally, twice a day, as directed
C. Penicillin, 500 mg, PO, BID, for 10 days
D. Penicillin V, 25 mg/kg, orally, twice a day, as directed
Penicillin V, 25.
E. 0 mg/kg, orally, b.d.s., for 10 days

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 23-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She feels well and has no history of serious illness. She reports that she has been married for 2 years and has argued with her husband a lot during the past 6 months because she suspects that he is cheating on her. She hasn't spoken to her sister in 4 years because her sister “always humiliates me in front of others.” She gets along well with her friends but does not talk to them about her problems because she is afraid that they will gossip about her behind her back. She works as a teacher at an elementary school. She has been monogamous with her husband for the entire marriage except for a sexual relationship with a colleague 13 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she has a stable mood and a neutral affect. Her thought process is goal-directed and thought content focuses on possible negative eventualities, but she demonstrates intact reality testing. Her speech is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Projection is a defense mechanism often seen in individuals with this condition.

A. Paranoid personality disorder
B. Schizoid personality disorder
C. Avoidant personality disorder
D. Schizotypal personality disorder
E. Borderline personality disorder
F. Delusional disorder

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is exclusively breastfed and receives no medications. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. All routine immunizations are administered. Anticipatory guidance about feeding and development is given. At the end of the visit, the mother asks if she can continue using an oral pacifier for her daughter. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? Correct pacifier use can lower the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)."There are no adverse effects associated with the use of pacifiers in early infancy, and they can be used up until 5 years of age."29%
"Avoid using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age as it compromises breastfeeding. After 6 months, it is ok to use a pacifier."13%
"Pacifiers are usually only effective in the first month of life. There are no major benefits associated with pacifier use after this age."8%
"Pacifier use has no benefit and is not recommended at any age."6%
"Continue using oral pacifiers until 6 months of age, especially at the beginning of bedtime and nap time."43%

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of persistent vomiting after meals. The vomitus consists of undigested food and a clear fluid. His last attempt to eat was 6 hours ago and his last bowel movement was 3 days ago. For the past 3 weeks, the patient has had worsening nausea and early satiety. He also reports a 6.8-kg (15-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months. He has hypercholesterolemia treated with atorvastatin. The patient drinks 2–3 glasses of wine daily. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min and blood pressure is 120/65 mm Hg. Examination shows dry oral mucosa and conjunctival pallor. Abdominal examination shows epigastric fullness with mild tenderness. A sloshing sound is heard upon auscultation of the epigastrium when rocking the patient back and forth. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? This man has nonbilious emesis following food intake, early satiety, weight loss, epigastric tenderness, and a succussion splash, all of which indicate gastric outlet obstruction (GOO). In adults, GOO is caused by a malignant obstruction in the majority of cases.

A. Esophageal manometry
B. Esophageal pH monitoring
C. Abdominal ultrasound
D. Fecal elastase measurement
E. Upper endoscopy
F. CT angiography

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 48-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because he has become increasingly restless and anxious. His wife says that he has seemed sad and irritable for the past 4 months. He lost his job as a store clerk 1 year ago because he often lied to avoid work, and spent most of his days on the phone placing bets on football games. He avoids all family-related events because he has borrowed money from most of his relatives. He is hopeful that his symptoms will improve once he is able to win some of his money back. He previously smoked 8–10 cigarettes daily but quit 1 month ago. He drinks beer on the weekends. On examination, he is uncooperative and dismissive. He is mildly tremulous. Neurologic examination is normal. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has depressed mood and his behavior has caused significant dysfunction in his life.

A. Major depressive disorder
B. Nicotine withdrawal
C. Gambling disorder
D. Opioid withdrawal
E. Acute stress disorder
F. Alcohol withdrawal
G. Bipolar II disorder
H. Adjustment disorder

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 72-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her son for evaluation of cognitive decline. Her son reports that she has had increased difficulty finding her way back home for the last several months, despite having lived in the same city for 40 years. He also reports that his mother has been unable to recall the names of her relatives and been increasingly forgetting important family gatherings such as her grandchildren's birthdays over the last few years. The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include enalapril and metformin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after 5 minutes. Her gait and muscle strength are normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings? This patient's insidious onset of memory impairment, language abnormalities (impaired naming), and disorientation are consistent with Alzheimer disease (AD).

A. Hallucinations
B. Resting tremor
C. Positive Babinski sign
D. Generalized cerebral atrophy
E. Urinary incontinence
F. Myoclonic movements

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has quadriparesis as a result of a burst fracture of the cervical spine that occurred after a fall from his roof 1 month ago. He has urinary and bowel incontinence. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 104/60 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity in all extremities. Muscle strength is decreased in proximal and distal muscle groups bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and temperature is absent below the neck. Sensation to vibration, position, and fine touch is normal bilaterally. Rectal tone is decreased. There is a 1-cm area of erythema over the sacrum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and fine touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

A. Cavitation within the spinal cord
B. Occlusion of the posterior spinal artery
C. Hemi-transection of the spinal cord
D. Damage to the anterior spinal artery
E. Injury to gray matter of the spinal cord

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 67-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well but reports occasional episodes of slurred speech and weakness during the past 6 months. He has a history of peripheral arterial disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gout. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He drinks 3 cans of beer daily. His current medications include aspirin, metformin, enalapril, simvastatin, and febuxostat. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Auscultation of the right side of the neck shows a bruit. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference ranges. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm, mild left ventricular hypertrophy, and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's occasional episodes of weakness and slurred speech are consistent with transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). This history, in combination with his peripheral vascular disease, multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia), and carotid bruit indicate symptomatic carotid artery stenosis (CAS) due to atherosclerosis.

A. Ultrasonography of the neck
B. Echocardiography
C. Warfarin therapy
D. CT angiography of the head
E. Digital subtraction angiography of the neck

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She reports that her “water broke” yesterday, and she has had malodorous discharge since then. Her pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. On admission, she has regular contractions that occur every 2 minutes, and her cervix is 10 cm dilated and fully effaced. After vaginal delivery of a 4136-g (9-lb 2-oz) male newborn, intravenous oxytocin infusion is started for active management of the third stage of labor, and the placenta is delivered completely. Shortly after, the patient develops heavy vaginal bleeding with clots. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft uterus that is palpated 5 cm above the umbilicus. Her bleeding continues despite bimanual uterine massage and manual removal of intrauterine clots. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? This patient has postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), as evidenced by the heavy vaginal bleeding after giving birth. Her soft, enlarged uterus indicates uterine atony as an underlying cause.

A. Transfuse fresh frozen plasma
B. Place compression sutures
C. Increase oxytocin infusion
D. Administer misoprostol
E. Perform intrauterine tamponade
F. Administer methylergonovine

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 65-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening shortness of breath and cough. She has a mild productive cough for the past 2 years but she noticed that her sputum is more yellow than usual over the past 2 days. She has not had any recent fevers, chills, sore throat, or a runny nose. Her only medication is a salmeterol inhaler that she uses twice daily. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 134/73 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. She appears uncomfortable and shows labored breathing. Auscultation of the lungs discloses rhonchi that disappear after coughing and diffuse bilateral wheezes. A chest x-ray shows mild hyperinflation and flattening of the diaphragm but no consolidation. She is started on supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. B. Albuterol and montelukast
C. Prednisone and salmeterol
D. Albuterol and theophylline
E. Prednisone and albuterol
F. Prednisone and tiotropium

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of belly pain and a pruritic skin rash on her shoulders for the last 6 months. She describes feeling bloated after meals. Over the past 3 months, she has had multiple loose bowel movements per day. She appears thin. She is at the 20th percentile for height and 8th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and inflammation of the corners of the mouth. There are several tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the shoulders bilaterally. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? This patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain and bloating, and features of malabsorption such as failure to thrive and signs of iron deficiency anemia (e.g., conjunctival pallor, angular cheilitis). These features together with dermatitis herpetiformis (several tense, grouped subepidermal blisters) are consistent with the diagnosis of celiac disease. The clinical features of celiac disease can occur at any age but typically begin in early childhood or between 20–40 years of age).

A. Multinucleated trophozoites in stool
B. Increased serum lipase
C. Inflammation of the terminal ileum
D. Esophageal webs
E. PAS-positive macrophages
F. IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies
G. Positive hydrogen breath test
H. Oocysts on acid-fast stain

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department in the middle of the night because of difficulties breathing. Her parents say that the breathing noises have become progressively worse throughout the day and are mainly heard when she inhales. They say that a change in posture does not seem to have any effect on her breathing. For the last three days, she has also had a runny nose and a harsh cough. She has not had hemoptysis. The parents are worried she may have accidentally swallowed something while playing with her toys since she tends to put small things in her mouth. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears anxious, and high-pitched wheezing is heard at rest during inhalation. Her skin tone is normal. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. B. Nebulized racemic epinephrine

E. Nebulized dexamethasone
F. Reassurance only
G. Intubation

Question

Question
A 27-year-old man with schizophrenia comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, he was admitted to the hospital and underwent treatment for a psychotic episode. He has had one prior psychotic episode 3 years ago. He is currently undergoing weekly sessions of cognitive behavioral therapy and his only medication is risperidone. He lives with his mother and two younger siblings; his father left the family when the patient was a teenager. The patient works about 20 hours each week in a fast food restaurant. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years and drinks two to three beers daily. He does not use illicit drugs. He appears well. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he has a neutral affect and describes his mood as “decent.” His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. His thought process is organized and there are no abnormalities of thought content. Short-term and long-term memory are intact. B. Social skills training

D. Assertive community treatment

Question

C. Dilation and curettage

Question

His parents state that he sometimes does not turn when called but gets startled by loud noises. He does not maintain eye contact. He was able to roll over from front to back at 5 months of age and has not yet begun to sit or crawl. His parents are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. Neurological examination shows generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows extensor response bilaterally. This infant presents with developmental delay, regression of achieved milestones (inability to roll over despite reaching this milestone three months prior), absence seizures (episodes of unresponsiveness with a blank stare), decreased eye contact, hypotonia, exaggerated startle response as a result of hyperacusis, hearing loss (unresponsive when called), hyperreflexia, and bilateral bright red (“cherry-red”) spots on fundoscopy, all of which are characteristic features of Tay-Sachs disease.

Question

Question

Question

Laboratory studies, including a urine toxicology screen, show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? B. Switch to oral clozapine

Question

Question
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive shortness of breath and difficulty swallowing. She can no longer take long walks with her dog because she gets out of breath easily. She has also had fatigue, muscle aches, and joint pain for 6 months. She says that her fingers recently started to become pale and numb in cold water, and warm and red on reheating. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one glass of wine weekly. Her pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. This patient presents with nonspecific features of an autoimmune connective tissue disease (CTD), including fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, Raynaud syndrome, anemia, and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs), in addition to signs of pulmonary involvement, which has led to pulmonary hypertension (e.g., dyspnea, jugular venous distention, accentuated, split S2). B. Sjogren syndrome

E. Mixed connective tissue disorder

Question
A 58-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of a 10-day history of progressively worsening diarrhea and bloating. He has been having 8–10 episodes of loose, watery stools each day, including during the night. He does not have nausea, vomiting, or blood in his stool. He has a history of metastatic colon cancer and started chemotherapy 2 weeks ago. He also has Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, for which he takes procainamide. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drank 2–3 beers daily but quit both last year when his grandson was born. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 105/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pale skin with a decreased turgor; capillary refill time is 2 seconds. His abdomen is distended and tender on palpation; bowel sounds are hyperactive. Laboratory studies show:Blood and stool cultures are negative. A test for Clostridioides difficile toxins is negative. In addition to oral rehydration, which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? This patient developed progressively worsening diarrhea shortly after starting chemotherapy, which suggests chemotherapy-induced diarrhea (CTID). Moderate nonbloody diarrhea, signs of mild dehydration (mild hypotension and tachycardia, decreased skin turgor, slightly delayed capillary refill, hemoconcentration, mild hypernatremia), normal creatinine, and lack of fever, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping indicate uncomplicated CTID.

A. Rectal budesonide
B. Oral rifaximin
C. Oral vancomycin
D. Intravenous octreotide
E. Oral loperamide

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 19-month-old girl is brought for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy. On physical examination, the child is alert and active. Her temperature is 37.3 °C (99.1 °F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/54 mm Hg. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and a split S2 during inspiration. A grade 2/6 soft mid-systolic murmur is heard maximally at the lower left sternal border. A contrast echocardiogram is performed and reveals a mild transient right-to-left interatrial shunt that becomes apparent when the child coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A right-to-left interatrial shunt (made apparent by a saline bubble study on echocardiography) that opens during coughing is diagnostic of patent foramen ovale (PFO). During coughing, right-to-left shunting of blood can occur through this defect because of the transiently increased pressure in the pulmonary circulation (and consequently increased right atrial pressure).

A. Percutaneous closure
B. No intervention
C. Warfarin therapy
D. Aspirin therapy
E. Surgical closure
F. Regular echocardiographies

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Question
A 71-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for evaluation after being treated for an intentional drug overdose. Her husband reports that she refuses to eat, often stays awake at night, and has lost 7 kg (15 lb) over the past month. He says that her symptoms began after the death of her estranged son 2 months ago. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease. She underwent coronary artery bypass grafting and pacemaker implantation 5 years ago. Her current medications include metformin, lisinopril, clopidogrel, and temazepam. She appears fatigued and emaciated. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 40 kg (88 lb); BMI is 15 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-healed midline scar over the sternum. A pacemaker is palpable below the left clavicle. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and a tearful affect. When asked about active suicidal ideation, she says in a soft voice, “It is not worth living anymore. My son is dead because I failed to reconcile with him. My death will make him happy.” Laboratory studies including thyroid function tests, serum electrolyte concentrations, and a 24-hour urine cortisol concentration are within reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Features of a major depressive episode (weight loss, sleep disturbance, suicidal ideation, depressed mood, fatigue) with mood-congruent psychoses (delusions of guilt) indicate a diagnosis of major depressive disorder (MDD) with psychotic features. Methohexital and succinylcholine are administered prior to initiation of the appropriate therapy for this patient.

A. Amitriptyline and olanzapine therapy
B. Transcranial magnetic stimulation therapy
C. Fluoxetine therapy
D. Acceptance-based depression and psychosis therapy
E. Electroconvulsive therapy
F. Lithium therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a rash on his neck and back for the past 6 hours. He says that he first noticed some reddening of the skin on his back the previous evening, which turned into a blistering, red rash overnight. He went surfing the previous day and spent 5 hours at the beach. He reports having applied at least 1 oz of water-resistant SPF 30 sunscreen 30 minutes before leaving his home. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows erythema of the skin over the upper back and dorsum of the neck, with 3 vesicles filled with clear fluid. The affected area is edematous and tender to touch. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate to prevent a recurrence of this patient's symptoms in the future? B. Apply sunscreen directly before getting into water
C. Use SPF 50 sunscreen
D. Only go outside on cloudy days
E. Apply at least 3 oz of sunscreen
F. Use waterproof sunscreen

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

Question
A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of chest pain and shortness of breath for 3 days. The pain is present at rest and worsens with deep inspiration. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows a small left-sided pleural effusion but no other abnormalities. A diagnostic thoracentesis is performed and 100 mL of bloody fluid are aspirated from the left pleural space. Pleural fluid analysis shows a lactate dehydrogenase of 150 U/L, a total protein of 5.1 g/dL, and a glucose concentration of 85 mg/dL. Pleural fluid cytology shows normal cell morphology. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show a history of which of the following? The serum and pleural fluid analysis fulfills all three Light criteria for exudative pleural effusion: pleural fluid protein:serum protein ratio is greater than 0.5, pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):serum LDH is greater than 0.6, and pleural LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal serum LDH (200 U/L).

A. Oropharyngeal dysphagia
B. Infliximab use
C. Prolonged immobilization
D. Congestive heart failure
E. Asbestos exposure
F. Alcoholic cirrhosis

Correct Answer: C

Question

After the physician administers the third dose of the rabies vaccine, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. This patient is expected to receive at least one more shot of rabies vaccine for the completion of her post-exposure prophylaxis.Inform the patient that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical.66%
Inform the patient that dating her will never be appropriate even once the physician-patient relationship has been terminated.21%
Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her, but that she will have to transfer her care to a different physician.11%

Question
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Urinalysis is positive for a polysaccharide antigen. Microscopic examination of a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen shows macrophages filled with oval cells that measure 1–5 μm and bud from a narrow base. Culture of the specimen on Sabouraud agar at 24°C grows molds composed of septate hyphae. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? Microbiological examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows a dimorphic fungus, which typically exists in a yeast form in body tissue (37°C) and in a hyphal form at room temperature (20–30°C). Microscopic findings also show that the yeast form of this pathogen is intracellular and smaller than an erythrocyte, which is 8–10 μm in size.

A. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
B. Cryptococcus neoformans
C. Legionella pneumophila
D. Coccidioides immitis
E. Aspergillus fumigatus
F. Pneumocystis jirovecii
G. Histoplasma capsulatum
H. Blastomyces dermatitidis

Correct Answer: G

Question

Question
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent, crampy abdominal pain, bloating, and nonbloody diarrhea. Two months ago, she went on a cruise in England and visited several cities in Norway to trace her ancestral roots. During the trip, she ate at a farm-to-table restaurant for dinner and had multiple episodes of nonbloody, nonbilious emesis overnight that resolved spontaneously. She has noticed that ever since returning home, she develops intermittent diffuse abdominal pain and excessive flatulence after ingesting certain foods, including ice cream, pizza, and milkshakes. She was diagnosed with asthma and atopic dermatitis as a child. She does not remember the last time she used her albuterol inhaler, which is prescribed as needed. She applies triamcinolone 0.1% cream to affected skin areas. She drinks 2 beers every weekend. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She is in no apparent distress. Examination shows a soft, nondistended, nontender abdomen. There are small, patchy areas of dry and lichenified skin inside her elbows and at the nape of her neck. A hydrogen breath test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s diarrhea? The hydrogen breath test assesses the intestinal absorption of individual carbohydrates. A rise in exhaled hydrogen levels (i.e., a positive hydrogen breath test) occurs when unabsorbed carbohydrates are metabolized by colonic bacteria, producing hydrogen during the process.

A. Infection with Tropheryma whipplei
B. Autoimmune-mediated intolerance to gliadin
C. Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine
D. Decreased pancreatic enzyme production
E. Loss of intestinal brush border
F. Allergic reaction to cow milk protein

Correct Answer: E

Question

Question
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department in active labor. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. The patient's blood type is Rh-negative. She received all of her prenatal care for this pregnancy including a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. Four hours after arrival, a healthy 3650-g (8-lb) female newborn is delivered. Delivery of the fetus is followed by placental retention and heavy vaginal bleeding. One hour later, the placenta is manually removed and the bleeding ceases. The mother's temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect of each thigh. The neonate's blood type is Rh-positive. The rosette test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In order to prevent Rh sensitization in nonsensitized Rh-negative mothers, anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered at 28 weeks' gestation (typically a single standard dose without confirmation of the fetal blood type) and, if the newborn is Rh-positive, within 72 hours following delivery. The risk of Rh sensitization is proportional to the amount of fetomaternal hemorrhage (FMH).

A. Perform a Kleihauer-Betke test
B. Perform an apt test
C. Administer a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin
D. Perform an indirect Coombs test
E. Reassurance only

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 41-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for worsening shortness of breath for several weeks. Her symptoms continued to worsen despite the administration of nebulized bronchodilators and oral corticosteroids. Physical examination shows accessory respiratory muscle use. There is inspiratory stridor. Pulmonary examination shows bilaterally diminished breath sounds and no wheezing. Cardiac and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? A flow-volume curve would show flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory portions of the flow-volume loop, which is characteristic of a fixed upper airway obstruction.

B. Measure total serum IgE concentration

Question
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of a 2-month history of painless swellings on his neck. He also reports a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss during this period and increased fatigue. He has no history of previous illness. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His only medication is a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several enlarged, rubbery, nontender, cervical lymph nodes on both sides of his neck, with the largest measuring 2 x 2 cm. An excisional cervical lymph node biopsy is performed. Histologic examination of the biopsy specimen shows giant, CD15+ and CD30+, binucleated cells with prominent nucleoli. In this patient's condition, which of the following is most likely to be associated with an unfavorable prognosis? Histologic examination of this patient's lymph node biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells, which are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) and confirm the diagnosis.

A. 12;21 chromosomal translocation on karyotyping
B. High lactate dehydrogenase concentration on serum studies
C. Lymphocytosis on lymph node biopsy

F. Basophilia on a complete blood count

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling in her legs for the past 2 months. She has noticed that her legs gradually swell up throughout the day. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. She works as a waitress at a local diner. Her father died of liver cancer at the age of 61 years. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the calves with relative sparing of the feet. There are several dilated, compressible tortuous veins measuring 4–5 mm over both lower extremities, and multiple excoriation marks are noted over both ankles. There is a 2 x 2-cm ulcer with a shallow base and irregular edges over the medial surface of the left ankle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Serum glucose, urea nitrogen, creatinine, D-dimer concentrations, and results of liver function tests are within the reference ranges. The ankle-brachial index is 1.1 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Lower extremity edema with relative sparing of the feet and dilated tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (varicose veins) in the absence of other systemic findings (e.g., pulmonary crackles, jugular venous distention) strongly suggests chronic venous disease (CVD), for which this patient's age, sex, and job that involves prolonged standing are risk factors. The presence of certain skin changes such as pruritic dermatitis or a venous ulcer indicates advanced CVD.

A. Sclerotherapy
B. Clopidogrel and cilostazol therapy
C. Duplex ultrasonography
D. Compression stocking therapy
E. Contrast venography

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for 3 days. The pain is retrosternal, 8 out of 10 in intensity, increases with respiration, and decreases while sitting upright and leaning forward. He has nausea and myalgia. He has not had fever or a cough. He has asthma and was treated for bronchitis 6 months ago with azithromycin. His mother has hypertension. He uses an over-the-counter inhaler. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched grating sound between S1 and S2. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations in all leads. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions? The patient's 3-day history of chest pain that increases with respiration and decreases while sitting up, in conjunction with a friction rub on cardiac auscultation, nausea, and myalgia, is suggestive of acute pericarditis. The ECG finding of ST elevations in all leads with a mild increase in troponin I further support the diagnosis.

A. Papillary muscle rupture
B. Pulmonary infarction
C. Mediastinitis
D. Cardiac tamponade
E. Ventricular aneurysm

Correct Answer: D

Question
An 8-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital after sustaining a left supracondylar humerus fracture and left proximal forearm fracture in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. He undergoes closed reduction and percutaneous pinning. The day after his surgery, he is crying and has severe left arm pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/76 mm Hg. When his fingers are extended passively, he yells in agony and says the pain is even worse. After the cast is removed, physical examination shows a diffuse firm swelling of the forearm and severe pain with palpation. The left radial pulse is palpable and the capillary refill time is 2 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate study to confirm the diagnosis? Severely tender forearm swelling accompanied by excruciating pain that worsens with palpation and passive muscle stretch in a patient with a history of bone fractures is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome. Palpable pulses and a normal capillary refill time indicate an early, reversible presentation.

A. Needle manometry
B. CT arteriography
C. Duplex ultrasonography
D. MRI of the left forearm
E. Nerve conduction study
F. Serum creatine kinase concentration

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath on exertion for 3 months. He has a history of recurrent patellar dislocations. E. Water hammer pulse

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is unconscious. Her pulse is 140/min, respirations are 12/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. 0.9% saline infusion is begun. A focused assessment with sonography shows blood in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen. Her hemoglobin concentration is 7.6 g/dL and hematocrit is 22%. The surgeon decides to move the patient to the operating room for an emergency explorative laparotomy. Packed red blood cell transfusion is ordered prior to surgery. A friend of the patient asks for the transfusion to be held as the patient is a Jehovah's Witness. The patient has no advance directive and there is no documentation showing her refusal of blood transfusions. The patient's husband and children cannot be contacted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Even though this patient's friend claims the patient is a Jehovah's Witness, there is no documentation to verify this claim nor the patient's wishes under these circumstances. B. Transfusion of packed red blood cells
C. Consult hospital ethics committee
D. Administer high-dose iron dextran
E. Proceed to surgery without transfusion

Correct Answer: B

Question

B. Coombs test
C. Eosin-5-maleimide binding test
D. Hemoglobin electrophoresis

Question
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because he has been waking up frequently during the night to urinate for the past 3 months. B. Clear cell renal carcinoma

Question
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of progressive fatigue and intermittent abdominal pain. During this time, she has noticed that her urine is darker when she wakes up in the morning. Her stool is of normal color. Five months ago, she was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. Physical examination shows pallor and jaundice. There is no splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:A direct antiglobulin test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications? This patient's clinical features (fatigue, abdominal pain, dark urine in the morning, jaundice), pancytopenia, intravascular hemolysis (unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated LDH, low haptoglobin, hemoglobinuria), negative direct Coombs test, and normal peripheral blood smear (PBS) are suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

A. Cholesterol gallstones
B. Acrocyanosis
C. Hepatocellular carcinoma
D. Venous thrombosis
E. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
F. Seizures

Correct Answer: D

Question
A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-week history of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. Last week he noticed that his eyes were gradually turning yellow and that his urine was dark. He reports no dysuria or changes in urinary frequency. He has a family history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae, jaundice, and splenomegaly. There is no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral blood smear shows gross polychromasia with nucleated red blood cells and spherocytes. A direct antiglobulin test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient's clinical (fatigue, jaundice, dark urine, splenomegaly) and laboratory findings (low hemoglobin and elevated reticulocytes, indirect bilirubin, and LDH) are consistent with hemolytic anemia. The positive direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) indicates the presence of antibodies bound to the RBC surface membrane.

A. Hereditary spherocytosis
B. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C. Alpha thalassemia
D. Spur cell hemolytic anemia
E. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

Correct Answer: E

Question

B. Vitamin B12 deficiency
C. Iron deficiency
D. Intravascular hemolysis

Question
A 71-year old man is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath that have lasted for 3 days. During the last month, he has also noticed dark-colored urine. He had an upper respiratory infection 6 weeks ago. He underwent cholecystectomy at the age of 30 years. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include simvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. He immigrated from Italy 50 years ago. He appears pale. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 128/98 mm Hg. Auscultation of the heart shows a grade 4/6 systolic murmur over the right second intercostal space that radiates to the carotids. Laboratory studies show:A direct antiglobulin test is negative. Stool testing for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient's anemia? The patient's dark urine, increased LDH, and decreased hemoglobin, hematocrit, and haptoglobin are consistent with intravascular hemolytic anemia (IHA). The presence of a loud systolic murmur in the second intercostal space with radiation to the carotid region suggests aortic stenosis (AS). Calcific AS can cause IHA due to increased turbulent flow.

A. Administration of corticosteroids
B. Administration of hydroxyurea
C. Supplementation with iron
D. Aortic valve replacement
E. Discontinuation of medication

Correct Answer: D

Question
One day after undergoing an open colectomy, a 65-year-old man with colon cancer experiences shivers. The procedure was originally scheduled to be done laparoscopically, but it was converted because of persistent bleeding. The surgery was uneventful. Five years ago, he underwent renal transplantation because of cystic disease and has been taking prednisolone since then. He has a history of allergy to sulfonamides. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/62 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a midline incision extending from the xiphisternum to the pubic symphysis. There is a 5-cm (2-in) area of purplish discoloration near the margin of the incision in the lower abdomen. Palpation of the abdomen produces severe pain and crackling sounds are heard. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This man with hyperglycemia and postoperative fever one day after undergoing open colectomy has purplish discoloration of the margins of his surgical incision along with severe tenderness to palpation and crackling sounds indicating necrotizing fasciitis. The raised blood urea and creatinine levels may indicate acute kidney injury, and a qSOFA score of 2 (respiratory rate > 22/min and systolic blood pressure < 100 mm Hg) suggests early sepsis.

A. X-ray of the abdomen and pelvis
B. Vacuum-assisted wound closure device
C. Surgical exploration with debridement
D. Oral cefuroxime and metronidazole therapy
E. CT scan of abdomen
F. Intravenous clindamycin therapy

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question
