Question
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of developmental delay. He could sit alone at 12 months and started walking with support at the age of 2 years. He can name only very few familiar objects and uses simple two-word sentences. He cannot stack more than 2 blocks. His parents report that he does not like playing with other children. He is at the 90th percentile for head circumference, 85th percentile for height, and 50th percentile for weight. He has a long and narrow face, a prominent chin and large protruding ears. His thumbs can be passively flexed to the ipsilateral forearm. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions? This boy's delayed development, autistic behavior, long and narrow face with a prominent chin, protruding ears, and above average head circumference indicate fragile X syndrome. Affected individuals often present with hypermobility of their joints and intellectual disability.

B. Acute myeloid leukemia
C. Hearing loss
D. Aortic dissection
E. Type 2 diabetes mellitus
F. Hyperuricemia

Question
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of difficulty speaking. The symptoms began abruptly one hour ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. He is right-handed. The patient speaks in short, simple sentences, and has difficulty repeating sequences of words. He can follow simple instructions. Right facial droop is present. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left, and there is a mild right-sided pronator drift downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms? This patient presents with sudden-onset focal neurologic deficits that are consistent with stroke. Telegraphic speech (as evidenced by the use of short, simple sentences), intact comprehension (as evidenced by the ability to follow commands), and impaired repetition of word sequences are consistent with Broca aphasia. The presence of this type of language deficit helps localize the damage to a specific region of the cortex.

A. Occlusion of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
B. Occlusion of the right penetrating arteries
C. Occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
D. Occlusion of the left penetrating arteries
E. Dissection of the right vertebral artery
F. Occlusion of the left middle cerebral artery
G. Rupture of right posterior cerebral artery malformation
H. Occlusion of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
. Rupture of left posterior cerebral artery malformation
. Dissection of the left vertebral artery

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 6-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of her eyes and body, vomiting, and poor feeding for 3 days. She has had diarrhea for the past 2 days. B. Frequent glucose feeds
C. Avoidance of milk feeds
D. Thiamine therapy
E. Levothyroxine therapy

Question

B. Electromyography

D. Thyroid ultrasound

Question
A 67-year-old man is brought to the physician because of increasing forgetfulness, unsteadiness, and falls over the past year. He reports that these symptoms seem to worsen with each fall. Initially, he could not remember directions to his home but now cannot remember recent conversations or appointments he has made. He often repeats questions that he asked shortly before. He has long-standing hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, carvedilol, enalapril, and atorvastatin. Examination shows a bruise over the left temple and an unsteady gait. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place only. Short-term memory is impaired; he can recall 0 out of 5 objects after 10 minutes. Long-term memory is intact. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressive headache and neck pain for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had multiple episodes of dizziness and tingling sensations in his arms and hands. A year ago, he underwent closed reduction of a dislocated shoulder he sustained after a fall. He underwent surgical removal of a saclike protuberance on his lower back, soon after being born. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. His neck is supple. Neurological examination shows sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally and normal gross motor function. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral optic disk swelling. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient presents with features of hydrocephalus (headache, dizziness, papilledema, and dilated ventricles on MRI), syringomyelia (cape-like distribution of tingling in the upper extremities), and myelomeningocele (a saclike lesion on the lower back), all of which are characteristic of this condition.

B. Intraventricular hemorrhage

D. Dandy-Walker malformation
E. Chiari II malformation
F. Vestibular schwannoma
G. Tuberculous meningitis
H. Brachial plexus injury
. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 36-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Apgar scores are 7 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and 15th percentile for length. Examination shows a prominent posterior part of the head. The ears are low-set and the jaw is small and retracted. The fists are clenched, with overlapping second and third fingers. The calcaneal bones are prominent and the plantar surface of the foot shows a convex deformity. Abdominal examination shows an omphalocele. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? Prominent occiput, microcephaly, low-set ears, clenched fists with flexion contractures, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet) are all characteristic of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).

A. Ventricular septal defect
B. Ebstein anomaly
C. Macroorchidism
D. Pheochromocytoma
E. Holoprosencephaly
F. Hirschsprung disease

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. His mother says he has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 49/min and blood pressure is 62/40 mm Hg. A grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border and a thrill is present at the same location. Echocardiography shows a 3-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is the most common congenital heart defect (CHD) and causes a holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Small VSDs (diameter ≤ 3 mm) cause less left-to-right shunting but louder murmurs than medium or large VSDs.

A. Amoxicillin therapy
B. Surgical patch closure
C. Prostaglandin E1 therapy
D. Outpatient follow-up
E. Indomethacin therapy
F. Cardiac catheterization
G. Transcatheter closure

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed that he tires easily and sweats while feeding. During the past week, she has noticed that his lips and nails turn blue while crying. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and weighed 2100 g (4 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 2300 g (5 lb 1 oz). His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 72/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is most responsible for this patient's cyanosis? The presence of intermittent cyanosis, fatigue, and sweating during periods of exertion in a neonate with a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border and a single S2 is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

A. Degree of right ventricular hypertrophy
B. Degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction
C. Size of ventricular septal defect
D. Degree of aortic override
E. Size of atrial septal defect
F. Degree of left ventricular outflow obstruction

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because his lips turned blue for several minutes while playing earlier that evening. She reports that he has had similar episodes during feeding that resolved quickly. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He is at the 25th percentile for length and below the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 83/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. During the examination, he sits calmly in his mother's lap. He appears well. The patient begins to cry when examination of his throat is attempted; his lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following? The cyanotic episode described here is characteristic of the tet spells seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

A. Pulmonary vascular congestion on x-ray of the chest
B. Decreased blood pressure in both lower extremities
C. Right axis deviation on ECG
D. Machine-like hum on auscultation
E. Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography
F. Diminutive left ventricle on echocardiogram

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath for the past 2 days. He is at 30th percentile for height and at 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 80/44 mm Hg. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination discloses a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border and a grade 1/6 middiastolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following? A holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and the middiastolic murmur (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect.

A. Cerebral aneurysm
B. Polycythemia
C. Systemic arterial hypertension
D. Thrombocytosis
E. Myocardial ischemia

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has tingling and numbness of his legs for the past 10 days. He has also felt more tired than usual. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and started on antituberculosis therapy. He appears pale. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry scaly lips and cracks at the corner of the mouth. Neurological examination shows normal muscle strength. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.4 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Administration of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's current symptoms? A. Iron
B. Pyridoxine
C. Intravenous immunoglobulins
D. Vitamin E
E. Folic acid
F. Vitamin B

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 33-year-old primigravid woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography at 12 weeks' gestation showed a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. At that visit, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A was decreased to 2 standard deviations below the mean. A chorionic villus sampling was performed, which showed a 47, XX karyotype. At today's visit, vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone. A quad screening test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings? Increased nuchal translucency, decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) levels, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. An ultrasound examination confirms the gestational age and shows one fetus with no indication of multiple gestations. During counseling on pregnancy risks and possible screening and diagnostic tests, the patient states she would like to undergo screening for Down syndrome. She wants to undergo screening immediately and would prefer a reliable screening method with a low risk to herself and the fetus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time? This patient requires a noninvasive screening test of high sensitivity and specificity for Down syndrome that can be performed at 10 weeks' gestation.

A. Maternal serum α-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, unconjugated estriol, and inhibin A
B. Amniocentesis
C. Nuchal translucency scan
D. Cell-free fetal DNA testing
E. Chorionic villus sampling

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 37-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 13 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her only medication is folic acid. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. A. Chorionic villus sampling
B. Quadruple marker test
C. Cell-free fetal DNA testing
D. Triple screening test
E. Amniocentesis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 μm3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. E. Recent history of NSAID use

Question
A 4-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned that he is losing weight. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz); he currently weighs 2830 g (6 lb 4 oz). Pregnancy was uncomplicated. He passed stool and urine 8 and 10 hours after delivery. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and feeds 11–12 times daily. His mother says she changes 5–6 heavy diapers daily. Examination shows an open and soft anterior fontanelle. B. Switch to soy-based formula

E. Add cow's milk-based formula

G. Continue breastfeeding

Question
Two hours after a 2280-g (5-lb) male newborn is born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, he has 2 episodes of vomiting and jitteriness. The mother has noticed that the baby is not feeding adequately. She received adequate prenatal care and admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily while pregnant. The newborn's temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 171/min and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows facial plethora. B. Intraventricular hemorrhage

D. Hyperinsulinism
E. Congenital heart disease

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of delay in attaining developmental milestones. He could sit upright by 14 months and has not been able to walk without support. He can build a tower of 3 blocks but cannot use utensils to feed himself. He speaks in unclear 2-word phrases and cannot draw a circle yet. His mother has noticed him hitting his head against the wall on multiple occasions. He is at 20th percentile for height and at 50th percentile for weight. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple lacerations of his lips and tongue. There are multiple healing wounds over his fingers. Neurological examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings? The presence of developmental delay, abnormal muscle tone, and self-injurious behavior in a boy with macrocytic anemia, increased creatinine, and hyperuricemia indicate Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

A. FMR1 gene mutation
B. MECP2 gene mutation
C. Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase complex deficiency
D. Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency
E. Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency
F. Uridine monophosphate synthetase deficiency
Microdeletion of paternal chromosome 152%
G. Iduronate-2-sulfatase deficiency

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He started walking at 20 months of age. He can use a cup to drink but cannot use silverware. He speaks in 2-word sentences and can build a tower of 4 blocks. He can scribble but cannot draw a circle. He is above the 99th percentile for height and at the 15th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral inferior lens dislocation. His fingers are long and slender. He has a high-arched palate. B. Fibrillin 1 deficiency

D. Cystathionine synthase deficiency
E. Galactokinase deficiency

Question

Question

The lesions first appeared at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. Immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groin, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient presents with recurring respiratory infections, lymphadenopathy, and inflammatory, pustular lesions, starting at a very young age. D. Atopic dermatitis
E. Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
F. Chediak-Higashi syndrome

Question
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child visit. At his last well-child visit 9 months ago, the patient had not begun talking. The parents report that their son frequently avoids eye contact and has no friends at daycare. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of otitis media 6 months ago, which was treated with amoxicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 95th percentile for height, 20th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears shy. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/55 mm Hg. Examination shows an elongated face, a prominent jaw, and large ears. The patient does not speak. He does not follow instructions to build a stack of 2 blocks. Throughout the examination, he continually opens and closes his mother's purse and does not maintain eye contact. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? This patient's facial features (long face, prominent jaw, large ears), above-average height and head circumference, intellectual disability (delayed language development, inability to follow instructions or stack two blocks), and autistic behavior (repetitive actions, lack of eye contact) are consistent with fragile X syndrome.

D. Defective phenylalanine hydroxlyase activity

Question

Question

Question

Question

She did not smoke or drink alcohol during her pregnancy. The infant appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 41/22 mm Hg. Examination shows clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion. An ECG shows frequent extrasystoles and peaked T waves. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Chromosomal analysis shows a 46,XX karyotype. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of additional serum findings? Virilization of the external genitalia in a karyotypically female infant (i.e., female pseudohermaphroditism), failure to thrive, and metabolic acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis indicate a diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The most common cause of CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-hour history of left shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder. He began taking swimming classes a couple of weeks ago and he has been complaining of shoulder pain during those classes. He often has to stop swimming and interrupt the class. His parents report that he has been healthy except for the fact that he bruises easily and sometimes does not eat because of pain while chewing. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows the left upper extremity externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the left shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The left humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The right upper extremity is unremarkable. The skin can be stretched further than normal and is fragile. There are widened atrophic scars on his knees. There is tenderness to palpation of the temporomandibular joints bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? Multiple episodes of shoulder pain during swimming classes are suggestive of shoulder subluxations.

A. Impaired copper absorption
B. Defective type III procollagen
C. Defective type V collagen
D. Fibrillin-1 gene mutation
E. Defective type I collagen

Correct Answer: C

Question

Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 64/min. Examination shows bluish extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. There are decreased breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities. Supplemental oxygen is administered by nasal cannula. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Signs of increased breathing effort (tachypnea, subcostal retractions), cyanosis, grunting, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation in a preterm neonate indicate neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). The x-ray with low lung volumes and diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) densities confirms the diagnosis.

A. Nitric oxide therapy
B. Corticosteroid therapy
C. Endotracheal intubation
D. Partial exchange transfusion
E. Continuous positive airway pressure ventilation
F. Ampicillin and gentamicin therapy
G. Surfactant therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 26-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and lethargy for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had a raspy cry. A. Thyroid dysgenesis
B. Acid maltase deficiency
Trisomy 218%
C. Biliary atresia
α-D. L-iduronidase deficiency
E. Chromosome 11p alteration

Correct Answer: A

Question

Last year, she sustained a spinal compression fracture after lifting a box during a move. She currently takes oral isotretinoin and an oral contraceptive. The patient is at the 97th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. Her vital signs are within normal limits. D. Hyperprolactinemia

F. Turner syndrome
G. Pregnancy
H. Aromatase deficiency

This patient presents with hypertension and proteinuria. In the absence of further symptoms, this is consistent with the diagnosis of preeclampsia without severe features.

A. Induce labor
B. Administration of dexamethasone
C. Administration of methyldopa
D. Reassurance
E. Fetal monitoring with continuous cardiotocography
F. Perform C-section

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding for the past hour. The patient reports that she felt contractions prior to the onset of the bleeding, but the contractions stopped after the bleeding started. She also has severe abdominal pain. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness with no rebound or guarding; no contractions are felt. A. Placenta previa
B. Abruptio placentae
C. Vasa previa
D. Uterine rupture
E. Uterine inertia
F. Amniotic fluid embolism

Correct Answer: D

Question

E. Serial measurements of serum gonadotropin concentrations

Question

B. Cretinism
C. Chromosomal abnormality
D. Neural tube defect
E. Premature placental separation
F. Right ventricular atrialization
G. Shoulder dystocia

Question

Question

Question
A 22-year-old primigravid woman at 41 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled corticosteroids. Medical history is remarkable for multiple lower limb and pelvic fractures due to a motor vehicle collision. She is otherwise healthy. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a 100% effaced and 10-cm dilated cervix; the vertex is at -4 station, with the occiput in the anterior position. Contractions occur every 2 minutes, last 1 minute, and are 55 mm Hg in amplitude. Maternal pushing occurs during the contractions. Fetal heart tracing is 166/min and reactive with no decelerations. Epidural anesthesia is initiated for pain relief. After 4 hours of pushing, the vertex is found to be at -4 station, with increasing strength and rate of uterine contractions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's prolonged labor? This patient had adequate uterine contractions, but the fetal head failed to descend during the second stage of labor.

A. Inefficient maternal pushing
B. Epidural anesthesia
C. Insufficient uterine contractions
D. Muscular constriction of uterus
E. Fetal malposition
F. Shoulder dystocia
G. Cephalopelvic disproportion
H. Deep transverse arrest

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 24-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. At the last two prenatal visits, transabdominal ultrasound showed the fetus in breech presentation. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her pulse is 95/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender; no contractions are felt. Pelvic examination shows a closed cervical os and a uterus consistent with 38 weeks' gestation. The fetal rate tracing shows a baseline heart rate of 152/min and 2 accelerations over 10 minutes. Repeat ultrasound today shows a persistent breech presentation. The patient states that she would like to attempt a vaginal delivery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

A. Recommend cesarean delivery
B. Observe until onset of spontaneous labor
C. Repeat ultrasound in one week
D. Offer external cephalic version
E. Offer internal podalic version

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 30-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron supplements. At the beginning of the first stage of labor, there are coordinated, regular, rhythmic contractions of high intensity that occur approximately every 10 minutes. Four hours later, the patient achieves 100% cervical effacement and 10-cm dilation; the vertex is at -1 station. Over the next 2 hours, there is minimal change in fetal descent; vertex is still at -1 station. Fetal birth weight is estimated to be at the 75th percentile. The fetal heart rate is 145/min and is reactive with no decelerations. Contractions occur approximately every 2 minutes with adequate pressure. The patient is coping well with pain, and epidural anesthesia has not been administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The second stage of labor begins once the cervix is completely dilated and ends with the birth of the neonate. This stage is typically longer in primiparous women.

A. Administration of terbutaline
B. Cesarean delivery
C. Vacuum-assisted delivery
D. Observation for another hour
E. Forceps delivery
F. Epidural anesthesia

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had unprotected sexual intercourse with her boyfriend 2 days ago. She does not wish to become pregnant in the next six months while she is still at college but would like to try to conceive with her partner after she graduates. She has had regular menses since menarche at the age of 12 years. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has no history of serious illness but is allergic to certain metal alloys in jewelry. She takes no medications. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. This option is not appropriate for patients taking certain cytochrome p450 inducers, such as rifampicin or carbamazepine, because of the risk of emergency contraception failure.

B. Insert a progestin-containing intrauterine device
C. Administer mifepristone
D. Administer ulipristal acetate
E. Administer depot medroxyprogesterone acetate
F. Administer combined oral contraceptives

Correct Answer: D

Question

Medical history is remarkable for recurrent episodes of pain in her right wrist and both knees. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 11 years but quit when she became pregnant. Question

She returned from a trip to Taiwan to celebrate her sister's wedding 2 days ago. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses a combined oral contraceptive pill. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her only other medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. B. Decreased Factor VII
C. Decreased fibrinogen

Question

B. CT angiography of the head

Question

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D

F. F

Question
A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 4-day history of weakness and abdominal pain. She also reports increased urination for the past 2 days. B. Decreased renal potassium excretion
C. Muscle cell breakdown

Question

Question

He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has not been evaluated by a physician in 8 years. His only medication is amlodipine. He is somnolent and oriented only to person. Question
A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of shortness of breath and a nonproductive cough for the past 4 months. He has two episodes per week, which resolve spontaneously with rest. Twice a month, he wakes up at night with shortness of breath. His pulse is 73/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows an FVC of 95%, an FEV1:FVC ratio of 0.85, and an FEV1 of 81% of predicted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy? A. Albuterol inhaler
B. Fluticasone inhaler
C. Oral montelukast sodium
D. Cromolyn sodium inhaler
E. Mometasone inhaler and oral zafirlukast
F. Salmeterol inhaler

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of depressed mood for 6 months. He works as a store manager and cannot concentrate at work anymore. He experiences daytime sleepiness and fatigue because he repeatedly wakes up at night and has difficulties falling asleep again after 4 AM. He reports no longer taking pleasure in activities he used to enjoy, such as going fishing with his son. He has decreased appetite and has had a weight loss of 5 kg (11 lb) over the past 6 months. He does not have suicidal ideation. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medication. He is divorced and lives with his girlfriend. He drinks several alcoholic beverages on the weekends. He is diagnosed with major depressive disorder and a trial of sertraline is suggested. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects? B. Serotonin syndrome

D. Urinary retention

Question

B. Increased CNS serotonergic activity
C. Dopamine receptor blockade
D. Anticholinergic toxicity

Question
A 22-year-old college student comes to the physician because of depressed mood and fatigue for the past 5 weeks. He has been feeling sad and unmotivated to attend his college classes. He finds it particularly difficult to get out of bed in the morning. He has difficulty concentrating during lectures and often feels that he is less intelligent compared to his classmates. In elementary school, he was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and treated with methylphenidate; he stopped taking this medication 4 years ago because his symptoms had improved during high school. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 8 years; he feels guilty that he has been unable to quit despite numerous attempts. During his last attempt 3 weeks ago, he experienced increased appetite and subsequently gained 3 kg (6 lb 10 oz) in a week. Mental status examination shows psychomotor retardation and restricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? This patient presents with depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of guilt, and psychomotor retardation for a period > 2 weeks, which is consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD). B. Mirtazapine
C. Lithium carbonate
D. Methylphenidate
E. Bupropion
F. Fluoxetine
G. Phenelzine
H. Valproic acid

Correct Answer: E

Question

She has difficulty staying asleep at night and often wakes up early in the morning. After losing her job as a waitress 1 month ago, she has been feeling guilty for not contributing to the household income. She would like to find a new position but is unable to decide “what to do with her life.” She was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa at age 18 and has gone to psychotherapy several times since then. Her weight had been stable for the past 5 years; however, within the past 3 weeks, she has had a 2.8-kg (6.2-lb) weight loss. She would like to regain some weight. G. Topiramate
H. Phenelzine

Correct Answer: D

Question

E. Chorea and hyperreflexia

Question
A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of a choking sensation, palpitations, diffuse sweating, and shortness of breath over the past 3 months. One episode occurred while at a shopping center, and she now avoids busy areas for fear of triggering another. She has been evaluated in the emergency department twice during these episodes; both times her ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and serum cardiac enzymes and thyroid hormone levels were normal. She does not currently have symptoms but is concerned that the episodes could occur again at any time and that there may be something wrong with her heart. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Question
A 27-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Paroxetine therapy was initiated 6 months ago for a major depressive episode. He now feels much better and says he is delighted with his newfound energy. He gets around 8 hours of sleep nightly and his appetite has increased. He has been able to resume his job at a local bank. He also exercises at the gym 3 times a week and enjoys reading books again. Over the past two years, he has also had two episodes of depressed mood, insomnia, low energy, and loss of appetite that lasted 6–8 weeks, for which he received treatment. During these episodes, he interrupted his job training because he had trouble concentrating on his classes and he stopped going to the gym with his friends. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 128/66 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he describes his mood as "good.” In addition to regular follow-up, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient? This patient presents with remission of symptoms after paroxetine therapy.

A. Taper paroxetine over 2 months
B. Maintain paroxetine therapy for 1–3 years
C. Switch from paroxetine to venlafaxine therapy
D. Discontinue paroxetine
E. Switch from paroxetine to valproic acid therapy
F. Continue paroxetine therapy for 6 months
G. Switch from paroxetine to cognitive behavioral therapy
H. Add lithium to current regimen
. Switch from paroxetine to lithium therapy

Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 56-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a 1-month history of sleep disturbance and sadness. The symptoms have been occurring since her husband died in a car accident. A. Schizoaffective disorder
B. Normal bereavement
C. Acute stress disorder
D. Major depressive disorder
E. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

Question
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 9-month history of sleep disturbances and restlessness. He has difficulty falling asleep and wakes up at least 3 times per night. He feels on edge most days and avoids socializing with his classmates because he is afraid that he will fail further exams. Question
A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate for unusual behavior. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/82 mmHg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and bilateral conjunctival injection. Breath sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Further evaluation will most likely reveal which of the following? This patient's anxiety, vital sign abnormalities (tachycardia, hypertension), dry mouth, and conjunctival injection suggest cannabis intoxication.

A. Sense of closeness to others
B. Violent behavior
C. Respiratory depression
D. Decreased appetite
E. Tactile hallucinations
F. Increased libido
G. Synesthesia
H. Pupillary constriction
. Impaired reaction time

Correct Answer: I

Question

Since then, she has not slept more than 4 hours per night because she has been working on her business plans. She used a significant portion of their savings to fund business trips to Switzerland in order to buy “only the best quality fabrics in the world.” She has not showered and has eaten little during the past 3 days. She had 2 similar episodes a few years ago that required hospitalization and treatment in a psychiatry facility. She has also experienced periods of depression. Question
A 27-year-old woman with cystic fibrosis comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She feels that she can never achieve a full and happy life because of her disease and says that she is “totally frustrated” with the barriers of her illness. Although her family is supportive, she does not want to feel like a burden and tries to shield them from her struggles. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician? When counseling patients with a chronic illness, physicians should show support and empathy in an open, nonjudgmental manner."I think it's really important that you talk to your family more about your feelings. I'm sure they can help you out."4%
"You should educate yourself about your condition using credible, current sources. Knowledge can help dispel fear and anxiety."1%
"I can understand that living with cystic fibrosis is frustrating. You are not alone in this. I would like to recommend a support group."89%
"I understand your frustration with your situation. I would like to refer you to a therapist."5%
"I see that you are frustrated, but this illness has its ups and downs. I am sure you will feel much better soon."0%

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question

At school, he experiences daytime sleepiness and drinks 1–2 cups of coffee in the morning. He avoids daytime naps. A. Question
A 68-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-week history of worsening shortness of breath. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril. Crackles are heard at both lower lung fields. She is diagnosed with acute congestive heart failure. When the physician responsible for the patient's care enters intravenous furosemide in the patient's orders, a clinical decision support system message appears on the computer saying that furosemide in combination with lisinopril may result in significant hypotension and decreased kidney function. The message also has a recommendation for dose adjustment and more frequent monitoring of vital signs and electrolytes when the patient is on both medications. The physician does not follow the recommendation and dismisses the message as one of the many inconsequential warnings that he encounters during his work. Two days after admission, the patient develops dizziness, severe hypotension, and chest pain. She is transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit and diagnosed with type 2 myocardial infarction secondary to hypotension. It is determined that a medication error occurred and personnel interviews are performed as part of a root cause analysis. These interviews reveal that the physician responsible for the patient's care has to take care of several complicated cases during the course of his shift and he has a high level of engagement with patients and a strong sense of personal accomplishment from his work. A fishbone diagram is most likely to reveal which of the following as the root cause of the error that occurred in this scenario? Measures designed to improve patient safety can sometimes unintentionally result in medical errors.

A. Adverse drug reaction
B. Physician burnout
C. Latent condition
D. Alert fatigue
E. Hindsight bias

Correct Answer: D

Question

This patient shows clinical (pruritus, palmar erythema, telangiectasias, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism), laboratory (anemia, thrombocytopenia, hypoalbuminemia, hyperbilirubinemia, increased liver enzymes), and ultrasonographic evidence of compensated cirrhosis. Question
A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He works as a nurse at a local hospital in the city. Three days ago, he had a needlestick injury from a patient whose serology is positive for hepatitis B. He is concerned about his risk of being infected with hepatitis B. He completed the 3-dose regimen of the hepatitis B vaccine during childhood. His other immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show negative results for hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis B surface antibody, and hepatitis C antibody. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The hepatitis B surface antibody is negative even after a three-dose hepatitis B (HBV) vaccine series, indicating this patient did not respond to this regimen. He, therefore, needs short-term as well as long-term immunity for adequate postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) against HBV.

A. Revaccinate with a single dose of hepatitis B vaccine
B. Retest hepatitis B serology in 3 months
C. Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin and a single dose hepatitis B vaccine
D. Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin
E. Revaccinate with two doses of hepatitis B vaccine
F. Revaccinate with 3-dose regimen of hepatitis B vaccine
G. Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin and begin new 3-dose regimen of hepatitis B vaccine

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of nail changes. She says that her nails look “so ugly” that she is afraid to show her hands in public. The changes began on the fourth finger of each hand before progressing to all of her fingers and toes. Treatment with terbinafine has provided no relief. During the same time, she has also noticed that she is perspiring more than usual. The patient has not had any fever, cough, or changes in bowel habits. Her menses occur at irregular 40- and 50-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has a seizure disorder and a history of migraine headaches. Current medications are valproic acid and over-the-counter ibuprofen. She has followed a strict vegan diet since the age of 22 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 147/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nonpitting plaques on the shins. Examination of the hands shows thickened nails with distal white discoloration. There is a distal separation of the nail plates of her fourth digits from the nail beds. There is no pain or swelling of the finger joints. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's nail changes? Thickened nails with distal white discoloration and separation of the nail plate are consistent with onycholysis.

A. Iron deficiency
B. Psoriasis
C. Adverse effect of medication
D. Hyperthyroidism
E. Menopause

Correct Answer: D

Question

B. Perform ureteral stenting
C. Initiate oxybutynin therapy
D. Place a suprapubic catheter
E. Initiate tamsulosin therapy

Question

This hematological disease primarily affects children < 5 years old.

B. Acute lymphocytic leukemia
C. Parvovirus B19 infection
D. Disseminated intravascular coagulation
E. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
F. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

Question
A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks’ gestation comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of palpitations and lightheadedness. Her pregnancy had been uncomplicated. She has mitral stenosis due to rheumatic heart disease. The patient immigrated from Sudan 11 months ago. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 132/min and irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/68 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, a grade 2/6 rumbling mid-diastolic murmur is heard best at the apex; no other abnormalities are noted. Results of complete blood count, serum chemistry profile, and thyroid function tests are within the reference ranges. An ECG is shown. Treatment with low molecular weight heparin is initiated. A. Administer adenosine
B. Perform 24-hour ECG monitoring
C. Perform transesophageal echocardiography
D. Initiate electrical cardioversion
E. Switch to warfarin regimen
F. Initiate pharmacological cardioversion

Question

He reports that, since then, he has often felt compelled to pace around his house and is unable to sit or stand still. He is switched to an alternative antipsychotic medication. A. Metoclopramide
B. Chlorpromazine
C. Trimipramine
D. Fluphenazine
E. Haloperidol

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 37-year-old woman is brought to the physician for worsening depressed mood and irritability. Her mood changes began several months ago. Her husband has also noticed shaky movements of her limbs and trunk for the past year. The patient has no suicidal ideation. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her father died by suicide at the age of 45 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. She speaks slowly and quietly and only looks at the floor. She registers 3/3 words but can recall only one word 5 minutes later. Examination shows irregular movements of the arms and legs at rest. Extraocular eye movements are normal. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is 5/5 throughout, and deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? This patient's chorea (e.g., involuntary limb and trunk movements), depression, irritability, and cognitive impairment (e.g., word recall difficulty) are suggestive of Huntington disease (HD).

A. Babinski sign on physical examination
B. Oligoclonal bands on lumbar puncture
C. Temporoparietal hypometabolism on PET scan
D. Caudate nucleus atrophy on MRI
E. Decreased ceruloplasmin on laboratory studies

Correct Answer: D

Question

The girl has also had constipation for the past few days. She has not had any vaginal discharge. Her older brother has psoriasis. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears well. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the genital area shows erythema and thin, white, well-demarcated plaques on the labia minora, clitoral hood, and perineum. There is a small tear in the anterior midline of the anoderm. B. Obtain biopsy specimen

D. Notify Child Protective Services

Question
A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician to discuss the results of a colonoscopy performed 1 week ago. The patient immigrated to the USA from Indonesia 4 years ago. She is accompanied by her daughter and a friend. The woman and her daughter have both been patients at the physician's practice but the physician does not know the patient's friend. B. Begin the consultation with the bystanders in the room
C. Ask the patient whether she would like the bystanders to be present
D. Politely ask the patient's friend to leave the room

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and progressive shortness of breath. She does not take any medications. Her pulse is 93/min and blood pressure is 112/80 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 22,000/mm3, and platelet count is 80,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows increased numbers of circulating myeloblasts. Bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia. ECG, x-ray of the chest, and echocardiogram show no abnormalities. The patient is scheduled to start induction chemotherapy with cytarabine and daunorubicin. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following long-term complications? Chemotherapeutic agents can cause many adverse effects that warrant post-exposure monitoring. Anthracyclines (including daunorubicin) are particularly dangerous, as they can cause lasting injury to tissue during, shortly after, and long after chemotherapy.

A. Tingling sensation in a stocking-glove distribution
B. Bilateral tinnitus
C. Gross hematuria
D. Decreased diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon dioxide
E. Endometrial hyperplasia
F. Left ventricular dysfunction

Correct Answer: F

Question

Question

His sinusitis has been acting up at night and I was not able to catch any sleep.” The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic sinusitis, and an allergy to dust mites. Medications include enalapril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. His pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. B. Transient upper airway obstruction
C. Hypophyseal neoplasm

Question
The patient undergoes polysomnography, which shows around 10 apneic episodes that cease on arousal, confirming a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea. Positive airway pressure (e.g., CPAP) is the first-line treatment for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). If the patient is unable to tolerate positive airway pressure therapy, a second-line treatment for OSA should be considered. The occurence of 5–15 apneic or hypopneic episodes during sleep consistent with mild OSA.

D. Mandibular advancement device

Question

His older brother had chickenpox 2 weeks ago but the patient has not had any sick contacts otherwise. He cries but calms when his mother picks him up. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows diffuse erythematous plaques on the soles and buttocks with desquamation. B. Nose and throat swab PCR

Question
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-week history of productive cough, swelling of the legs and feet, and fatigue. He has had progressive dyspnea on exertion for the past 2 months. Twelve years ago, he received a porcine valve replacement for severe mitral valve regurgitation. He has coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include aspirin, simvastatin, ramipril, metoprolol, metformin, and hydrochlorothiazide. He appears pale. He is 179 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 127 kg (279.9 lb); BMI is 41 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. Bilateral basilar rales are heard on auscultation of the lungs. Cardiac examination shows a laterally displaced apical heartbeat. A grade 3/6, crescendo-decrescendo diastolic murmur is heard over the apex. There is bilateral pitting edema of the feet and ankles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient's cough, swelling of the lower extremities, fatigue, progressive dyspnea on exertion, and pitting edema in addition to bilateral basilar rales (suggestive of pulmonary edema) and a laterally displaced apical heartbeat (suggestive of an enlarged heart), are consistent with congestive heart failure (CHF).

A. Infective endocarditis
B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
C. Pneumonia
D. Valve degeneration
E. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening upper abdominal discomfort and lack of appetite for 2 weeks. He has had 3–4 episodes of vomiting during this period. Over the last year, he has had frequent episodes of abdominal pain at night that were relieved by eating. He has no history of serious illness. Question

Two years ago, the patient underwent scapular repair after a bicycle accident. Her postoperative pain was managed with oxycodone, which she found difficult to discontinue. She reports that she needs the medication to prevent nausea and malaise. She says that she knows that the medication is bad for her health and wants to do what is best for her baby. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is alert and oriented. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Her pupils measure 3 mm bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 28,500 mIU/mL. Test results for syphilis, chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and hepatitis B and C are negative. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an intrauterine gestational sac with fetal heart tones present. B. Naloxone therapy
C. Clonidine therapy

E. Continue oxycodone therapy

Question
A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 2 hours. Her husband says that she reported heaviness and pain in her left leg over the past week. Medical history is remarkable for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and chronic venous insufficiency. Two years ago, the patient had a deep venous thrombosis that was treated with low molecular weight heparin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 42 years and quit 2 years ago. Medications are albuterol, formoterol, budesonide, and tiotropium. She is alert but appears distressed. Pulse is 115/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 89/61 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Examination shows perioral cyanosis and jugular venous distention. The left lower extremity is swollen and erythematous. ECG shows sinus tachycardia, deep S waves in lead I, pathological Q waves in lead III, and T-wave inversions in lead III. CT angiography of the chest shows a large filling defect in the left pulmonary artery. At this time, which of the following most strongly indicates a poor prognosis for this patient? This patient's CT and ECG findings are consistent with pulmonary embolism (PE). The Pulmonary Embolism Severity Index (PESI) is a prognostic risk stratification tool that can help assess the risk of mortality in patients with PE by using 11 variables, including comorbidities, clinical findings, and patient characteristics such as age.

A. Decreased systolic blood pressure
B. Female sex
C. Perioral cyanosis
D. Sinus tachycardia
E. Previous deep venous thromboses

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 76-year-old Japanese man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-month history of loose stools and worsening peripheral edema. He also reports fatigue, a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 weeks, and a tingling sensation in his hands and feet over the same time period. Two years ago, he underwent a partial gastrectomy with jejunal anastomosis for gastric cancer. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and tamsulosin. B. Increased intestinal motility

D. Rapid gastric emptying

Question
A 55-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 3, comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well besides a vague sensation of vaginal fullness for the last 5 months. Upon questioning, she also reports occasional mild lower back pain that worsens with prolonged standing or lifting. She does not have urinary or fecal incontinence. Ten years ago, she underwent a mastectomy for intraductal carcinoma of the right breast and has been cancer-free since then. All of her children were delivered vaginally without complications. Her last menstrual period was 3 years ago. She is sexually active with her husband only. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (188 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination during Valsalva maneuver shows visible protrusion of the cervix proximal to the level of the hymen into the vagina. B. Topical estrogen therapy

Question
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4th to 6th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. B. Conjunction fallacy
C. Zebra retreat
D. Information bias
E. Premature closure

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe lower back pain for the past 3 weeks. The pain was initially exacerbated by activity but now presents also at rest. Question
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a severe headache over the past hour. He also reports nausea and one episode of non-bloody vomiting. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include enalapril and metformin, but he states that he does not take his medications on a regular basis. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. He is oriented to person but not place or time. Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength in the right leg and arm. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the right upper and lower extremities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a solitary hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema in the left cerebral hemisphere. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient presents with acute onset of severe headache, vomiting, and focal neurologic deficits (unilateral muscle weakness and hyperreflexia), which strongly suggests a cerebrovascular accident (CVA). Poorly controlled hypertension is a major risk factor for the underlying cause of this CVA.

A. Intracranial neoplastic cell growth
B. Rupture of a small penetrating artery
C. Rupture of bridging veins
D. Rupture of a saccular aneurysm
E. Rupture of the middle meningeal artery
F. Rupture of an arteriovenous malformation

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department from a homeless shelter because of bizarre behavior. He avoids contact with others and has complained to the supervising staff that he thinks people are reading his mind. Three days ago, he unplugged every electrical appliance on his floor of the shelter because he believed they were being used to transmit messages about him to others. The patient has schizophrenia and has been prescribed risperidone but has been unable to adhere to his medications because of his unstable living situation. He is disheveled and malodorous. His thought process is disorganized, and he does not make eye contact. Which of the following is the most appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy? B. Oral clozapine
C. Oral haloperidol
D. Intramuscular benztropine
E. Oral diazepam
F. Intramuscular risperidone
G. Intramuscular diphenhydramine

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 3-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She has been well, but her mother is concerned about a rash that appeared on her cheeks 6 days ago. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 75th percentile for length and weight and at the 60th percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. B. Topical mupirocin therapy
C. Topical tacrolimus therapy
D. Oral isotretinoin therapy

Question
A 52-year-old man is on a week-long cruise vacation with his family to celebrate his mother's 80th birthday. He has a very important presentation at work to give in one month, which will in part determine whether he receives a promotion. He decides to focus on enjoying the vacation and not to worry about the presentation until the cruise is over. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating? This individual is exhibiting a mature ego defense mechanism, which is the result of conscious effort (unlike other defense mechanisms that operate at a subconscious level). Another example would be a married woman who actively decides to ignore feelings of attraction towards her husband's best friend.

A. Isolation of affect
B. Repression
C. Introjection
D. Inhibition
E. Dissociation
F. Displacement
G. Blocking
H. Regression
. Denial
. Suppression

Correct Answer: J

Question

B. Posterior limb of the internal capsule

E. Ventral posterior thalamus

Question
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of cough and progressively worsening difficulty walking up the stairs in his apartment. He has noticed that it is easier for him to climb the stairs after he has exercised. He has also had a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. B. Polymyalgia rheumatica

F. Lambert-Eaton syndrome

Question
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of acute confusion and sudden weakness of her left leg that lasted for about 30 minutes. One hour prior to admission, she was unable to understand words and had slurred speech for about 15 minutes. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Her pulse is 110/min and irregular; blood pressure is 135/84 mmHg. Examination shows cold extremities. There is a mild bruit heard above the left carotid artery. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic ejection murmur that begins with a midsystolic click. Neurological and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. ECG shows irregularly spaced QRS complexes with no discernible P waves. Doppler ultrasonography shows mild left carotid artery stenosis. A CT scan and diffusion-weighted MRI of the brain show no abnormalities. Which of the following treatments is most likely to prevent future episodes of neurologic dysfunction in this patient? Acute confusion, hemiparesis, and slurred speech are signs of an acute cerebrovascular accident. The full reversal of all neurologic symptoms within 1 hour and absence of signs of ischemia on neuroimaging makes a transient ischemic attack (TIA) very likely in this patient. In addition, this patient has an irregular pulse and, on ECG, irregularly spaced QRS complexes and no distinct P waves, all of which are characteristic findings in atrial fibrillation (Afib).

A. Atorvastatin
B. Enalapril
C. Carotid endarterectomy
D. Rivaroxaban
E. Aspirin
F. Clopidogrel

Correct Answer: D

Question

She is sexually active with one male partner. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals with a normal flow; her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She had a normal Pap smear 1 year ago. She does not have any children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 63 years. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. She does not wish to have any children and uses oral contraceptive therapy. She has no known allergies, and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears healthy. Question

Question

Question

550/25006%

450/25000%

Question

She has not had fever, nausea, wheezing, itching, or rash. She has no history of serious illness or allergies. She takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows congested nasal mucosa, enlarged tonsils, and pharyngeal postnasal discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Chronic rhinorrhea and nasal congestion in association with a known trigger (strong odor) without symptoms of allergic rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, itchy eyes/nose) strongly suggest vasomotor rhinitis, a type of nonallergic rhinitis. B. Oral phenylephrine
C. Oral diphenhydramine
D. Intranasal azelastine

Question
A previously healthy 73-year-old man comes to the physician at his wife's insistence because of a skin lesion on his back. A biopsy of the skin lesion is performed and histological examination shows clusters of infiltrative melanocytes. Upon repeat questioning, the patient reaffirms his wish to not know the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician? This patient is a legally emancipated adult who does not show any signs of mental impairment. There is no indication that he lacks full decision-making capacity."I have a moral obligation as a physician to inform you about the diagnosis."1%
"I would like to do further testing to investigate how far this cancer has spread."0%
"I don't have to tell you, but I will have to tell your wife so we can plan your therapy."2%
"I'll have to consult with the ethics committee to determine further steps."0%
"I would like to know more about why you don't want to hear your test results."96%

Question
A 68-year-old man with bilateral percutaneous nephrostomy tubes is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of altered mental status. The wife says that he is “not his usual self” and responded with nonsensical phrases when she awoke him for breakfast. She adds that, after both nephrostomy tubes were exchanged 4 days ago, the urine output from the right nephrostomy bag was relatively low, and that he complained of right flank pain yesterday. He has prostate cancer and receives leuprolide injections every 3 months. He appears uncomfortable and diaphoretic. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 76/50 mm Hg when supine. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. The right nephrostomy bag contains a small amount of cloudy urine; the left nephrostomy bag contains clear urine. Hemoglobin concentration is 12 g/dL, leukocyte count is 22,000/mm3, platelet count is 180,000/mm3, and serum lactic acid concentration is 4.2 mmol/L (N < 2). In the emergency department, a central venous catheter is placed and hemodynamic monitoring shows:The results of blood and urine cultures are pending. Fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy are initiated. After 2.5 L of 0.9% saline infusion, his blood pressure is 78/54 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy? This patient meets the qSOFA criteria for septic shock (≥ 2 of the following: altered mental status, systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mm Hg, respiratory rate ≥ 22/min) and has persistent hypotension (i.e., failure to maintain a mean arterial pressure of ≥ 65 mm Hg during or after fluid resuscitation). The underlying etiology is likely urinary infection of the right nephrostomy tube secondary to obstruction.

A. Phenylephrine therapy
B. Dopamine therapy
C. Dobutamine therapy
D. Norepinephrine therapy
E. Hydrocortisone therapy
F. No additional pharmacotherapy is indicated

Correct Answer: D

Question
A previously healthy 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreasing exercise tolerance over the past 6 weeks. She also has intermittent episodes of dizziness. She has never smoked and does not drink alcohol. She takes a daily multivitamin. She appears pale. Physical examination shows a smooth liver that is palpable 1 cm below the costal margin. The spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral blood smear shows anisocytosis and bone marrow aspirate shows ringed sideroblasts. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following? This patient's symptomatic macrocytic anemia (low hemoglobin, high MCV) with an insufficient reticulocyte response indicates dysplastic hematopoiesis. Her normal folate and vitamin B12 levels indicate refractory anemia. Together with the presence of ringed sideroblasts, the laboratory results raise concern for myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

A. Sézary syndrome
B. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
C. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
D. Acute myelocytic leukemia
E. Multiple myeloma
F. Hairy cell leukemia

Correct Answer: D

Question

D. Absence of reduced glutathione

The risk of developing open-angle glaucoma is higher in patients with diabetes than in those without diabetes.3%

Question
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Purpura, arthralgia, hypocomplementemia, and increased serum concentration of polyclonal IgG and IgM are highly suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia. Patients with mixed cryoglobulinemia can be positive for rheumatoid factor (RF) because the IgM in mixed cryoglobulinemia has the activity of RF. The RF-like activity of IgM also causes decreased complement levels because the IgM binds to the Fc portion of IgG and causes complement activation.

A. Rapid plasma reagin test
B. Bone marrow biopsy
C. Hepatitis C serology
D. Skin biopsy
pE. ANCA assay
F. Bence Jones protein test

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. While he used to be able to walk 4–5 blocks at a time, he now has to pause every 2 blocks. He also reports waking up from having to urinate at least once every night for the past 5 months. Recently, he has started using two pillows to avoid waking up coughing with acute shortness of breath at night. He has a history of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications include daily amlodipine and prazosin, but he reports having trouble adhering to his medication regimen. His pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Auscultation shows an S4 gallop and fine bibasilar rales. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following pathophysiologic changes in this patient? This patient has classic signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), including dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, nocturia, bibasilar rales from pulmonary edema (suggestive of left-sided heart failure), and pitting edema (suggestive of right-sided heart failure). CHF is characterized by reduced cardiac output (CO), which activates numerous compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms.

B. Decreased alveolar surface tension
C. Increased bicarbonate excretion
D. Decreased systemic vascular resistance
E. Increased left ventricular compliance
F. Increased potassium retention

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing generalized fatigue for 3 months. He does not smoke and drinks two to three beers on weekends. His medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/73 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hematocrit is 27%, leukocyte count is 4500/mm3, and platelet count is 102,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows numerous blast cells that stain positive for myeloperoxidase, CD33, and CD34. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? All three cell lines (RBCs, WBCs, and platelets) are either reduced or at the lower end of the reference range, indicating impaired hematopoiesis. This patient's condition has a peak incidence of 65 years of age.

A. Acute myeloid leukemia
B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
C. Hairy cell leukemia
D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
E. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

The patient agreed to the treatment plan, which included both pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy. The patient reports that she stopped going to psychotherapy for 2 weeks because the psychologist is a "traitor" who manipulates her emotions. "Quitting psychotherapy is only possible if we increase your visits to this practice.”2%
“It would make sense for you to choose a different psychologist."14%
"When setting your treatment goals, you agreed to attend sessions with your psychologist."62%
"If this is your decision, we can pause psychotherapy for 3 months"11%

Question
Five days after undergoing an open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, a 68-year-old woman has crampy abdominal pain. During this period, she has also had two episodes of loose, bloody stools. The patient has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease. The patient has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years and drinks 3–4 glasses of wine every week. Her current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, amlodipine, aspirin, and metoprolol. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen with absent bowel sounds. The abdomen is exquisitely tender to palpation in all quadrants. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S4 gallop. An x-ray of the abdomen shows air-filled distended bowel. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair performed, requiring instrumentation of the aorta and disruption of normal blood flow through the aorta. The procedure was complicated by blood loss, presumably with hypovolemia, and the subsequent use of vasopressors to constrict blood vessels and preserve perfusion of important structures, especially the brain.

A. Abdominal compartment syndrome
B. Postoperative ileus
C. Pseudomembranous colitis
D. Ischemic colitis
E. Abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture

Correct Answer: D

Question

D. Discontinuation of intravenous morphine
E. Subcutaneous injections of low-molecular-weight heparin

Correct Answer: C

Question

The remainder of the examination and the laboratory study results, including a complete blood count and coagulation studies, show no abnormalities. Question
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain. The pain started four days ago and is now a diffuse crampy pain with an intensity of 6/10.
