Question
An 18-year-old previously healthy woman is brought to the physician by her father because she has been acting strangely for the past week. The patient's only brother died of leukemia 10 days ago. The father says that since the funeral a week ago, the patient has stayed in her brother's room most of the time and only joined the parents for breakfast and dinner. She has not gone to school since her brother's death. She eats very little and stays awake most of the night. The father reports that he has heard her talking in her brother's room even though she was alone and her phone was on the kitchen table. At the dinner table, she asked if she could have two extra plates for her friends, “Anna and Joseph,” although nobody had ever heard these names before. The patient says that she misses her brother a lot and that she feels tired and sad all the time. She does not have nightmares or flashbacks and remembers details of her brother's last days and the funeral. She denies suicidal ideations or feelings of guilt. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use drugs recreationally. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She appears calm and is attentive. Her speech is clear and organized. Her vital signs are within normal limits. D. Normal bereavement

Question

Question
A previously healthy 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of left-sided weakness for the past 4 hours. As she was getting dressed this morning, she was suddenly unable to button up her shirt. When she showed her husband, he noticed that she was confused. She has a 3-year history of diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. She had a knee operation 1 month ago. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 138/85 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person. Neurologic examination shows diminished muscle strength on the left side. There are scattered petechiae over the chest, arms, and legs. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral smear shows numerous schistocytes. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings? This patient has the classic constellation of findings found in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP): neurologic abnormalities (likely TIA or stroke, confusion), fever, impaired renal function (increased BUN and creatinine), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin, elevated LDH and indirect bilirubin, schistocytes), and thrombocytopenia.

B. Antibodies against platelet factor 4 on serologic testing

E. Mutations of alternative complement pathway genes on genetic testing
F. Decreased ADAMTS13 activity in serum
G. Antibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins on serologic testing
H. Elevated fibrin degradation products in serum

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and swollen legs for the past 4 weeks. She has tried sleeping in a raised position using 2 pillows but still wakes up occasionally from a choking sensation. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, arterial hypertension, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her sister has polymyalgia rheumatica. Her current medications include insulin, enalapril, and omeprazole. She has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Examination shows an enlarged tongue, pitting edema below the knees, and jugular venous distention. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. Her hemoglobin concentration is 9.0 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6100/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 62 mm/h, and serum creatinine is 2.1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? B. Systemic sclerosis
C. Multiple myeloma
D. Hemochromatosis
E. Rheumatoid arthritis
F. Viral myocarditis

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 6-day history of progressive lower abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite. She also noticed mild pain with urination and a mild fever for the past 2 days. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 1 week. Her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She has no history of serious illness or surgery and takes no medications. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and usually uses condoms for contraception. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants with mild guarding. There is bloody discharge from the cervix. Bimanual examination shows cervical motion tenderness and a tender right adnexal mass. Her hematocrit is 34%, leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 80 mm/h. Pelvic ultrasonography shows an enlarged uterus with a thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has multiple sexual partners and does not necessarily use condoms consistently. Combined with her symptoms (e.g., fever, vaginal discharge, pain with urination), examination findings (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, bloody cervical discharge), and positive inflammatory markers on laboratory studies (leukocytosis, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate), this points to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

A. Appendiceal abscess
B. Tuboovarian abscess
C. Ovarian cancer
D. Ovarian torsion
E. Ectopic pregnancy
F. Ruptured ovarian cyst

Correct Answer: B

Question

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E
F. F

Correct Answer: D

Question
A researcher is conducting a study to compare fracture risk in male patients above the age of 65 who received annual DEXA screening to peers who did not receive screening. He conducts a randomized controlled trial in 900 patients, with half of participants assigned to each experimental group. The researcher ultimately finds similar rates of fractures in the two groups. He then notices that he had forgotten to include data from 400 patients in his analysis. Which of the following is most likely to result from including the data of these participants in the analysis? Increasing the sample size of a study results in increased statistical power.

A. Decreased significance level of results
B. Wider confidence intervals of results
C. Increased probability of committing a type II error
D. Increased probability of correctly rejecting the null hypothesis
E. Increased external validity of results
F. Decreased probability of seeing a difference between the groups when there truly is no difference

Correct Answer: D

Question
An 18-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of vision problems. He recently enlisted in the US Army and started military training 2 weeks ago, but was not able to continue because his vision became severely blurry. He ambulates with a walking cane and wears dark glasses. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father has hyperopia. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the eyes shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy findings are normal. Snellen eye chart examination shows a visual acuity of 20/200 on the right and 20/100 on the left. When the physician suddenly passes a hand in front of the patient's eyes, he starts blinking. When asked to close his eyes, extend his hands, and touch the tip of his nose with his index finger, the patient touches his eyebrow and chin instead of his nose. The remainder of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. When asked to perform an additional perimetry test, the patient says “I'm really tired at this point and would really like to go home. I would really appreciate it if you could verify that I cannot see and that I cannot continue the military training.” In addition to acknowledging the patient's concerns, which of the following is the most appropriate action from the physician? This patient's physical examination findings (abnormal finger-to-nose test indicating a cerebellar condition, eye blinking as a response to a sudden hand wave indicating intact visual pathway) do not correlate with his presenting symptom (blurry vision) and additional examination findings (poor visual acuity indicating defective visual pathway). In combination with his request for a letter excusing him from military training, this should raise concern for malingering.

A. Schedule regular follow-up meetings
B. Initiate a discussion about the patient's recent enlistment to the military
C. Provide the patient with an exemption letter for military service
D. Refer the patient to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation
E. Educate the patient about his diagnosis

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of fatigue and difficulty sleeping over the past month. During this time, she has had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss despite an increased appetite. Two months ago, she delivered a healthy girl with a birth weight of 3500 g (7 lb 11 oz) at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. She exclusively breastfeeds her infant and does not report any difficulty with lactation. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Her only medication is insulin. She is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lbs); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin and a mildly enlarged, nontender thyroid gland. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. The uterus is fully involuted and pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a full range of affect. She says she is not depressed. Laboratory studies show:Doppler ultrasonography of the thyroid gland shows diffusely decreased blood flow. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition? This patient's increased free T4 and decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) indicate hyperthyroidism. Slightly increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), low thyroid blood flow on Doppler ultrasonography, and the onset of symptoms within one year of delivery are consistent with postpartum thyroiditis.

A. Hyperplasia of thyrotropic pituitary cells
B. Granulomatous inflammation of the thyroid gland
C. Production of human chorionic gonadotropin by a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm
D. Release of thyroid hormone from damaged follicular cells
E. Binding of thyroid stimulating antibodies to thyrotropin receptors
F. Somatic activating mutation of the thyrotropin receptor gene

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple, ulcerative skin lesions over various parts of her body that first appeared 6 months ago. They occur episodically and usually start as reddish spots, which then expand in size and ulcerate over the next ten days. They resolve spontaneously and reappear at another location a few days later. Over the past 6 months, she has had multiple episodes of diarrhea. She has had an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss during this period and feels tired constantly. She has not had a fever. She was treated for deep venous thrombosis 3 years ago and took medication for 6 months after the episode. She appears pale. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She has multiple, tender, ulcerative skin lesions on her legs and buttocks. Her hemoglobin is 9.6 mg/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 82 μm3, and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 154 mg/dL. Her serum glucagon concentration is elevated. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals a 5.6-cm, well-demarcated, hypoechoic mass in the pancreatic body and multiple, small masses in the liver of variable echogenicity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Necrolytic migratory erythema, normocytic normochromic anemia, chronic diarrhea, and elevated glucose levels are characteristic clinical features of glucagonoma. The diagnosis is confirmed by elevated serum glucagon levels. An abdominal ultrasound showing masses in the pancreas and liver is likely indicative of metastatic disease.

A. Schedule distal pancreatectomy
B. Measure serum zinc levels
C. Perform endoscopic ultrasonography
D. Obtain cancer antigen 19-9 levels
E. Administer octreotide
F. Measure glycated hemoglobin

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest pain is retrosternal in nature and does not radiate. She feels nauseated but has not vomited. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is pale and diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98°F), pulse is 136/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. B. Hemodialysis
C. Intravenous fluid infusion

E. Norepinephrine infusion

Question

Question

Question

Examination shows mild scoliosis. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a mid-systolic click. The right knee shows a large, tender effusion and the patella is displaced laterally. Lachman test, posterior drawer test, and Apley test are negative. E. Total knee replacement

Question

Question

Question
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath. The symptoms most commonly occur when lying flat at night. He also reports shortness of breath when walking up the two flights of stairs to his apartment. He reports no chest pain. Medical history is remarkable for myocardial infarction 2 years ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not exercise. His medications include aspirin, lisinopril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. Pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows an extra heart sound during early diastole on auscultation. Faint crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is 1+ ankle edema bilaterally. Cardiac ultrasonography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.35. Which of the following hemodynamic changes are most likely present in this patient? Features of pulmonary congestion (exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, bibasilar crackles) and an S3 gallop along with a history of myocardial infarction suggest congestive heart failure (CHF) most likely due to ischemic heart disease. A decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) indicates systolic dysfunction.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows a wedge-shaped non-enhancing lesion in the spleen. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? This woman's CT findings and acute onset of left-sided abdominal pain are consistent with acute splenic infarction. Question

Question

Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Physical examination shows labored breathing and thready pulses. Crackles are heard at both lung bases. The abdomen is nontender and the uterus is soft. Speculum examination shows pooling of bright red blood in the cervical canal. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 7.6 mg/dL and an undetectable fibrinogen concentration. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition? This patient presents with acute respiratory distress (dyspnea, tachypnea, decreased oxygen saturation), cardiovascular compromise (tachycardia, hypotension), altered consciousness (agitation, confusion), and hyperfibrinolysis (uterine bleeding, undetectable fibrinogen concentration) in the peripartum period.

E. Systemic bacterial infection
F. Premature separation of the placenta from the uterus

Question
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless reddening and swelling of her right foot. The swelling of the foot started several months ago, but the redness along with warmth only appeared last week, after a strenuous hike with her husband. She does not recall any recent trauma, fever, or chills. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include metformin, losartan, and atorvastatin. She has not seen a physician for 1 year. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 144/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a severely swollen, erythematous, right foot and ankle with collapse of the midfoot; range of motion is decreased but not painful. There is no focal tenderness. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition? A. Smoking cessation
B. Regular foot examination
C. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation
D. Reduced meat intake
E. Prophylactic antibiotic therapy

Question

Question
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent urinary incontinence. She loses small amounts of urine after voiding but is otherwise continent. She underwent a bilateral salpingectomy after her last pregnancy. She is sexually active with her husband and does not use condoms. She has three children who were delivered vaginally without complication. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a soft, tender, 2 x 2-cm mass in the anterior vaginal wall. There is no cervical motion tenderness. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. A. Bartholin gland cyst
B. Anterior vaginal wall prolapse
C. Vesicovaginal fistula
D. Interstitial cystitis
E. Paraurethral gland cyst
F. Urethral diverticulum
G. Endometriosis

Correct Answer: F

Question
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 4-hour history of nausea and upper abdominal pain. The mother reports that he vomited dark-green secretions 2 hours ago. One day before, he fell off his bicycle and the handlebar struck his abdomen. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 97/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly distended abdomen that is tender to palpation. There are multiple ecchymoses on the upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are present. His hemoglobin concentration is 13 mg/dL, serum ALT activity is 38 U/L, and serum amylase activity is 102 U/L. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a large gastric bubble with no free intraperitoneal air. A. Splenic laceration
B. Intestinal perforation
C. Duodenal hematoma
D. Acute pancreatitis
E. Liver hematoma

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb, 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb, 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. Which of the following is the most likely cause? C. Transplacental passage of thyroid peroxidase antibodies
D. Transplacental passage of TSH receptor antibodies
E. Transplacental passage of L-thyroxine

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She feels well. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus well controlled with insulin. Other medications include a prenatal multivitamin. Upon examination, the patient requests to schedule a cesarean delivery because she is "too afraid of the pain during labor" after hearing about some of her friends' birth experiences. The physician personally disapproves of performing cesarean delivery unless the fetal or maternal risks of vaginal delivery outweigh the risks of cesarean delivery. Physical examination shows a nontender, soft uterus consistent in size with a 34-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic position. Fetal monitoring shows no contractions and a reassuring heart rate. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician? A. Emphasize the increased risk of placental attachment abnormalities in subsequent pregnancies
B. Schedule cesarean delivery at 39 weeks' gestation
C. Ask the patient to involve the other parent in the decision-making process regarding the mode of delivery
D. Inform the patient about prenatal childbirth education and obstetric analgesia
E. Refer the patient to another obstetrician to plan for cesarean delivery

Question
Two days after delivery, a 2450-g (5-lb 6-oz) male newborn has three episodes of green vomitus. He has passed urine twice daily but has not yet passed stool. He was born at 34 weeks' gestation. B. Infertility
C. Alzheimer disease

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-month history of stool incontinence. He was potty-trained at 4 years but now soils in his clothes 1–2 times a month and does not seem to notice when he needs to go to the bathroom. He now sleeps with pull-up diapers at night and he frequently urinates in them. He has large, hard stools and painful bowel movements once a week. They moved to a new town 5 months ago and the patient has had trouble adjusting. He also started school a few months ago, which according to the mother “only made things worse.” He has bronchial asthma well controlled with a corticosteroid inhaler, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder for which he takes methylphenidate. He eats a regular diet but dislikes vegetables apart from green peas and potatoes. He is at the 50th percentile for weight and 25th percentile for height. His temperature is 36.7°C (96.1°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is mildly distended and there is firmness to palpation in the left lower quadrant; there is no guarding or rebound. Digital rectal examination shows a normal sphincter tone. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? According to the DSM-5 criteria, encopresis is defined as the involuntary elimination of feces in children ≥ 4 years in inappropriate settings for their developmental age (e.g., in their clothes, on the floor), occurring more than once a month for ≥ 3 months. Encopresis is classified as either retentive or nonretentive. This patient’s history (large, hard stools with painful bowel movements, nocturia) and physical examination findings (mild abdominal distension, firmness in the left lower quadrant) indicate that he has retentive encopresis.

A. X-ray of the abdomen
B. High-fiber diet
C. Disimpaction and laxative therapy
D. Biofeedback training
E. Reassurance and regular follow-up
F. MRI of the lumbosacral spine

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question

Question

He moves his extremities in response to commands. There is a 3-cm scalp laceration. There are multiple bruises over the right upper extremity. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Two large-bore peripheral intravenous catheters are inserted. A 0.9% saline infusion is begun. B. Decompressive craniectomy
C. Lumbar puncture
D. Intravenous hypertonic saline

Question

C. Urosepsis
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Coronary artery disease

Question
A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of worsening severe abdominal pain and bilateral lower extremity numbness and weakness. She had intermittent chest and joint pain as a child that resolved with over-the-counter pain medication. The patient emigrated from Afghanistan 3 years ago. She takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 95/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen without involuntary guarding, rebound, or tenderness. Question

Three days later, a physician colleague approaches the physician who treated the patient in the lobby of the hospital and states, “I just want to know what happened. I'm her neighbor and childhood friend, and I'm worried about her.” Which of the following responses by the treating physician is the most appropriate? The physician colleague is not directly involved in this patient's care.

B. "Why don't you go ahead and ask her directly? She is currently in the psychiatric ward."
C. "Her urine toxicology screening was positive for alcohol, benzodiazepines, and barbiturates."
D. "I'm not the right person to ask. Please ask her primary care physician."
E. "I understand your concern, but I am unable to provide information about this situation."
F. "Let's go to my office to discuss her situation privately."

Correct Answer: E

Question

This patient's high risk sexual behavior, dysuria, and pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase) are consistent with epididymitis but his young age, the sudden onset of scrotal pain, and the presence of vomiting and testicular swelling also increase the likelihood of a condition that can result in permanent morbidity if not detected and treated within 6 hours of symptom onset.

Question
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain for the past 3 hours. He reports that he can only take shallow breaths because deep inspiration worsens the pain. Current medications include aspirin, ticagrelor, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. Question
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of severe abdominal pain that started suddenly 1 hour ago while he was having a barbecue with his family. B. Anticoagulation with warfarin

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of abdominal pain, nausea, and a progressively worsening rash on his legs for the past 5 days. He was well until 2 weeks ago when he developed a cough and a sore throat. These symptoms resolved spontaneously 1 week ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears well-developed and well-nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the skin shows clusters of nonblanchable, erythematous papules on the lower extremities. Palpable purpura, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hematuria 1–3 weeks after an acute upper respiratory tract infection indicate immunoglobulin A vasculitis (IgAV), the most common systemic vasculitis in children. B. Administration of oral glucocorticoids
C. Renal biopsy
D. Measurement of serum ANCA titers
E. Observation and supportive care only
F. Administration of intravenous immunoglobulin

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia controlled with atenolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation finding? VIDEOThe auscultatory finding in this patient is an S4 gallop, which occurs as the atria pump blood into the ventricles. An S4 gallop is almost always pathological.

A. Increased left ventricular filling pressures
B. Dilation of the aortic root
C. Thickening of the mitral valve leaflets
D. Decreased compliance of the left ventricle
E. Impaired closure of the mitral valve

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of insufficient weight gain and worsening constipation for the past 2 months. The father reports that since birth she has had infrequent bowel movements, but currently only has one bowel movement every 14 days and passes small, narrow stools. Treatment with prune juice has been unsuccessful. The girl was born at term by home birth; pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. The girl did not undergo newborn screening. The father does not remember when she passed her first stool after birth. Until the introduction of solids at the age of 6 months, she had been exclusively breastfed. Now she eats three solid meals of a balanced diet and nurses twice daily. Her mother has celiac disease. The patient is at the 3rd percentile for weight and the 10th percentile for length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Patients with this condition frequently present with delayed passage of meconium at birth.

A. Anorectal manometry
B. Lactulose therapy
C. Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis
D. Gluten-free diet
E. Thyroid function tests

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 27-year-old woman who is a military veteran is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her mood. They say that she has “not been herself” since the death of her friend, who was killed 3 weeks ago when the fighter jet he piloted was shot down overseas. She says that since the incident, she feels sad and alone. She reports having repeated nightmares about her friend's death. Her appetite has decreased, but she is still eating regularly and is otherwise able to take care of herself. She does not leave her home for any social activities and avoids visits from friends. She went back to work after taking 1 week off after the incident. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she appears sad, has a full range of affect, and is cooperative. In addition to taking measures to evaluate this patient's anxiety, which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician at this time? This patient is experiencing a reaction to a recent traumatic event."I am worried that you may be having an abnormally severe reaction to what is an understandably stressful event. I recommend attending behavioral therapy sessions to help you deal with this challenge."2%
"I understand that the sudden loss of your friend has affected you deeply. Sometimes in situations like yours, people have thoughts that life is not worth living; have you had such thoughts? "93%
"Your grief over the loss of your friend appears to have a negative effect on your social and functional capabilities. I recommend starting antidepressants to help you deal with this challenge."0%
"I can see that you have gone through a lot recently, but I think that your reaction is especially severe and has persisted for longer than normal. Would you be open to therapy or medication to help you manage better? "3%
"I'm so sorry, but the loss of loved ones is a part of life. Let's try to find better ways for you to deal with this event."2%

Correct Answer: B

Question

She does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. The patient has smoked 5 cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. She drinks 4–6 alcoholic beverages with friends on weekends and tried marijuana once in her freshman year. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and takes an oral contraceptive pill. B. Observation and follow-up in 1 week

D. Perform CT pulmonary angiography

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is produced by the fetus and can be measured in maternal serum (MSAFP), which continuously rises during the second trimester. B. Underestimation of gestational age

D. Spina bifida occulta

Question

Physical examination shows a shorter left lower extremity compared to the right one, pelvic instability on palpation, and an inguinal hematoma. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The results of a FAST scan, imaging of the head and cervical spine, and retrograde urethrography are normal. His daughter, who is an orthopedic trauma surgeon at the same hospital, comes to see him before the procedure. The patient asks his daughter to perform the surgery because he considers his daughter to be an “excellent surgeon” and believes that she would “act in his best interests.” Despite counseling by the primary attending orthopedic surgeon and the patient's daughter, the patient insists that his daughter perform the procedure. Question

Question

Question

A. Examine the central line placement curriculum used for all surgical residents
B. Research other cases of catheter-associated venous air embolisms that have occurred nationally
C. Conduct interviews with all staff members involved in the patient's care

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after a screening test had shown elevated serum calcium levels. He feels well. He has not had abdominal pain or colic, bone pain, fatigue, or weight loss. There is no history of serious illness. His only medications are fish oil, a multivitamin, and calcium supplementation. His mother died of hepatic cancer at the age of 66 years. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 131/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no abnormalities. Renal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scan reveals a T-score of -0.6 SD at the hip and lumbar spine and -0.5 SD at the distal radius. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Elevated serum levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and calcium along with decreased serum levels of phosphorus are consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism. Evaluation for the severity of the condition is used to guide further management.

A. Refer for parathyroidectomy
B. Schedule follow-up visit to assess calcium, creatinine, and repeat DXA
C. Prescribe alendronate
D. Perform DNA testing
E. Discontinue calcium and multivitamin supplementation

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician with a 12-year history of recurrent heartburn. He has also had a cough, which is worse at night, for the past year. He has not seen a physician for 8 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His only medication is an over-the-counter antacid. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (209 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. An upper endoscopy shows dark pink mucosa up to 2 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. C. Esophagectomy

Question
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of persistent epigastric abdominal pain. B. Plain abdominal CT
C. Contrast-enhanced abdominal CT
D. Endoscopic ultrasonography
E. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Question
A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Question

C. Color blindness
D. Methemoglobinemia

Question
A group of investigators conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a new medication in the treatment of infectious mononucleosis. They enroll 3143 patients between the ages of 18 and 30 years who presented with mononucleosis-like illness and had a positive Monospot test. These patients are randomized to receive either the new drug or placebo for a period of one week. The primary endpoint of the trial is the time to resolution of symptoms from the onset of therapy and the secondary endpoint is the splenic volume as measured by ultrasonography one month after initiating therapy. At the end of the study, the mean differences of endpoint measures in each arm are determined and evaluated using t-statistics. For analysis, the investigators decide to exclude patients from both arms who did not adhere to the treatment protocol or dropped out of the study. When compared to an analysis that includes the nonadherent patients and dropouts from both study arms, the analysis performed by the investigators is most likely to have which of the following properties? When analyzing data from a randomized controlled trial, the two main ways of dealing with study protocol violations (e.g., dropouts, nonadherence) are intention-to-treat analysis (ITT analysis), which includes all subjects (once randomized, always analyzed), and per-protocol analysis (PP analysis), which only includes subjects who adhered to the study protocol.

A. Higher type 2 error probability
B. Larger effect size
C. Greater external validity
D. Lower confounding risk
E. Shorter lead time

Correct Answer: B

Question
A group of investigators designs a small phase 0 trial to evaluate the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of a new drug against pregnancy-induced hypertension. They decide to conduct the study after a renowned journal published the results of an animal trial that showed the drug to be safe and effective in reducing blood pressure in pregnant chimps. No teratogenic effects were reported. The investigators receive a grant from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the drug after the company contractually agrees not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication of the trial in any way. The grant funds are designated to be used for expenses incurred in conducting the study. Other than a grant-drawn salary for the predetermined duration of the trial, no financial or material compensation would be offered to the investigators. The investigators propose to recruit a group of ten healthy pregnant women. Both the study participants and the fathers of their children would be informed in their native language, verbally as well as in writing, about the investigators' industry affiliation, the purpose and design of the study, the benefits and known side effects of the new drug, and the alternative options for treating pregnancy-induced hypertension. The participants would also be informed of their rights to confidentiality, to withdraw from the trial at any time, to free medical treatment as well as financial compensation in the event of harm to them or their fetus, and to decision-making autonomy regarding termination or continuation of the pregnancy, antenatal care, and medical or surgical treatment. For participating in the study, they would be offered subsidized antenatal care with a health care provider of their choosing, and the subsidy would not be stopped even if they were to withdraw after enrolling. The investigators would enroll the prospective participants only after the participant and the child's father confirm their understanding of the provided information and sign a consent form. Which of the following would most likely be the cause for the rejection of this study design by an institutional review board? All aboard the sleepy train… This is a very long question with a lot of words, but the answer lies on the surface for the attentive reader.

A. Participation of healthy individuals
B. Lack of informed consent
C. Research in a vulnerable population
D. Conflict of interest
E. Plagiarism

Correct Answer: C

Question
Three days after admission to the intensive care unit for treatment of major trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident, a 65-year-old woman develops respiratory distress. Her current temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Question

Question

Question

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and irregular menstrual cycles for the past year. She also complains of recurrent sinus infections. During the past 6 months, she has had increased urinary frequency and swelling of her feet. She has also had difficulty lifting her 3-year-old niece for the past 3 weeks. She was recently diagnosed with depression. She works as a medical assistant. The patient has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks four beers on the weekends. Her only medication is escitalopram. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows excess fat around the base of the neck and an enlarged abdomen. Examination of the skin shows multiple bruises on her arms and legs. There is generalized weakness and atrophy of the proximal muscles. Laboratory studies show:A 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol of 167 nmol/L (N < 50) and a 24-hour urinary cortisol is 425 μg (N < 300 μg). Serum ACTH is 169 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Subsequently, a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows a serum cortisol level of 164 nmol/L (N < 50). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? In a patient who is not on glucocorticoid therapy, serum cortisol levels that remain elevated following a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test are consistent with endogenous hypercortisolism. Elevated serum ACTH levels suggest secondary hypercortisolism, while elevated serum cortisol levels following a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test indicate ectopic ACTH production.

A. Exogenous corticosteroid administration
B. Pituitary adenoma
C. Adrenal carcinoma
D. Hypothyroidism
E. Pheochromocytoma
F. Small cell lung cancer
G. Adrenal adenoma

Correct Answer: F

Question

One night he parked his car in a neighbor's bushes and was found wandering the street. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and COPD. The diagnosis is supported by his Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score (13–20 points: moderate dementia). E. PET scan

Question
A group of researchers carries out a retrospective multicenter cohort study to evaluate survival in 4,000 patients aged 65–85 years undergoing either mitral valve repair or replacement to treat mitral valve prolapse. Descriptive analysis shows that 94% of patients in the valve repair group and 83% of patients in the valve replacement group are alive at a 5-year follow-up. The Kaplan-Meier survival analysis shows that the valve replacement group has a hazard ratio for 5-year mortality of 2.31 (95% CI, 2.29–2.33) when compared to the valve repair group. Which of the following is most likely to be the p-value for the hazard ratio? If the 95% confidence interval (CI) of a hazard ratio does not include the value 1.0, the results of the analysis are statistically significant. Confidence intervals and p-values are interrelated.p=0.00272%
p=0.04922%
p=0.1304%
p=1.0002%
p=1.2041%

Correct Answer: A

Question

B. Ulna
C. Radius

Question
A new rapid test for the diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection is evaluated in 200 study participants. At a given cutoff, the test shows a true-negative rate of approximately 70% and a true-positive rate of approximately 65%. Which of the following labeled graphs is most likely to represent this diagnostic test? The false-positive (FP) rate is calculated from the true-negative rate (specificity) using the formula FP rate = 1 - specificity. The curve that is obtained by plotting the true-positive rate (TP rate or sensitivity) against the FP rate is called a receiving operating characteristic (ROC) curve. The area under this curve (AUC) positively correlates with the diagnostic value of the test.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of lower abdominal pain. She has also had multiple episodes of loose stools with blood during this period. Her maternal grandfather died of colon cancer at the age of 52 years. She does not smoke. She drinks 3–5 beers on social occasions. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation of the left lower quadrant. There is no guarding or rigidity. Rectal examination shows no masses. Laboratory studies show:A colonoscopy is scheduled for the next day. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present on colonoscopy of this patient? Question
A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has had occasional tiredness and frequent urination throughout her pregnancy but has otherwise been well. She has attended all scheduled prenatal visits. Her weight gain has been normal. She is in a monogamous relationship with a male partner who is the father. Current medications include micronutrient supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Examination shows minimal bilateral edema below the knees. The uterus is consistent in size with a 35-week gestation. Transabdominal ultrasound shows an intrauterine pregnancy in a longitudinal lie with breech presentation; fetal cardiac activity is normal. The physician explains the complications associated with breech delivery and recommends an external cephalic version. The patient refuses and states that she would like to attempt a vaginal delivery at home. In addition to acknowledging the patient's choice and exploring the reasons for her choice, which of the following statements by the physician is most appropriate? The physician must apply the principle of directive counseling in this scenario."A home birth with assistance from a certified midwife certainly has a few advantages. I would like to contact your midwife so that I can discuss your care prior to delivery."14%
"A home birth increases the risk of harm to your baby. You must discuss this matter with your partner and obtain his consent before choosing home birth."0%
"The hospital is the safest environment for delivery. Although we are equipped to deal with any potential complication, the risk of medical intervention during a hospital delivery is actually lower when compared to home birth."17%
"A home birth is generally not recommended. It concerns me that, if a complication occurs, the delay in transfer to the hospital would result in severe harm to you or your baby."22%
"You and your baby are at risk of developing serious complications during delivery, which cannot be managed at home. I strongly recommend that you choose to come to the hospital."46%

Correct Answer: E

Question

Question
