Question
A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends 30 minutes after falling down a flight of stairs. His friends report that they were at a college party, where he drank large amounts of alcohol. His friends also say that the patient usually drinks at least two beers every night and more than that on the weekends. The patient is aggressive and restless. Examination shows tenderness to palpation and swelling of his right lower leg. An x-ray of the right leg shows a lower tibial shaft fracture. The physician recommends overnight observation and surgery the following morning. The patient refuses the suggested treatment because he is convinced that his leg is not fractured. He requests immediate discharge. Otherwise, he says, he will call his lawyer and sue the entire medical staff involved in his care. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? The treating physician has the responsibility to determine the patient's decision-making capacity, which consists of the ability to understand the information provided, appreciate the relevant facts, communicate one's choice, and describe the reasoning for one's decision.“I am sorry but treatment is medically indicated and I am obligated to obtain consent from your parents if you do not agree to the treatment.”2%
"I acknowledge that you want to go home but would like to ask some more questions first. Have you ever felt you should cut down on your drinking? "4%
"You can leave the hospital after signing a self-discharge against medical advice form."8%
"I respect your choice. Let's talk about the alternative treatment options and whether you would agree to one of them."37%
"I understand that you want to go home but you have to stay at the hospital for as long as you are intoxicated."49%
"You will be discharged if you wish but I will have to inform your parents of this incident."0%

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of back pain. For the past six days, she has had a burning pain in her upper right back and chest. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of back pain. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. The patient volunteers at an animal shelter three times a week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and pantoprazole. The patient appears healthy and well-nourished. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Examination shows a long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease? This patient has multiple vesicles and crusty lesions with severe burning pain, located in a well-circumscribed area of the body, which probably corresponds to a dermatome. These features are typical of a shingles infection.

A. Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia
B. Type IV hypersensitivity drug reaction
C. IgA deposits in the upper dermis
D. Bacterial lymphatic infection of the epidermis
E. Infestation with bloodsucking parasites
F. Infection with a gram-negative bacillus
G. Mite burrows into the stratum corneum
H. Myocardial ischemia
. Brown recluse spider envenomation

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of vomiting and severe testicular pain for 3 hours. During this time, the patient has had 4–5 episodes of vomiting. He has never had a similar episode in the past and takes no medications. His father died of testicular cancer at the age of 50. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears anxious and uncomfortable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. The right scrotum is firm, erythematous, and swollen. There is severe tenderness to palpation of the right scrotum. The pain persists on elevation of the right testicle. Stroking the inner side of the right thigh fails to elicit elevation of the scrotum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This adolescent boy presents with acute testicular pain, a negative Prehn sign (persistence of pain on elevation of the testicle), and an absent cremasteric reflex, indicating testicular torsion.

A. Urine dipstick
B. Surgical exploration of the scrotum
C. Close observation
D. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
E. Doppler ultrasound of the scrotum
F. Ceftriaxone and doxycycline therapy

Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a rash for the past day. She has had no fever, runny nose, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her parents say they have not used any new laundry detergents or cosmetics and that she has not been in contact with any animals. Two days ago, the family arrived in Miami to introduce the girl to her grandparents during the summer vacation. The parents report that they dressed her in several layers of clothing to protect her from direct sun exposure. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 55th percentile for length and weight and at the 65th percentile for head circumference. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple erythematous papules measuring 2–4 mm in diameter with background erythema in the axillae and on the neck and trunk. The oral mucosa appears normal. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient developed an erythematous, papular rash after arriving in a hot and humid climate, which is characteristic of miliaria rubra.

A. Apply topical diphenhydramine
B. Reassurance only
C. Prescribe oral acetaminophen
D. Apply topical nystatin
E. Recommend light, breathable clothing

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 76-year-old woman with hypertension and coronary artery disease is brought to the emergency department after the sudden onset of right-sided weakness. Her pulse is 83/min and blood pressure is 156/90 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows right-sided lower facial drooping and complete paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities. Tongue position is normal and she is able to swallow liquids without difficulty. Sensation to vibration, pain, position, and light touch is normal bilaterally. She is oriented to person, place, and time, and is able to speak normally. Occlusion of which of the following vessels is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms? This patient has features of a pure motor stroke without any sensory deficits or cortical signs (e.g., aphasia, agnosia, apraxia). The lesion is most likely located in the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

A. Ipsilateral anterior cerebral artery
B. Anterior spinal artery
C. Contralateral middle cerebral artery
D. Ipsilateral posterior inferior cerebellar artery
E. Contralateral lenticulostriate artery

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 33-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of increased flow and duration of her menses. Menses previously occurred at regular 32-day intervals and lasted 4 days with normal flow. They now last 10 days and the flow is heavy with the passage of clots. During this period, she has also had dyspareunia and cyclical lower abdominal pain. Her mother died of cervical cancer at the age of 58 years. Her BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows an asymmetrically enlarged, nodular uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings? The condition causing abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in this patient is more common in those who experienced early menarche (e.g., < 10 years of age).

A. Endometrial tissue within the ovaries
B. Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall
C. Excessive serum androgen levels
D. Benign tumor of the myometrium
E. Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue
F. Inflammation of the endometrium
G. Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue
H. Pedunculated endometrial mass
. Malignant proliferation of trophoblasts

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. She has cystic fibrosis and, during the past year, has had 4 respiratory exacerbations that have required hospitalization. Current medications include an inhaled bronchodilator, an inhaled corticosteroid, inhaled N-acetylcysteine, and azithromycin. The patient appears chronically ill. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 22/min and labored, and blood pressure is 106/64 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows an increased anteroposterior chest diameter. There is digital clubbing. Chest excursions and tactile fremitus are decreased on the right side. On auscultation of the chest, breath sounds are significantly diminished over the right lung field and diffuse wheezing is heard over the left lung field. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms? This patient presents with acute onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea with right-sided diminished breath sounds as well as right-sided decreased tactile fremitus. These symptoms in conjunction with a history of severe underlying pulmonary disease should raise concern for secondary spontaneous pneumothorax (SSP).

A. Bronchial hyperresponsiveness
B. Inflammation of costal cartilage
C. Infection with gram-negative coccobacilli
D. Apical subpleural cyst rupture
E. Pulmonary parenchymal fibrosis
F. Increased pulmonary capillary permeability
G. Pulmonary artery thromboembolism

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician because she has been regurgitating and vomiting 10–15 minutes after feeding for the past 3 weeks. She is breastfed and formula-fed. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2966 g (6 lb 9 oz). She currently weighs 5878 g (12 lb 15 oz). She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen and no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? An infant who regurgitates and vomits its feed without any alarming clinical features like poor weight gain or weight loss, irritability, or rectal bleeding most likely has benign gastroesophageal reflux.

A. Esophageal pH monitoring
B. Upper endoscopy
C. Ultrasound of the abdomen
D. Pantoprazole therapy
E. A diet free of cow's milk
F. Positioning therapy
G. X-ray of the abdomen

Correct Answer: F

Question
A research group develops a screening test for the early detection of lung cancer based on a newly discovered serum protein. A PhD student in the research group evaluates the performance of the test depending on different cutoff values of the serum protein. All patients in the study population are > 50 years of age, and each has a history of smoking of at least 30 pack years. The researcher plots the new test's sensitivity and specificity data on a receiver operator characteristic (ROC) curve. The test has the best performance in identifying lung cancer in patients with a serum protein cutoff value of > 50 U/mL, for which the sensitivity of the test is 93% and the specificity is 88%. A fellow PhD research student decides to repeat the study using the same screening test with the same cutoff value in patients aged < 50 years without a history of smoking. In this patient group, significantly fewer patients have lung cancer. Which of the points on the graph best represents the performance of the test in this patient group? Although the prevalence of lung cancer is lower in the second study, some test characteristics are not influenced by changes in pretest probability.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has had dyspnea and palpitations with mild exertion for the past 8 days. Initially, the symptoms subsided immediately after cessation of activity, but they have worsened and now last up to 45 minutes. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Vermont 6 weeks ago. She says she had “an episode of flu” with fever and chills 1 month ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56 years. She drinks two to four beers on social occasions and occasionally smokes marijuana. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 47/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. A resting ECG is shown. Two-step serological testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Although no tick bite or rash (erythema migrans) have been reported, an episode of flu-like symptoms shortly after a camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for Lyme disease, which is diagnosed with two-step serological testing (ELISA followed by Western blot). The ECG strip shows progressively longer PR intervals before a QRS is dropped and resets the cycle, indicating second-degree AV block, Mobitz I.

A. Intravenous ceftriaxone therapy
B. Oral amoxicillin therapy
C. Beta-blocker therapy
D. Oral doxycycline therapy
E. Atropine therapy
F. Permanent pacemaker implantation

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 75-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fatigue and black sticky stools during the past 3 days. He also complains of nausea and has had a 2-kg (4.4-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has a history of polycystic kidney disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, furosemide, valsartan, and atorvastatin. He is thin and appears tired. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and numerous excoriations on the extensor surfaces of his upper extremities. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. There is a flapping tremor when both wrists are extended. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition? This patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) presents with clinical signs of uremia (flapping tremor, pruritus leading to excoriations) and gastrointestinal bleeding (melena). Individuals with CKD are at increased risk of bleeding and anemia.

A. Inherited antithrombin deficiency
B. Inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes
C. Dysfunctional platelet aggregation
D. Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor
E. Acquired factor VII deficiency
F. Impaired production of thrombopoietin

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of lower back pain. The pain wakes him up at night and radiates down to his legs. During this time, he has also had stiffness of his back muscles. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles bilaterally. The physician decides to prescribe acetaminophen. During a follow-up examination, the patient reports feeling somewhat better but says he is “a bit tired and sleepy throughout the day.” The physician reviews the patient's prescription and notices that cyclobenzaprine was prescribed instead of acetaminophen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician? This elderly patient with acute lumbosacral radiculopathy was inadvertently prescribed cyclobenzaprine, a muscle relaxant, instead of a nonopioid analgesic (medication error).

A. Disclose the error to the patient
B. Switch medication to acetaminophen
C. Continue with the current drug regimen
D. Prescribe a topical analgesic ointment
E. Refer the patient to physical rehabilitation

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2 comes to the physician requesting advice on breastfeeding. Three weeks ago, she delivered a healthy girl. Delivery was uncomplicated, and she and her child received adequate postnatal care. Three days ago, she was diagnosed with mastitis, which is managed with cold compresses and ibuprofen. She has chronic hepatitis B infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her other medication is pantoprazole. She uses cocaine once every 1–2 months and smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is positive for CMV antibodies. The patient is apprehensive about taking care of her baby and asks for information on breastfeeding. Which of the following is most likely a contraindication for breastfeeding in this patient? I can't feel my face when I'm with you
But I love it, but I love it, oh…

A. Pantoprazole intake
B. Acute mastitis
C. Hepatitis B infection
D. Seropositivity for cytomegalovirus
E. Active cocaine use
F. Regular cigarette smoking

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for progressively worsening emesis, nausea, and a 2-kg (4.7-lb) weight loss over the past 2 weeks. The most recent bouts of vomiting occur around 3–4 times a day, and she is stressed that she had to take a sick leave from work the last 2 days. She is currently taking ginger and vitamin B6 with limited relief. Her pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. Orthostatic vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is alert and oriented. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Her hematocrit is 40%. Venous blood gas shows:In addition to oral fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's venous blood gas results show a slightly elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide and bicarbonate but an otherwise normal partial pressure of oxygen and oxygen saturation. Moreover, she has no clinical signs of dehydration (e.g., severe weight loss, abnormal orthostatic vital signs). These findings indicate uncomplicated nausea and vomiting of pregnancy.

A. IV fluid resuscitation
B. Administration of supplemental oxygen
C. Scheduled meal times
D. Monitoring and stress counseling
E. PO bismuth subsalicylate
F. Trial of metoclopramide
G. Discontinuation of ginger and vitamin B
H. Addition of doxylamine

Correct Answer: H

Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of sore throat and a painful swelling on the left side of his neck that has become progressively larger. He has had pain during swallowing and has refused to eat solid foods for the past 3 days. He immigrated to the United States one year ago from India. His immunization records are unavailable. His family keeps 2 cats as pets. He appears well. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 92/60 mm Hg. The oropharynx is erythematous; the tonsils are enlarged with exudates. There is a 3-cm warm, tender, nonfluctuant cervical lymph node on the left side of the neck. His hemoglobin is 12.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,100/mm3, and platelet count is 180,000/mm3. In addition to obtaining a throat swab and culture, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The patient has acute unilateral cervical lymphadenitis, which is most commonly caused by a bacterial infection.

A. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine therapy
B. Incision and drainage
C. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy
D. Clindamycin therapy
E. Tuberculin skin test
F. Immunoglobulin therapy
G. Excisional biopsy
H. Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of chest pain, racing pulse, dizziness, and difficulty breathing. The episodes last up to several minutes. She also reports urinary urgency and two episodes of loss of consciousness followed by spontaneous recovery. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Holter monitoring is performed. ECG recordings during episodes of tachycardia show a QRS duration of 100 ms, regular RR-interval, and absent P waves. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? This patient's symptoms together with her ECG findings (narrow QRS complex with no discernible P waves) suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), which is most commonly caused by atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

A. Macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium through cavotricuspid isthmus
B. AV node with slow and fast pathway
C. Preexcitation of the ventricles
D. Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium
E. Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels
F. Bursts of electrical activity from automatic foci near the pulmonary veins

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Her husband noticed a “weird-looking” dark skin lesion on her hand 3 months ago. She has not seen any changes in the lesion since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. The patient has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has light skin but no freckles. There is an elevated, symmetrical skin lesion with uniform borders on the medial aspect of the patient's left hand. The lesion measures 5 mm in diameter and is dark brown. Dermoscopy shows a brown pigment network with scattered grey and reddish spots. Which of the following is the strongest indicator for performing an excisional biopsy? A pigment network is characteristic of a melanocytic lesion. Consider the ABCDE criteria to identify signs of malignant melanoma: Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution.

A. Multiple colors of the lesion
B. 5 mm diameter of the lesion
C. No change in the lesion over the past 3 months
D. Uniform borders of the lesion
E. Symmetrical appearance of the lesion
F. Elevation of the lesion

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 2300-g (5-lb 1-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 45 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn? Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for infants born to mothers with HIV infection to decrease the risk of transmission.

A. HIV RNA testing
B. HIV antibody testing
C. Administer zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine
D. Reassurance and follow up
E. Administer lamivudine and nevirapine
F. Administer zidovudine

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border. The murmur decreases in intensity on rapid squatting and increases in intensity when he performs the Valsalva maneuver. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications? Echocardiography would most likely show asymmetric interventricular septal hypertrophy and/or systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, which are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

A. Angiodysplasia
B. Infective endocarditis
C. Sudden cardiac death
D. Paradoxical embolism
E. Pulmonary apoplexy
F. Cerebral aneurysm

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 55-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of heavy vaginal bleeding, requiring more than 5 pads per day. Menarche was at the age of 10 years. Menopause occurred 1 year ago. She has a history of hypothyroidism and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. Current medications include levothyroxine and metformin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild vaginal atrophy and a normal cervix. The uterus and adnexa are nontender to palpation. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows an endometrial thickness of 6 mm. Endometrial biopsy shows noninvasive proliferation of endometrial glands with no nuclear or cytological atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In postmenopausal women, endometrial thickness > 5 mm with no evidence of atypia or invasion on endometrial biopsy, is diagnostic of endometrial hyperplasia.

A. Total hysterectomy
B. Estrogen vaginal cream
C. Reassurance and follow-up
D. Progestin therapy
E. Surgical endometrial ablation
F. Anastrozole therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 61-year-old man with progressive left hip pain comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One year ago, he was diagnosed with osteoarthritis of the left hip. Since then, he has had an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss after changing to a vegetarian diet, regular swimming, and physical therapy. The pain worsens when he climbs stairs, which makes it increasingly difficult for him to reach his apartment located on the second floor. Over the last few weeks, he gradually increased the frequency of diclofenac intake but says that even a daily intake does not provide complete pain relief. He asks for a treatment that will lead to a long-term improvement of his symptoms. He has no history of major medical illness. His only other medication is pantoprazole. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Physical examination of the left hip shows crepitus, a limited internal rotation, and pain with full flexion and extension. An x-ray of the left hip shows joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis and cysts. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient? Long-term improvement of osteoarthritis (OA) of the hip joint requires treating the cause rather than the symptoms.

A. Arthroscopic hip debridement
B. Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections
C. Walking aids
D. Fentanyl patch
E. Total hip arthroplasty

Correct Answer: E

Question
Two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit for a hemorrhagic stroke, a 54-year-old man regains consciousness. At the time of admission, a CT scan of the head showed evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a ruptured aneurysm. The patient is mechanically ventilated via a tracheostomy tube. Neurologic examination shows quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a Babinski sign in both legs. He responds to questions by blinking, but neck, lingual, and other facial movements are lost. Doll's eye testing shows restricted horizontal movement and preserved vertical movement. On mental status examination, he is alert and comprehends the physician's questions. This patient's condition is most likely caused by bleeding in a region supplied by which of the following arteries? This patient presents after a period of coma with quadriplegia and anarthria in conjunction with the preservation of consciousness, cognition, vertical eye movements, and blinking, all of which are characteristic of locked-in syndrome. This condition is typically a result of bilateral damage to the ventral pons.

A. Posterior cerebral
B. Anterior communicating
C. Posterior inferior cerebellar
D. Middle cerebral
E. Anterior spinal
F. Basilar

Correct Answer: F

Question
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 12-hour history of suspected abdominal pain. The mother says that he has not had any fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago and appeared hard. He was recently introduced to solid food and his diet consists of breast milk, yogurt, fruits, vegetables, and infant cereals. He is restless and cries when his abdomen is touched. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 135/min, and respirations are 35/min. The abdomen appears mildly distended. On auscultation, there are hyperactive bowel sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This 8-month-old patient, who has recently started eating solid foods, presents with abdominal pain, infrequent, hard bowel movements, hyperactive bowel sounds, a normal ultrasound, and no alarm symptoms (e.g., fever, vomiting, diarrhea), all of which suggests primary constipation.

A. Recommend apple juice diluted with water
B. Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up in 1 month
C. Administer intravenous fluids
D. Perform a barium enema
E. Recommend oral mineral oil

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after falling on the road while taking her dog for a walk. She says that she has not lost consciousness but “simply tripped over a rock.” A similar event happened 2 weeks ago when she fell while grocery shopping. She has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her family history is significant for Parkinson disease. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks one to two glasses of wine each week. Current medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, aspirin, metformin, and empagliflozin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. Examination shows an abrasion on her right knee and a deep cut on her right hand. Neurologic examination shows normal sensation to pinprick and vibration. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the left lower limb and 2+ in the right lower limb. She was able to get up out of her chair and walk to the wall and back to the chair without any problems. Which of the following is the most important risk factor for future falls in this patient? The “Timed Up and Go” test is used to assess musculoskeletal function and postural stability in patients who have fallen. The patient is asked to get up from a chair, walk a certain distance, turn around, walk back, and sit down again.

A. Previous falls
B. Medication use
C. Peripheral neuropathy
D. Orthostatic hypotension
E. Family history of Parkinson disease
F. Alcohol use

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency over the past month. She also reports having dry mouth and feeling thirsty all the time despite drinking several liters of water per day. She has not had any weight changes and her appetite is normal. She has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers per day. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:The patient is asked to stop drinking water for 3 hours. Following water restriction, urine osmolality is measured every hour, whereas serum osmolality is measured every 2 hours. Repeated laboratory measurements show a serum osmolality of 280 mOsmol/kg H2O and a urine osmolality of 650 mOsmol/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? After the water deprivation test, the patient's serum and urine osmolality are normal. These findings are suggestive of a condition that is commonly associated with psychiatric diseases such as obsessive-compulsive disorder.

A. Cerebral salt wasting
B. Central diabetes insipidus
C. Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion
D. Diabetes mellitus
E. Beer potomania
F. Primary polydipsia
G. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 23-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of nausea and vomiting. She has no fever, abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, or dysuria. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft; there is no rebound tenderness or guarding. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy consistent in size with an 8-week gestation. The hormone that was measured in this patient's urine to detect the pregnancy is also directly responsible for which of the following processes? Levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) peak in the first trimester of pregnancy.

A. Inhibition of ovulation
B. Maintenance of the corpus luteum
C. Hypertrophy of the uterine myometrium
D. Inhibition of preterm uterine contractions
E. Preparation of the uterine endometrium for implantation
F. Fetal angiogenesis

Correct Answer: B

Question
A physician at an internal medicine ward notices that several of his patients have hyponatremia without any associated symptoms. Severe hyponatremia, often defined as < 120 mEq/L, is associated with altered mental status, coma, and seizures, and warrants treatment with hypertonic saline. Because some patients are chronically hyponatremic, with serum levels < 120 mEq/L, but remain asymptomatic, the physician is considering decreasing the cutoff for severe hyponatremia to < 115 mEq/L. Changing the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L would affect the validity of serum sodium in predicting severe hyponatremia requiring hypertonic saline in which of the following ways? Keep in mind that this is a low value test: lowering the cutoff to < 115 mEq/L would result in an increase in true negatives and false negatives.

A. Increased specificity and decreased negative predictive value
B. Decreased specificity and increased negative predictive value
C. Decreased sensitivity and increased negative predictive value
D. Increased sensitivity and decreased positive predictive value
E. Decreased sensitivity and decreased positive predictive value
F. Increased specificity and decreased positive predictive value

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and increasing shortness of breath with exertion. Medical history is remarkable for hyperlipidemia, recurrent urinary tract infections, and aortic stenosis treated with aortic valve replacement 3 years ago. Current medications include atorvastatin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, warfarin, and aspirin. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/83 mm Hg. Examination shows yellowing of the eyes. A grade 2/6, high-pitched diastolic murmur is heard best at the left sternal border. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral blood smear is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient's peripheral blood smear (PBS) shows schistocytes, which, in conjunction with anemia, low haptoglobin, elevated bilirubin, and elevated LDH suggests intravascular hemolytic anemia (IHA).

A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
B. Hereditary spherocytosis
C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
D. Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia
E. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe chest discomfort. The chest discomfort usually occurs after heavy meals or eating in the late evening and lasts several hours. He has nausea sometimes but no vomiting. He has also had an occasional nighttime cough during this period. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 41 years and drinks one beer daily. Current medications include metformin, naproxen, enalapril, and sitagliptin. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows no abnormalities. An upper endoscopy shows that the Z-line is located 4 cm above the diaphragmatic hiatus and reveals the presence of a 1.5-cm esophageal ulcer with an erythematous base and without bleeding. Esophageal biopsy specimens show no signs of dysplasia. The physician recommends weight loss as well as smoking and alcohol cessation. Treatment with omeprazole is begun. One month later, his symptoms are unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This overweight patient has severe chest discomfort following large meals and eating late (likely related to lying down) and an occasional nighttime cough, suggesting gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The endoscopy shows a type I hiatal hernia and an esophageal ulcer, which indicates severe GERD.

B. Laparoscopic herniotomy
C. Laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication with hiatoplasty
D. Calcium carbonate therapy for 2 months
E. Sleeve gastrectomy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 35-year-old military nurse with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of fever, fatigue, dry cough, headache, and myalgia. An x-ray of the chest shows hilar lymphadenopathy with central calcification and multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules measuring 1–10 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? This patient takes immunosuppressive medications and has nonspecific constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss), oral ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, pulmonary involvement (e.g., cough, crackles, hilar lymphadenopathy, well-defined pulmonary nodules), pancytopenia, and increased transaminase levels. Question
A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

B. Head bobbing in synchrony with heart beat
C. Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
D. Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing
E. Jugular venous distention on inspiration
F. Crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur

Question

Examination shows “punched-out” skin lesions on the scalp, cleft lip, and a small chin. The patient's feet have a convex plantar surface. Auscultation shows a holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. Some of her intestines protrude through the umbilicus, covered by a thin membranous sac. An MRI of the brain shows a single ventricle and fusion of the basal ganglia. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient? Aplasia cutis (“punched-out” scalp lesions), cleft lip, holoprosencephaly on MRI, and findings indicative of congenital heart disease (holosystolic murmur), in addition to low birth weight, microcephaly, small chin, rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity with prominent heels), and omphalocele, are all highly suggestive of trisomy 13.

B. Webbed neck
C. High-pitched crying
D. Overlapping fingers
E. Hypoplastic philtrum

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

They don't even know about my boyfriend.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response? "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents only if you are legally emancipated."1%
"I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but I am obligated to inform your partner of your diagnosis."9%
"I can prescribe you antibiotics only if one of your parents consents."0%
"I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, and I recommend that your partner get tested."86%

Question

B. Inform the friend that it is never appropriate for a physician to be involved in the treatment of a friend or family member
C. Prescribe oral contraceptives if the friend agrees to undergo a proper physical examination
D. Prescribe oral contraceptives after ruling out that the friend has any contraindications, but emphasize that this is an exception
E. Explain that it is not appropriate to prescribe medication to a friend unless in an emergency

During the consultation, the physician realizes that the patient is not aware of the results of the HIV test that was performed a year ago. In addition to disclosing the results of the previous HIV test, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician? The failure to provide full disclosure in a timely manner constitutes a medical error. The right action in this scenario is based on the principles of professional respect and a systems-based approach towards medical error.

A. Request that the patient contact the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
B. Speak to the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test
C. Report the colleague who ordered the initial HIV test to the state medical board
D. Disclose to the patient that a colleague forgot to follow up on the results of the initial HIV test

Question
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, nasal discharge, and dry cough. He has had no dyspnea, visual changes, or painful eye movements. He has not been going to work during this time because he has been sleeping poorly. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 8 years. The patient is allergic to penicillin. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Examination shows clear mucus in the nostrils and the posterior oropharynx. Pulmonary examination is shown. There are no focal neurologic findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? VIDEOThis patient's rhinorrhea, fever, headache, dry cough, duration of symptoms, and physical examination findings are consistent with acute viral rhinosinusitis.

A. Inhaled beclomethasone therapy
B. Reassurance and close follow-up
C. CT scan of the sinuses
D. Oral levofloxacin
E. Sputum Gram stain and culture
F. Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate therapy
G. X-ray of the chest

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of persistent fever and cough. Three days ago, he was diagnosed with pneumonia and acute otitis media. He was started on ampicillin-sulbactam and clarithromycin, but his symptoms did not improve. The mother reports that her son has been hospitalized 3 times due to pneumonia. He was first diagnosed with pneumonia at the age of 10 months. She also reports several episodes of bilateral otitis media and recurrent respiratory tract infections. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Otoscopic examination shows purulent otorrhea bilaterally. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds over both lung fields. The palatine tonsils and adenoids are hypoplastic. These features suggest X-linked (Bruton) agammaglobulinemia.

B. Deficient beta-2 integrin
C. Defective IL-2R gamma chain
D. Defect in the ATM gene
E. WAS gene mutation
F. Tyrosine kinase gene mutation

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after being bitten by a rattlesnake. He was hiking in the Arizona desert when he accidentally stepped on the snake and it bit his right leg. His pulse is 135/min and blood pressure is 104/81 mm Hg. Examination shows right lower leg swelling, ecchymosis, and blistering. Right ankle dorsiflexion elicits severe pain. A manometer inserted in the lateral compartment of the lower leg shows an intracompartmental pressure of 67 mm Hg. In addition to administration of the antivenom, the patient undergoes fasciotomy. Two weeks later, he reports difficulty with walking. Neurologic examination shows a loss of sensation over the lower part of the lateral side of the right leg and the dorsum of the right foot. Right foot eversion is 1/5. There is no weakness upon dorsiflexion. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient? A. Tibial nerve
B. Sural nerve
C. Deep peroneal nerve
D. Superficial peroneal nerve
E. Saphenous nerve

Correct Answer: D

Question

After intubation, his pulse is 91/min and blood pressure is 135/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. D. Administer inhaled albuterol

Question

Question

During the past week, he has had up to 4 episodes of watery stools daily. He has also had pain in the mouth and gums for 6 days. He has not had nausea, vomiting, or fever. Four months ago, he went on a 1-week trip to the Dominican Republic. He has atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypothyroidism. Current medications include levothyroxine, metoprolol, and warfarin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. D. Ischemic colitis

Question

Question

She is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and scheduled for a laparoscopic appendectomy the next day. She is given nothing by mouth, and administration of intravenous fluids is begun. On the night before the surgery, she experiences severe abdominal pain and asks for pain medication. The physician on call prescribes intravenous acetaminophen. A nurse connects the medication to the patient's infusion set, opens one side clamp, and leaves the room. One hour later, the patient is still in severe pain and calls the physician again. The physician discovers an additional closed side clamp that he had not noticed in his past five years at the hospital. He opens the clamp, and the infusion starts to run. When the physician discusses the incident with his colleagues, someone says, “We have two types of infusion sets in the hospital. This one is new.” The underlying cause of the delay in this patient's treatment is best described by which of the following terms? Standardization of infusion sets could have prevented the delay in treatment.

A. Physician impairment
B. Latent error
C. Deprescribing
D. Workaround
E. Compassion fatigue

Question

As the urologist is called to see a different emergency patient, she asks the emergency department resident to obtain informed consent for the procedure. The resident recalls a lecture about the different modes of catheterization, but he has never seen or performed a suprapubic catheterization himself. Which of the following statements by the emergency department resident is the most appropriate? Written informed consent should be obtained for invasive procedures.“I will make sure the patient reads and signs the informed consent form.”8%
“I would be happy to obtain informed consent on your behalf, but I'm not legally allowed to do so during my residency.”8%
“Suprapubic catheterization is not the treatment of choice for this patient.”0%
“I would prefer that you obtain informed consent when you become available again.”83%
“I will ask the patient to waive informed consent because this is an urgent procedure.”0%

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of reduced vision in her eye. She says that she can see black moving spots and flashes of light in her right eye. The symptoms started when she was jumping on a trampoline with her grandchild. She does not report pain. Her medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and atrial fibrillation. Since childhood, she has worn glasses for progressive myopia. Her medications are metformin, metoprolol, and apixaban. She is alert and fully oriented. Question
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue for the past 4 months. Two years ago, she came to the office with dysphagia and underwent an upper endoscopy, which showed a dilated esophagus. There is no family history of serious illness. She emigrated from Argentina 5 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (137 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1ºC (98.8ºF), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distension. Cardiac examination discloses an S3 gallop and a displaced left ventricular impulse. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows right and left ventricular dilation and global hypokinesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings? This patient's findings of left ventricular dilation and global hypokinesis on echocardiography are consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy, which typically manifests with features of congestive heart failure (CHF; e.g., progressive exertional dyspnea, jugular venous distension, S3 gallop, displaced left ventricular impulse). ECG findings of left ventricular hypertrophy are common in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy.

A. Coxsackie B virus infection
B. Thiamine deficiency
C. Iron accumulation
D. Anti-topoisomerase I antibodies
E. Trypanosoma cruzi infection
F. Chronic tissue ischemia

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of confusion and rapidly progressive dyspnea. He has had a fever and chills for the past five days. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with hepatitis C. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and drinks one to two beers daily. He has a history of past intravenous heroin use. He appears pale, anxious, and in severe distress. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), respirations are 30/min, pulse is 59/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 75%. Examination shows multiple linear hemorrhages underneath the nails. There are nontender maculae on both palms and soles. Fine rales are heard bilaterally on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows an S3; a grade 3/6 high-pitched decrescendo early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border and right second intercostal space. An x-ray of the chest shows a normal-sized heart and pulmonary edema. An ECG shows P waves and QRS complexes that occur at regular intervals, but independently of each other. Transesophageal echocardiography of this patient is most likely to show which of the following? The combination of fever, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, and a heart murmur characteristic of aortic regurgitation suggests infective endocarditis (IE). Rapidly progressive dyspnea, bilateral rales on auscultation, pulmonary edema, hypotension, and hypoxia are consistent with acute heart failure. ECG findings show a third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block.

A. A highly echogenic, thin, linear structure in the right atrium
B. Heterogeneous mass attached to the interatrial septum
C. Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium
D. Perivalvular thickening with an echolucent cavity
E. Oscillating mobile mass on the tricuspid valve
F. Eccentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle

Correct Answer: D

E. Foreign body aspiration

Question
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a routine health examination. According to the patient's mother, the boy has been more withdrawn lately and has also lost some weight, which she finds “suspicious.” Their family moved from a different state 6 months ago. The boy has some difficulty making friends at the new school but has good academic performance. He enjoys playing drums and has a good appetite. The patient says he tried beer before but does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His vital signs are normal. Physical and mental status examinations show no abnormalities. The physician reassures the parents that their son is experiencing a normal stress reaction. At the end of the visit, the patient's mother asks if she could talk to the physician in private. When left alone with the physician, the mother says: “I think my son is lying about the drug use. Could you please run a drug test on him but tell him it is just a routine laboratory test? ” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? Regardless of the medical issue, it is preferable for the physician to gain the minor's approval before starting medical care."We can perform this test only if you as a parent sign a liability waiver."0%
"I understand your concern and will schedule the test for our next appointment."0%
"I do not think your son is using drugs, since his examination showed no abnormalities."1%
"I cannot lie to your son about the nature of the test. Why do you think your son is lying about the drug use? "91%
"I could do this, but I think it would be better if you discussed your concerns with your son first."8%

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent shortness of breath while going upstairs and walking his dog. It began about 1 month ago and seems to be getting worse. He has also developed a dry cough. He has not had any wheezing, fevers, chills, recent weight loss, or shortness of breath at rest. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma, for which he was treated with chemotherapy and radiation to the chest 7 years ago. He also has hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. Ten years ago, he retired from work in the shipbuilding industry. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily since the age of 21. Vital signs are within normal limits. On lung auscultation, there are mild bibasilar crackles. A plain x-ray of the chest shows bilateral ground-glass opacities at the lung bases and bilateral calcified pleural plaques. A. Occupational exposure
B. Smoking history
C. Advanced age
D. Family history
E. Radiation therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 2-hour history of word-finding difficulty, speech slurring, and weakness and sensory loss of his right arm and leg. He has not had fever, nausea, headache, or diarrhea. His mother reports an episode of severe pain and swelling of his hands and feet when he was 12 months old, which self-resolved after 2 weeks. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. He follows commands but has nonfluent aphasia. Examination shows marked weakness and decreased sensation of the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Babinski sign is present on the right. An MRI scan of the brain shows signs of an evolving cerebral infarction on the patient's left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? In a young patient, ischemic stroke, a history of dactylitis (pain/swelling of the hands and feet), and low O2 saturation suggest sickle cell disease (SCD). Sickled red blood cells are rigid and tend to clump along the walls of arteries, which can lead to thrombosis, infarction, and end-organ ischemia (cerebral infarction in this case).

A. Exchange transfusion therapy
B. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator therapy
C. Mechanical thrombectomy
D. Hydroxyurea therapy
E. Heparin therapy
F. Aspirin therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

C. Consult a multidisciplinary team specialized in gender identity services

Question
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on her neck for 7 months. It is neither pruritic nor painful. She has tried using over-the-counter topical medications, but none have helped. She has hypertension, hypothyroidism, and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, levothyroxine, and pantoprazole. She is a farmer and lives with her two children. C. Schedule external beam radiotherapy sessions
D. Administer topical 5-fluorouracil to the lesion

G. Perform a wedge biopsy of the lesion and surrounding tissue

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of diffuse abdominal pain and intermittent constipation over the past year. Question
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels that her baby's movements have decreased recently. She says that she used to feel 10–12 movements/hour earlier, but that it has decreased to about 7–8/hour since the day before. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. A nonstress test (NST) is considered reactive if there are ≥ 2 fetal heart rate accelerations that last for at least 15 seconds and are > 15 bpm above the baseline within a 20-minute period.

A. Repeat the nonstress test weekly
B. Reposition the mother
C. Provide reassurance to the mother
D. Perform a biophysical profile test
E. Administer intravenous oxytocin
F. Perform vibroacoustic stimulation
G. Extend the nonstress test by 20 minutes

Question

He returned from a mission trip to Haiti 3 weeks ago where he worked in a rural health clinic. He appears lethargic. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows equal and reactive pupils. There are scattered petechiae over the trunk and lower extremities. Range of motion of the neck is decreased due to pain. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Blood cultures are obtained and a lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows neutrophilic pleocytosis and decreased glucose concentration. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition? Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings of neutrophilia and decreased glucose concentration support this diagnosis.

A. Fluconazole therapy
B. Mefloquine therapy
C. Inactivated whole-cell vaccine
D. Toxoid vaccine
E. Polysaccharide conjugate vaccine
F. Permethrin spray
G. Erythromycin therapy
H. Live attenuated vaccine

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of nausea, loss of appetite, and abdominal pain. He has dyslipidemia and hypertension. Medications are atorvastatin and valsartan. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart sounds are normal. On abdominal examination, there is periumbilical tenderness with mild guarding but no rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory studies show:ECG shows no abnormalities. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In patients with a nonspecific clinical presentation, scoring systems can help guide management decisions. This patient has an Alvarado score of 6 based on the following features: temperature > 37.3°C (1 point), anorexia (1 point), nausea (1 point), and leukocytosis > 10,000/mm3 (2 points) with left shift (1 point). This score indicates a moderate likelihood of appendicitis.

A. X-ray of the abdomen
B. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
C. Pain relief and observation only
D. Abdominal ultrasonography
E. Surgical exploration

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A previously healthy 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of chronic, progressive fatigue over the last 18 months. About four months ago, he started experiencing left-sided abdominal discomfort and occasionally has left shoulder pain. He also has had a 7-kg (15.4-lb) weight loss during this period. He has not seen a physician since he retired from his job on a production line at a shoe factory 5 years ago. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nontender, bilateral axillary, and right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 7 cm below the left costal margin and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count of 40,000/mm3 with marked lymphocytosis, and a thrombocyte count of 97,000/mm3. Peripheral blood smear shows numerous mature lymphocytes and smudge cells. Flow cytometry shows B cells that express CD20. Which of the following is the strongest indicator of a poor prognosis for this patient's condition? This patient presents with chronic, progressive fatigue, painless, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. In addition, he has left shoulder pain (likely referred pain), lymphocytosis, smudge cells, and B cells with CD20 expression. Exposure to organic solvents (e.g., from working in a shoe production factory) increases the risk of developing hematological conditions, making chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the most likely diagnosis.

A. Peripheral lymphadenopathy
B. Splenomegaly
C. CD20+ expression
D. Thrombocytopenia
E. Lymphocytosis
F. Smudge cells

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of mild right upper abdominal pain. She has not had any fevers, chills, or weight loss. B. Biliary peritonitis
C. Bacteremia
D. Metastatic spread
E. Anaphylactic shock

Question

Question
A group of investigators conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of rivaroxaban to warfarin for ischemic stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. A total of 14,000 participants were enrolled and one half was assigned to each of the cohorts. The patients were followed prospectively for 3 years. At the conclusion of the trial, the incidence of ischemic stroke in participants taking rivaroxaban was 1.7% compared to 2.2% in participants taking warfarin. The hazard ratio is calculated as 0.79 and the 95% confidence interval is reported as 0.64 to 0.97. If the study was conducted with a total of 7000 participants, which of the following changes would most be expected? Decreasing the number of participants (i.e., the sample size) also decreases the power of the study.

A. Increased risk of selection bias
B. Decreased hazard ratio
C. Increased confidence interval range
D. Decreased type I error rate
E. Increased risk of confounding bias
F. Decreased type II error rate

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question
A 38-year-old primigravid woman at 33 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She feels well and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has completed all previous routine prenatal visits. Medical history is remarkable for pregestational hypertension. Her medications are methyldopa, low-dose aspirin, and a prenatal multivitamin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Between 24 and 36 weeks' gestation, the fundal height (in cm) should roughly equal the gestational age (in weeks). A fundal height of at least 3 cm less than the gestational age, as seen here, should raise concern for intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

A. Cell-free fetal DNA testing
B. Transabdominal ultrasonography
C. Glucose challenge test
D. Contraction stress test
E. Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks
F. Betamethasone therapy and induction of labor

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a fall. He has been seen by the triage nurse but has not been evaluated by a physician. He is heard yelling down the hallway, requesting to speak to “whoever is in charge.” He refuses to talk to the emergency resident and insists on talking to the attending physician despite being informed that the attending is currently resuscitating a patient who was in a car accident. He says that he deserves better treatment because he has made numerous contributions to the field of medicine. When asked about his work, he mentions that he was a medical device salesman. He is accompanied by his wife, who appears embarrassed. She claims that her husband frequently makes a scene and apologizes for her husband's behavior. She says that this has been like that “for years”. On mental status examination, the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. He appears agitated and speaks in short, pressured sentences. There is no disorder of thought process or content. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This man exhibits a grandiose sense of self-importance and a feeling of entitlement. His attempt to interrupt the attending's efforts to save another patient's life also suggests a lack of empathy. He exaggerates his achievements, expects to be recognized as superior, and becomes upset and/or agitated when others fail to acknowledge his superiority. B. Antisocial personality disorder
C. Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder
D. Borderline personality disorder
E. Histrionic personality disorder
F. Intermittent explosive disorder
G. Bipolar disorder
H. Narcissistic personality disorder

Correct Answer: H

Question
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of a 3-day history of left lower abdominal pain. During this period, the patient has also had a low-grade fever and has not had a bowel movement. He has a history of constipation. He underwent a cholecystectomy at the age of 53 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows left lower quadrant tenderness with no guarding or rebound. There is no edema of his lower extremities. CT of the abdomen with contrast shows segmental wall thickening of the descending colon with multiple diverticula, surrounding fat stranding, and a 5.5-cm, low-attenuating pelvic fluid collection. Intravenous fluids and bowel rest are started. Treatment with intravenous morphine, ciprofloxacin, and metronidazole is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's history of constipation and left lower quadrant pain together with CT findings of segmental colonic wall thickening with multiple diverticula and surrounding fat stranding suggest acute diverticulitis. The > 4.0-cm low-attenuating fluid collection is consistent with a large pelvic abscess, which has developed as a complication of diverticulitis. There are no signs that suggest peritonitis (e.g., guarding, rebound tenderness, rigid abdomen). Intravenous antibiotics alone are highly unlikely to resolve this patient's condition.

A. Observation and serial CT scans
B. Left laparoscopic hemicolectomy
C. Colonoscopy
D. CT-guided percutaneous abscess drainage
E. Exploratory laparotomy
F. Segmental colonic resection

Correct Answer: D

Question
An outbreak of Ebola virus disease occurs in West Africa. Question

Question
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of intermittent fevers, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Three weeks ago he was treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate and azithromycin, which did not improve his symptoms. He is also worried because he has noticed “some new bumps on his skin”. He lives in upstate New York along the Mohawk River. He has rheumatoid arthritis. He does not smoke cigarettes. His medications include methotrexate and a multivitamin. His temperature is 38.1ºC (100.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard over both lung fields. Skin examination shows multiple, white, verrucous papules and nodules on the thighs. A CT scan of the chest shows bilateral tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes. A biopsy of a skin nodule shows pyogranulomatous inflammation and round yeast cells. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen? This patient has subacute pneumonia that has not improved with antibiotic therapy. His extrapulmonary manifestations (cutaneous lesions), imaging findings (tree-in-bud opacities in the lower lobes), and biopsy findings (round yeast cells) are characteristic of a disseminated infection caused by a fungus endemic to the eastern and central United States. Question
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. Two days ago, he had a routine health maintenance examination that showed 3+ proteinuria on urine dipstick testing. He works as an intern at a shooting range, where he does not usually use appropriate hearing protection. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. There is mild sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Question

Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and severe labor pains, and the patient received epidural analgesia. Question
A 15-month-old girl is brought to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit to receive the fourth dose of her diphtheria tetanus acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine. She is up-to-date on her vaccinations. Three months ago, she received her first dose of measles, mumps, rubella (MMR), first dose of varicella, third dose of Haemophilus influenza tybe B (HiB), fourth dose of pneumococcal conjugate (PCV13), and third dose of polio vaccine. Thirteen days after receiving these vaccinations, the child developed a fever up to 40.5°C (104.9°F) and had one generalized seizure that lasted for 2 minutes. She was taken to the emergency department. The girl was sent home after workup for the seizure was unremarkable and her temperature subsided with acetaminophen therapy. She has not had any other symptoms since then. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her mother is concerned about receiving further vaccinations because she is afraid of her daughter having more seizures. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time? The patient's history of one generalized seizure with associated fever and an unremarkable workup is consistent with a febrile seizure.

A. Refrain from administration of the DTaP vaccine
B. Administration of the DTaP vaccine with prophylactic aspirin
C. Administration of the DTaP vaccine as scheduled
D. Administration of the DTaP vaccine with valproic acid
E. Administration of a reduced-dose DTaP vaccine

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

To reduce costs, the clinic pharmacy decides to transition from buying injectable operating room drugs in prefilled single-dose syringes to bulk packages of multidose vials that have to be prepared for single-use injection. An anesthesiologist raises the concern that multidose vials increase the risk of perioperative medication errors. If the clinic continues to purchase multidose vials, which of the following actions is most likely to maximize patient safety? B. Drawing up of drugs by the circulating nurse during surgery based on instructions by the anesthetist
C. Drawing up of drugs by the anesthesiologist during surgery
D. Drawing up of drugs by a scrub nurse before surgery based on the patient's diagnosis
E. Drawing up and labeling of drugs by the surgeon before surgery

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after an episode of cyanosis and muscle hypotonia that resolved after 2 minutes. Diagnostic evaluation fails to discover an exact etiology of the boy's symptoms and the episode is classified as a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE). The risk profile for BRUE in infants remains largely unknown. The pediatrician who saw the boy in the emergency department is trying to identify risk factors for BRUE. She is aware of several confounders, including age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness. She recruits 75 infants under 1 year of age with BRUE and 75 infants without BRUE of the same age, socioeconomic background, and family history of medical illness. She then compares the two groups with regard to history of feeding problems and history of recent upper respiratory infection. Which of the following methods was conducted to control confounding bias in the study? A. Stratified analysis
B. Increased sample size
C. Blinding
D. Restriction
E. Randomization
F. Matching

Correct Answer: F

Question

Question
A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive swelling of his legs over the past 2 months. During this period, the patient has had an unintentional 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain. He also reports frequent numbness of the tips of his fingers and cramping in his back and leg muscles. He has a history of HIV infection treated with combined antiretroviral therapy. The patient immigrated to the US from Nigeria 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 3+ periorbital and lower extremity edema bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased around the mouth and along the fingers. Laboratory studies show:A kidney biopsy is most likely to show which of the following findings under light microscopy? This patient has several features of nephrotic syndrome, i.e., edema of the face and extremities, hypoalbuminemia, hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, weight gain, symptoms of hypocalcemia (paresthesias, muscle cramping), and heavy proteinuria (4+ on urine dipstick). Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. He also had a sore throat 2 weeks ago. Laboratory studies show:Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. The combination of intussusception with palpable purpura on the lower extremities, bilateral arthritis of the ankle joints, and hematuria (indicating nephritic syndrome) are highly suggestive of a type of small-vessel vasculitis.

B. P-ANCA vasculitis of small vessels

D. Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct
E. Disseminated infection with gram-negative cocci
