Question
A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain and a burning sensation in both feet. The symptoms worsen when she tries to fall asleep at night. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic knee pain. Current medications are enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, sitagliptin, and tramadol. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination of the lower legs and feet shows bilateral varicose veins and mild edema; the skin is scaly but intact. Neurologic examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration in both feet. Ankle reflexes are absent bilaterally. Romberg test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's pain? In a patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, pain and burning in both lower extremities most likely indicate painful diabetic neuropathy.

A. Naproxen therapy
B. Duloxetine therapy
C. Gabapentin therapy
D. Vitamin B12 therapy
E. Insulin therapy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of increasing weakness and chills. She also notes difficulty breathing for the last 3 days. Eight weeks ago, she underwent a left hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. She subsequently developed a severe urinary tract infection, was treated in the intensive care unit for 4 days, and was discharged from the hospital 3 weeks ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, osteoporosis with lumbar pain, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. She does not drink alcohol and has never used illicit drugs. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. She appears lethargic and has a large conjunctival hemorrhage in her left eye. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 126/79 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals a new holosystolic murmur over the apex. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the upper quadrants and a well-healed 12-cm paramedian scar. There are multiple tender nodules on the palmar surface of her fingertips. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages with pale centers. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition? This patient has definite subacute infective endocarditis (IE) according to the Duke criteria: she fulfills 1 major criterion (new valvular regurgitation on auscultation) and 3 minor criteria (fever, vascular abnormalities (conjunctival hemorrhage), and immunologic manifestations (Osler nodes, Roth spots). Her history of a nosocomial urinary tract infection (UTI) indicates infection with a certain pathogen.

A. Pulmonary metastases
B. Streptococcus sanguinis infection
C. Cardiobacterium hominis infection
D. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis
E. Aspergillus fumigatus infection
F. Enterococcus faecalis infection

Correct Answer: F

Question
Fourteen days after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis, a 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of persistent episodic epigastric pain for 3 days. The pain radiates to her back, occurs randomly throughout the day, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. Each episode lasts 30 minutes to one hour. Antacids do not improve her symptoms. She has hypertension and fibromyalgia. She has smoked 1–2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years and drinks 4 cans of beer every week. She takes lisinopril and pregabalin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 127/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the upper quadrants without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. The incisions are clean, dry, and intact. Serum studies show:Abdominal ultrasonography shows a common bile duct measuring 11 mm in diameter and no gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? B. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
C. Helicobacter pylori stool antigen testing
D. Proton pump inhibitor therapy
E. Reassurance and follow-up in 4 weeks
F. CT scan of the abdomen

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after an episode of violent jerky movements of his arms and legs. He has no recollection of the episode. The episode lasted for 3–4 minutes. His girlfriend reports that he has not been sleeping well over the past month. He is only oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count, as well as serum concentrations of glucose, electrolytes, and calcium, are within the reference range. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Violent jerky movements of arms and legs and a loss of consciousness, along with a prolonged phase of confusion and mild anterograde amnesia after regaining consciousness, indicate a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. Normal blood tests, a negative toxicology screen, and the absence of findings on cranial imaging suggest that the patient has a primary seizure disorder.

A. Lorazepam
B. Lumbar puncture
C. Serum prolactin level
D. Tilt table test
E. Electroencephalography
F. Lamotrigine

Correct Answer: E

Question

B. Adenosine therapy

Question
A 72-year-old man is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care physician for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 3 years ago. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care physician's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the physician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, “I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time.” Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management? To ensure the quality of care and avoid patient harm, critical imaging results should be communicated with the referring physician in a timely manner.

A. Computerized alert notifications for the primary care physician upon uploading of the radiology report
B. Explanation of the imaging findings to the patient by the radiologist in person
C. Sending concrete follow-up recommendations and a compact disc of the images to the primary care physician via registered mail
D. Verbal communication of imaging results between the providers via phone
E. Asking the patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly until the imaging results are available

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever, malaise, productive cough, and left-sided chest pain for 2 weeks. During this time, he has woken up to a wet pillow in the morning on multiple occasions and has not been as hungry as usual. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 1 year ago. He currently stays at a homeless shelter. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 22 years. He has a history of intravenous illicit drug use. He drinks 5–6 beers daily. He is receiving combined antiretroviral therapy but sometimes misses doses. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Auscultation shows decreased breath sounds over the left base of the lung. There is dullness to percussion on the left lower part of the chest. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows a left-sided pleural effusion and hilar lymphadenopathy. B. Rheumatoid arthritis
C. Infective endocarditis
D. Congestive heart failure
E. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
F. Pulmonary embolism
G. Lung cancer
H. Pulmonary tuberculosis

Correct Answer: H

Question
An 86-year-old man with metastatic pancreatic cancer is admitted to the hospital for palliative care and pain management. He had provided advanced directives against life-sustaining measures including resuscitation and intubation. Three days after admission, a nurse caring for the patient calls the on-call physician and says, “The patient has just died. His family have been in his room since yesterday and were aware that he would die soon.” The physician obtains necessary information from the nurse, reviews the patient's records, informs the attending physician responsible for the patient's care, and enters the patient's room with the nurse. After a self-introduction to the family, which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician? When family members are present, performing death pronouncements in a step-wise, solemn, and ritualized manner can provide the family with closure and allow them to grieve.

A. "Could you please confirm the identity of the patient for me? I would like to examine him in order to finalize his medical records."
B. "I am sorry for your loss. I am here to examine your loved one and pronounce his death."
C. "I know what you are going through. How have you been coping with this situation so far?"
D. "I have been informed that you were expecting him to pass away soon. Do you have any questions for me at this time?"
E. "This must be very difficult for you. Could I ask you to step outside the room while I finish the examination?"

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of sudden, right-sided flank pain, nausea, and vomiting that started 4 hours ago. The pain radiates down to her groin. She has never had any similar episodes in the past. Two years ago, she had right upper quadrant abdominal pain and was diagnosed with acute cholecystitis, for which she underwent cholecystectomy. Question

She eats a balanced diet, and there are no associations between her symptoms and specific foods. Question
A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request? This patient wants to discontinue her participation in a human subjects research study. The investigator should follow the guidelines set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP).

A. Consult the institutional review board overseeing the trial
B. Unblind the participant by revealing which group she was in
C. Destroy all clinical and diagnostic data collected on the participant so far
D. Ask the participant if she is willing to undergo any follow-up evaluation
E. Offer remaining compensation for subsequent visits

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for a severe, sudden-onset generalized headache that began while she was riding an exercise bike at home that morning. After quickly getting off the bike and lying down, she lost consciousness. She was unconscious for a period of one minute. When she regained consciousness, she had neck stiffness, nausea, and two episodes of vomiting. She has hypertension. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include chlorthalidone and a multivitamin. She is in severe distress. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1F°), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 169/102 mm Hg. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows hyperdense material between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater. The patient is taken to the operating room for surgical clipping and transferred to the intensive care unit. Five days later, she has new-onset focal weakness of her left lower extremity. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left lower extremity and 5/5 in the right lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient’s current condition? B. Intravenous fresh frozen plasma
C. Intravenous sodium nitroprusside
D. Oral nimodipine
E. Oral aspirin and clopidogrel
F. Intravenous phenytoin

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness and weakness in her right hand for the past 4 weeks. Question

Question

Question
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her 17-year-old sister because of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 4 hours. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant; rebound and guarding are present. Bowel sounds are decreased. Ultrasonography shows an enlarged appendix with a thickened wall. The surgeon recommends an emergency appendectomy. The patient's parents are away and cannot be reached. She is afraid of undergoing surgery. Which of the following actions by the physician is most appropriate? 

A. Schedule hospital ethics consult
B. Perform emergency appendectomy
C. File for a court order for surgery
D. Obtain consent from the patient's sister
E. Obtain consent from the patient

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of a 1-year history of abnormal behavior. During this time she has been irritable, and restless, and has had multiple episodes of hearing voices. Over the past month, she has also had difficulty swallowing. She has a 2-year history of depression. She was let go by her employer 6 months ago because she could no longer handle all her tasks and often forgot about assignments. Her father died by suicide at the age of 50 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily over the past 20 years. She has a history of smoking cocaine for 8 years but stopped 1 year ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is confused and oriented to person and place only. Neurologic examination shows a delayed return to neutral ankle position after triggering the plantar reflex. A. Wilson disease
B. Sydenham chorea
C. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
D. Parkinson disease
E. Multiple sclerosis
F. Drug-induced chorea
G. Huntington disease

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity appears normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. B. Decreased sensation of the dorsum of thumb, index, and middle fingers
C. Decreased sensation of the lateral upper arm
D. Inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers
E. Decreased sensation of the lateral lower arm

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent yellowing of his eyes over the past 2 years. He reports that each episode lasts 1–2 weeks and resolves spontaneously. Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 27-year-old man comes to the physician 2 weeks after undergoing successful repair of a torn medial collateral ligament in his left knee. There were no complications. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's request? This patient has appropriately been prescribed opioids for a limited postoperative time, but he complains of persisting severe pain. Together with a history of illicit drug use and the patient's emotional demand for an oxycodone refill, this is concerning for substance use disorder.

B. Request further information about which drugs he has taken recently and in the past
C. Request consent for urine test to assess current drug use
D. Prescribe a short course of oxycodone and schedule a follow-up appointment in one week
E. Refer to a substance use counselor for addiction counseling

Question

Question

Question

B. Intrauterine pressure catheter placement

Question
A previously healthy 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She feels well. She emigrated from India 3 months ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 26/min. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A child from a country with endemic tuberculosis (TB) must be evaluated for TB infection. Note that IGRA is usually unaffected by prior BCG vaccines.

B. Perform acid-fast stain on induced sputum
C. Administer isoniazid and rifapentine
D. Reassurance and follow up
E. Perform tuberculin skin test
F. Administer rifampin, isoniazid, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide

Question
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 hours after ingesting approximately 40 tablets of aspirin. He is dizzy and nauseated but has not vomited. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 105/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Mental status examination shows confusion. He is oriented to person but not to time or place. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L and a chloride concentration of 103 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings? In the early phase of aspirin toxicity, patients develop respiratory alkalosis as a result of hyperventilation (due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center in the medulla by salicylate). In the late phase, which occurs several hours after ingestion, patients develop an additional high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) primarily because salicylate uncouples mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and increases the conversion of acetyl-CoA and pyruvate to ketoacids and lactate respectively.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E
F. F
G. G

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial swelling that started 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies show:A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? A. Splitting of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy
B. Mesangial proliferation on light microscopy
C. Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
D. Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence
E. Linear deposition of anti-GBM antibodies on immunofluorescence
F. Normal light microscopy findings
G. Granular subepithelial deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence
H. Apple-green birefringence with Congo red stain
. Effacement of foot processes of podocytes on light microscopy
. Segmental sclerosis on light microscopy

Correct Answer: F

Question

Question

Question

His father's vaccination records are unavailable. The patient's temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F). Examination shows no abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 42,000/mm3. Question
A 3-week-old female newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of bluish discoloration of the feet, poor feeding, excessive sweating, and irritability. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities and she was discharged two days later. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 168/min, and respirations are 66/min. Her blood pressure is 91/69 mm Hg in the right arm, 90/70 mm Hg in the left arm, 72/67 mm Hg in the right lower limb, and 70/68 mm Hg in the left lower limb. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98% in the right hand and 78% in the right foot. On examination, subcostal retractions are seen and the liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. D. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form
E. Anterosuperior displacement of the infundibular septum
F. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral

Correct Answer: C

Question

B. Overactive bladder
C. Interstitial cystitis
D. Urinary retention
E. Diabetes insipidus

Question
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of right forearm pain at the site of a honeybee sting. She was stung a few hours ago at tennis practice when she inadvertently picked up a ball with a honeybee on it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She has no allergies, takes no medications, and her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a stinger with the attached venom sac in her right forearm. There is an area of erythema and swelling of approximately 1 cm in diameter at the sting site that is tender to palpation. The physician scrapes off the stinger with a piece of gauze, washes the sting site with soap and water, and applies a cold compress. In addition to prescribing analgesics and asking the patient to keep the right forearm elevated, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with a small area (< 5 cm in diameter) of erythema and swelling around a Hymenoptera sting site, indicating an uncomplicated local reaction.

A. Perform allergic skin testing
B. Administer oral prednisone
C. No further management is indicated at this time
D. Admit the patient for observation
E. Administer epinephrine

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic rash. Initially, he noticed a set of small, red “bumps” in a linear pattern along his arm. Although these started to recede after a few days, he found another set of similar lesions in clusters on his back yesterday morning. The itching is worse at night. His roommates have also developed similar rashes since moving into their new apartment in San Francisco 2 weeks ago. There are no pets at home. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The pruritic, erythematous papules of this patient and his roommates are in linear series or clusters and arose shortly after moving into a new apartment, suggesting a bedbug infestation. Bedbug bites more commonly occur on unclothed locations (e.g., neck, face, hands, arms). Because these blood-feeding insects are nocturnal, affected individuals experience greater pruritus at night.

A. Prescribe oral doxycycline and schedule a follow-up visit
B. Ask the patient to consult a pest control service
C. Examine the patient's clothing seams and hair
D. Prescribe oral fexofenadine and schedule a follow-up visit
E. Prescribe topical permethrin for the patient and his roommates

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of clumsiness and difficulty walking. She began to walk at 12 months and continues to have difficulty standing still without support. She also appears to have difficulty grabbing objects in front of her. Over the past year, she has had 5 episodes of sinusitis requiring antibiotic treatment and was hospitalized twice for bacterial pneumonia. B. Conjunctival telangiectasias
C. Pes cavus
D. Cardiac rhabdomyoma
E. Celiac disease
F. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Question
A 25-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her mother because she refuses to get out of bed and spends most days crying or staring at the wall. Her symptoms started 3 months ago. The patient states that she is very sad most of the time and that none of the activities that used to interest her are interesting now. She sleeps more than 10 hours every night and naps during the day for several hours as well. Her mother, who cooks for her, says that she has been eating much larger portions than she did prior to the onset of her symptoms. The patient moved in with her mother after splitting up with her boyfriend and being expelled from her doctoral program at the local university, and she feels guilty for not being able to support herself. Two months ago, the patient was diagnosed with atypical depression and prescribed fluoxetine, which she has taken regularly since that time. Vital signs are within normal limits. E. Continue fluoxetine and add bupropion

G. Taper fluoxetine and switch to sertraline

Question

In the past year, she thought of looking for a job but never felt confident enough to start the process. Her mom arranges her doctor's appointments and handles her car maintenance. She describes feeling uneasy when she is alone. She has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. Question
A 71-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of worsening abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, propranolol, and apixaban. Examination shows a firm, tender mass in the left lower quadrant near the midline. The mass does not expand upon coughing. Active straight leg raise in the supine position increases pain and prominence of the mass but causes no change in the location of the mass. Palpation of the other abdominal quadrants shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings? Risk factors for this patient's condition include anticoagulant therapy, advanced age, and hypertension, all of which are seen here. C. Incarceration of bowel contents

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 71-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe, progressive left leg pain and tingling for 8 hours. The symptoms began while he was watching television. For several months, the patient has noticed calf cramping when going for long walks, as well as occasional foot tingling and numbness, but did not seek medical attention. He has no history of recent injuries. He has poorly controlled hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteoarthritis. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit 15 years ago. He drinks 3 beers every night. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, atorvastatin, metformin, and ibuprofen. He appears to be in severe pain and is clutching his left leg. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 163/94 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is a harsh 2/6 systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The left leg is cool to the touch with decreased popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses. There is 5/5 strength on left hip, knee, and ankle testing. The left hip, knee, and ankle show no effusion, erythema, or tenderness to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? Given this patient's history of multiple atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking) along with severe, acute pain, tingling, coolness, and decreased pulses in the leg, he most likely has acute limb ischemia (ALI) as a result of arterial thrombosis. The classic presentation of this condition includes the 6 Ps: pain, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis, paresthesia, and poikilothermia.

A. Creatine kinase concentration
B. O2 saturation of a leg artery
C. Digital subtraction angiography
D. Fibrin degradation products
E. Ankle-brachial index
F. Compartment pressures

Correct Answer: C

Question

She is 188 cm (6 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 158/89 mm Hg. This step is usually performed every 3–5 years in healthy people aged 18–39 years and every year in adults aged ≥ 40 years and those at increased risk.

D. Prescribe a thiazide diuretic

Question
An 18-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy and well-nourished. The uterus is palpated up to the level of the umbilicus. Laboratory studies show a maternal serum α-fetoprotein concentration of 640 ng/ml (N = 10–150). Ultrasonography shows a defect in the fetal abdominal wall to the right of the umbilical cord. A part of the fetus's bowels herniates through the abdominal defect and is suspended freely in the amniotic fluid. Which of the following extraintestinal structural abnormalities is most likely to be found on further evaluation of the fetus? This fetus has gastroschisis, a condition in which the intestines herniate freely through an abdominal defect in the paraumbilical area. By contrast, omphalocele is a condition in which the intestines protrude at the midline through the navel but are contained in a hernia sac. Both abdominal wall defects are associated with an elevated 2nd-trimester maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) concentration.

A. Brachycephaly
B. Spina bifida
C. No extraintestinal structural abnormalities are expected
D. Bladder exstrophy
E. Organomegaly
F. Ventricular septal defect

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and confusion. He has been treated twice in the past year for acute pancreatitis. He emigrated from India 15 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is a calcium supplement. D. Bacterial translocation

Question

Apart from a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics, he reports no other personal or family history of serious illness. He works as an assistant at a veterinarian clinic. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count within the reference range. An MRI of the brain is shown. Intravenous mannitol and levetiracetam are administered. Question

These shaking episodes have occurred about six times over the last hour and have lasted for about 40 seconds. He has also had rapid breathing and poor feeding. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of serious illness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? Calcium homeostasis is influenced by a delicate interplay of hormones (e.g., PTH, Vitamin D) and electrolytes (e.g., Ca2+, Mg2+). During pregnancy, the fetus' metabolic balance largely depends on regulatory processes in the mother's body. When these maternal regulatory processes cease after birth, the newborn may experience rebound symptoms (as seen with neonatal hypoglycemia in response to maternal diabetes).

B. Defective fetal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches
C. Neonatal ingestion of formula with high phosphate load
D. Neonatal hypoglycemia
E. Increased neonatal thyroid hormone secretion
F. Maternal opioid use during pregnancy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of irritability and vomiting for 2 hours. During this period, he has vomited bilious fluid three times. He has not yet passed stool. The mother has breastfed the newborn every 2 hours. He has wet two diapers during the last 2 days. He was born at term and was delivered at home. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care during pregnancy. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) and is 50 cm (19.6 in) in length. The newborn appears restless. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.14°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 60/45 mm Hg. There is no redness or warmth around the umbilical cord stump. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are sparse. The abdomen is distended. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. A nasogastric tube is placed and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? This newborn presents with bilious vomiting, a distended abdomen, and sparse bowel sounds, all of which are consistent with bowel obstruction. The findings of dilated small bowel loops on abdominal x-ray and a microcolon indicate meconium ileus as the cause for obstruction and explains why he has not yet passed stool.

B. Gastrografin enema
C. Exploratory laparotomy
D. Rectal suction biopsy
E. Colonoscopy
F. CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of burn injuries that she sustained after stumbling into a bonfire 1 hour ago. The patient has severe pain in her left leg and torso, and minimal pain in her right arm. She does not smoke cigarettes. She takes no medications. She is tearful and in moderate distress. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Her pulse oximetry is 98% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There are two tender, blanchable erythemas without blisters over a 5 x 6-cm area of the left abdomen and a 3 x 2-cm area of the left anterior thigh. There is also an area of white, leathery skin and tissue necrosis encircling the right upper extremity just proximal to the elbow, which is dry and nontender. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no ST or T wave changes. Administration of intravenous fluids is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has a 3rd degree (full-thickness) circumferential burn on her right upper extremity, as indicated by the encircling white, leathery skin and necrosis without feeling. Such burns may lead to distal ischemia and compartment syndrome.

A. Serial arterial blood gas analysis
B. Soft-tissue ultrasound
C. Intravenous ampicillin therapy
D. Monitoring of peripheral pulses and capillary filling
E. X-ray of the chest

Correct Answer: D

Question
Three hours later, the patient is reassessed. Her right arm is put in an elevated position and a physical examination of the extremity is performed. The examination reveals reduced capillary return and peripheral pallor. Pulse oximetry of her right index finger on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 84%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's circumferential burn can cut off blood supply to the extremity.

A. Perform fasciotomy
B. Perform right upper extremity amputation
C. Obtain split-thickness skin graft
D. Decrease rate of IV fluids
E. Perform escharotomy

Correct Answer: E

Question

She has had occasional streaks of blood in her stools during periods of constipation. She was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus at the age of 24 years and has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her current medications include insulin, lisinopril, aspirin, and atorvastatin. Her diet mostly consists of white meat and vegetables. Her pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Sensation to pinprick is decreased bilaterally over the dorsum of her feet. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A fecal occult blood test is pending. C. Increased hepcidin production

Question

She says that since the divorce 3 years ago, her ex-husband has been seeking revenge and thinks that he has installed cameras in her apartment to spy on her and their son. She has never seen any of these cameras but when she is alone in the apartment, she can sometimes hear them beeping and feel them recording her. He agrees with the mother's distrust towards his father and reports that he has also occasionally heard a camera beeping but has not been able to find any cameras yet. Question

Question

B. Breastfeeding only

Question

Question

His pulse is 135/min, and blood pressure is 76/55 mm Hg. His hemoglobin concentration is 5.9 g/dL. His son sustained multiple body contusions and loss of consciousness. He remains unresponsive in the emergency department. A focused assessment of the boy with sonography is concerning for multiple organ lacerations and internal bleeding. The physician decides to move the man's son to the operating room for emergency surgical exploration. The father says that he and his son are Jehovah's witnesses and do not want blood transfusions. The physician calls the boy's biological mother who confirms this religious belief. She also asks the physician to wait for her arrival before any other medical decisions are undertaken. B. Transfuse packed red blood cells to son but not to father
C. Seek court order for medical treatment of the son
D. Transfuse packed red blood cells to both son and father
E. Wait for the son's mother before providing further treatment
F. Proceed to surgery of the son without transfusion

Question
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of progressively worsening pain and itching in both breasts. She describes the pain as “stabbing” and reports that it begins in her nipples, radiates to the chest, and is worsened by breastfeeding. Fifteen days ago, she gave birth to a healthy 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn at term via vaginal delivery. She did not receive regular antenatal care and delivery was uncomplicated. Vital signs for mother and child are normal. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for length and 45th percentile for weight. Examination of the breasts shows mild flaking around the nipple-areolar complex without erythema, fissuring, or tenderness. Examination of the newborn shows a white coating on the tongue that is easily scraped off. In both the mother and newborn, the remainder of the examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In a newborn, white oral lesions that can be scraped off suggest neonatal oral thrush. This feature together with stabbing breast pain that is more severe than would be expected from examination findings and worsens with breastfeeding is characteristic of mammary candidiasis.

A. Systemic antifungal therapy for the mother along with formula feeding until the newborn's oral lesions resolve
B. Systemic antifungal therapy for mother and newborn along with continued breastfeeding
C. Topical antifungal therapy for mother and newborn along with continued breastfeeding
D. Topical antifungal therapy for the newborn along with formula feeding until the results of HIV testing and breast milk culture are obtained

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 69-year-old woman is hospitalized for the treatment of pneumonia by the end of the inpatient staff's morning shift after a routine admission procedure. She has hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include simvastatin and insulin. The physician covering the morning shift orders antibiotics and the patient's current medications, all of which are prepared in the hospital pharmacy as ready-to-use single doses in medication dispensers with barcode stickers. After receiving a standardized handoff in a designated distraction-free zone from the team covering the morning shift, the nurse covering the subsequent shift enters the patient's room with a workstation on wheels and the patient's medication dispensers. He introduces himself to the patient. The patient introduces herself with her surname and starts to converse with the nurse. During the conversation, the nurse notices that the patient's issued armband with a patient barcode and identification number is by the bedside on the nightstand. In addition to verifying the type, route, timing, and dose of the medications, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the nurse before administering the medications? To prevent patient identification errors, the Joint Commission recommends using two patient identifiers prior to any medical intervention.

A. Scan the barcodes on the patient's armband and the medication dispensers
B. Ask the patient to state her full name and date of birth
C. Request that the patient name and visually identify her chronic disease medications
D. Check the patient's room number and patient identification number against the inpatient ward logs
E. Telephone the nurse who covered the previous shift

Correct Answer: B

Question

B. Short stature
C. Infertility
D. Genu varum
E. Osteoporosis
F. Coarse facial features

Question
A 57-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 6-hour history of persistent vertigo and nausea. She has been unable to walk due to dizziness and has vomited once since this morning. She has no history of similar symptoms and no recent trauma. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and drinks one to two glasses of wine on weekends. Medications are lisinopril, metformin, and simvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. She is alert and fully oriented. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 132/87 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows normal strength and sensation in all extremities. Reflexes are 2+ throughout. She sways towards the right side when asked to stand upright with her feet together. She is able to fixate her eyes on a stable point while her head is rotated. There is vertical nystagmus that persists on gaze fixation of the right eye. Otoscopic examination shows normal tympanic membranes bilaterally. She is able to hear fingers rubbing next to her ears and to repeat words whispered in her ears bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The combination of acute nausea, imbalance, and vertigo is concerning for acute vestibular syndrome (AVS). The Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew (HINTS) exam is used to differentiate between central and peripheral causes of AVS. This patient's negative head impulse test and vertical nystagmus are consistent with a central cause of AVS.

A. Audiometry
B. MRI of the brain
C. Dix-Hallpike maneuver
D. Caloric testing
E. Lumbar puncture

Correct Answer: B

Question
 to either tDCS or sham tDCS over the temporoparietal cortex. Both procedures were conducted so that patients experienced the same sensations while receiving treatment. Question
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to the left chest. On arrival, he has rapid, shallow breathing and appears anxious. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg. Examination shows no active external bleeding. There is a 2.5-cm single stab wound to the left chest at the 4th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Cardiovascular examination shows muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention. B. A drop in systolic blood pressure of 14 mm Hg during inspiration
C. Herniation of the stomach into the chest
D. Subcutaneous emphysema
E. Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing

Question

Question
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of difficulty swallowing solids and liquids. He points to the middle of his sternum, saying “I feel like food is getting stuck there.” He has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months and reports that his symptoms have progressively worsened over the same period. He also reports intermittent heartburn that is worse after drinking coffee. Treatment with over-the-counter pantoprazole has been ineffective. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He underwent a cholecystectomy for cholecystitis 10 years ago and partial bowel resection for complicated sigmoid diverticulitis 5 years ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/85 mm Hg. C. Fibrosis of esophageal smooth muscle
D. Outpouching of the upper esophageal wall
Eosinophilic inflammation of the esophagus
Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 60-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of severe, retrosternal chest pain. She also has pain when swallowing solid food and medications. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, poorly-controlled asthma, and osteoporosis. She was recently admitted to the hospital for an acute asthma exacerbation that was treated with bronchodilators and a 7-day course of oral corticosteroids. Her current medications include aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, insulin, beclomethasone and albuterol inhalers, and alendronate. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the oral pharynx appears normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. An upper endoscopy shows a single punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa at the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsies of the ulcer are taken. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has medication-induced esophagitis, a condition that typically manifests with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia as seen in this case. Dysphagia is another common manifestation. The characteristic finding on upper endoscopy is a punched-out ulcer with normal surrounding mucosa, often located at a site of anatomic narrowing (e.g., the gastroesophageal junction).

A. Start ganciclovir
B. Discontinue alendronate
C. Start nystatin
D. Start pantoprazole
E. Discontinue amlodipine
F. Start fluconazole

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

B. B

Question
A clinical trial is conducted to determine the efficacy of ginkgo biloba in the treatment of Parkinson disease. A sample of patients with Parkinson disease is divided into two groups. Participants in the first group are treated with ginkgo biloba, and participants in the other group receive a placebo. A change in the Movement Disorder Society-Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) score is used as the primary endpoint for the study. The investigators, participants, and data analysts were meant to be blinded throughout the trial. However, while the trial is being conducted, a technical flaw discloses the participants' demographics and their allocated groups to the investigators, but not to the participants themselves or the data analysts. The study concludes that there is a significant decrease in MDS-UPDRS scores in patients treated with ginkgo biloba. Which of the following is most likely to have affected the validity of this study? The trial was designed as a triple-blind study. The technical flaw in this scenario causes unblinding of the investigators and introduces a specific bias.

A. Recall bias
B. Pygmalion effect
C. Hawthorne effect
D. Effect modification
E. Procedure bias
F. Ascertainment bias

Correct Answer: B

Question
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a high fever, progressive shortness of breath, and a cough productive of moderate amounts of yellow sputum for the past 2 days. He had meconium ileus as a newborn and was subsequently diagnosed with cystic fibrosis during routine neonatal screening. Since then, he has had recurrent respiratory infections that have required hospitalization. Current medications include albuterol, pancreatic enzymes, and vitamin A and vitamin D3 supplements. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 44/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows labored breathing and subcostal retractions. There is dullness to percussion of the right upper lung; breath sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the chest shows consolidation in the right upper lobe of the lung; there is increased translucency and tram-track opacities in the upper lung fields. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms? This patient's history (e.g., fever, dyspnea, and productive cough) and examination findings (e.g., hypoxia, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion) in combination with a consolidation of the right upper lobe in his chest x-ray are consistent with pneumonia. The most likely causative pathogen is the most common cause of pulmonary infections in infants and children with cystic fibrosis (CF).

B. Burkholderia cepacia complex
C. Streptococcus pneumoniae
D. Aspergillus fumigatus
E. Streptococcus agalactiae
F. Staphylococcus aureus
G. Haemophilus influenzae
H. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Correct Answer: F

Question

B. Immunoglobulin administration

Question
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his brother after losing consciousness 1 hour ago. The brother reports that the patient was skateboarding outside when he fell on the ground and started to have generalized contractions. There was also some blood coming from his mouth. The contractions stopped after about 1 minute, but he remained unconscious for a few minutes afterward. He has never had a similar episode before. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He does not use illicit drugs. He takes no medications. On arrival, he is confused and oriented only to person and place. He cannot recall what happened and reports diffuse muscle ache, headache, and fatigue. He appears pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. There is a small wound on the left side of the tongue. Correct Answer: F

Question
Ten minutes after starting bag-mask ventilation, the patient's respiratory distress worsens. The otolaryngologist who has been called prepares for fiberoptic endotracheal intubation. Visualization of the posterior pharynx shows a swollen, red epiglottis. An anesthesiologist attempts endotracheal intubation using a fiberoptic guide and is unable to place the tube during the first attempt. The patient's respirations are 31/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 77%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient is in worsening respiratory distress despite bag-mask ventilation and needs prompt intervention.

A. Continue bag-mask ventilation and move to intensive care unit
B. Perform tracheostomy
C. Reattempt fiberoptic endotracheal intubation
D. Perform surgical cricothyroidotomy
E. Place a laryngeal mask

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with locally advanced cancer of the left breast. She has a history of mild hypertension. At the previous visit, she was informed of the diagnosis and the possible complications of her condition. The physician recommends mastectomy and initiates a conversation about the procedure. When trying to inform the patient about possible complications from the procedure, the patient interrupts the physician and says, “Doctor, I am aware of the severity of my situation, and I want to continue with surgery. Please don't tell me how things can go wrong or if I will need chemotherapy in the future. I know that things can go wrong during surgery, but I am already anxious, and all the information will overwhelm me.” Which of the following answer options most accurately describes the correct course of action for the physician in this case? The procedure cannot be performed because the patient currently lacks decision-making capacity.2%

The procedure cannot be performed because the patient lacks competence.1%

The procedure can be performed because therapeutic privilege has been invoked.20%

Correct Answer: A

Question

Two years ago, he was diagnosed with Paget disease of bone during a routine health maintenance examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition? There is mild tenderness to palpation of the left upper quadrant with no guarding or rebound. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. There is no redness or swelling of the joints. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This previously healthy child presents with high fever, arthralgia, a new-onset murmur, and splenomegaly. In combination with leukocytosis, an elevated ESR, and signs of glomerulonephritis (elevated creatinine, RBCs, and mild proteinuria on urinalysis), these findings suggest acute infective endocarditis (IE).

A. Administer intravenous vancomycin
B. Measure antinuclear antibodies
C. Measure rheumatoid factor
D. Obtain three sets of blood cultures
E. Obtain a transesophageal echocardiography
F. Obtain a renal biopsy

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? In children aged between 2 and 24 months, a test to identify vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is indicated if any of the following are present: a previously confirmed urinary tract infection (UTI), slow response to antibiotic therapy (> 48 hours), poor urine flow, flank or suprapubic mass, organisms other than Escherichia coli on urine culture, increased creatinine levels, ultrasonographic evidence of hydronephrosis, ureteric dilation, or renal scarring.

B. Intravenous pyelography
C. Dynamic renal scintigraphy
D. Urodynamic testing

F. Voiding cystourethrography

Question

She works as a sales manager at a pharmaceutical company; she has been under a lot of stress lately and has been sleeping poorly. She reports that she “just wanted to blow off some steam”. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 127/71 mm Hg. This patient initially presented with palpitations, an irregularly irregular pulse, and absent P waves on ECG, which is consistent with new-onset atrial fibrillation (Afib). B. Prescribe oral apixaban
C. Begin oral metoprolol therapy

Question

Question
A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of weakness in her right arm, leg, and face. Her husband says that she was finishing her breakfast when suddenly her right leg and arm “stopped working properly.” She tried to talk to him but her speech was incoherent. For the past 4 months, she has been more anxious than usual and experienced dizziness on several occasions. She used to exercise regularly but had to give up her exercise routine 3 months ago because of generalized fatigue, and lightheadedness and shortness of breath with exertion. She has a history of hypertension. She takes lisinopril daily and alprazolam as needed. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is a tax accountant and has had increased stress at work recently. On presentation, she is alert and fully oriented; her speech is normal. The patient's pants are soaked with urine. On neurologic examination, she has a slight right facial droop and 4/5 muscle strength in the right arm and leg. Sensation is slightly diminished over the right side of the face and right arm and leg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following? Right-sided weakness and numbness in the upper and lower limbs, urinary incontinence, and aphasia (incoherent speech) suggest stroke affecting several different vascular territories: the left anterior cerebral artery and left middle cerebral artery. These features in combination with rapid clinical improvement after symptom onset suggest a specific etiology of stroke, which is further supported by the history of fatigue, exertional dyspnea, and lightheadedness.

A. Irregularly irregular R-R intervals on electrocardiogram
B. Ruptured saccular aneurysm on CT angiography of the head
C. Valvular vegetations on transthoracic echocardiography
D. Double lumen of the left-sided carotid artery on duplex ultrasound
E. Intraparenchymal hyperdensity on CT scan of the head

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a drowning incident at the swimming pool. He dove into the water, hit his head against the bottom of the pool, and lost consciousness. He was pulled out of the water shortly after the incident and took approximately 2 minutes to regain consciousness. On arrival, he is conscious and responsive. His temperature is 36.8ºC (98.2ºF), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 124/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. CT scan of the head and x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Six hours later, he is short of breath and confused. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen at 15 L/min via nonrebreather mask shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates with air bronchograms. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated with a FiO2 of 0.9, a PEEP of 8 cm H2O, a tidal volume of 408 mL (6 mL/kg), and a respiratory rate of 20/min. The next day, arterial blood gas analysis shows:With the current mechanical ventilation settings, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following? This patient has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), as evidenced by acute onset respiratory failure after a noncardiac inciting event, bilateral opacities on chest x-ray, and evidence of hypoxemia (PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300 mm Hg). To avoid complications, the FiO2 must be kept as low as possible.

B. Cicatrization atelectasis
C. Respiratory alkalosis
D. Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
E. Oxygen toxicity

Correct Answer: E

Question
A previously healthy 2-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. D. Persistent pulmonary hypertension

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician for a 3-month history of fatigue. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had a transient ischemic attack 3 years ago. He drinks 3 beers a day, and sometimes a couple more on social occasions. He currently takes aspirin, simvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and metoprolol. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. He is in no apparent distress. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and multiple pinpoint, red, nonblanching spots on his extremities. On abdominal examination, his spleen is significantly enlarged. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 8.0 g/dL, leukocyte count of 80,000/mm3, and platelet count of 34,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows immature cells with large, prominent nucleoli and elongated, needle-shaped cytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Constitutional symptoms (e.g., fatigue), leukocytosis with features of bone marrow failure (e.g., petechiae due to thrombocytopenia, pallor due to anemia), and splenomegaly are nonspecific features of most hematological malignancies but the characteristic cytoplasmic inclusions, which are also known as Auer rods, are pathognomonic for this disease.

A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
B. Chronic myelogenous leukemia
C. Myelodysplastic syndrome
D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
E. Acute myelogenous leukemia

Correct Answer: E

Question

B. Giant cell myocarditis
C. Borrelia burgdorferi infection

E. Respiratory syncytial virus infection
F. Rhinovirus infection

Question

She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, asthma, and atrial fibrillation. She has smoked 1.5 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. C. Laser photocoagulation of the retina
D. Administration of topical latanoprost

Question

He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and gastroesophageal reflux disease. His medications are metformin and omeprazole. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Question

Question
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.Data on the incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions was collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.Table - Association of major depression, ADHD, bipolar disorder, and psychotic disorder at 20-year follow-up of participants who received afterschool enrichment during childhood*.*Adjusted for income and family history of psychiatric illness.This study highlights the potential of high-quality afterschool programming during childhood in promoting long-term adult mental health.Source of funding: Wisconsin Children's Mental Health Foundation, National Early Childhood Education CoalitionPlease refer to the summary above to answer this questionAn 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination at a clinic for low-income residents. Although her son's elementary school offers free afterschool programming, her son has not been interested in attending. Both the son's maternal and paternal grandmothers have major depressive disorder. The mother is enquiring about the benefits of afterschool programming and asks for the physician's input. Based on the study results, which of the following statements best addresses the mother's question? The abstract describes a prospective cohort study. Results from this type of study are not generalizable to an individual, only to a population. With this in mind, take a look at the hazard ratios and p-values in the table and try to identify which of these statements is correct.High-quality afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing ADHD risk in adults than major depressive disorder risk.3%
The patient's family history of psychiatric illness prevents any conclusions from being drawn from the study.4%
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with a decreased bipolar disorder risk in adults.2%
High-quality afterschool programming would decrease this patient's risk of developing major depressive disorder.35%
High-quality afterschool programming should be free of charge for low-income children to improve adult mental health.1%
High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds may correlate with decreased ADHD risk in adults.55%

Correct Answer: F

Question
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.Data on incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions were collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.Table - Association of major depression, ADHD, bipolar disorder, and psychotic disorder at 20-year follow-up of participants who received afterschool enrichment during childhood*.*Adjusted for income and family history of psychiatric illness.This study highlights the potential of high-quality afterschool programming during childhood in promoting long-term adult mental health.Source of funding: Wisconsin Children's Mental Health Foundation, National Early Childhood Education CoalitionPlease refer to the summary above to answer this questionThe APPLE study investigators are currently preparing for a 30-year follow-up evaluation. They are curious about the number of participants who will partake in follow-up interviews. The investigators noted that of the 83 participants who participated in APPLE study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group. This finding raises concerns for which of the following? Longitudinal studies with a large number of participants lost to follow-up are prone to this type of selection bias.

A. Volunteer bias
B. Lead-time bias
C. Error in randomization
D. Allocation bias
E. Attrition bias
F. Inadequate sample size
G. Reporting bias

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after losing control of his bicycle and colliding with a parked car. He was thrown over the handlebars and hit the ground. He reports that he was wearing a helmet and that he did not lose consciousness. He has mild pain in his legs and on his right side but says that he feels well otherwise. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There are a few bruises over his right chest, flank, and lower extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is tenderness to palpation over the right thorax. There is no pelvic instability. The external genitalia appear normal. Complete blood count, prothrombin time, and serum concentrations of glucose, creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. A voided urine specimen is clear. Microscopic examination of the urine shows 85 RBCs/hpf. A focused assessment with sonography for trauma shows no free intraabdominal fluid. C. Exploratory laparotomy
D. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
E. Retrograde urethrocystography
F. Observation and follow-up

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath, abdominal discomfort, and swelling of his legs. He does not have fever, chills, or chest pain. Auscultation of the lungs shows diffuse expiratory wheezes. The liver edge is palpated 3–4 cm below the right costal margin. An abdominal fluid wave is present. B. Chronic malnutrition
C. Chronic pulmonary hypertension
D. Chronic kidney disease
E. Chronic liver disease

Question

Question

Question
Many large clinics have noticed that the prevalence of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) has increased significantly over the past 20 years. An epidemiologist is working to identify possible reasons for this. After analyzing a series of nationwide health surveillance databases, the epidemiologist finds that the incidence of PBC has remained stable over the past 20 years. Which of the following is the most plausible explanation for the increased prevalence of PBC? The increased prevalence of PBC is unlikely to be attributable to increased incidence of PBC, given the stable number of new PBC cases over the past 20 years. More people are being documented as having PBC, while the number of new cases has remained the same.

A. Increased exposure to environmental risk factors for PBC
B. Improved quality of care for PBC
C. Increased availability of diagnostic testing for PBC
D. Increased average age of the population at risk for PBC
E. Increased awareness of PBC among clinicians

Correct Answer: B

Question
Three weeks after birth, a newborn girl develops episodes of respiratory arrest. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past two days and today experienced two episodes in which she stopped breathing for 10 seconds. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1600 g (3 lb 8 oz). Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 60/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. She appears pale. Physical examination shows pallor of the mucous membranes and no other abnormalities. Hemoglobin is 6.5 g/dL, reticulocyte count is 0.5%, and mean corpuscular volume is 92 μm3. Leukocyte count, platelet count, total bilirubin, and indirect bilirubin are all within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's anemia? This patient presents with severe anemia and episodes of apnea, which are most likely caused by poor tissue oxygenation. Her condition manifests in premature infants typically at the age of 3–12 weeks.

A. Impaired synthesis of hemoglobin β-chain
B. Defective δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase
C. Bone marrow suppression
D. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
E. Iron deficiency
F. Impaired erythropoietin production

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening back pain over the past month. He says that the pain is worse at night and exacerbated by movement. He has no bowel or bladder symptoms. Two months ago, he was admitted to the hospital for bullous pemphigoid and treated with intravenous methylprednisolone. During his treatment, he developed septic thrombophlebitis of the left cubital fossa. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His current medications are insulin and ramipril. B. Ankylosing spondylitis
C. Spinal epidural abscess
D. Metastatic prostate cancer
E. Vertebral osteomyelitis
F. Spinal osteoarthritis
G. Vertebral compression fracture

Question

Question

After 5 minutes, he continues having jerky movements and is unresponsive to verbal and painful stimuli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Tonic-clonic movements and unconsciousness for > 5 minutes indicate status epilepticus, which is a medical emergency! Question

Question

Cardiac examination shows a regular heartbeat and a systolic ejection murmur heard best over the upper right sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Pedal pulses are intact. An ECG shows inverted T waves in leads I, avL, and V5–6. Urine toxicology screening is positive for cocaine. Question
A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of heavy bleeding with menses that often requires her to change her sanitary pads every 6 hours. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals. She has had no pelvic cramping, intermittent bleeding, changes in bowel habits, or abnormal vaginal discharge. A Pap smear 1 year ago showed no abnormalities. Medical history is unremarkable. She has been in a monogamous relationship with her girlfriend for 3 years and attends a local college. Her immunizations are up-to-date. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Numerous petechiae are seen on bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:A blood smear shows a low number of circulating platelets of normal size and morphology. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's history of menorrhagia and petechiae in combination with thrombocytopenia and a normal coagulation profile suggests immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). B. Corticosteroid therapy
C. Endometrial biopsy
D. Plasma exchange therapy
E. Oral contraceptives
F. Close observation only

Question
A 52-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for treatment of a meningioma located in the posterior fossa. During surgery, the anesthesiologist notices a sudden fall in end-tidal carbon dioxide. Pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 88%. Examination shows jugular venous distension, and a churning sound in the precordial region is heard throughout the cardiac cycle. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally and there are occasional diffuse wheezes. In addition to high-flow oxygen and intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A churning sound in the precordial region (also known as the mill-wheel murmur) is consistent with air in the heart chambers. This finding is characteristic of venous air embolism. Other common features of this condition include sudden hypotension, tachycardia, jugular vein distension, signs of respiratory distress, and, in patients who are being mechanically ventilated, a sudden fall in end-tidal carbon dioxide.

A. Place the patient in the left lateral decubitus position
B. Administer blood products
C. Administer unfractionated heparin
D. Administer epinephrine and high-dose corticosteroids
E. Perform a coronary angiography

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent reddening of the face for the past 3 months. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. He has hypertension and asthma. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 28 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage per day. Question

Question
A mother brings her 3-year-old son to his pediatrician because he is having tantrums. The boy has no history of serious illness and is on track with developmental milestones. His mother recently returned to work 2 weeks ago. She explains that, since then, her son has had a tantrum roughly every other morning, usually when she is getting him dressed or dropping him off at daycare. He cries loudly for about 5 minutes, saying that he does not want to go to daycare while thrashing his arms and legs. According to the daycare staff, he is well-behaved during the day. In the evenings, he has tantrums about twice per week, typically when he is told he must finish his dinner or that it is time for bed. These tantrums have been occurring for about 6 months. The mother is concerned her son may have a behavioral disorder. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the boy's behavior? A. Autism spectrum disorder
B. Conduct disorder
C. Normal development
D. Oppositional defiant disorder
E. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
F. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
