Question
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of skin lesions on his lower extremities. The patient also states that he has been feeling more tired than usual and feels that his right hand has been getting progressively numb and weak. He does not have abdominal pain, cough, or shortness of breath. He has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. He was incarcerated for 10 years and got out of jail last year; he has been homeless since then. He has a history of intravenous drug use, but he has not used illicit drugs for the past 5 years. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. His temperature is 38.1ºC (100.6ºF), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 148/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows palpable purpura on his lower extremities. Muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and sensations are decreased in his right upper extremity. Distal extremity pulses are present bilaterally and there is no pedal edema. Chest auscultation shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Transient elastography shows mild hepatic fibrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the treatment of this patient? A history of palpable purpura, increased fatigue, progressive sensorimotor neuropathy, mildly decreased C3 levels, and nearly undetectable C4 levels in a patient with hepatitis C (hepatitis C antibody and HCV RNA positive) is suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia. In HCV-associated mixed cryoglobulinemia, the severity of the disease (i.e., mild, severe, or life-threatening) determines the initial management. This patient presents with findings of glomerulonephritis (e.g., elevated creatinine) and progressive peripheral neuropathy (e.g., decreased muscle strength, deep tendon reflexes, and sensations in the upper extremity), which indicate a severe course of the disease.

A. Immunosuppressive therapy
B. Direct-acting antiviral therapy
C. Interferon therapy
D. Intravenous immune globulin therapy
E. Plasma exchange therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent painful double vision for the past 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and horizontal nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and horizontal nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy shows bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings? Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye (i.e., dissociated nystagmus) on lateral horizontal gaze should raise concern for internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), in which convergence is usually preserved. This patient's findings are consistent with bilateral INO. In addition, painful eye movements and hyperemia of the optic discs suggest optic neuritis.

A. Caudal displacement of cerebellar vermis
B. Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
C. Antibodies against acetylcholine receptors
D. Compressive tumor of the pons
E. Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency
F. Subdural hematoma extending into the orbit
G. Infarction of the brainstem

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided back pain for the last hour. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Question
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because she is seeing things that she knows are not there. Sometimes she sees a dog in her kitchen and at other times she sees a stranger in her garden, both of which no one else can see. She also reports a lack of motivation to do daily tasks for the past week. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with Parkinson disease and was started on levodopa and carbidopa. Her younger brother has schizophrenia. The patient also takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to drink a bottle of wine every day, but she stopped drinking alcohol 2 months ago. A. Adverse effect of medication
B. Alcohol withdrawal
C. Schizophrenia
D. Major depressive disorder
E. Poorly controlled hypothyroidism

Question
A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of irritability and poor feeding that began 2 days ago. His mother reports that he has been crying more than usual during this period. He refused to eat his breakfast that morning and has not taken in any food or water since that time. He has not vomited. When changing the boy's diapers this morning, the mother noticed his urine had a strong smell and pink color. He has not passed urine since then. He was born at term and has been healthy. He appears ill. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 116/min, and blood pressure is 98/54 mm Hg. The boy cries when the lower abdomen is palpated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This boy presents with irritability, poor feeding, strong-smelling urine, signs of hematuria, and lower abdominal pain, all of which are suggestive of a urinary tract infection (UTI).

A. Perform renal ultrasound
B. Perform voiding cystourethrogram
C. Obtain clean-catch urine sample
D. Perform transurethral catheterization
E. Administer cefixime

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion over the past 2 hours. She has had fever, productive cough, fatigue, and malaise for the past 2 days. She has not seen a physician in approximately 3 years. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 133/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 86/48 mm Hg. Mucous membranes are dry. Pulmonary examination shows subcostal retractions and coarse crackles bilaterally. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.4 g/dL and her leukocyte count is 16,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear shows sickled red blood cells. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition? This patient, who has sickle cell disease (SCD), has developed altered mental status, fever, hypotension, and leukocytosis; these features are concerning for a diagnosis of sepsis. The sepsis in this patient is most likely secondary to pneumonia, which caused her productive cough, tachypnea, and coarse crackles. Patients with SCD have an increased risk of infection by encapsulated pathogens.

A. Salmonella paratyphi
B. Streptococcus pneumoniae
C. Neisseria meningitidis
D. Staphylococcus aureus
E. Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fever and a cough productive of a moderate amount of yellowish sputum. He has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss during this period. He emigrated from the Middle East around 2 years ago. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 54 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 18 years. His only medication is a daily multivitamin. He appears malnourished. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:Urinalysis is within normal limits. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's symptoms (productive cough, systemic symptoms), in addition to a history of immigration from a country with a high burden of tuberculosis (TB) and the patient's findings on chest x-ray (apical cavernous lesion and fibrosis, patchy infiltrates in upper lung fields) raise suspicion for reactivation TB.

A. Perform a high-resolution CT scan of the chest
B. Start treatment with oral levofloxacin
C. Collect sputum specimens for acid-fast bacilli smear microscopy, culture, and nucleic acid amplification
D. Perform transbronchial lung biopsy of the suspected lesion
E. Start treatment with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol
F. Perform an interferon-gamma release assay

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of frequent urination for the past 2 months. He has been urinating 10–12 times during the day and 3–4 times during the night. He says he is drinking a lot of water to compensate for any dehydration. He is concerned he may have diabetes mellitus like his parents. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A water deprivation test is conducted. After 2 hours of fluid restriction, his plasma osmolality is 315 mOsmol/kg H2O and his urine osmolality is 210 mOsmol/kg H2O. One hour after an ADH analog injection, his plasma osmolality is 276 mOsmol/kg H2O and his urine osmolality is 425 mOsmol/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has mild hypernatremia, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Administration of an ADH analog increases urine osmolality and causes plasma osmolality to normalize. This combination of findings is highly suggestive of central diabetes insipidus (DI).

A. Demeclocycline therapy
B. Desmopressin therapy
C. Hydrochlorothiazide therapy
D. Tolvaptan therapy
E. Amiloride therapy
F. Fluid restriction

Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 5 hours after the onset of abdominal pain and nausea. Over the past 2 weeks, he has also had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss. The mother reports that her son has been drinking more water than usual during this period. Last week he wet his bed three times despite being completely toilet-trained since 3 years of age. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 95/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows deep and labored breathing and dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Serum studies show:Urine dipstick is positive for ketones and glucose. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? Type 1 diabetes mellitus should always be suspected in the classic presentation of weight loss, lethargy, polydipsia, polyuria (and resulting secondary nocturnal enuresis), and glucosuria in a child. Additional signs of acute abdominal pain, nausea, Kussmaul breathing (deep and labored breathing), dehydration (dry mucous membranes), hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and ketonuria all indicate life-threatening diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

A. Decreased total body potassium
B. Increased arterial blood pH
C. Increased total body sodium
D. Increased arterial pCO
E. Hypervolemia
F. Serum glucose concentration of 650 mg/dL

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 46-year-old man comes to the office because of lesions on his tongue and both inner cheeks that he first noticed 2 weeks ago. He says that he stopped drinking juice and eating spicy food because they lead to a burning sensation on his tongue. He has chronic hepatitis C infection treated with ledipasvir and sofosbuvir. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years and drinks three to four glasses of wine per week. His vital signs are within normal limits. B. Topical nystatin therapy
C. Topical corticosteroid therapy
D. Cryotherapy
E. Oral acyclovir therapy

Question
Six days after admission to the intensive care unit, a 28-year-old man is evaluated for sudden onset hypertension, tachycardia, and muscle contractions of his extremities and back. He had a similar episode 3 hours ago, which resolved spontaneously after 10 minutes. Both episodes began shortly after he was repositioned in his bed. One week ago, he was brought to the emergency department in an unresponsive state after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hematoma and the patient was transferred to the operating room for an emergency craniotomy with hematoma evacuation. Since his arrival to the intensive care unit after the procedure, he has remained intubated and mechanically ventilated, and his vital signs have been stable. His medical history is unavailable. He appears diaphoretic. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 155/min, and blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg. Cardiac examination discloses no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally. The cranial surgical site is dry. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient's condition occurred as a complication of his traumatic brain injury (TBI).

A. Paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity
B. Reflex epilepsy
C. Sepsis
D. Pulmonary embolism
E. Elevated intracranial pressure

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing weakness and numbness of her legs for 3 days. She noticed that the weakness was more severe after she had a hot shower that morning. A year ago, she had an episode of partial vision loss in her left eye that resolved within 3 weeks. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 108/77 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity and decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Sensation to vibration and position over the lower extremities shows no abnormalities. Tandem gait is impaired. MRI of the brain and spine is inconclusive. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? Relapsing remitting central neurologic symptoms, especially in a woman of childbearing age, are concerning for multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's visual changes that resolved without treatment likely represent optic neuritis, the most common first manifestation of MS. Hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, and absent abdominal reflex are signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction. Worsening of symptoms following a hot shower is referred to as Uhthoff phenomenon.

A. Positive rapid plasma reagin test
B. Peripheral nerve demyelination
C. Fasciculations on electromyography
D. Elevated intrinsic factor antibody level
E. Oligoclonal bands in cerebral spinal fluid
F. Positive ELISA for anti-HIV antibodies

Correct Answer: E

Question
A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for the past 4 months. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time she has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative and stool microscopy reveals no pathogens and no leukocytes. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g (N < 7) of fat. The patient is asked to consume 25 g of d-xylose. Five hours later, its concentration is measured in urine at 2 g (N = > 4 g/5 h). The test is repeated after a two-week course of rifaximin, but the urinary concentration of d-xylose remains the same. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without enzymatic breakdown and is primarily excreted via urine. After consumption of d-xylose, urinary levels of this monosaccharide typically increase. Loss of absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa leads to a low urinary d-xylose concentration, known as a positive d-xylose test.

A. Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the colon
B. Lactose intolerance
C. Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency
D. Tropheryma whipplei infection
E. Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine
F. Hypersensitivity to gliadin

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of 24-hour blood pressure monitoring results. Over the last 3 months, she has had intermittent nausea, decreased appetite, and increasing weakness and fatigue during the day. She has been treated twice for kidney stones within the past year. Her current medications include lisinopril, amlodipine, and furosemide. She is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 97 kg (214 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 152/98 mm Hg. C. Increased serum parathyroid hormone
D. Decreased serum thyroid-stimulating hormone
E. Decreased renal blood flow

Question

Question

Question

On the way to the hospital, he took a sublingual nitrate tablet that he had at home, which helped relieve the pain. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 144/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with no ST-segment abnormalities. An esophagogram shows areas of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms in several segments along the length of the esophagus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? E. Elevated CK-MB levels on serum studies

Question
A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive unsteadiness while walking and an inability to sit upright without support. He has alcoholic fatty liver disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years and has been drinking three to four 12-oz beers daily over the past 12 years. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg. He is cooperative and oriented to person, place, and time. Physical examination shows mild gaze-evoked horizontal nystagmus and swaying of the trunk. When asked to walk down the hall, he is unsteady and uncoordinated. When asked to walk in tandem, he wobbles and is not able to finish the task. During heel-knee-shin testing, he is unable to keep his foot on the shin. Finger-to-nose testing shows no abnormalities. B. Tabes dorsalis
C. Wernicke encephalopathy
D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
E. Subacute combined degeneration
F. Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration

Question
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a weak urinary stream and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying for the past 4 months. Two years ago, he had a transurethral resection of the prostate for benign prostatic hyperplasia without any procedural complications, which resulted in complete resolution of his symptoms. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis of the knees. He has been sexually active in a monogamous relationship for the past 30 years with his husband. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Question

Question

C. Phencyclidine
D. Cocaine

Question
Two hours after undergoing a platelet transfusion, a 55-year-old man develops fever, chills, and headache. He was admitted to the hospital 4 hours ago for an uncontrolled nosebleed and was treated with anterior nasal packing and an oxymetazoline spray. The platelet count at the time of admission was 33,000/mm3. Medical history is remarkable for multiple myeloma complicated by bone marrow failure. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 143/96 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, scattered petechiae on his upper and lower extremities, and gauze packing in the nasal cavity. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:A direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) is negative. Blood cultures grow no organisms. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's transfusion-related complication? The combination of fever, chills, and headache occurring 1–6 hours posttransfusion in a hemodynamically stable patient with no evidence of hemolysis (i.e., normal LDH and total bilirubin), a negative direct antiglobulin test, and negative blood culture is consistent with febrile nonhemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR).

A. Premedication with antihistamines
B. Using platelet concentrate only from male donors and screening for antineutrophil antibodies
C. Slowing the rate of transfusion
D. Leukoreduction of the platelet concentrate before storage
E. System-based training of health care personnel for proper patient identification

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening bilateral foot pain for the past 2 months. The pain used to only occur after long walks and subside with rest. For the past week, the pain has been continuous and associated with burning sensations. He has also had transient painful nodules along the course of the leg veins for 4 months that resolve spontaneously. The patient is wearing an ankle brace for support because of a sprained left ankle that occurred 3 months ago. His mother was diagnosed with protein C deficiency as a teenager. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and does not drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ulcers on the distal portion of his left great, second, and fifth toes. The feet are cool. Pedal pulses are barely palpable. Ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.3 in the left leg and 0.5 in the right leg. Which of the following interventions is most likely to decrease the risk of amputation in this patient? Claudication pain, features of critical limb ischemia (rest pain for > 2 weeks, decreased peripheral pulses, cold extremities, digital ulcers, very low ankle-brachial pressure index), and history of migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (transient, painful nodules along the course of the veins) in a young, male patient indicate thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO).

B. Removing the ankle brace
C. Bypass grafting
D. Smoking cessation
E. Enoxaparin therapy
F. Prednisolone therapy
G. Iloprost therapy
H. Simvastatin therapy
. Avoidance of cold temperatures

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

Question
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 2-month history of chest pain and heartburn after meals. The patient reports that the pain is worse at night and especially when lying down. She has a history of occasional small joint pain and Raynaud disease treated with nifedipine. There is no family history of serious illness. She emigrated to the US from Nigeria 5 years ago. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Thickening and hardening of the skin is seen on the hands and face. There are several firm, white nodules on the elbows and fingertips. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? This middle-aged woman with a history of Raynaud disease presents with gastroesophageal reflux, sclerodactyly, and calcinosis cutis. These features indicate CREST syndrome, a manifestation of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (SSc).

A. Anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies
B. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies
C. Anti-U1 RNP antibodies
D. Anticentromere antibodies
E. Anti-Scl-70 antibodies
F. Anti-dsDNA antibodies

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of nonbloody diarrhea and recurrent episodes of flushing and wheezing. She does not take any medications. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented rash around the base of her neck. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Echocardiography shows right-sided endocardial and valvular fibrosis with moderate tricuspid regurgitation; there are no septal defects or left-sided valvular defects. Urinalysis shows increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms? This patient's presentation (e.g., cutaneous vasomotor flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and cardiac involvement) is highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, the primary molecule produced by carcinoid tumors. Carcinoid heart disease is typically caused by valvular and endocardial fibrosis that affects the right heart, leading to right-sided valvular disease (e.g., tricuspid regurgitation).

A. Tumor in the pancreas without metastasis
B. Tumor in the terminal ileum with hepatic metastasis
C. Tumor in the left atrium with hepatic metastasis
D. Tumor in the appendix without metastasis
E. Tumor in the lung without metastasis
F. Tumor in the descending colon with hepatic metastasis

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of severe ear pain and yellow discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. It is also mildly pruritic. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a red and edematous external auditory canal. A diagnostic tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead. The patient reports hearing the sound more loudly in the left ear. The tuning fork is then placed on the mastoid process of the left ear. Once she can no longer hear the sound, the tuning fork is placed in front of the auricle, and she reports no longer hearing the sound. On the right side, once the sound from the mastoid process subsides and the tuning fork is placed in front of the right ear, she reports hearing the sound again. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? A Weber test that lateralizes to the affected ear (the left ear in this patient) in combination with a negative Rinne test in the same ear suggests conductive hearing loss. Ear pain, otorrhea, pruritus, and an edematous, reddened external auditory canal indicate that the cause of conductive hearing loss is otitis externa.

B. Infection with varicella-zoster virus
C. Infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae
D. Abnormal squamous epithelial growth
E. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa
F. Pleomorphic replacement of normal bone

Correct Answer: E

A. 17-alpha hydroxylase deficiency
B. Mullerian duct agenesis
C. 5-alpha reductase deficiency
D. Androgen insensitivity
E. Sex chromosomal monosomy
F. Pure gonadal dysgenesis
G. Failure of Mullerian duct recanalization

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital 1 week after his general physician detected a solitary lesion of the liver on a routine ultrasonography examination. He feels well. He has a 10-year history of chronic hepatitis C infection. He has no other history of serious illness and takes no medication. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a nontender abdomen; the liver edge is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:An abdominal CT scan with contrast shows a solitary 3 cm lesion in segment II of the left liver lobe with vivid contrast enhancement during the late arterial phase, followed by rapid washout. There is no evidence of invasion of hepatic vasculature. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's findings are consistent with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is characterized by the presence of a solitary tumor < 5 cm or up to three tumors < 3 cm confined to the liver, preserved hepatic function (Child-Pugh class A or B cirrhosis), and no evidence of portal hypertension or invasion of the hepatic vasculature.

A. Liver transplantation
B. Left lobe resection
C. Systemic chemotherapy
D. Radiofrequency ablation
E. Transcatheter arterial chemoembolization

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath, abdominal fullness, and pedal edema for 3 months. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and is currently receiving therapy with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 96/70 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. There is jugular venous distention. The jugular venous pressure rises with inspiration. Breath sounds are decreased at the lung base bilaterally. Cardiac examination reveals an early diastolic sound over the left sternal border. The abdomen is distended and a shifting dullness test is positive. An ECG shows low-amplitude QRS complexes. Chest x-ray shows small pleural effusions bilaterally and calcifications over the left cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography shows a 40% decrease in the velocity of peak diastolic blood flow across the mitral valve during inspiration. Cardiac catheterization shows elevated right ventricular diastolic pressure with characteristic dip-and-plateau waveform. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient with tuberculosis and dyspnea, ascites (distended abdomen, shifting dullness), and peripheral edema has a positive Kussmaul sign (increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration) and a pericardial knock (early diastolic sound over the left sternal border). These features along with calcifications on chest x-ray and an exaggerated respiratory variation of blood flow on echocardiography indicate constrictive pericarditis, which may be confirmed by a positive square root sign on cardiac catheterization (dip-and-plateau waveform).

A. Implantable cardioverter defibrillator
B. Corticosteroid therapy
C. Colchicine therapy
D. Pericardiectomy
E. Metoprolol therapy
F. Heart transplantation
G. Pericardiocentesis

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, increased sweating, and itching in his legs for the past 2 years. He has chronic bronchitis. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 24 years and drinks one to two beers every night. His only medication is a tiotropium bromide inhaler. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 116 kg (256 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Physical examination shows facial flushing and bluish discoloration of the lips. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? This patient presents with constitutional symptoms (fatigue, sweating), pruritus, and plethora (i.e., facial flushing and cyanotic lips). In combination with an increase of all three blood cell lines (i.e., erythrocytosis, leukocytosis, and thrombocytosis), these findings suggest polycythemia vera (PV). In patients with PV, low serum iron and serum ferritin, as well as high-normal total iron-binding capacity indicate increased incorporation of iron into hemoglobin due to excessive hematopoiesis and hemoglobin production.

A. Weight loss
B. Iron supplementation
C. Imatinib
D. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation
E. Hydroxyurea
F. Inhaled budesonide
G. Phlebotomy

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because she thinks that her “right wrist is broken.” She says that she has severe pain and that “the bone is sticking out.” She has not had any trauma to the wrist. Her medical records indicate that she was diagnosed with schizophrenia 2 years ago and treated with olanzapine; she has not filled any prescriptions over the past 4 months. Three weeks ago, she stopped going to work because she “did not feel like getting up” in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right wrist shows no visible injury; there is no warmth, swelling, or erythema. Range of motion is limited by pain. On mental status examination, she has a flat affect. Her speech is pressured and she frequently changes the topic. She has short- and long-term memory deficits. Attention and concentration are poor. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An x-ray of the wrist shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns? This patient presents with a somatic delusion (broken wrist), flattened affect, avolition, disorganized and pressured speech, poor concentration, and memory deficits, which suggests an acute psychotic episode. Her history of schizophrenia and discontinuation of antipsychotic treatment for the last four months further support this diagnosis.“I cannot see any injury of your wrist and the physical exam as well as the x-ray don't show any injury. I imagine that feeling as if your wrist was broken may be very uncomfortable. Can you tell me more about what it feels like? ”81%
"I can imagine that you are uncomfortable. That certainly looks painful. Let's take care of this injury first and then we should talk about your problems getting up in the morning."5%
“It seems as though you are having a schizophrenia relapse. If you don't follow my recommendations and take your medications, you will most likely have further and possibly more severe episodes.”1%
"You are clearly distressed. However, your tests do not suggest a physical problem that can be addressed with medications or surgery. I suggest that we meet and evaluate your symptoms on a regular basis."10%
"Your physical examination findings and the x-ray cannot explain your symptoms, suggesting a psychological rather than a physical problem. I will prescribe olanzapine, which should relieve your symptoms."3%

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of impaired sleep. She feels well physically but reports difficulty sleeping and a feeling of emptiness and sadness since her wife died from breast cancer 6 weeks ago. Sometimes when she thinks of her wife, she suddenly starts crying. The patient says, “I feel bad for not taking proper care of her before she passed. She might have been in pain, and I did not notice it. I wish I could talk to her on the other side to tell her how much I want to be with her again.” She reports having had a nightmare about being diagnosed with cancer a few days after her wife passed. Several times while falling asleep, she has seen her wife sitting in the chair next to her bed, smiling at her. She goes to bed late and always wakes up before her alarm but does not feel tired during the day. She has a good relationship with her son and moved to his home 3 weeks ago because her own apartment reminded her too much of her wife and felt too large for her alone. She attends a chess club 3 days per week and says that she almost forgets about the death of her wife while she is playing chess, which makes her feel guilty later. D. Prazosin therapy
E. Mirtazapine therapy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 2 hours after the sudden onset of nausea, vomiting, and confusion. She was found on the kitchen floor along with candies, prescription pills, and several bottles. Her father has a history of hypertension and chronic low back pain and her mother has fibromyalgia. On arrival, the patient is obtunded and appears dehydrated. Temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Examination shows dilated pupils, dry lips, and flushed skin. Bowel sounds are decreased. The patient is unable to cooperate with neurologic examinations. ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. Supportive therapy with intravenous fluids and supplemental oxygen is begun. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This girl presents with features of anticholinergic toxicity (hyperthermia, pupillary dilation, flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, sinus tachycardia), antihistaminic effects (sedation), α1 receptor inhibition (hypotension), and inhibition of cardiac fast sodium channels (QRS widening), which together strongly suggest tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) intoxication. TCAs are used in the treatment of fibromyalgia.

A. Intramuscular glucagon
B. Intravenous physostigmine
C. Oral N-acetylcysteine
D. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate
E. Intravenous naloxone

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of diarrhea that has become progressively worse over the past four months. He currently has 4–6 episodes of foul-smelling stools per day. Over the past three months, he has had fatigue and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He returned from Bangladesh six months ago after a year-long business assignment. He has osteoarthritis and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine and naproxen. He appears pale and malnourished. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 140/86 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae and dry mucous membranes. Angular stomatitis and glossitis are present. The abdomen is soft without tenderness. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Stool culture and studies for ova and parasites are negative. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Fecal fat content is 22 g/day (N<7). Fecal lactoferrin testing is negative and fecal elastase level is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? Combined with a history of loose stools, fatigue, and travel to the Indian subcontinent, features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea (elevated fecal fat content) and vitamin deficiencies (e.g., angular stomatitis, glossitis, macrocytic anemia) are highly suggestive of tropical sprue.

A. CT scan of the abdomen
B. Schilling test
C. IgG against deamidated gliadin peptide
D. Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody
E. Endoscopic small bowel biopsy
F. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of gingival bleeding and worsening fatigue. He has also had decreased appetite and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has tried over-the-counter vitamin supplements with no relief of his symptoms. He appears pale. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows numerous petechial lesions over the upper and lower extremities. A bone marrow smear is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient? The bone marrow smear shows multiple Auer rods, which are a characteristic finding of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML often presents with symptoms related to anemia (fatigue, weakness) and thrombocytopenia (bleeding, petechiae).Translocation t(9;22)34%

A. Positive heterophile antibody test
B. Peroxidase-positive granules
C. Cold agglutinin antibodies
D. Follicular hyperkeratosis

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 42-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of several episodes of rectal bleeding over the past 2 weeks. He has had pain around the anal area for the past month. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with esophageal candidiasis and was treated with oral fluconazole. He has had 9 male sexual partners over his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. The patient's current medications include dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) and weighs 66 kg (146 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show a hard 2-cm mass palpable 0.5 cm above the anal verge that bleeds on contact. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 95/mm3. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following interventions? Anal canal cancer typically presents as an exophytic, hard anal mass that is often tender and bleeds easily. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer (approx. 90% of cases) and it typically arises just above the anal verge and below the dentate line, which is located approx. 2 cm away from the anal verge.

A. Radiochemotherapy
B. Abdominoperineal resection
C. Local 5-fluorouracil therapy
D. Total mesorectal excision
E. Injection sclerotherapy
F. Submucosal hemorrhoidectomy

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 5-week-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 1-week history of yellow discoloration of her skin. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Her older brother had physiological neonatal jaundice. She does not appear to be in distress. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F) and pulse is 139/min. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and sclerae. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver edge is palpated 3.5 cm below the right costal margin and the spleen tip 2 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? Features of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (e.g., dark urine, acholic stools, increased direct bilirubin) along with mildly elevated transaminases and disproportionately elevated alkaline phosphatase and γ-Glutamyltransferase suggest obstructive cholestasis. In a 5-week-old infant, these findings should raise concern for biliary atresia (BA).

B. Liver biopsy
C. CT scan of the abdomen
D. Cholangiography
E. Abdominal ultrasound

Correct Answer: D

Question

Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.3°F), pulse is 110/min and irregular, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 102/60 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. The abdomen is tympanitic on percussion. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Question
Ten days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a 3-minute episode of myoclonic jerking movements and urinary incontinence. After regaining consciousness, the patient has no recollection of what happened and seems confused. He has bipolar disorder, which has been controlled with maintenance therapy for the past 15 years, as well as hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and chronic lower back pain. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry oral mucosa, muscle fasciculations, and bilateral coarse hand tremor. His speech is slow and he is disoriented. Which of the following drugs most likely precipitated this patient's current condition? Lithium is commonly used for maintenance therapy of bipolar disorder. This patient has lithium toxicity, which can cause myoclonic seizures, altered mental status, coarse tremors, and neuromuscular excitability.

A. Valproic acid
B. Acetaminophen
C. Theophylline
D. Fluoxetine
E. Enalapril

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of an unusual cough, a raspy voice, and noisy breathing for the last 2 days. During this time, the symptoms have always occurred in the late evening. The parents also report that prior to the onset of these symptoms, their son had a low-grade fever and a runny nose for 2 days. He attends daycare. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and respirations are 33/min. Physical examination shows supraclavicular retractions. There is a high-pitched breath sound on inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely location of the abnormality? A chest x-ray of this patient would most likely reveal a steeple sign.

A. Bronchioles
B. Distal trachea
C. Epiglottis
D. Pharynx
E. Supraglottic larynx
F. Subglottic larynx
G. Pulmonary parenchyma
H. Bronchi

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive weakness on the right side of her face. During this time, she has also noticed increased dryness of her right eye. Her medical history is remarkable for migraine headaches for which she takes sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows asymmetrical facial expression with a right-sided drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is deeply concerned that her current symptoms are going to be permanent. She asks what her long-term prognosis will be. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concern? Acute onset of progressive unilateral facial weakness, decreased lacrimation, drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling are consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.“I can make an accurate statement about your prognosis only after obtaining imaging studies of your head.”16%
”With oral prednisone therapy, approximately 2 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”6%
”Even without treatment, at least 7 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”69%
”These symptoms are likely to be permanent, as there is currently no effective treatment for your condition.”1%
"These symptoms will likely resolve spontaneously within a few months, but almost 9 out of 10 patients with your condition develop facial contractures as a late complication."8%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 21-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of headaches and nausea for 2 months. His headaches are holocephalic and most severe upon waking up. During this time, he has also been feeling tired and sleepy during the day despite going to bed at 10 pm and sleeping for 8 hours at night. He is concerned about losing his spot on next season's college track team because of a recent decline in his performance during winter training. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 months ago, for which he did not seek medical care. One year ago he moved into a new house with his friends, where he lives in the basement. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His only medication is a daily multivitamin. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (140 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? It is probably cold in the basement during the winter.

A. Chronic cerebral hypoxia
B. Increased intracranial pressure
C. Exogenous erythropoietin use
D. Acquired gene mutation
E. Overuse of NSAIDs

Correct Answer: A

Question
Eighteen hours after the vaginal delivery of a 2788-g (6-lb 2-oz) newborn, a 22-year-old woman has weakness and numbness of her right foot. She is unable to walk without dragging and shuffling her foot. The delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and the patient had received epidural analgesia. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-stepping gait. There is weakness upon right foot dorsiflexion and right ankle eversion. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the right foot and the anterolateral aspect of the right lower extremity below the knee. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? The semi-Fowler lithotomy position (legs flexed at the hips, abducted, and externally rotated), forceful knee flexion, and use of obstetrical stirrups are common during childbirth and put mothers at risk for a specific nerve lesion.

A. L2-L4 radiculopathy
B. Effect of epidural anesthesia
C. Postpartum angiopathy
D. Compression of the common peroneal nerve
E. Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve injury

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a 5-month history of painful sexual intercourse. She also reports vaginal pruritus and occasional spotting. She has no pain with urination. She had two urinary tract infections over the past 3 years that resolved with oral antibiotic therapy. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Her last menstrual period was 8 months ago. She is sexually active with her husband and has two children. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 29 years. Current medications include ramipril, metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 140/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows decreasing labial fat pad, receding pubic hair, and clear vaginal discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? Receding pubic hair and decreasing labial fat pads are typical symptoms for genitourinary syndrome of menopause (atrophic vaginitis).

A. Oral fluconazole
B. Topical nystatin
C. Topical estrogen cream
D. Oral metronidazole
E. Topical corticosteroids

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he suffered a spinal fracture after a fall from the roof, which was managed with external bracing, physical therapy, and rest. He feels well. His father has multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings? The hypercalcemia in this adolescent is due to excess osteoclastic bone resorption.

A. Sarcoidosis
B. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
C. Immobilization
D. Parathyroid adenoma
E. Pseudohypercalcemia
F. Paraneoplastic syndrome

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of a burning sensation in his chest. The sensation is most prominent when he is lying in bed and is also present after eating heavy meals. He also states that his breath has an unpleasant odor in the morning. He has not lost any weight during this period. He has hypothyroidism. His father died of colon cancer and his mother has hypertension. He drinks 2–3 beers on weekends; he does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. His medications include levothyroxine and an over-the-counter multivitamin. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The burning sensation in this patient's chest, exacerbated by consuming heavy meals and lying down, and halitosis are suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

A. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy
B. Urea breath test
C. Proton-pump inhibitor therapy
D. H2 receptor blocker therapy
E. Barium swallow test
F. Amoxicillin and clarithromycin therapy
G. Calcium carbonate therapy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department for progressively worsening abdominal pain. The pain started 2 weeks ago and is localized to the right upper quadrant. He feels sick and fatigued. He also reports breathlessness when climbing the stairs to his first-floor apartment. He is a retired painter. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms consistently. He began having sexual relations with his most recent partner 2 months ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin and enalapril. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (264 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jaundice, a distended abdomen, and tender hepatomegaly. There is no jugular venous distention. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the right upper sternal border. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? Erythrocytosis is an important risk factor for Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS), which is characterized by progressive abdominal pain, jaundice, tender hepatomegaly, and elevated serum transaminases. Patients may also develop massive ascites, which can cause abdominal distension and dyspnea. The soft ejection systolic murmur in this patient is most likely not diagnostically significant.

A. Hepatotropic viral infection
B. Increased iron absorption
C. Hepatic vein obstruction
D. Thickened pericardium
E. Hepatic steatosis

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of headache, fever, chills, shortness of breath, and abdominal pain for 1 week. He also feels tired and nauseous. He returned from a trip to Botswana 2 weeks ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks a glass of beer daily. His only current medication is metformin. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F), pulse is 122/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 109/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Examination shows jaundice. A few scattered inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.31. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis? This patient with a travel history to a malaria-endemic region presents with signs of hemolysis (elevated LDH, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, and anemia), thrombocytopenia, signs of pulmonary edema (dyspnea, decreased oxygen saturation, and inspiratory crackles), renal involvement (3+ blood on urine dipstick), and metabolic abnormalities (hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis). He most likely has severe malaria, which is usually caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

A. Coombs test
B. Blood culture
C. Chest x-ray
D. Blood smear
E. Abdominal ultrasound
F. Serologic testing

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left leg pain and swelling for 1 day. She has had two miscarriages but otherwise has no history of serious illness. Physical examination shows stiff, swollen finger joints. The left calf circumference is larger than the right and there is a palpable cord in the left popliteal fossa. Laboratory studies show a prothrombin time of 12 seconds and an activated partial thromboplastin time of 51 seconds. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? Multiple miscarriages, deep vein thrombosis (asymmetric calf swelling with a palpable cord), and prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are consistent with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).

A. Anti-nuclear antibodies
B. Anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies
C. Anti-cyclical citrullinated peptide antibodies
D. Anti-DNA topoisomerase I antibodies
E. Anti-β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies
F. Anti-synthetase antibodies

Correct Answer: E

Question
Three days after undergoing open surgery to repair a bilateral inguinal hernia, a 69-year-old woman has retrosternal chest pain and nausea. Her symptoms are present at rest and have worsened progressively over the past 6 hours. There were no complications during surgery or during the immediate postsurgical period. Ambulation was restarted on the first postoperative day. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She appears diaphoretic and anxious but is alert and oriented. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg in both arms. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. The abdomen is soft without tenderness or distention. There are two healing surgical scars with moderate serous discharge; bowel sounds are normal. Cardiopulmonary examination and repeat ECGs show no abnormalities. D-dimer concentration and serially measured cardiac troponin concentrations are within the reference range. An x-ray of the chest and abdomen, and point of care ultrasonography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Certain serum biomarkers only appear once tissue necrosis occurs.

A. Intravenous alteplase therapy
B. CT scan of the chest with contrast
C. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
D. Intravenous pantoprazole therapy
E. Cardiac catheterization

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening pain and swelling of her left knee. For the past year, she has had pain in her knees and hands bilaterally, but never this severe. During this period, she has also had difficulties moving around for about an hour in the mornings and has been sweating more than usual, especially at night. She has been sexually active with a new partner for the past 4 weeks, and they use condoms inconsistently. She occasionally drinks alcohol. The day before she drank 6 beers because she was celebrating a friend's birthday. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; movement is restricted due to pain. There is swelling of the metacarpophalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Arthrocentesis of the knee with synovial fluid analysis shows a greenish, turbid fluid, a cell count of 68,000 WBC/μL, and Gram-negative diplococci. An x-ray of the affected knee is most likely to show which of the following findings? This patient presents with fever, joint pain, restricted range of motion, and arthrocentesis findings showing green turbid fluid, increased WBC count, and Gram-negative diplococci, all of which are characteristic of septic arthritis. Symmetric joint pain, swelling of the finger joints and knee, morning stiffness > 30 minutes, and constitutional symptoms suggest an underlying diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), in which characteristic x-ray findings would be expected.

A. Calcifications and osteolysis with moth-eaten appearance
B. Sunburst appearance of lytic bone lesions and Codman triangle
C. Irregularity or fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity
D. Punched-out lytic bone lesions with spiky periosteal appositions
E. Calcification of the meniscal and hyaline cartilage
F. Joint space narrowing and bone erosions

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of a generalized rash. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, and respirations are 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A pustular smear from this newborn will show eosinophils.

A. Congenital candidiasis
B. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
C. Acropustulosis
D. Erythema toxicum
E. Milia
F. Pustular melanosis
G. Cutis marmorata
H. Congenital syphilis

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a nonproductive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 mL of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion? This patient presents with chronic fatigue, nonproductive cough, weight loss, and nodular pleural lesions on x-ray, the combination of which raises concern for malignancy. Her work as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years is a risk factor for asbestos exposure. Based on Light's criteria (effusion protein: serum protein ratio > 0.5 and effusion LDH: serum LDH ratio > 0.6), this patient has an exudative pleural effusion.

A. Bronchial adenocarcinoma
B. Mesothelioma
C. Nephrotic syndrome
D. Tuberculosis
E. Congestive heart failure

Correct Answer: B

Question
An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-year history of behavioral problems. She has temper outbursts six to seven times per week, which last anywhere between five minutes and half an hour. According to her father, she screams at others and throws things in anger “when things don't go her way”. He says that she is constantly irritable between outbursts. She has been suspended from school three times in the past year for physical aggression toward her classmates, but her grades have remained unaffected. She appears agitated and restless. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and refuses to answer questions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This child presents with severe and explosive temper outbursts, which have been present for > 12 months and are causing impairment at home and school.

A. Attention deficit hyperactive disorder
B. Pediatric bipolar disorder
C. Conduct disorder
D. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
E. Oppositional defiant disorder
F. Intermittent explosive disorder

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue for the past 3 months. During this time, his grades have declined in his college courses because he has had difficulty focusing on assignments and sometimes sleeps in class. He no longer plays the drums for his band and has stopped attending family events. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he describes his mood as “ok.” He has a flat affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. His speech is slow in rate and monotone in rhythm, and his thought process is organized. He has no delusions or hallucinations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, sleep changes, fatigue, diminished concentration and cognition, psychomotor slowing) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD). The presence of anhedonia or depressed mood is necessary to meet the diagnostic criteria.

A. Escitalopram therapy
B. Reassurance
C. Lithium therapy
D. Phenelzine therapy
E. Selegiline therapy
F. Diazepam therapy
G. Amitriptyline therapy
H. Risperidone therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and increased straining during defecation for 3 months. During this time, he has lost 5 kg (11 lb) despite no change in appetite. He has a family history of colon cancer in his maternal uncle and maternal grandfather. His mother died of ovarian cancer at the age of 46 years. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, hematocrit is 34%, and mean corpuscular volume is 76 μm3. Colonoscopy shows an exophytic mass in the ascending colon. Pathologic examination of the resected mass shows a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis shows a mutation in the MSH2 gene. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Mutations in the MSH2 DNA mismatch repair gene lead to microsatellite instability. In addition to having an increased risk of colorectal cancer, individuals with this mutation are more likely to develop other cancers such as endometrial, ovarian, and gastric carcinomas.

A. Familial adenomatous polyposis
B. Li-Fraumeni syndrome
C. Turcot syndrome
D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
E. Gardner syndrome
F. Lynch syndrome

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 5-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because he has had trouble holding his head straight. His mother says he was able to do so until 3 weeks ago, at which time he began feeling “floppier” when she held him. She also mentions that she has had more difficulties feeding him as he often chokes while being breastfed. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He is at the 40th percentile for height and weight. He is alert and looks to his mother when he hears her voice. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased muscle tone in all extremities. The left leg is slightly shorter than the right leg and is positioned in external rotation. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout. Oral examination shows tongue fasciculations. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has a congenital motor neuron disease that affects the lower motor neurons.

A. Neonatal myasthenia gravis
B. Myotonic dystrophy
C. Spinal muscular atrophy
D. Infant botulism
E. Duchenne muscular dystrophy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, a runny nose, and chills for 6 hours. He has also had diarrhea and difficulty sleeping. He appears irritable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows cool, damp skin with piloerection. The pupils are 7 mm in diameter and equal in size. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is tender to palpation. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ bilaterally. Withdrawal from which of the following substances is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? To quote John Lennon: “My body is aching, Goose-pimple bone, Can't see no body, Leave me alone - My eyes are wide open, Can't get to sleep, One thing I'm sure of, I'm in at the deep freeze - Cold turkey has got me on the run.”

A. Alcohol
B. Methamphetamine
C. Gamma-hydroxybutyric acid
D. Barbiturates
E. Cannabis
F. Phencyclidine
G. Heroin

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 43-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Four months ago, he was treated conservatively for ureteric colic. He has noticed during micturition that his urine is reddish-brown initially and then clears by the end of the stream. He has no dysuria. He has hypertension. His only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 122/86 mm Hg.
