The bladder stores urine (and sometimes blood) from the upper genitourinary tract, where the contents mix for extended periods of time.

A. Renal glomeruli
B. Ureter
C. Renal pelvis
D. Urethra
E. Urinary bladder

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of a swollen right knee. Over the past 6 weeks, he has had painful episodes affecting the right knee and the left elbow. He previously had a rash, which subsided 2 months ago. He lives in Connecticut and works as a landscaper. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms consistently. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and warm right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hematocrit is 44%, leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3, and platelet count is 145,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed and the synovial fluid appears cloudy. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 27,000/mm3 and 80% neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has progressed to stage III of the illness.

A. Lyme arthritis
B. Osteoarthritis
C. Rheumatoid arthritis
D. Gonococcal arthritis
E. Reactive arthritis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening pain on the outer side of his right elbow. He does not recall any trauma to the area. The patient plays tennis recreationally and has recently gone from playing weekly to playing daily in preparation for a local tournament. He has had some pain relief with ibuprofen. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the lateral surface of the right distal humerus. The pain is reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? Progressively worsening pain near the lateral epicondyle in a tennis player suggests lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow).

A. Nerve compression at the elbow
B. Bursal inflammation
C. Repeated wrist flexion
D. Excessive stress to bone
E. Repeated wrist extension

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 50-year-old woman reports uncontrolled abdominal pain 18 hours after undergoing an emergency laparotomy following a motor vehicle collision. She is receiving intravenous morphine via a patient-controlled pump and scheduled doses of intravenous hydromorphone. The on-duty physician increases the dose of the scheduled intravenous hydromorphone and then signs out to the covering physician, letting the covering physician know the names of his patients, their locations, and the reasons for their admissions. Overnight, the patient continues to report uncontrolled pain. The covering physician decides to get some sleep in case he has a busy night. He is awoken during the night by one of the nurses, who informs him about the patient's pain. The covering physician orders a one-time dose of intravenous hydromorphone. Shortly after the ward nurse administers the dose, the patient becomes confused, and her respirations decrease to 10/min. Physical examination shows constricted pupils and decreased bowel sounds. An iatrogenic opioid overdose is suspected. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this medical error? Administration of an additional one-time dose of intravenous hydromorphone would have been an appropriate choice of therapy before the increase of the scheduled doses by the on-duty physician.

A. Patient-controlled pump malfunction
B. Fatigue of the covering physician
C. Nonstandardized patient handoff
D. Accidental mix-up of drugs
E. Excessive workload of the covering physician

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of worsening upper abdominal pain that he first noticed this morning after waking up. The pain is of tearing and burning quality and radiates to his back. Yesterday, he underwent an upper endoscopy and was diagnosed with gastritis and a large hiatal hernia. He has hypertension, hypercholesteremia, and a left bundle branch block that was diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient's mother died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years, and his father died of aortic dissection at the age of 65 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. He drinks three beers daily. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, atorvastatin, and pantoprazole. The patient appears to be in mild distress. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg in the left arm and 132/90 mm Hg in the right arm. Cardiopulmonary examination shows crackling with every heartbeat. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the epigastric region; bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show:Chest x-ray shows a large hiatal hernia and mediastinal lucency. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia and a left bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? This patient underwent an upper endoscopy yesterday and now presents with upper abdominal pain, tachycardia, and crackling with every heartbeat associated with lucency of the mediastinum, indicating mediastinal emphysema (Hamman sign). The combination of these findings suggests iatrogenic esophageal perforation.

A. Coronary angiography
B. Contrast-enhanced CT of the aorta
C. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy
D. Abdominal ultrasound
E. Contrast esophagography with gastrografin
F. Barium swallow

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 14-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of an abdominal bulge that has become more noticeable as he began to walk 2 weeks ago. The bulge increases on crying and disappears when he is lying down. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section. He has met all developmental milestones. He has been breastfed since birth. He appears healthy and active. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a nontender, 1-cm midabdominal mass that is easily reducible. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The patient's physical examination is most consistent with a congenital umbilical hernia.

A. Emergency open repair
B. Elective open repair
C. Reassurance and observation
D. Abdominal ultrasonography
E. Elective laparoscopic repair
F. CT scan of the abdomen

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 32-year-old man, who is a military veteran, comes to the emergency department because of high-grade fever and malaise for 3 days. He has severe generalized joint and body pains refractory to acetaminophen. He also has a severe stabbing pain behind his eyes. One week ago, he returned from deployment for a peace-keeping mission in Taiwan. He is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Urinalysis is normal. An ELISA test for HIV is negative. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient’s condition? This patient presents with features of dengue (high fever, retroorbital pain, lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and increased serum transaminases) following recent travel to an endemic region (Taiwan). Severe arthralgia and myalgia are common in patients with dengue, which is why this condition is also referred to as “break-bone fever.”

A. Safe sexual practices
B. Mosquito repellent
C. Prophylaxis with doxycycline
D. Vaccination
E. Frequent hand washing

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of a mass on her belly that has become more pronounced since she delivered healthy twins 2 months ago. Delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and maternal exhaustion, and cesarean delivery was performed. She has recovered but has noticed a midline bulge on her abdomen that has become more pronounced as she has returned to her prepregnancy weight. She has not had any other symptoms. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 114/65 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a soft, nontender bulge along the supraumbilical midline without overlying erythema or skin changes. There is a horizontal lower abdominal incision with no erythema, swelling, or discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient's condition? The protrusion of abdominal content through abdominal rectal muscles indicates diastasis recti, which commonly develops in women during pregnancy as a result of increased abdominal pressure.

A. Compression garment
B. Laparoscopic hernia repair
C. Weight loss program
D. Exercise program
E. Abdominoplasty

Correct Answer: D

Question
Five hours after an elective total hip replacement surgery for advanced osteoarthritis, a 62-year-old man has a fever and chills. The operation was performed under general anesthesia with sevoflurane and lasted 3 hours. The patient received cefazolin for antibiotic prophylaxis and one unit of packed red blood cells during the procedure. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His preadmission medications are amlodipine, atorvastatin, formoterol, and ipratropium as needed. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 143/95 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart sounds are normal. Examination of the left hip shows a fresh, mildly tender surgical wound with mild erythema. A urinary catheter is in place and draining clear urine. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's fever? The timing of fever after surgery is key in establishing the most likely etiology. This patient has an immediate postoperative fever!

A. Pulmonary embolism
B. Surgical site infection
C. Malignant hyperthermia
D. Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction
E. Surgically induced tissue trauma
F. Urinary tract infection

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-week history of a foul-smelling discharge from the left nostril. She also had one episode of blood-tinged fluid draining from the nostril during this period. She has been mouth breathing in her sleep for the past 4 days. She was born at term. Her 1-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 3 weeks ago. She is at 60th percentile for height and at 70th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 96/54 mm Hg. Examination shows mucopurulent discharge in the left nasal cavity. Oral and otoscopic examination is unremarkable. Endoscopic examination of the nose confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Note that the child has strictly unilateral nasal symptoms.

A. Transnasal puncture and stenting
B. Tumor embolization
C. Foreign body extraction
D. Perform septoplasty
E. Functional endoscopic sinus surgery
F. Adenoidectomy
G. Intranasal glucocorticoid therapy

Question
A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of palpitations and irritability. Over the past 4 months, she has had several episodes of heart racing and skipping beats that lasted between 30 seconds and several hours. She has also been arguing with her husband more, often about the temperature being too warm. The patient has also lost 8.8-kg (19.4-lb) over the past 4 months, despite being less strict with her diet. She has mild asthma treated with inhaled bronchodilators. Her pulse is 102/min and blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. On physical examination, the skin is warm and moist. A mass is palpated in the anterior neck area. On laboratory studies, thyroid stimulating hormone is undetectable and there are antibodies against the thyrotropin-receptor. Thyroid scintigraphy shows diffusely increased iodine uptake. Two weeks later, a single oral dose of radioactive iodine is administered. This patient will most likely require which of the following in the long-term? This patient presents with features of Graves disease: hyperthyroidism (palpitations, irritability, weight loss, heat intolerance, increased sweating, warm skin), a palpable goiter, thyrotropin-receptor antibodies, and diffuse iodine uptake of the thyroid gland. She received radioactive iodine ablation (RAIA), during which radioactive iodine is taken up by the thyroid gland, emits beta radiation, and destroys thyroid tissue.

A. Near-total thyroidectomy
B. Potassium iodide therapy
C. Methimazole therapy
D. Propranolol therapy
E. L-thyroxine therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in both of her wrist joints and her fingers for the past 24 hours. She has a 6-month history of similar episodes, which are often associated with stiffness for about 90 minutes when she wakes up in the morning. She has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease, for which she underwent treatment. Current medications include fenofibrate and amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. She is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination shows swelling and tenderness of the wrists and metacarpophalangeal joints bilaterally. Range of motion is decreased due to pain. There are subcutaneous, nontender, firm, mobile nodules on the extensor surface of the forearm, with the overlying skin appearing normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate acute treatment for this patient's symptoms? This patient presents with classic signs of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), including symmetrical joint pain and swelling (particularly affecting the metacarpophalangeal joints), morning stiffness, and rheumatoid nodules. Her current exacerbation of symptoms suggests an acute flare.

A. Indomethacin
B. Methotrexate
C. Prednisolone
D. Adalimumab
E. Vitamin D and calcium supplements
F. Colchicine
G. Sulfasalazine

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 57-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of abdominal bloating and increased frequency of stools. He describes the stools as bulky, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. He also has a 4-month history of recurrent dull upper abdominal pain that usually lasts for a few days, worsens after meals, and is not relieved with antacids. He has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss in the past 4 months. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. He has a 12-year history of drinking 6 to 8 beers daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 52 kg (115 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows mild epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? This patient presents with steatorrhea (bulky, foul-smelling, difficult-to-flush stools), recurrent epigastric pain, and weight loss. These features, especially in an individual with a history of chronic alcohol use, are strongly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis (CP).

A. Abdominal CT scan
Measurement of serum cancer antigen 19-93%
B. Endoscopic ultrasonography
C. Abdominal ultrasound
D. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy
E. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
F. Abdominal x-ray

Question
A 42-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks’ gestation comes to the physician because she has gained 15.5 kg (34 lb) from her prepregnancy weight. She has otherwise had an uneventful pregnancy. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include prenatal vitamins and subcutaneous insulin. Her pulse is 101/min and blood pressure is 132/81 mm Hg. Her prepregnancy BMI was 31 kg/m2. On pelvic examination, the uterine fundus is felt at the costal arch. The fetal heart rate is 129/min. Ultrasonography shows fetal head circumference, abdominal circumference, and estimated fetal weight above the 95th percentile. The child is at greatest risk of which of the following complications? An estimated fetal weight over the 95th percentile, as seen in this case, suggests fetal macrosomia. This woman's advanced maternal age, obesity, history of diabetes mellitus, and excessive gestational weight gain are risk factors for this condition.

A. Spina bifida
B. Shoulder dystocia
C. Neonatal hyperglycemia
D. Potter sequence
E. Sudden infant death syndrome
F. Anemia

Correct Answer: B

Question

She first noticed her symptoms after getting up this morning and she was dragging her right foot while walking. She feels tired. She has a history of chronic sinusitis. Six months ago, she was diagnosed with asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroids. Dorsiflexion of the right foot is impaired. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is decreased over the ulnar aspect of the left forearm. Question

B. Physiologic neonatal jaundice
C. Hypothyroidism

Question

She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date; she completed the vaccination course for human papillomavirus 2 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora. The ulcers are 1–3 mm in diameter. There is bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition? The presence of several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in an individual with high-risk sexual behavior is indicative of genital herpes, which is diagnosed by performing a polymerase chain reaction test or viral culture on a smear obtained from the ulcer.

B. Curettage
C. Azithromycin therapy
D. Doxycycline therapy
E. Penicillin therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question

Six months ago, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and was treated with oral trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. She appears pale. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows an infiltrate at the right lung base. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? She has a CURB-65 score of 0.

D. Outpatient treatment with oral levofloxacin

Question
A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with an acute onset of weakness in her left hand that started 6 hours ago. She has not had numbness or tingling of the hand. Other than recent episodes of blurry vision and headaches, her medical history is unremarkable. She has one daughter who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis at age 23. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 144/84 mm Hg. Examination shows facial erythema. There are mild scratch marks on her arms and torso. Left hand strength is slightly decreased and there is mild dysmetria of the left hand on finger-to-nose testing. The remainder of the neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Her laboratory studies show:Her erythropoietin levels are decreased. CT scan of the head without contrast shows two focal areas of hypo-attenuation in the right frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to prevent complications of this patient's underlying condition? This patient's sudden hand weakness in conjunction with her CT findings is suggestive of stroke. Considering her facial erythema, scratch marks, history of blurry vision and headaches, and her laboratory values (elevated erythrocyte, granulocyte, and platelet counts), polycythemia vera (PV) is the most likely cause.

B. Glucocorticoid therapy
C. Warfarin therapy
D. Imatinib therapy
E. Repeated phlebotomies
F. Interferon alpha

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. She is in moderate distress. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F) and pulse is 91/min. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and yellow discoloration of the skin. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show:Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows bile duct wall thickening and a 3-cm, well-circumscribed anechogenic lesion in the bile duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography shows a biliary cyst in the common bile duct. Biliary drainage is performed and empiric antibiotic therapy is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Biliary cysts are associated with an increased risk of inflammatory (e.g., cholangitis, cholelithiasis, pancreatitis) and malignant complications (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, gallbladder cancer, pancreatic cancer). This patient's cyst was most likely complicated by acute cholangitis, which would explain her symptoms and increased cholestatic parameters (i.e., ↑ ALP, ↑ bilirubin).

A. Direct cholangioscopy with biopsy of cyst mucosa
B. Surgical cyst excision
C. Follow-up with serial magnetic resonance imaging
D. No further intervention is necessary at this time

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of generalized fatigue and numbness of his legs and toes for the past 5 months. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for peptic ulcer disease 15 years ago. He is a painter. Current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and glossitis. Sensation to vibration and position is absent over the lower extremities. He has a broad-based gait. The patient sways when he stands with his feet together and closes his eyes. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4500/mm3, and platelet count is 110,000/mm3. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient? Anemia, thrombocytopenia, glossitis, signs of dorsal column dysfunction (absent vibration and position sense, positive Romberg test), and a broad-based gait are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

A. Decreased serum iron levels
B. Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid
C. Elevated methylmalonic acid levels
D. Basophilic stippling on peripheral smear
E. Positive rapid plasma reagin test

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a follow-up examination 6 weeks after presenting with a painless mass in her left breast. Breast and pubic hair development began at the age of 10 years. Menarche started at the age of 13 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 5 days ago. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient appears well and is at the 65th percentile for both height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Breast and pubic hair development are Tanner stage 3. Palpation of the left breast shows a nontender, rubbery, discrete, and mobile mass in the upper outer quadrant. There are no overlying skin changes or associated warmth and no nipple retraction or discharge; these findings are unchanged since the last visit. Examination of the right breast and axillary lymph nodes shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the left breast shows a well-circumscribed, solid 1.5 x 1.1-cm mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? In an otherwise healthy adolescent, a nontender breast mass that remains unchanged for 6 weeks and is solid with well-defined borders on ultrasound suggests fibroadenoma.

A. Reassurance and follow-up examination in 6 months
B. Mammography
C. Fine-needle aspiration
D. Reassurance alone
E. Excisional biopsy

Correct Answer: A

Question

His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated, and there is purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient develops muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is markedly increased. B. Dantrolene therapy
C. Bromocriptine therapy

E. Cyproheptadine therapy

D. Microcytic anemia

Question

B. Cigarette smoking

Question
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? This patient has classic features of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, hyperglycemia, proximal muscle weakness, menstrual cycle changes, truncal obesity, striae, hirsutism, and hypertension. This patient's hypernatremia and hypokalemia are most likely due to the mineralocorticoid effect of high levels of cortisol. Her low ACTH levels indicate primary hypercortisolism.

B. Metyrapone therapy
C. Adrenalectomy
D. Polychemotherapy and radiation therapy
E. Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy

Correct Answer: C

In addition to recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), common manifestations of this disorder include recurrent miscarriages, livedo reticularis, and transient ischemic attacks.

B. Deficiency in factor VIII
C. Deficiency in antithrombin III

Question
A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because she is unable to sit and has not learned how to crawl. She keeps her hips and elbows flexed and her parents have to use considerable force to passively extend her joints. She attained neck control at 4 months and could roll from front to back at 5 months of age. She does not engage in play, reach for toys, or maintain eye contact. She babbles and does not mimic sounds. She does not follow simple instructions. She has difficulty swallowing solid foods and often coughs at meal times. Her maternal cousin has Down syndrome. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is at the 25th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. Neurological examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. The ankle clonus and extensor plantar responses are present bilaterally. The Moro reflex is present. An MRI of the brain shows periventricular leukomalacia. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of this patient's condition? Ankle clonus, a positive Babinski sign, and a persistent Moro reflex indicate upper motor neuron (UMN) injury. In addition, all developmental milestones are delayed except for rolling over, which is a sign of spasticity. Spasticity and UMN injury, together with feeding difficulties and periventricular leukomalacia on MRI of the brain, are consistent with spastic cerebral palsy (CP).

A. Neonatal jaundice
B. Maternal smoking during pregnancy
C. Preterm birth
D. Congenital rubella infection
E. Maternal alcohol use during pregnancy
F. Congenital toxoplasmosis
G. Congenital CMV infection
H. Advanced maternal age

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. She has a 2-year history of depressed mood and fatigue accompanied by early morning awakening. One week ago, she started feeling a decrease in her need for sleep and now feels rested after about 5 hours of sleep per night. She reports increased energy and libido. She had two similar episodes that occurred 6 months ago and a year ago, respectively. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the past month because she does not feel hungry. She enjoys her work as a librarian. She drinks two to three glasses of wine per week. Three months ago, she started using MDMA (ecstasy) occasionally at parties. On mental examination, she is alert and oriented to time and place; she appears irritable. She does not have auditory or visual hallucinations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has symptoms of hypomania (e.g., increased energy and libido, decreased need for sleep) and depression (e.g., depressed mood, fatigue, insomnia) but does not fully meet the criteria for a hypomanic episode, a manic episode, or a major depressive episode.

A. Substance-induced bipolar disorder
B. Bipolar disorder with rapid cycling
C. Delusional disorder
D. Schizoaffective disorder
E. Cyclothymic disorder

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 25 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever and right-sided flank pain. During this period, she also had chills, nausea, vomiting, and burning on urination. Her last prenatal visit was 10 weeks ago. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. The abdomen is soft and nontender, and no contractions are felt. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 25-week gestation. Fetal heart rate is 170/min. Laboratory studies show:Blood and urine samples are obtained for culture and drug sensitivity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Costovertebral angle tenderness, burning on urination, fever, and leukocytosis in conjunction with positive nitrite and pyuria on urinalysis are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis.

A. Inpatient treatment with antibiotic therapy after culture results are available
B. Ultrasonography of the kidneys
C. Outpatient treatment with oral ciprofloxacin
D. CT scan of the abdomen with and without contrast
E. Inpatient treatment with intravenous cefotaxime
F. Outpatient treatment with oral fosfomycin

Correct Answer: E

Question

A. Addition of enalapril
B. Addition of chlorpheniramine

Question

Question
A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89–2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1–2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate? A hazard ratio (HR) equal to 1.0 means there is no difference in the long-term VTE risk between the rheumatoid arthritis and control groups.The results of study B are less likely to be accurate than the results of study A.3%
The HR of study B is less likely to be statistically significant than the HR of study A.6%
Study A likely had a larger sample size than study B.7%
The p-value of study A is likely larger than the p-value of study B.77%
The power of study B is likely smaller than the power of study A.7%

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents in June because of continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. His father has noticed that he keeps tugging at his left ear. He was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of the rotavirus, diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV13), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8ºC (100.1ºF); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Question
The height of American adults is expected to follow a normal distribution, with a typical male adult having an average height of 69 inches with a standard deviation of 0.1 inches. An investigator has been informed about a community in the American Midwest with a history of heavy air and water pollution in which a lower mean height has been reported. The investigator plans to sample 30 male residents to test the claim that heights in this town differ significantly from the national average based on heights assumed to be normally distributed. The significance level is set at 10% and the probability of a type 2 error is assumed to be 15%. Based on this information, which of the following is the most accurate estimate of the statistical power of the proposed study? Statistical power is the probability that the study will detect a statistically significant difference between the two experimental groups if one truly exists. The statistical power can be calculated directly using the probability of incorrectly rejecting the alternative hypothesis.0.8581%
0.154%
0.104%
0.907%
0.053%

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 months. The dyspnea occurs on moderate exertion and during the night; he sometimes wakes up coughing and “gasping for air.” He has also had several episodes of heart pounding. Two weeks ago, he had a runny nose and a productive cough. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. He has never smoked. He drinks one to two beers occasionally. He has a history of intravenous illicit drugs use but has not used in over 25 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral basilar rales. Cardiac auscultation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? VIDEOThis patient presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and features of pulmonary congestion (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar rales on auscultation). In combination with a heart murmur, these findings are highly suggestive of left-sided heart failure (LHF) caused by valvular heart disease. The auscultation findings reveal a systolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left intercostal space (ICS), the area of the cardiac apex.

A. Mitral valve regurgitation
B. Pericarditis
C. Tricuspid valve regurgitation
D. Pulmonary valve stenosis
E. Aortic valve regurgitation
F. Mitral valve stenosis
G. Aortic valve stenosis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. D. Diffuse brainstem glioma

Question

Question

A. Reaction formation
B. Suppression
C. Acting out
D. Projection
E. Passive aggression

Question
A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a constant, dull headache and generalized body pains for the past 8 months. She has also had difficulty hearing, which started a month after the onset of the headaches. Five months ago, she had surgery to treat a fracture of the right femur that occurred without a fall or any significant trauma. Five years ago, she underwent total thyroidectomy for localized thyroid carcinoma. She takes levothyroxine and calcium supplements, which she started after menopause. Physical examination reveals a prominent forehead and irregular, tender skull surface. Bony tenderness is present over bilateral hip and knee joints, with decreased range of motion of the right hip joint and increased anterior curvature of both tibias. Laboratory studies show a highly elevated level of alkaline phosphatase, with vitamin D, calcium, and parathyroid hormone levels within normal limits. A plain x-ray of the head is most likely to show which of the following findings? Bone pain and deformity (saber shin), apparent skull enlargement, hearing loss, and a history of a pathological fracture indicate a defect in bone remodeling. Laboratory findings show elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels with other bone-related parameters within normal ranges, suggesting a diagnosis of Paget disease of bone (PDB).

A. Lytic lesions with no sclerotic margin
B. Multiple, well-defined, punched out lytic lesions
C. Mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions
D. Periosteal trabeculations with radiolucent marrow hyperplasia
E. Lobulated lesions with a thin cortex and ground-glass appearance
F. Generalized dense, sclerotic bone

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for periconception counseling. She reports that she has been trying to conceive with her husband for 2 months. She has been in a monogamous relationship for 10 years. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She had chickenpox when she was 16 years old and reports that she is up-to-date on her immunizations. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. She feels well today. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 mIU/mL (N ≤ 5). An HIV antibody/antigen test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A. Recommend iron supplementation
B. Obtain rubella antibody titer
C. Obtain rectal swab for group B streptococcus
D. Screen for chlamydia infection
E. Recommend 5 kg weight loss
F. Perform 1-hour oral glucose challenge test

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 20-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Navy is brought to a military hospital because of a 1-hour history of back pain, inability to urinate, progressive leg weakness, and a burning and prickling sensation in the lower limbs. He is a military diver in training. Four hours before the onset of symptoms, he had taken part in a 3-hour scuba diving exercise to a depth of 30 m (98.4 ft). The dive was uneventful until the patient encountered problems with mask clearing, which led to a rapid ascent. About 1 hour after surfacing, the patient began to feel exceptionally tired and started having headaches. He appears somnolent. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mottling, reticular skin rash. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left leg and 4/5 in the right leg. Sensation to vibration and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has decompression sickness (DCS), which typically occurs within 24 hours after scuba diving and can affect the spinal cord (e.g., back pain, paresis and paresthesias of the lower extremities, bladder dysfunction), brain (e.g., headache, altered mental status), and skin (e.g., cutis marmorata).

A. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy
B. Lumbar decompression surgery
C. Trendelenburg positioning
D. Induced hypothermia
E. Thrombolytic therapy
F. Dexamethasone therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

Question
A multicenter study was performed with 5000 pregnant women to evaluate a new blood test for the prenatal diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Samples were taken at 30 weeks' gestation. 29 participants had positive tests. After birth, a sweat chloride test was obtained in all infants. Of the 29 pregnant women with abnormal blood test findings, 26 had babies with a positive sweat chloride test. Which of the following is required to calculate the specificity of this new blood test? The specificity of a test is the probability that a given test is negative when the disease is absent. Specificity can be calculated using the formula Specificity = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives).

A. Probability that a newborn whose mother had a positive blood test has cystic fibrosis
B. Incidence of cystic fibrosis in the general population
C. Number of mothers with a normal blood test whose newborns do not have cystic fibrosis
D. Prevalence of cystic fibrosis in the general population
E. Probability that a newborn has cystic fibrosis before the sweat chloride test is performed

Correct Answer: C

 ratio), which is typically due to an infranodal block.

Question
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of lower back pain. Three years ago, he was in a motor vehicle collision that caused a lumbar fracture and spinal injury; since then, he has had no sensation in the lower extremities and has to use a wheelchair. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Pulses are palpable in the lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows paraparesis. A photograph of the sacral region is shown. The affected area is not warm but is tender to palpation. His serum C-reactive protein concentration is within the reference range. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The photograph shows a red-purple area of skin over the sacrum with a small amount of superficial (epidermal) skin loss. These findings, in conjunction with this patient's history and clinical presentation, are consistent with a stage 2 decubitus ulcer.

A. Improved blood sugar management
B. Compression therapy
C. Peripheral artery bypass surgery
D. Wound care with hydrocolloid dressings
E. Intravenous antibiotics
F. Surgical debridement

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain, excessive tearing, and blurry vision of his right eye. He first noticed his symptoms last evening while he was watching a movie at a theater. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has atopic dermatitis treated with topical hydrocortisone. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and 20/40 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea with a whitish exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Fluorescein staining shows a round corneal infiltrate. B. Oral acyclovir
C. Topical ofloxacin
D. Topical timolol and pilocarpine
E. Topical prednisolone
F. Topical ganciclovir

Question
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of cough productive of yellowish sputum. He has had fever, chills, and worsening shortness of breath during this time. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. His current medications include atorvastatin, amlodipine, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He appears in mild distress. He has rales over the left lower lung field. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3 (87% segmented neutrophils). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:An x-ray of the chest shows a consolidation in the left lower lobe. Asking the patient to lie down in the left lateral decubitus position would most likely result in which of the following? The dependent portions of the lung are better ventilated and perfused than the nondependent portions. Intrapleural pressure surrounding dependent portions of the lungs is less negative because of an increase of fluid in the pleural cavity. The increased weight of fluid results in reduced expansion and greater compliance of the alveoli compared to nondependent portions of the lung. Increased alveolar compliance leads to more pronounced expansion on inspiration and a subsequent increase in ventilation. Perfusion in the dependent portions of the lung is greater than in nondependent portions, as gravity pulls the blood downward.

A. Increased perfusion of right lung
B. Improved hypoxemia
C. Worsened hypocapnia
D. Decreased ventilation of the left lung
E. Increased A-a gradient

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? B. Bed rest only
C. Analgesia and regular activity
D. MRI of the spine
E. X-ray of the spine

Question
A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-month history of chest pain, mild shortness of breath, and a dry cough. The chest pain is exacerbated by coughing and deep breathing. She is homeless and has not seen a physician in more than 20 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 33 years and drinks 3–4 beers daily. Physical examination shows scleral jaundice, diffuse telangiectasias on the chest, and bilateral pedal edema. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion on the right side. Cardiac examination shows normal heart sounds with no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Based on the findings on CT scan, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The CT scan shows a large, hyperdense area on the right side of the thoracic cavity in a gravity-dependent position, which, in combination with this patient's clinical features (pleuritic chest pain, cough, decreased breath sounds, and dullness to percussion on the right side), is consistent with pleural effusion.

B. Insert a chest tube
C. Obtain a pleural fluid specimen
D. Begin therapeutic anticoagulation
E. Begin broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy
F. Begin diuretic therapy

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

G. Polyomavirus-associated nephropathy

Question

Question
Two hours after undergoing laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, a 44-year-old man has pain at the site of surgery and nausea. He has vomited twice in the past hour. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include insulin, atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, acetaminophen, and prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. He drinks two to three beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 130 kg (286 lb); BMI is 42 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination shows five laparoscopic incisions with no erythema or discharge. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is mild diffuse tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are reduced. Laboratory studies show:Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acid-base status? This patient's arterial blood gas analysis indicates metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.35, bicarbonate < 22) with respiratory compensation (pCO2 < 35 mm Hg). His high anion gap (136 mEq/l - (98 mEq/L + 14.4 mEq/L) = 23.6 mEq/L) suggests the accumulation of an unmeasured organic anion.

A. Blind loop syndrome
B. Diabetic ketoacidosis
C. Alcohol withdrawal
D. Vomiting
E. Dumping syndrome
F. Hypoxia

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of headache, dizziness, trouble sleeping, and worsening nausea. She also reports abdominal pain and a tremor in both hands during this period. She has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease treated with daily tiotropium, formoterol, budesonide, and theophylline, and she uses an albuterol inhaler as needed. She has a history of depression treated with fluoxetine. One week ago, she was started on cimetidine for gastroesophageal reflux disease. She smoked 1½ packs of cigarettes daily for 36 years but quit 2 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. She appears drowsy. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 86/54 mm Hg. Cardiac examination discloses no rubs or murmurs. There is no wheezing heard on auscultation. The pupils are 4 mm and reactive to light. Neurologic examination shows a resting tremor of both hands. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ and symmetric. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient's condition can also cause tachyarrhythmias and metabolic disturbances (e.g., hypokalemia, hyperglycemia, metabolic acidosis).

A. Excess serotonergic activation
B. Increased anticholinergic activity
C. Decreased theophylline clearance
D. Excess activation of thyroid hormone receptors
E. Carbon dioxide retention

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in his left groin for the past hour. The pain began soon after he returned from a walk. He describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity and he vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had a swelling of the left groin for the past 2 months. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypertension. Current medications include amlodipine, an albuterol inhaler, and a salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender bulge on the left side above the inguinal ligament that extends into the left scrotum; lying down does not reduce the swelling. Coughing does not make the swelling bulge further. The skin overlying the bulge is warm and erythematous. The abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Scattered rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's 2-month history of left groin swelling suggests an inguinal hernia, for which chronic cough (a symptom of COPD) is a risk factor. Acute onset of severe groin pain, vomiting, an inguinal bulge with overlying erythema and warmth, and a distended abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds indicate acute hernia strangulation with concurrent bowel obstruction.

A. Surgical drainage
B. Antibiotic therapy
C. Taxis under general anesthesia
D. Open surgical repair
E. Surgical exploration of the testicle
F. Laparoscopic surgical repair

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasing shortness of breath on exertion, dry cough, and fatigue. He has not had any fevers or night sweats. He worked in a glass manufacturing factory for 15 years and retired 2 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows well-defined calcification of the rims of hilar lymph nodes and scattered nodules in both upper lung fields. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following complications? In patients who worked as glass-factory workers, clinical features of interstitial lung disease (e.g., progressive dyspnea, dry cough, fatigue, fine crackles) with calcification of the rims of hilar lymph nodes (eggshell calcification) and predominant involvement of the upper lobes suggest silicosis.

A. Malignant mesothelioma
B. Invasive aspergillosis
C. Pneumocystis pneumonia
D. Spontaneous pneumothorax
E. Pulmonary embolism
F. Pulmonary tuberculosis

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough for the past 4 days. During this period, he has had shortness of breath and chest pain that is worse on inspiration. He also reports fatigue and nausea. He has refractory schizophrenia and recurrent asthma attacks. He used to attend college but was expelled after threatening to harm one of his professors 2 months ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Crackles and bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the left lung. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking? Other side effects of this drug include seizures (dose-dependent risk) and myocarditis.

A. Clozapine
B. Olanzapine
C. Haloperidol
D. Risperidone
E. Chlorpromazine
F. Quetiapine

Correct Answer: A

Question
Two days after undergoing outpatient percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement in the right coronary artery, a 60-year-old woman has left-sided painful facial swelling. The pain is worse when chewing. The patient has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and a multivitamin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left parotid gland as well as oral erythema with scant purulent discharge upon parotid gland massage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This condition is generally precipitated by a reduction in the flow of saliva (e.g., in postoperative patients).

A. Perform salivary duct dilation
B. Perform parotidectomy
C. Obtain a parotid biopsy
D. Administer nafcillin and metronidazole
E. Perform incision and drainage
F. Administer vancomycin and meropenem

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive weakness in his upper extremities over the past 7 months. He initially noticed difficulty writing but now has difficulty performing his activities of daily living. He currently lives with his son. He has no personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in the upper extremities and normal in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the upper extremities, 4+ in the right lower extremity, and 2+ in the left lower extremity. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration is intact in all extremities. On mental status examination, he is cooperative with a mildly anxious mood and a neutral affect. His speech is slightly slurred and hypernasal. Needle electromyography shows spontaneous fasciculation potentials in multiple muscles, fibrillations, and positive sharp wave potentials. Spirometry shows an FVC of 85% of predicted. A diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is made and treatment with riluzole is initiated. After discussion with the patient and his son, a decision to transfer the patient to hospice care is made. Before transferring the patient to hospice care, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with features of bulbar palsy (e.g., tongue atrophy and fasciculations, dysarthria, hypernasal speech) as a manifestation of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Bulbar palsy can cause a symptom that increases the morbidity of patients with ALS and should therefore be assessed.

A. Initiate noninvasive ventilation
B. Perform genetic testing
C. Initiate amitriptyline therapy
D. Perform a bedside swallowing test
E. Perform percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy

Correct Answer: D

Question
An otherwise healthy 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter because of a 1-day history of a diffuse headache and an inability to understand speech. There is no history of head trauma. He drinks 1–2 beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. His vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows fluent but meaningless speech and an inability to repeat sentences. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows an acute hemorrhage in the left temporal lobe and several small old hemorrhages in bilateral occipital lobes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's neurological symptoms? This elderly man presents with a spontaneous superficial intracerebral hemorrhage (i.e., a cortical lobar hemorrhage affecting the temporal lobe), which is most commonly caused by the deposition of a congophilic substance in the cortical blood vessels.

A. Vascular lipohyalinosis
B. Ruptured vascular malformation
C. Hypertensive encephalopathy
D. Intracerebral malignancy
E. Cardiac embolism
F. Amyloid angiopathy

Correct Answer: F

Question
A new assay for Lyme disease has been developed. While the assay has been tested extensively in Maine, a group of investigators is planning to test it in Southern California. In comparison to the assay's performance in Maine, testing the assay in Southern California would affect the performance of the assay in which of the following ways? Lyme disease primarily occurs in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US; its prevalence is much lower in Southern California than in Maine. Prevalence (pretest probability) affects posttest probabilities, i.e., negative predictive value (NPV) and positive predictive value (PPV).

A. Decreased negative likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
B. Lower likelihood that a patient without Lyme disease truly has a negative test
C. Greater likelihood that an individual with a positive test will truly have Lyme disease
D. Decreased positive likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
E. Lower likelihood that a patient with Lyme disease will truly have a positive test
F. Greater likelihood that an individual with a negative test will truly not have Lyme disease

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 4-week-old infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of blood-tinged stools for 3 days. He has also been passing whitish mucoid strings with the stools during this period. He was delivered at 38 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. He was monitored in the intensive care unit for a day prior to being discharged. His 6-year-old brother was treated for viral gastroenteritis 1 week ago. The patient is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. He appears healthy and active. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. A stool test for occult blood is positive. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The presence of blood-tinged stools in an otherwise active and healthy infant raises concern for food protein-induced proctocolitis.

A. Perform an upper gastrointestinal series
B. Assess for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies
C. Continue breastfeeding and advise mother to avoid dairy and soy products
D. Perform stool antigen immunoassay
E. Stop breastfeeding and switch to soy-based formula
F. Administer broad-spectrum parenteral antibiotics
G. Perform an air enema on the infant

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. Initially, the vomitus was food that he had recently eaten, but it is now bilious. He has had similar symptoms several times in the past 6 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years and drinks 18 oz of whiskey daily. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 48 kg (105 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an epigastric mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient presents with recurrent abdominal pain, vomiting, and a palpable epigastric mass, while his vital signs and physical examination are otherwise unremarkable. His history of alcohol use suggests an underlying condition that is often caused by chronic alcohol use.

A. Chronic cholecystitis
B. Retroperitoneal fibrosis
C. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
D. Pancreatic pseudocyst
E. Gastric adenocarcinoma

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 17-year-old girl comes to the urgent care center after testing negative for HIV. She recently had sexual intercourse for the first time and had used a condom with her long-term boyfriend. She has no personal history of serious illness and no history of sexually transmitted infections. However, the patient is still worried about the possibility she has HIV despite the negative HIV test. She states that the package insert of the HIV test shows that of 100 patients who are found to be HIV-positive on PCR, 91 tested positive via the HIV test. Later in the day, a 23-year-old woman with a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection also comes to the urgent care center after testing negative for HIV. She states that she recently had unprotected intercourse with “someone who might have HIV.” If the test is conducted on the 23-year-old patient, how will its performance compare to the test conducted on the 17-year-old patient? Given her sexual history (previous sexually transmitted infections, unprotected sexual intercourse with a partner who might have HIV), the 23-year-old patient has a higher pretest probability compared to the 17-year-old patient.

A. Increased sensitivity
B. Increased validity
C. Increased specificity
D. Decreased positive predictive value
E. Decreased negative predictive value

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 28-year-old woman with bronchial asthma comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a progressively worsening cough. Initially, the cough occurred 3 or 4 days per week and was nonproductive. Over the past month, the cough has been occurring daily and is accompanied by thick brown sputum that is occasionally blood-tinged. Until 4 months ago, her only medications were inhaled albuterol as needed and daily low-dose inhaled budesonide; 2 months ago, treatment with daily inhaled formoterol was initiated. She does not smoke. She has not traveled recently. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 128/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Chest auscultation shows scattered expiratory wheezing in both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows linear opacities in both upper lobes and thickened airways with irregular cystic opacities primarily near the hilar region. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 75% and a FEV1 of 70% of predicted. A tuberculin skin test shows an induration of 3 mm. In addition to the continued use of inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient? An antigen skin test for Aspergillus in this patient would be positive.

A. Oral prednisone and itraconazole therapy
B. Oral rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol therapy
C. Oral prednisone and montelukast sodium therapy
D. Intravenous methylprednisolone, oral cyclophosphamide and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole therapy
E. Oral ivermectin therapy
F. Oral prednisone and azithromycin therapy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient describes his stool as soft and voluminous but not bloody. He has not had a fever. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. He lives alone and has 3 pet cats. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks two beers daily. Current medications include lisinopril and simvastatin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and diffuse abdominal tenderness. A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism? The photomicrograph shows an oval-shaped cyst with a prominent double-layered wall.

A. Campylobacter species
B. Giardia lamblia
C. Toxoplasma gondii
D. Trichomonas species
E. Entamoeba histolytica
F. Tropheryma whipplei
G. Enterobius vermicularis
H. Shigella dysenteriae

Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of lethargy, confusion, and nausea for the past 2 days. His past medical history is unremarkable. His only medications are a daily multivitamin and acetaminophen, which he takes daily for hip pain that started 2 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is disoriented to place and time but recognizes his wife. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.1 g/dL, a serum calcium concentration of 14.7 mg/dL, and a serum creatinine concentration of 2.2 mg/dL. According to the patient's medical records, the results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes and creatinine, performed 5 months ago were within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition? This patient has severe hypercalcemia, manifesting with lethargy, confusion, and nausea. The development of hypercalcemia, anemia, renal dysfunction (as indicated by the increased serum creatinine concentration), and bone pain (hip pain) over a relatively short period of time (laboratory studies were normal 5 months ago) raises concern for a malignant etiology.

A. Decreased excretion of calcium from renal tubular cells
B. Excessive intake of calcium
C. Increased production of calcitriol
D. Increased secretion of PTH from parathyroid chief cells
E. Release of osteoclast activating factors from malignant plasma cells
F. Release of PTH-related protein from malignant renal cells

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm for 1 day. The rash started as small papules, then progressed into blisters with oozing. He has had atopic dermatitis since the age of 6 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. This patient's symptoms are likely the result of a T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

A. Antibiotics
B. Cats
C. Bees
D. Plants
E. Sun
F. Gluten

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 53-year-old man comes to the emergency department for severe left knee pain for the past 8 hours. He describes it as an unbearable, burning pain that woke him up from his sleep. He has been unable to walk since. He has not had any trauma to the knee. Ten months ago, he had an episode of acute pain and swelling of the right big toe that improved with analgesics. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, psoriasis, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include topical betamethasone, metformin, glipizide, losartan, and simvastatin. Two weeks ago, hydrochlorothiazide was added to his medication regimen to improve blood pressure control. He drinks 1–2 beers daily. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 110 kg (242 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Examination shows multiple scaly plaques over his palms and soles. The left knee is erythematous, swollen, and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. In addition to administering analgesics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with a history of podagra in addition to multiple risk factors for gout (obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, psoriasis, thiazide use, and alcohol use). His acutely inflamed knee is most likely the result of an acute gout flare.

A. Obtain blood cultures
B. Measure serum uric acid levels
C. Perform arthrocentesis of the knee
D. Measure serum anticitrullinated peptide antibodies
E. Obtain x-ray of the knee

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 41-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She recently moved to the area. She feels well. She has dyslipidemia treated with pravastatin. Her past three Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 2 years ago. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 56 years, and her brother died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 51 years. The patient smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 10 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 68/min and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time? This patient's dyslipidemia and obesity put her at risk of developing a chronic medical condition that can cause microvascular damage.

A. Obtain Pap smear
B. Measure fasting blood glucose concentration
C. Perform abdominal ultrasonography
D. Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest
E. Perform breast ultrasonography
F. Administer pneumococcal vaccine

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 28-year-old female is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious outside of a local nightclub by her friends. On arrival the patient is stuporous. Her temperature is 35.0°C (95.0°F), pulse is 55/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 105/75 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. The pupils are 1 mm and react sluggishly to light. She does not respond to any commands, and painful stimuli cause her to withdraw all extremities. No injection marks can be found on her extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms? The same drug can often be consumed in several ways.

A. Amitriptyline
B. Phencyclidine
C. MDMA
D. Heroin
E. Cannabis

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for contraceptive counseling. The patient's mother has already discussed different contraceptive options with her. The mother says, “Most teenagers her age are already engaging in sexual intercourse, so it's about time my daughter got protection. She has plans to go to college and cannot have a baby at this point.” The patient has no history of serious illness. She feels well but appears uncomfortable during the conversation. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician asks the mother to leave the room for the patient's privacy. After the physician initiates a conversation about contraception, the patient reveals that she wants to start engaging in sexual activity with her girlfriend. The patient has not been sexually active before. She says that she is afraid to tell her parents because they oppose same-sex relationships. Which of the following is the most appropriate next action by the physician? Adolescents should be counseled on the prevention of sexually transmitted infections, pregnancy, and substance use, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

A. Recommend an oral contraceptive
B. Ask the mother's permission to educate the patient about safer sex practices
C. Tell the patient to disclose her sexual orientation to her mother
D. Screen for chlamydia and gonorrhea infection
E. Recommend HPV vaccination

Correct Answer: E

Question
An epidemiologist is interested in studying the clinical utility of a free computerized social skills training program for children with autism. A total of 125 participants with autism and mean age of 12 years were recruited for the study and took part in weekly social skills training sessions for 3 months. Participants were recruited from support groups in a large US city for parents with autistic children. Parents in the support group were very eager to volunteer for the study, and over 300 children were placed on a waiting list while the study was conducted. At baseline and at the end of the 3-month period, participants were observed during a videotaped social play exercise and scored on a social interaction rating scale by their parents. Social interaction rating scores following the 3-month intervention were more than twice as high as baseline scores (p < 0.001). During exit interviews, one parent commented, "I knew from the start that this program was going to be life-changing for my son!" This sentiment was echoed by a number of other parents. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the study's result? Performance was rated by the participants' parents, who had high expectations of this study. This may have influenced the positive outcome of the study.

A. Social desirability bias
B. Recall bias
C. Hawthorne effect
D. Observer bias
E. Sampling bias
F. Confounding bias

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for 12 hours. The pain extends from the epigastrium to the right upper quadrant and radiates to the right scapula. The patient has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She underwent total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma 3 years ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. She is a farmer and spends most days working outside. Current medications include levothyroxine, omeprazole, and a multivitamin. The patient appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to deep palpation in the right upper quadrant. Her leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3. Abdominal ultrasonography shows thickening of the gallbladder wall, without dilatation of the intra- or extrahepatic bile ducts. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is performed. Pathological examination of the resected specimen shows acute cholecystitis. There is a black, ulcerated 1 x 1.5-cm mass in the fundus of the gallbladder with invasion of the gallbladder wall and adjacent lymphatic vessels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition? The presence of a black and ulcerated gallbladder mass with invasion of the gallbladder wall and lymphatics suggests malignancy. UV exposure (e.g., from agricultural work) is the primary risk factor for the underlying cause.

A. Adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon
B. Cutaneous malignant melanoma
C. Recurrence of papillary thyroid carcinoma
D. Multiple endocrine neoplasia
E. Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting for 6 hours. He has not had bowel movements in the past 24 hours. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F) and pulse is 122/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen; guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Bowel sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. He has been accompanied by his 14-year-old brother. The surgeon recommends an emergency laparotomy. The parents are away visiting friends and cannot be reached. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's condition is considered a surgical emergency.

A. Get consent from the patient's brother
B. Get consent from the patient
C. Obtain a court order for surgery
D. Schedule hospital ethics consult
E. Perform emergency laparotomy
F. Delay surgery until parental consent

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose. The lesion has gradually increased in size since it first appeared 11 months ago. He is a farmer and lives together with his wife. His mother died of metastatic melanoma at the age of 67 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks 1–2 glasses of whiskey on weekends. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. A. Amelanotic melanoma
B. Molluscum contagiosum
C. Keratoacanthoma
D. Trichoepithelioma
E. Basal cell carcinoma
F. Squamous cell carcinoma
G. Actinic keratosis

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of loose stools. He has 2–3 episodes of loose stools a day that are occasionally bloody. During this period, he has also had crampy abdominal pain, generalized fatigue, and a 2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows mild lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,400/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 14 mm/h. Test of the stool for ova and parasites is negative. A colonoscopy shows a friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact with the endoscope. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. B. Proctocolectomy
