Question
A 25-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit 6 weeks after a positive home pregnancy test. During this period she has experienced mild nausea, but otherwise feels well and has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medications are prenatal supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a fundal height of 16 cm. Fetal ultrasonography shows two fetuses that are both consistent in size with a 15-week gestation. There is a single placental mass; no intertwin membrane is visible. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. The abdominal ultrasound is shown. Based on these findings, which of the following complications is most likely to occur during the patient's current pregnancy? 

A. The ultrasound image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twin pregnancy, in which the fetuses share a single placenta and a single amniotic sacAmniotic band sequence
B. Intertwin amniotic fluid discordance
C. Spontaneous fetomaternal bleeding
D. Umbilical cord entanglement
E. Precipitous labor

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and excessive thirst. During this period, she has not been able to sleep through the night because of the frequent urge to urinate. She also urinates more than usual during the day. She drinks 4–5 liters of water and 1–2 beers daily. She has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, hypertension treated with lisinopril, and bipolar disorder. Therapy with valproic acid was begun after a manic episode 3 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Irregular flank masses are palpated bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:The urine osmolality does not change after 3 hours despite no fluid intake or after administration of desmopressin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient with a history of renal disease presents with polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, mild hypernatremia, a high serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In combination with the absent response to fluid restriction and desmopressin administration, these features suggest nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

A. Metformin therapy
B. Further water restriction
C. Amiloride therapy
D. Chlorpropamide therapy
E. Discontinue valproic acid
F. Begin infusion of 3% saline
G. Hydrochlorothiazide therapy
H. Desmopressin therapy

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of pain and redness of both eyes. He has new blurry vision and difficulty opening his eyes in bright surroundings. He has not had any recent trauma. He uses contact lenses daily. He had surgery on his left eye 6 months ago after a penetrative trauma caused by a splinter. His vital signs are within normal limits. B. Autoimmune reaction against retinal antigens

D. Impaired drainage of aqueous humor

Question
A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening dyspnea. During this time, he also has had intermittent episodes of chest pain, which was 4/10 in intensity and increased on inspiration. He does triathlons and has not been able to train because of these symptoms. He has had no fever or syncopal episodes. He had an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago. His father died of heart disease at the age of 55 years. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 113/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. Inspiratory crackles are heard throughout the lung fields. On cardiac examination, an S3 gallop is heard. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette and prominent vascular markings in both lung fields. ECG shows diffuse T-wave inversions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Dyspnea, jugular venous distention, tachycardia, an S3 gallop, inspiratory crackles, and x-ray findings of pulmonary congestion (e.g., increased vascular markings, cardiac enlargement) are consistent with decompensated heart failure (HF). In this young and otherwise healthy patient with a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection and chest pain that increases during inspiration (indicating pericardial involvement), HF is most likely secondary to viral myocarditis.

B. Pericardial tamponade
C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
D. Aortic valve stenosis
E. Mitral valve stenosis
F. Dilated cardiomyopathy
G. Bacterial endocarditis

Correct Answer: F

Question
Twelve hours after undergoing urgent angioplasty via arterial catheterization of the left femoral artery for critical ischemia of the left leg, a 69-year-old woman has a painful mass in the left groin. She has peripheral artery disease, coronary artery disease, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Current medications include enalapril, aspirin, rivaroxaban, simvastatin, metformin, and sitagliptin. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. Examination shows a 4-cm (1.6-in) tender, pulsatile mass in the left groin. The skin over the mass shows mild ecchymosis but no erythema. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation over this area. Examination of the lower extremities shows no peripheral edema or pulse deficit. Sensation is intact. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations, are within normal limits. Duplex ultrasonography shows an inhomogeneous hypoechoic sac connected to the left common femoral artery, with pulsatile and turbulent bidirectional blood flow between the artery and the sac. The femoral vein does not communicate with the hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A postinterventional pulsatile groin mass with a bruit on auscultation, together with ultrasound findings of a hypoechoic sac connected to the femoral artery, is in keeping with a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm. The treatment thereof is determined according to the aneurysm size (more or less than 3 cm) and the presence of complications (e.g., hemodynamic instability, limb ischemia, skin necrosis, infection, rapid hematoma expansion).

A. Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection
B. Ultrasound-guided compression
C. Observation and serial imaging
D. Open surgical repair
E. Covered stent implantation

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms? Dilation of the ventricles and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), such as vomiting, papilledema, and irritability, indicate hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus in a 3-year-old child with a mass in the 4th ventricle suggests an ependymoma.

A. Cerebrospinal fluid overproduction
B. Edema of brain parenchyma
C. Closed foramen of Magendie
D. Impaired reabsorption of cerebrospinal fluid
E. Cerebrospinal fluid outflow obstruction

Correct Answer: E

Question
In a private conversation, physician A discloses to physician B that he sometimes leaves the hospital during working hours to go to the mall for personal errands. Physician A claims that he is “doing nothing wrong” as he only leaves when there are just a few patients in the ward. He says that “the nurses don't mind” because he "always brings some donuts back for them." When physician B confronts him about the situation, physician A insists that “nothing bad has ever happened” and “the nurses have everything under control.” A few days later, physician B sees physician A returning to the hospital in the middle of a shift with several bags from the shopping mall. Physician A's actions are best described by which of the following terms? Physician A's behavior violates the ethical principles of nonmaleficence and beneficence.

A. Malpractice
B. Misconduct
C. Slip
D. Mistake
E. Lapse

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent nose bleeds that occur with light trauma or at random times during the day. Over the past 6 months, the patient has felt weak and fatigued and has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. He has poor appetite and abdominal discomfort. He does not have night sweats. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. The spleen is palpated 10 cm below the left costal margin. Multiple bruises are noted on both upper extremities. Laboratory studies show.A peripheral blood smear detects tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient? Peripheral blood smear in this patient would also show abnormally large WBCs with centrally placed nuclei and multiple fine, radial, hair-like cytoplasmic projections, indicating hairy cell leukemia.

A. Transfusion of packed red blood cells
B. Cyclophosphamide
C. Transfusion of platelets
D. Rituximab
E. Melphalan
F. Cladribine

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of nausea, vomiting, headache, and light-headedness. Over the past month, he has also had increased thirst and frequent urination. He has a history of celiac disease and follows a gluten-free and vegetarian diet. His brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. His medications include occasional ibuprofen for headaches. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (179 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's current symptoms? This patient has hypotonic hyponatremia and nonspecific symptoms of sodium imbalance (e.g., nausea, vomiting, headache). Had he undergone a water deprivation test, his urine osmolality would have risen to normal levels.

A. Decreased pituitary secretion of antidiuretic hormone
B. Osmotic diuresis
C. Impaired renal response to antidiuretic hormone
D. Low dietary solute intake
E. Excess water intake

Correct Answer: E

Question
An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of decreased vision in his right eye. He has no pain in the eye and has never had a similar episode in the past. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and open-angle glaucoma. He does not smoke and occasionally drinks 1–2 glasses of wine. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, lisinopril, and topical latanoprost. His temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 68/min and regular, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. The direct pupillary reflex is brisk in the left eye but absent in the right eye. Applanation tonometry shows an intraocular pressure of 20 mm Hg in the right eye and 18 mm Hg in the left eye (N = 10–21). Fundoscopy of the right eye shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Fundoscopy shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in all four retinal quadrants (blood and thunder appearance), tortuous dilated veins, papilledema, and cotton wool spots. In conjunction with sudden painless loss of vision and an afferent pupillary defect, these findings suggest ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Risk factors for this condition include older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and glaucoma.

A. Digital ocular massage, sublingual nitroglycerin, and hyperbaric oxygen therapy
B. Emergency retinal tamponade
C. Topical pilocarpine and systemic acetazolamide therapy
D. Fluorescein angiography
E. Ocular ultrasonography
F. MRI of the head

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Facial muscle paralysis (lagophthalmos of the left eye, drooping of the left corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.

A. Reassurance
B. Corticosteroid therapy
C. Surgical repair
D. Acyclovir therapy
E. Surgical decompression

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 63-year-old man with non-Hodgkin lymphoma is brought to the emergency department because of fever and confusion that have progressively worsened over the past 3 days. He also has a 3-day history of loose stools. He returned from France 2 weeks ago where he stayed in the countryside and ate typical French cuisine, including frog, snail, and various homemade cheeses. His last chemotherapy cycle was 3 weeks ago. He is oriented to person but not to place or time. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is involuntary flexion of the bilateral hips and knees with passive flexion of the neck. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:Blood cultures are drawn and the patient is started on empiric therapy. A CT scan of the head shows enhancement of the arachnoid and pia mater. A lumbar puncture is performed. The results of blood cultures and lumbar puncture are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric pharmacotherapy for this patient? This patient presents with findings suggestive of meningitis: fever, confusion, and Brudzinski sign. The history of immunosuppression and consumption of homemade cheeses should raise suspicion of Listeria monocytogenes as a possible causative organism.

A. Vancomycin and cefotaxime
B. Ampicillin and gentamicin
C. Vancomycin, cefotaxime, and dexamethasone
D. Ampicillin and cefotaxime
E. Ampicillin, gentamicin, and dexamethasone
F. Ampicillin, cefotaxime, and dexamethasone
G. Acyclovir
H. Vancomycin, ampicillin, and cefepime

Correct Answer: H

Question
A previously healthy 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic abdominal pain. During this time, he has been more tired than usual. For the past 2 months, he has also had bulky stools that are difficult to flush. His maternal aunt has systemic lupus erythematosus. The boy is at the 31st percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows scattered ecchymoses across bilateral knees, the left forearm, and the upper back. The abdomen is mildly distended; bowel sounds are hyperactive. Laboratory studies show:Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? Failure to thrive, steatorrhea, iron deficiency anemia, and ecchymoses with prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) raise concern for malabsorption syndrome, which can result in deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K). His prolonged PTT and PT but normal bleeding time suggest an abnormality in secondary hemostasis.

A. Deficiency of clotting factor VIII
B. Increased activity of protein S
C. Increased serum anti-phospholipid antibodies
D. Impaired synthesis of von Willebrand factor
E. Deficiency of clotting factor II
F. Impaired platelet-to-platelet aggregation

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 37-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, comes to the physician for evaluation of urinary incontinence. She emigrated from Ethiopia with her family 6 months ago. She has had intermittent, painless involuntary urine leakage for many years. Her urinary incontinence worsened following the delivery of her last child. She describes the birth as having been “very difficult.” She says that she does not feel that her bladder is full. Since her early 20s, she has had multiple episodes of vaginal infections for which she received over-the-counter antibiotics. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Her older sister and mother had urinary incontinence starting in their mid-30s. The patient is currently not sexually active. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Pelvic examination discloses a nontender scar in the anterior portion of the vagina. A double dye test shows pooling of dyed fluid in the vagina. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for this patient's condition? This patient's history of multiple vaginal infections, persistent urinary incontinence that worsened after a difficult delivery, a scar on the anterior vaginal wall, and a positive double dye test are consistent with a vesicovaginal fistula.

A. Family history
B. Pelvic inflammatory disease
C. Multiparity
D. Obesity
E. Diabetes mellitus
F. Obstructed labor

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. On admission, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 80% effaced; the vertex is at -2 station. Cardiotocography shows contractions every 6 minutes and a reassuring fetal heart rate. Two hours later, the cervix is 10 cm dilated and 100% effaced; the vertex is at 0 station with the occiput in the anterior position. Over the next three hours, there is minimal fetal descent; the vertex is still at 0 station. The patient has regular, rhythmic uterine contractions that occur every 3 minutes with adequate pressure. Fetal heart rate is 150/min; there are no decelerations. The patient is coping well with the pain; epidural anesthesia was not administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Arrest of fetal descent for > 2 hours in multiparous patients (or > 3 hours in those who have received an epidural) is consistent with prolonged second stage of labor. Action should be taken to prevent complications (e.g., postpartum hemorrhage, poor neonatal outcome).

A. Observation for another hour
B. External cephalic version
C. Lateral positioning of the mother
D. Augmentation with oxytocin
E. Operative vaginal delivery

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of fever, chills, abdominal pain, and profuse nonbloody diarrhea. Her symptoms began 1 week ago when she had several days of low-grade fever and constipation. She returned from Indonesia 2 weeks ago, where she spent the summer with her grandparents. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.8°F). Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness and mild hepatosplenomegaly. There is a faint salmon-colored maculopapular rash on her trunk and abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism? This patient's illness may have been prevented with an intramuscular Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine.

A. Giardia lamblia
B. Yersinia enterocolitica
C. Schistosoma mansoni
D. Entamoeba histolytica
E. Escherichia coli
F. Clostridioides difficile
G. Cryptosporidium parvum
H. Campylobacter jejuni
. Shigella dysenteriae
. Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi
. Clostridium perfringens
. Vibrio cholerae

Correct Answer: J

Question
A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of noisy breathing. Her parents state that her breathing has become progressively louder during this time. It is worse when she is lying on her back, feeding, and crying, and it improves when she is placed on her abdomen. Her mother also mentions that the girl has been regurgitating milk more than usual for the past few weeks. She was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her diet consists exclusively of formula milk. She is at the 65th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination discloses inspiratory stridor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? In infants who are otherwise healthy, this condition is typically self-limited.

A. Vascular ring
B. Food allergy
C. Laryngomalacia
D. Croup
E. Foreign body aspiration
F. Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening abdominal pain over the last 3 months. He has also had recent feelings of sadness and a lack of motivation at work, where he is employed as a computer programmer. He denies suicidal thoughts. He has a history of multiple kidney stones. He has a family history of thyroid cancer in his father and uncle, who both underwent thyroidectomy before 30 years of age. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an obese, diffusely tender abdomen but is otherwise unremarkable. Serum studies show:Genetic testing shows a mutation in the RET gene. The physician refers him to an endocrine surgeon. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has primary hyperparathyroidism, which can cause abdominal pain, depressed mood, kidney stones, and increased calcium and parathyroid hormone concentrations. This condition, in combination with young age at presentation and a family history of thyroid cancer, raises suspicion for an underlying diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A), which is confirmed by the detection of a mutation of the RET gene.

A. Thyroidectomy
B. Parathyroidectomy
C. Measurement of urine metanephrine concentrations
D. Measurement of urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration
E. Measurement of midnight salivary cortisol concentration
F. Measurement of serum gastrin concentration

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of progressive right upper quadrant pain, nausea, fever, and yellowing of the eyes and skin. He has no family history of serious illness. He has a 4-year history of intravenous heroin use and shares needles. His immunization history is unknown. Six months ago, he was screened for hepatitis B infection during a routine health maintenance visit. The results of the screening test were negative for anti-HBc antibodies and HBsAg. He refused hepatitis B vaccination at the time. He appears ill. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 109/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:Further workup including serological studies and a quantitative polymerase chain reaction indicates infection with the hepatitis B virus. Which of the following set of serological findings is most likely to have been reported on diagnostic evaluation? Negative HBsAg and negative anti-HBc antibody 6 months ago indicate that this patient recently became infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV) and now presents with features of acute viral hepatitis (fever, hyperbilirubinemia, severe transaminitis) and acute hepatic failure (elevated PT/INR). HBV infection has an incubation period of 1–6 months.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the oncologist for a follow-up examination 6 months after he underwent uncomplicated operative resection of the right colon and adjuvant chemotherapy for stage II colon cancer. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril, atorvastatin, and a daily multivitamin. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-healed surgical scar on the right abdomen. Results of laboratory studies, including carcinoembryonic antigen levels, are within the reference ranges. The patient reports that he generally feels fine and asks if the blood tests he undergoes during monthly visits to his primary care physician (PCP) are necessary. While reviewing the patient's electronic health record (EHR), the physician notices that the PCP has been ordering monthly complete blood counts and serum ferritin tests since the cancer diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician? This action is necessary to avoid health care fragmentation.

A. Report the PCP to the state medical licensing board
B. Use the patient’s EHR to ask the PCP to stop ordering the tests
C. Contact the PCP directly and ask about the monthly tests
D. Assure the patient that the tests are indicated
E. Ask the patient to discuss the need for the tests with the PCP

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of a painless ulcer on his neck. He reports that the ulcer bleeds when lightly touched and that the application of an over-the-counter ointment has not helped it heal. He has a history of Crohn disease that is well controlled with azathioprine. He works as a landscaper in a botanical garden. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and does not drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 1-cm ulcer on the right lateral aspect of his neck. The edges of the ulcer are everted, the floor is covered with granulation tissue, and the surrounding skin is indurated. A biopsy of the ulcer shows dysplastic keratinocytes with pearls of keratin. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition? A chronic nonhealing ulcer with everted edges, granulation tissue covering its base, and surrounding induration are suggestive of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC). Biopsy findings of dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls confirm the diagnosis.

A. Advanced age
B. Immunosuppression
C. Chronic inflammation
D. UV-light exposure
E. Light skin
F. Ionizing radiation

Correct Answer: D

Question
A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of a rash and swelling on his left lower leg. His mother says the boy complained of an insect bite while playing outdoors 3 days before the onset of the lesion. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height and the 85th percentile for weight. He has no known allergies. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mm Hg. The lower left leg is swollen and tender with sharply demarcated erythema. There is also a narrow red line with a raised border that extends from the lower leg to the groin. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings? The narrow red line on this patient's leg suggests lymphangitis, which, in conjunction with classic signs of inflammation (swelling, tenderness), systemic symptoms (e.g., fever), and sharply demarcated erythema of the lower leg, raises suspicion for erysipelas.

A. Clostridium perfringens infection
B. Staphylococcus aureus infection
C. Staphylococcus epidermidis infection
D. Sporothrix schenckii infection
E. Contact dermatitis
F. Vasculitis
G. Streptococcus pyogenes infection

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has been feeling very stressed over the past several months. She is constantly worried and feels more tired than usual. She works at an accountant's office and reports difficulty concentrating on her work. The patient has been working longer shifts because one of her coworkers is on vacation. She is married and frequently fights with her husband. In order to deal with her stress, she goes shopping, during which time she steals small trivial items and feels immediately relieved. She discards the objects she steals and has feelings of shame and guilt about her actions. Her husband is concerned about her behavior, but she is unable to stop shoplifting. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She reports feeling anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with recurrent inability to resist impulses to steal objects that are not needed for personal use. She also has increasing internal tension before committing the theft and relief at the time of theft, followed by feelings of guilt. These features are suggestive of kleptomania according to the DSM-5.

A. Administration of lithium
B. Interpersonal therapy
C. Administration of clozapine
D. Dialectical behavioral therapy
E. Psychodynamic psychotherapy
F. Administration of fluoxetine
G. Cognitive behavioral therapy
H. Motivational interviewing

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 15 years ago. He was taking triple antiretroviral therapy but stopped a few months ago because he was feeling well. He lives in Wyoming. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 47/mm3. The patient currently refuses to restart antiretroviral therapy. Which of the following medication regimens is most appropriate at this time? In individuals with HIV, preventing opportunistic infections involves the optimization of antiretroviral therapy (the most effective measure) and, depending on the CD4+ T-lymphocyte count, antimicrobial prophylaxis for various pathogens. This patient is severely immunocompromised and refuses combined antiretroviral therapy (cART). His risk of developing pneumocystis pneumonia, toxoplasmosis, and Mycobacterium avium complex-related diseases is now significantly higher.

A. Dapsone, pyrimethamine, azithromycin
B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
C. Azithromycin and itraconazole
D. Azithromycin and amphotericin B
E. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and azithromycin
F. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and itraconazole
G. Dapsone, pyrimethamine, itraconazole, azithromycin

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a fall associated with a 6-month history of increasing difficulty walking. Over the last year, his friends have also noticed his speech becoming slower. During this period, he also gave up his hobby of playing video games because he has become clumsy with his hands. His father died of esophageal varices at the age of 40 years. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. He appears sad. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His speech is slurred and monotonous; his gait is unsteady. Examination shows scleral icterus and some drooling. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1 to 2 cm below the left costal margin. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? Examination of the cornea in this patient would very likely show Kayser-Fleischer rings.

A. Increased transferrin saturation
B. Increased number of CAG repeats
C. Oligoclonal bands on CSF analysis
D. Ventriculomegaly on CT scan of the brain
E. Ground glass hepatocytes on liver biopsy
F. Low serum ceruloplasmin concentration

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician? There are exceptions to when consent from a parent is required before treating a minor.

A. Prescribe medication for the patient and inform the girlfriend’s parents
B. Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient’s parents give consent to treatment
C. Prescribe medication for the patient and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
D. Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient meets the criteria for legal emancipation
E. Prescribe medication for the patient without notifying the patient’s parents or the girlfriend’s parents
F. Prescribe medication for the patient and his girlfriend and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 86/70 mm Hg. CT angiography of the chest shows a large embolus at the right pulmonary artery. Pharmacotherapy with a tissue plasminogen activator is administered. Six hours later, she develops right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Laboratory studies show elevated prothrombin and partial thromboplastin times and normal bleeding time. A CT scan of the head shows a large, left-sided intracranial hemorrhage. Administration of which of the following is most appropriate to reverse this patient's acquired coagulopathy? This patient with a confirmed diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism was treated with a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and subsequently developed bleeding as a complication of therapy. Tissue plasminogen activators (e.g., alteplase) increase thrombolysis by converting plasminogen to plasmin, which directly dissolves the thrombus by degrading fibrin.

A. Protamine sulfate
B. Vitamin K
C. Plasmin
D. Desmopressin
E. Aminocaproic acid

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe headaches and lightheadedness for 2 months. She has also been hearing a 'swoosh' sound in her left ear for the past month. She has allergic rhinitis and acne. Her sister is being treated for thyroid cancer. Current medications include levocetirizine, topical clindamycin, and azelastine-fluticasone nasal spray. She appears anxious. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 168/96 mm Hg. Examination shows cystic acne over the face and back. The pupils are equal and reactive. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is an abdominal bruit on the left side. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following? The presence of headaches, lightheadedness, and tinnitus in a young woman with elevated blood pressure and concurrent cervical and abdominal bruits is suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia.

A. Increased 24-hour urine cortisol
B. Elevated plasma metanephrine level
C. Abnormal breathing pattern at night
D. Adrenal adenoma
E. Parathyroid adenoma
F. Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
G. Elevated renin level

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's history of chronic, widespread muscle tenderness, morning stiffness, fatigue, cognitive dysfunction (difficulty concentrating), and sleep disturbances, in conjunction with normal laboratory studies, suggests fibromyalgia (FM). FM mostly affects women between the second and fifth decade of life and is often associated with psychiatric disorders, such as depression.

A. Electromyography
B. Muscle biopsy
C. Prednisone therapy
D. Ketorolac therapy
E. Regular exercise
F. Oxycodone therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient's recurrent edema of the face and feet, hypertension, elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine, and urinalysis that shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria are suggestive of nephritic syndrome. The combination of intermittent gross hematuria, nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus in a patient with a family history of renal disease is indicative of Alport syndrome.

A. IgA deposits
B. Type II hypersensitivity reaction
C. WT1 gene mutation
D. Phospholipase A2 receptor antibody
E. Defective type IV collagen
F. Prior streptococcal infection
G. Autosomal-recessive kidney disease

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had swollen legs, mild shortness of breath, and generalized fatigue for the past 2 weeks. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities, but no erythema or tenderness. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's symptoms? In the later stages of pregnancy, the gravid uterus often puts pressure on the inferior vena cava and the iliac veins.

A. Echocardiography
B. Screen for proteinuria
C. Lower extremity doppler
D. D-dimer level
E. Ventilation-perfusion scan
F. Reassurance and monitoring

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain for 2 days. The pain is diffuse and constant, and she describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. She has also had numbness in her lower extremities for 12 hours. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, migraine with aura, and essential tremor. She appears uncomfortable. She is oriented to place and person only. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 123/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended abdomen with no tenderness to palpation. Bowel sounds are decreased. Muscle strength and sensation are decreased in the lower extremities. There is a tremor of the right upper extremity. Urinalysis shows elevated levels of aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This woman's abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, confusion, and elevated urinary levels of aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen are due to acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). Remember the 5 P's of AIP: Painful abdomen, Polyneuropathy, Psychologic disturbances, Purple pee, Precipitated by triggers (like drugs).

A. Primidone
B. Amitriptyline
C. Flunarizine
D. Metoclopramide
E. Sumatriptan
F. Insulin
G. Propranolol

Correct Answer: A

Question
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after being bitten by his neighbor's dog. He was chasing the dog with a stick when it attacked him. He has fed the dog on multiple occasions and it has never bitten him before. His father saw the dog 2 hours after the incident and its behavior seemed normal. There is no personal or family history of serious illness in the family. The last vaccination the boy received was against varicella 2 years ago; he has never been immunized against rabies. He is not in acute distress. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 2-cm (0.8 in) puncture wound on his left calf; there is minimal erythema around the wound. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. The wound is irrigated and washed with saline and chlorhexidine solution. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? After a potential rabies exposure, the type of animal and the context of the bite injury should be taken into consideration when evaluating the need for postexposure prophylaxis (PEP).

A. Observe the dog for 10 days
B. Euthanize the dog and test for rabies
C. Administer rabies vaccine and immune globulin
D. Administer rabies immune globulin
E. Administer rabies vaccine

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of rash that began on his right ankle and gradually progressed up his calf. The rash is itchy and mildly painful. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, glipizide, and enalapril. He returned from a trip to Nigeria around 5 weeks ago. He works on a fishing boat. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. A pruritic, migrating, serpentine rash in a patient with recent travel to Africa is consistent with this condition.

A. Contact dermatitis
B. Cutaneous larva migrans
C. Tinea corporis
D. Superficial thrombophlebitis
E. Swimmer's itch

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritation and redness in both eyes. Her symptoms initially started in the left eye and progressed to involve both eyes within 24 hours. She presents with profuse tearing and reports that her eyes are sticky and difficult to open in the morning. She was diagnosed with asthma 2 years ago and has been admitted to the hospital for acute exacerbations three times since then. Current medications include inhaled beclomethasone, inhaled albuterol, and montelukast. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination reveals a tender left preauricular lymph node. There is chemosis and diffuse erythema of the bulbar conjunctiva bilaterally with watery discharge. Slit-lamp examination shows a follicular reaction in both palpebral conjunctivae and diffuse, fine epithelial keratitis of both corneas. Corneal sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Redness and profuse watery discharge which start in one eye and rapidly spread to the other, preauricular lymphadenopathy, low-grade fever, and signs of corneal inflammation are consistent with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

A. Supportive therapy
B. Oral cetirizine
C. Topical prednisolone acetate
D. Oral acyclovir
E. Topical natamycin
F. Topical moxifloxacin
G. Topical erythromycin

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past year. He has difficulties understanding conversations in crowded places and when more than one person talks at the same time. He has no dizziness, ear discharge, ringing noise, or ear pain. He has a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include enalapril, metformin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows pearly gray, translucent tympanic membranes with a normal light reflex. A vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed on the left mastoid process. Once the patient no longer hears a tone, the fork is held over the ipsilateral ear and the patient reports hearing the tone again. The same test is repeated on the right side with similar results. There is no lateralization when a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This older patient presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss and difficulty hearing in noisy, crowded environments. These features together with bilateral positive Rinne test and no lateralization on Weber test are suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss.

A. Cerumen impaction
B. Ototoxicity
C. Otosclerosis
D. Cholesteatoma
E. Vestibulocochlear nerve damage
F. Presbycusis
G. Acoustic neuroma

Correct Answer: F

Question

He is at the 15th percentile for height and weight and at the 1st percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Question
A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of increasing confusion and abnormal speech for 1 day. He had generalized weakness and fever for 3 days, but the weakness has now become more pronounced in his right extremities. His wife reports that he tried to take all of his clothes off while they were at a shopping center earlier that afternoon. He has nausea but no vomiting. He recovered from an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. He is unable to remember his birthday and makes paraphasic errors. There is no nuchal rigidity. Neurological examination shows decreased strength in his upper and lower right extremities and hyperreflexia. Serum glucose is 90 mg/dL. B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Question
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of fever, congestion, and malaise for the past 2 days. He reports a sensation of pressure over his nose and cheeks. Over the past year, he has had an intermittent cough productive of green sputum and lately has noticed some streaks of blood in the sputum. He has had over 10 episodes of sinusitis, all of which were successfully treated with antibiotics. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient's vaccinations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over both cheeks. Crackles and rhonchi are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows an absence of heart sounds along the left lower chest. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient? This patient presents with recurrent sinusitis, symptoms of bronchiectasis, and presumably situs inversus (absence of heart sounds on the left side), all of which are highly suggestive of Kartagener syndrome.

A. Defective interleukin-2 receptor gamma chain
B. Absence of B lymphocytes
C. Increased forced expiratory volume
D. Increased sweat chloride levels
E. Immotile sperm
F. Decreased levels of immunoglobulins
Microdeletion at chromosome 222%

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-week history of pain in his left thigh. The mother reports that her son fell from a ladder while playing with friends about a month and a half ago. He had a runny nose 3 weeks ago. He has no history of serious illness. He has reached all developmental milestones for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. His 7-year-old brother has asthma. The patient is at 60th percentile for height and 65th percentile for weight. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild left-sided antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation; abduction and internal rotation are limited by pain. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,800/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left femoral epiphysis that is smaller than the right with widening of the medial joint space on the left. The femoral head shows little discernible damage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Antalgic gait and hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip should raise concern for Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years. This patient's x-ray shows erosion of the femoral epiphysis with minimal damage to the femoral head.

A. Femoral osteotomy
B. Casting and bracing
C. Femoral head pinning
D. Limited weight bearing and physical therapy
E. Intravenous nafcillin therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question

B. Botulinum toxin injection
C. Stretching program
D. X-ray of the cervical spine
E. Fine needle aspiration
F. Myotomy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, is brought to the emergency department at 39 weeks' gestation in active labor. Her first child was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation by elective cesarean section due to a limited range of motion in her hip. The patient has sickle cell disease. She has had multiple episodes of acute chest syndrome and has required several transfusions in the past. An uncomplicated repeat cesarean section is performed, and a 2.7-kg (6-lb) infant is delivered with approx. 550 mL blood loss. Perioperatively, she received one dose of intravenous cefazolin. Following the surgery, the patient continues to bleed, and she receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells. One hour later, the patient begins to have flank pain and appears to be in acute distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 99/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following? This patient developed a fever, hypotension, tachypnea, tachycardia, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria within 1–2 hours of receiving a blood transfusion, which is consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

A. Serum antibodies against Class I HLA antigens
B. Low levels of serum IgA immunoglobulins
C. Positive blood cultures
D. Positive direct Coombs test
E. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray

Correct Answer: D

Question

B. Acetaminophen
C. Ibuprofen
D. Ergotamine

Question

Question
A 48-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a productive cough with brownish sputum and shortness of breath on exertion. During this period, he has also had a 5-kg (11 lb) weight loss despite no change in appetite. He has not had fever or night sweats. Three years ago, he was treated for pulmonary tuberculosis for 6 months. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include metoprolol, aspirin, rosuvastatin, enalapril, and antiretroviral therapy. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He lives in California and has not traveled in the last 6 months. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 79 kg (175 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 138/92 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows inspiratory crackles at the right infraclavicular area. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,300/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 38 mm/h. CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 490/mm3. A. Reactivation tuberculosis
B. Histoplasmosis
C. Lung adenocarcinoma
D. Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis
E. Lung abscess
F. Pneumocystis pneumonia

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 26-year-old man comes to his physician because he has started to experience shortness of breath when exercising. He does not have shortness of breath at rest. He has also had lower back pain for the past year. He describes the pain as an aching stiffness that improves with movement. He has not had fever, cough, rhinorrhea, or weight loss. Medical history otherwise is unremarkable and he takes no routine medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints bilaterally. A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of bilateral knee pain for the past year. She reports that the pain is worse with movement and is relieved with rest. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient says her mother takes leflunomide for a “joint condition.” The patient's medications include metformin and a multivitamin. Question

She has also noticed darkening of her urine, which she attributes to not drinking enough water recently. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She drinks one to two beers daily. She works as a nursing assistant in a rehabilitation facility. Current medications include glyburide, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. She appears tired. Question
A previously healthy 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of an abdominal mass noticed a few days ago. He appears markedly pale and lethargic. Examination shows a 6-cm, nonmobile mass in the left upper quadrant that crosses the midline. 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid. Further evaluation including biopsy confirms the diagnosis of intermediate-risk neuroblastoma. The physician recommends the established standard treatment, which is initiation of neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection, if possible. After a thorough discussion of the risks and benefits of chemotherapy, the likelihood of unresectability without neoadjuvant treatment, and the prognosis without it, the patient's parents steadily refuse chemotherapy because they do not want their son to suffer the side effects. They prefer to take their son home for supportive care only. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician? This patient has a severe condition that has a good prognosis if lifesaving treatment is started soon but will likely turn fatal if only supportive care is given.

A. Initiate neoadjuvant chemotherapy
B. Help the parents to arrange supportive care at home
C. Refer the patient to another oncologist
D. Recommend for parents to take 2 weeks to think about decision
E. Seek a court order for neoadjuvant chemotherapy
F. Attempt surgical resection of the tumor

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 77-year-old woman comes to a medical school's free clinic for follow-up examination after a urinary tract infection (UTI) and is seen by a fourth-year medical student. The clinic serves largely uninsured low-income patients in a New York City neighborhood with a large African American and Latino population. Two weeks ago, the patient was treated in the local emergency department where she presented with an altered mental state and dysuria. The medical student had recently read about a study that described a strong relationship between cognitive impairment and UTI hospitalization risk (RR = 1.34, p < 0.001). The attending physician at the medical student's free clinic is also familiar with this study and tells the medical student that the study was conducted in a sample of upper-middle-class Caucasian patients in the Netherlands. The attending states that the results of the study should be interpreted with caution. Which of the following concerns is most likely underlying the attending physician's remarks? The study was conducted in an upper-middle-class Caucasian sample in the Netherlands while the medical student's clinic is situated in a largely African American and Latino enclave in New York City.

A. Confounding bias
B. Low internal validity
C. Poor reliability
D. Lack of precision
E. Low external validity
F. Selection bias

Correct Answer: E

Question

Question
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? Serum osmolality and volume status are important for differentiating the etiology of hyponatremia. This patient's serum osmolality is low (hypotonic) and she does not have edema or signs of hypovolemia, making her euvolemic. Euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia in the context of recent neurosurgery is suggestive of a specific underlying condition.

A. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome
B. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
C. Opioid overdose
D. Primary polydipsia
E. Mineralocorticoid deficiency

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 41-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 35 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is remarkable for type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and a daily multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mm Hg. Examination discloses right upper quadrant tenderness. Fundal height is 36 cm. Fetal heart rate is reactive with no decelerations. Laboratory studies show:A blood smear shows schistocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Findings consistent with hemolysis (i.e., anemia, elevated total bilirubin, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, blood smear with schistocytes), elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST), and thrombocytopenia in a pregnant woman establish the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome. This condition is typically associated with hypertension of pregnancy and preeclampsia, although 15% of affected patients are normotensive.

A. Platelet transfusion
B. Dexamethasone
C. Ursodeoxycholic acid
D. Labetalol
E. Immediate delivery
F. Betamethasone and magnesium sulfate

Correct Answer: E

Question
