Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for bedwetting. He went 2 months without wetting the bed but then started again 6 weeks ago. He has been wetting the bed about 1–2 times per week. He has not had daytime urinary incontinence or dysuria. His teachers report that he is attentive in preschool and plays well with his peers. He is able to name 5 colors, follow three-step commands, and recite his address. He can do a somersault, use scissors, and copy a square. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Recommendations for managing nocturnal enuresis depend on the child's age.

A. Enuresis alarm
B. Bladder training exercises
C. Oxybutynin therapy
D. Star chart
E. Reassurance
F. Desmopressin therapy
G. Urinalysis

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of irritability and poor feeding that began 2 days ago. He was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and his birth weight was 3280 g (7 lb 4 oz). His 8-year-old sister and his father are healthy. During both pregnancies, his mother had severe polyuria. Today, he weighs 2900 g (6 lb 6 oz). Physical examination shows dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and a sunken anterior fontanelle. During the examination, he cries without tears. Laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 305 mOsmol/kg H2O and a urine osmolality of 45 mOsmol/kg H2O. After the administration of a vasopressin analog, urine osmolality remains decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this newborn's condition? Features of severe dehydration (e.g., weight loss > 9%, irritability, poor feeding, dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, sunken anterior fontanelle, increased serum osmolality) and very low urine osmolality that does not correct with the administration of a vasopressin analog indicate nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

A. High-protein diet
B. High-sodium diet
C. Demeclocycline therapy
D. Desmopressin therapy
E. Indomethacin therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of elevated total protein of the blood that was found incidentally during a routine health maintenance examination 1 week ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She reports feeling well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral blood smear shows no abnormalities. Serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation shows an M-protein spike due to IgG heavy chains and quantitative assessment shows an M-protein concentration of 0.7 g/dL. A serum-free light chain assay shows normal kappa and lambda light chain concentrations and a normal free light chain ratio. Electrophoresis and immunofixation of a 24-hour urine specimen and bone densitometry show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Monoclonal paraproteins (M-proteins) in an otherwise healthy patient indicate monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), which is the most common type of plasma cell dyscrasia (PCD). The prevalence of MGUS increases with age and although MGUS is initially benign, it is the precursor to severe PCDs such as multiple myeloma (MM), Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (WM), and primary amyloidosis (AL). Risk stratification based on the type and concentration of the M-protein, and results of serum-free light chain (SFLC) studies guide the management of MGUS.

A. Rituximab therapy
B. Reassurance and follow-up
C. Plasmapheresis
D. Skeletal survey radiographs
E. Bone marrow biopsy
F. CT scan of the abdomen

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 35-year-old woman comes to employee health services 30 minutes after a work-related incident. She works as a phlebotomist and reports that blood splashed into her right eye when she was drawing blood from a 30-year-old male patient. Immediately following the incident, she flushed her eye with water for several minutes. The patient from whom she drew blood was admitted for hemoptysis, weight loss, and night sweats. He is an intravenous drug user and is sexually active with several male and female partners. The phlebotomist has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to drawing her blood for viral serologies, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This phlebotomist's mucous membranes were contaminated by blood from a source patient with risk factors for a bloodborne disease.

A. Start raltegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine
B. Start zidovudine
C. Start tenofovir and emtricitabine
D. Provide reassurance
E. Start sofosbuvir and velpatasvir
F. Administer hepatitis B immune globulin and vaccine

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Two features specific to this patient's diagnosis are severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness.

A. Conus medullaris syndrome
B. Cauda equina syndrome
C. Central cord syndrome
D. Brown-Sequard syndrome
E. Anterior spinal cord syndrome

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of lightheadedness, weakness, and abdominal pain for 6 hours. Over the past 3 days, she has also had severe nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. She was diagnosed with pulmonary sarcoidosis 2 years ago. Current medications include prednisone. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a round face with prominent preauricular fat pads. Her fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following laboratory changes? Hypotension, hypoglycemia, and abdominal pain in a patient on prolonged high-dose glucocorticoid therapy(as is evident in her Cushingoid facies) should raise concern for acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal crisis). Adrenal crisis is a severe, acute glucocorticoid deficiency that is usually precipitated by a trigger such as infection, dehydration, trauma, or surgery. It can also occur when glucocorticoids are abruptly discontinued and/or their absorption is impaired, e.g., due to acute gastroenteritis, as is likely the case here.

A. Increased cortisol
B. Decreased corticotropin-releasing hormone
C. Decreased norepinephrine
D. Decreased aldosterone
E. Increased adrenocorticotropic hormone

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing weakness of his arms and legs over the past year. He has also had difficulty speaking for the past 5 months. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for gastric cancer 10 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dysarthria. There is mild atrophy and twitching of the tongue. Muscle strength is decreased in all extremities. Muscle tone is decreased in the right lower extremity and increased in the other extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the right lower extremity and 4+ in the other extremities. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is intact in all extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? This patient has clinical features of upper motor neuron (UMN) dysfunction, such as increased muscle tone, extensor plantar response, and increased deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), as well as lower motor neuron (LMN) dysfunction, such as decreased muscle tone, atrophy, fasciculations, and absent DTRs, which suggest amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

A. Vitamin B
B. Nusinersen
C. Glatiramer acetate
D. Riluzole
E. Pyridostigmine
F. Corticosteroids

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He feels well. He was diagnosed with hypertension 3 months ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 4 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol on the weekends. He walks for 45 minutes daily and eats three meals per day. His current diet consists mostly of canned tuna and cured meats. He started eating whole-wheat bread after he was diagnosed with hypertension. He drinks 1 to 2 cups of coffee daily. His mother has a history of hyperthyroidism. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and a multivitamin pill every night before sleeping. His wife told him that he sometimes snores at night, but he reports that he usually sleeps well and feels refreshed in the mornings. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? Despite therapy with an antihypertensive drug, this patient continues to have elevated blood pressure.

A. Increase hydrochlorothiazide dose
B. Add metoprolol
C. Measure thyroid-stimulating hormone levels
D. Start a structured exercise program
E. Counsel on dietary modification
F. Conduct a sleep study

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 28-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after a previous visit showed an elevated serum calcium level. He has a history of bipolar disorder. His mother had a parathyroidectomy in her 30s. The patient does not drink alcohol or smoke. Current medications include lithium and a daily multivitamin. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings? In an asymptomatic patient with mild hypercalcemia and nonsuppressed PTH (at the upper limit of normal or mildly elevated), urinary calcium excretion (measured via 24-hour urine calcium or calcium-to-creatinine ratio) distinguishes between primary hyperparathyroidism and familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.

A. Excess calcium intake
B. Abnormal calcium sensing receptors
C. Chronic renal failure
D. Excess vitamin D intake
E. Lithium toxicity
F. Parathyroid adenoma

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of persistent headaches for the last 2 months. The symptoms started insidiously. Menses had previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals with moderate flow. Her last menstrual period was 12 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband but reports decreased interest in sexual intercourse over the past few months. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A pelvic ultrasound shows atrophic endometrium. A cranial MRI with contrast shows a 2-cm intrasellar mass. A hormone assay confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management? This patient presents with persistent headaches, decreased libido, atrophic endometrium, and secondary amenorrhea, all of which suggest a pituitary adenoma. The intrasellar mass seen on the cranial MRI and a positive hormone assay confirm the suspected diagnosis.

A. Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy
B. Cabergoline therapy
C. Radiotherapy
D. Observation and outpatient follow-up
E. Domperidone therapy
F. Biopsy of intrasellar mass

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after a sexual assault during which she was penetrated vaginally. After the assailtant left, the patient immediately drove to the hospital. She did not call the police or her family because she felt too embarrassed. Her medical and family history are unremarkable. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears tearful and startles when the door to the examination room is slammed shut. She is fully oriented and gives consent to proceed with physical examination and documentation of findings in the presence of a chaperone. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 126/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows several bruises and abrasions on her upper arms and neck. Pelvic examination shows swelling and erythema of the vulva and vagina. There are multiple abrasions of the labia minora and majora with superficial bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The physician orders vaginal specimen nucleic acid amplification tests for chlamydia, gonorrhea, and trichomonas, and serum testing for HIV, hepatitis B, and syphilis. The patient receives psychological counseling, and with her consent, the appropriate legal authorities are notified about the incident. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Individuals who have experienced sexual assault require active management during their initial presentation to decrease the risk of developing certain diseases.

A. Administer mifepristone and misoprostol 24 hours apart
B. Prescribe tenofovir and abacavir
C. Administer HPV vaccine
D. Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin
E. Prescribe ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole

Correct Answer: E

Question
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of rapidly progressive weakness of his legs and an inability to walk since that morning. He reports that he felt a tingling sensation in his feet yesterday before the weakness set in. He was sent home early from a school trip 2 weeks ago because he had a fever, runny nose, and a cough, which all resolved without treatment. Examination shows a mild, symmetrical decrease in sensation in the legs and absent ankle and patellar reflexes. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings in this patient? The development of rapidly progressive paralysis with symmetrical peripheral paresthesias and absent muscle reflexes 2 weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection is highly suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 3200-g (7.1-lb) female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The mother had regular prenatal visits throughout the pregnancy. The newborn's blood pressure is 53/35 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows clitoromegaly and posterior labial fusion. One day later, serum studies show:Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows a normal uterus and ovaries. Further evaluation of the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings? This female newborn presents with hypotension, ambiguous external genitalia (clitoromegaly with labial fusion), hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, all of which are characteristic of the salt-losing form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

A. Decreased dehydroepiandrosterone
B. Increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone
C. Increased 11-deoxycorticosterone
D. Increased bicarbonate
E. Increased corticosterone
F. Decreased renin activity

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus treated with insulin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/86 mm Hg. Examination shows minimal bilateral edema below the knees. The uterus is consistent in size with a 29-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Transabdominal ultrasound shows an intrauterine pregnancy in longitudinal lie, normal fetal cardiac activity, an amniotic fluid index of 4 cm, and calcifications of the placenta. This patient's child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions? This patient presents with a small uterine size for gestational age. Ultrasonography confirms the presence of oligohydramnios (amniotic fluid index ≤ 5 cm).

A. Renal dysplasia
B. Meningomyelocele
C. Anencephaly
D. Esophageal atresia
E. Pulmonary hypoplasia

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 23-year old man is brought to the emergency department by his brother after trying to jump out of a moving car. He says that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been following him for the last 7 months. He recently quit his job at a local consulting firm to work on his mission to rid the world of evil. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He takes no medications. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/86 mm Hg. On mental status examination, his response to the first question lasts 5 minutes without interruption. He switches topics a number of times and his speech is pressured. He speaks excessively about his plan to “bring absolute justice to the world”. He has a labile affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. A toxicology screen is negative. He is admitted to the hospital and treatment is initiated. One week later, he develops difficulty walking and a tremor that improves with activity. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's motor symptoms? This patient presented with features of schizophrenia (delusions for at least 6 months, pressured and disorganized speech). The development of tremor and difficulty walking following initiation of treatment for schizophrenia are suggestive of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS).

A. Cholinesterase inhibitor
B. Gamma-aminobutyric acid agonist
C. Dopamine agonist
D. Dopamine antagonist
E. Acetylcholine antagonist
F. Serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
G. Histamine antagonist
H. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
. Gamma-aminobutyric acid antagonist

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 36-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of pelvic discomfort and heavy menstrual bleeding. The pain is dull and pressure-like and occurs intermittently; the patient is asymptomatic between episodes. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 8 days with heavy flow. Her last menstrual period ended 5 days ago. She is sexually active and does not use contraception. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows white cervical mucus and a firm, irregularly-shaped uterus consistent in size with a 5-week gestation. A spot urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? This patient presents with an irregularly enlarged uterus, heavy, regular menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and, presumably, infertility (no prior pregnancy despite being sexually active and not using contraception). This constellation of features suggests uterine leiomyomas.

A. Colposcopy with cervical cultures
B. Laparoscopy
C. Non-contrast pelvic CT scan
D. Pelvic MRI
E. Dilation and curettage
F. Pelvic ultrasound
G. Repeat β-HCG test

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 42-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently moved to the area. He feels well. He has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus, and his paternal uncle had prostate cancer at the age of 73 years. The patient does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks three glasses of wine weekly. He works as a scriptwriter for a film production company and runs marathons to raise money for charity organizations in his free time. He has been monogamous with his wife for 15 years. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Screening for which of the following is most appropriate at this time? Screening for this disorder is recommended by the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and various other expert groups for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD).

A. Hyperlipidemia
B. Chlamydia and gonorrhea
C. No further evaluation is necessary
D. Prostate cancer
E. Osteoporosis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a severely painful right eye. The pain started an hour ago and is accompanied by frontal headache and nausea. The patient has vomited twice since the onset of the pain. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He immigrated to the US from China 10 years ago. He works as an engineer at a local company and has been under a great deal of stress lately. His only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right eye is red and is hard on palpation. The right pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. The left pupil is round and reactive to light and accommodation. Which of the following agents is contraindicated in this patient? This patient presents with a unilateral red, hard, severely painful eye with a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil as well as frontal headaches, vomiting, and nausea. These features are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma. The condition is particularly common in Asian individuals and can be precipitated by stress.

A. Topical pilocarpine
B. Topical timolol
C. Topical epinephrine
D. Topical apraclonidine
E. Oral acetazolamide

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 64-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She reports a 6-week history of fatigue and muscle cramps in her calves. Medical history is remarkable for hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. She retired from her job as a teacher 6 months ago. Medications are atorvastatin and lisinopril. She appears tired. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 130/83 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin concentration is 6.7 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 67 μm3. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status of this patient? Anemia results in decreased arterial oxygen content despite normal arterial oxygen saturation and partial pressure. In order to compensate for the reduced oxygen content, minute ventilation increases (i.e., respiratory rate and tidal volume), reducing pCO2.

A. Primary respiratory alkalosis, uncompensated
B. Primary respiratory alkalosis, renal compensation
C. Primary respiratory alkalosis and secondary metabolic acidosis
D. Primary metabolic alkalosis, uncompensated
E. Primary respiratory and secondary metabolic alkaloses
F. Primary metabolic alkalosis, respiratory compensation

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a right breast mass that she noticed 3 weeks ago. It has rapidly increased in size during this period. She does not have pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows large dense breasts; a 5-cm, nontender, multinodular mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. There are no changes in the skin or nipple. There is no palpable cervical or axillary adenopathy. Mammography shows a smooth polylobulated mass. Biopsy of the mass shows papillary projections of epithelial-lined stroma with hyperplasia and atypia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A leaf-like architecture of papillary projections of epithelium-lined stroma is characteristic of this condition.

A. Intraductal papilloma
B. Phyllodes tumor
C. Paget disease of the breast
D. Fibroadenoma
E. Fibrocystic disease of the breast
F. Invasive ductal carcinoma
G. Invasive lobular carcinoma

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 50-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He feels well but is worried about his health because his father died of myocardial infarction 2 weeks ago at the age of 80. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 15 years. He does not follow any specific diet; he usually eats sandwiches at work and fried chicken or a burger for dinner. He says that he has been struggling with a stressful project at work recently. His mother was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 45. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 20 years ago. He drinks one to two beers daily. He is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 127/82 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender; waist circumference is 103 cm. Fasting serum studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with elevated serum fasting concentrations of glucose (≥ 100 mg/dL) and triglycerides (≥ 150 mg/dL), and increased waist circumference (≥ 102 cm), which are diagnostic of metabolic syndrome.

A. Prescribe metformin
B. Prescribe fenofibrate
C. Recommend structured exercise program
D. Schedule a follow-up visit to repeat fasting glucose and lipid profile testing in 3 months
E. Perform cardiac stress testing

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of yellow discoloration, dark urine, and itchiness. She does not have diarrhea but says her stools “look pale”. She has also had a fever and severe fatigue. She reports having symptoms of the stomach flu a week ago, which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She has no personal history of serious illness. She does not smoke and drinks an average of two beers on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 12 years and uses condoms consistently. She works as a flight attendant for an international airline. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus, excoriation marks over her extremities, and parched lips. The liver is tender on palpation; there is no splenomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to be present in this patient? Tender hepatomegaly with signs and symptoms of cholestasis (jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, pruritus, direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated transaminases and alkaline phosphatase), preceded by fever, nausea, and vomiting, suggest a specific type of acute hepatitis.

A. Antimitochondrial antibodies
B. Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
C. Anti-HAV IgM antibodies
D. Anti-HEV IgG antibodies
E. Anti-HAV IgG antibodies
F. HBsAg

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a cough productive of frothy, light yellow sputum and worsening breathlessness. The cough used to occur only in the mornings but is now present throughout the entire day. One year ago, she had a similar episode of cough lasting 4–5 months but did not seek medical treatment. She has not had fever, night sweats, hemoptysis, or weight loss. She has hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Her only medication is simvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 134/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Pulmonary function testing is most likely going to show which of the following findings? This patient has a significant smoking history and has symptoms that meet the criteria for chronic bronchitis, (productive cough for ≥ 3 months each year for ≥ 2 consecutive years), a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E
F. F
G. G
H. H

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 32-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for 2 days. The pain began after she did some household chores and has since limited her daily activities; the patient identifies the pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. Over the past 2 years she has had intermittent diarrhea, bloating, and a 15-kg (33-lb) weight loss. She has not seen a doctor in a few years. Menarche occurred at the age of 13 years and her periods are irregular. There is no family history of serious illness. She is inconsistent with her dietary habits and does not always have a good appetite. She takes walks in the park daily. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is insulin. She appears pale. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 40 kg (88 lb); BMI is 17 kg/m2. Examination of the back shows spinal tenderness at the T12 vertebral level. There is proximal muscle weakness in the lower limbs. Cardiopulmonary, neurologic, and pelvic examinations show no abnormalities. A test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the spine shows a compression fracture of the T12 vertebra. Which of the following is the primary mechanism underlying this patient's musculoskeletal symptoms? This patient has bone pain due to a spinal fracture that occurred with minimal trauma, which is concerning for a pathologic fracture. These findings in addition to muscle weakness, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia raise concern for osteomalacia.

A. Impaired cholecalciferol synthesis in the skin
B. Low dietary intake of calcium
C. Intestinal malabsorption
D. Decreased parathyroid hormone synthesis
E. Impaired hydroxylation of calcifediol

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of fever, malaise, and right upper abdominal pain. Examination of the abdomen shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3 (92% neutrophils) and serum alkaline phosphatase is 130 U/L. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a 3-cm hypoechoic lesion in the right lobe of the liver with a hyperemic rim. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? A triad of fever, malaise, and right upper abdominal pain in a patient with neutrophilic leukocytosis and a hepatic lesion with a hyperemic rim (due to surrounding edema and inflammation) on ultrasonography is diagnostic of a liver abscess.

A. Colorectal cancer
B. Infectious endocarditis
C. Echinococcosis
D. Diverticulitis
E. Cholangitis
F. Perinephric infection

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He describes the pain as an 8/10 in intensity with no radiation. He denies fever or chills. He has not passed urine since the early morning. He took oral diphenhydramine last night because he had difficulty falling asleep. He has a history of hypertension. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily but quit 1 year ago. Current medications include amlodipine. He appears restless. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable suprapubic mass. Digital rectal examination shows a mildly enlarged, nontender prostate without any palpable masses. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A bedside ultrasound scan shows a large anechoic mass in the lower abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? This patient's anuria and palpable suprapubic mass along with a distended bladder (anechoic mass) on ultrasound suggest acute urinary retention (AUR). First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) increase the risk of developing this condition, especially in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (as suggested by an enlarged, smooth, and nontender prostate on digital rectal examination).

A. Start treatment with oral finasteride
B. Place suprapubic catheter
C. Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
D. Administer oral bethanechol
E. Insert transurethral Foley catheter
F. Administer normal saline bolus

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening bilateral lower extremity pain for the past 8 months. The pain begins after walking one to two blocks and radiates bilaterally down the buttocks with cramping and tingling. He reports that the pain is worse while walking downhill and is relieved by sitting and leaning forward. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55 years and an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at the age of 60 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications include sitagliptin, metformin, atorvastatin, metoprolol succinate, amlodipine, and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/87 mm Hg. Examination shows full muscle strength. Sensation is reduced bilaterally in the feet and toes. Straight leg raise test is negative. X-ray of the spine shows degenerative changes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? Bilateral buttock pain that worsens with lumbar extension (e.g., walking) and is relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting, leaning forward) is consistent with neuropathic claudication, which is commonly seen in lumbar spinal stenosis. Symptoms of neuropathic claudication can occur in the absence of lower back pain.

A. Measurement of HLA-B27 antigen
B. Measurement of the ankle brachial index
C. MRI scan of the spine
D. Polysomnography
E. Measurement of serum creatine kinase

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. Four years ago, she underwent cholecystectomy for recurrent cholecystitis. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, with a waist circumference of 94 cm. Serum studies show:Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions? This patient has hypertension, abdominal obesity, insulin resistance (fasting glucose ≥ 100 mg/dL and previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes), low HDL, and moderate hypertriglyceridemia. These findings are consistent with metabolic syndrome.

A. Central sleep apnea
B. Osteoporosis
C. Steatohepatitis
D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
E. Rheumatoid arthritis

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 35-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, at 34 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. She does not note any contractions or fluid from her vagina. Her third child was delivered spontaneously at 35 weeks' gestation; pregnancy and delivery of her other two children were uncomplicated. Vital signs are normal. The abdomen is nontender and no contractions are felt. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 34 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a breech presentation. The fetal heart rate is 148/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The patient is not in active labor and the gestational age is < 37 weeks.

A. Intravenous magnesium sulfate
B. Assisted vaginal breech delivery
C. Internal cephalic version
D. Cesarean delivery
E. External cephalic version
F. Observation
G. Intramuscular dexamethasone
H. Intravenous penicillin

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 45-year-old man with a history of epilepsy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had trouble moving the right side of his body for 2 weeks. Three weeks ago he was admitted to the hospital for a generalized convulsive seizure. He was treated with intravenous lorazepam and phenytoin; the seizure activity resolved after 50 minutes on EEG monitoring. He was discharged 2 days later after no further epileptic activity occurred. Physical examination at discharge showed no abnormalities. He has had multiple hospitalizations for similar episodes over the past year. His only medication is lamotrigine, though he says that he sometimes forgets to take it. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis, right homonymous hemianopsia, and receptive aphasia. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms? This patient had status epilepticus (seizure activity lasting > 30 minutes or an operational definition of continuous seizures for ≥ 5 minutes) and most likely had hypoxia during the seizure. Status epilepticus can be induced by withdrawal from antiepileptic drugs, e.g., due to inconsistent medication intake, as in this patient.

A. Lacunar stroke
B. Brain abscess
C. Cortical laminar necrosis
D. Intraventricular hemorrhage
E. Ruptured intracranial aneurysm

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for sudden leakage of clear fluid from her vagina. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has largely been adherent to her prenatal care but missed some appointments. She has a history of chronic hypertension. She drinks a glass of wine once per week. Current medications include labetalol, iron, and vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen on palpation. Speculum examination demonstrates clear fluid in the cervical canal. The fetal heart rate is reactive at 170/min with no decelerations. Tocometry shows no contractions. The vaginal fluid demonstrates a ferning pattern when placed onto a glass slide. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition? Arborization or ferning is indicative of the presence of amniotic fluid, confirming premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

A. Hypertension
B. Primiparity
C. Ascending infection
D. Sexual intercourse during third trimester
E. Beta blocker use
F. Alcohol use
G. Oligohydramnios

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 4-month history of unpredictable behavior. Last week, when his teacher asked him to present his homework in class, he started shouting and cursing and threw a book on the floor. The teacher has reported that similar outbursts occur at least twice weekly for no apparent reason; otherwise, he is usually calm and sits quietly during class. His mother reports that during driving lessons he regularly becomes angry “if other people drive too slowly”, and that has led to him almost losing control of the car. After these episodes, he feels embarrassed and apologizes for his actions. When asked about his behavior in these situations, he says, “I feel a sudden rage inside of me, my mind is racing, and I can feel my heart pounding.” His mother is concerned that he may not be able to get his driver's license if he cannot control himself. He is otherwise healthy, takes no medications, and does not use illicit drugs. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient has a type of impulse-control disorder that is characterized by recurrent aggressive outbursts that are disproportionate to circumstances and typically followed by feelings of remorse and embarrassment.

A. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder
B. Conduct disorder
C. Oppositional defiant disorder
D. Intermittent explosive disorder
E. Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
F. Antisocial personality disorder

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressively worsening headache and nausea. He started having chills last night and could not fall asleep. He has not had any vomiting or diarrhea. He has a history of hypertension treated with ramipril. He works 80 hours per week as an investment banker and says that his job is stressful. He is sexually active with several female partners and uses condoms consistently. He drinks alcohol occasionally on the weekends and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears exhausted. He is oriented to place and person but not to time. He becomes increasingly somnolent as one of the nurses takes his vital signs. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 127/77 mm Hg. Physical examination shows photophobia and nuchal rigidity; Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. Fundoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Blood samples are obtained for cultures and therapy with vancomycin and cefotaxime is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? Acute headache, fever, photophobia, and signs of meningeal irritation (neck stiffness, positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs) strongly suggest acute meningitis.

A. CT scan of the head
B. Electroencephalography
C. MRI of the head
D. Lumbar puncture
E. Cerebral arteriography

Correct Answer: A

Question
Two days after admission to the intensive care unit for septic shock and bacteremia from a urinary tract infection, a 54-year-old woman has persistent hypotension. Her blood cultures were positive for Escherichia coli, for which she has been receiving antibiotics since admission; antibiotic susceptibility test results are still pending. She has no history of serious illness. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include norepinephrine, ceftriaxone, and acetaminophen. She appears well. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate 96/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral tenderness bilaterally. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's laboratory abnormalities? This patient has persistent hypotension from her bacterial infection. Her labs indicate that she is slowly improving, and her low T3 is likely unrelated to her hypotension.

A. Medication toxicity
B. Euthyroid sick syndrome
C. Fibrous thyroiditis
D. Pituitary apoplexy
E. Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
F. De Quervain's thyroiditis
G. Subclinical hypothyroidism

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 70-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 3-day history of worsening cough productive of yellow sputum and difficulty breathing. He has been hospitalized twice in the past year for similar symptoms. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. His medications include daily inhaled budesonide, formoterol, and tiotropium bromide, and he uses an ipratropium-albuterol inhaler as needed. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 142/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 86%. His breathing appears labored. Examination shows perioral cyanosis. Auscultation of the lungs discloses diffuse end-expiratory wheezes. Heart sounds are distant. In addition to administering albuterol nebulizer therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient is experiencing cardinal symptoms of an acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD): worsening of dyspnea, increased frequency and severity of cough, and increased volume and/or purulence of sputum. Patients with COPD can have distant heart sounds due to pulmonary hyperinflation.

A. Invasive mechanical ventilation
B. Long-term oxygen therapy
C. Empiric antibiotic therapy
D. Inhaled corticosteroid therapy
E. Spirometry

Correct Answer: C

Question
Four days after an operation for a perforated gastric ulcer, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops decreased urinary output, hyperkalemia, and severe uremia. A tunneled central venous catheter is placed in the subclavian vein and renal replacement therapy is initiated. Ten days later, the patient develops fever and hypotension. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The skin overlying the catheter appears well perfused, with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection? The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), even if the CVC's exit site does not show evidence of infection (e.g., tenderness, purulence). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.

A. Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units
B. Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance
C. Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein
D. Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire
E. Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of progressive intermittent pain and swelling in both knees and right ankle and wrist for 3 months. She has been taking acetaminophen and using ice packs, both of which relieved her symptoms. The affected joints feel "stuck” and difficult to move when she wakes up in the morning, but she can move them freely after a few minutes. She has also occasional mild eye pain that resolves spontaneously. Five months ago she was diagnosed with upper respiratory tract infection that resolved without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows that the affected joints are swollen, erythematous, and tender to touch. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Slit-lamp examination shows an anterior chamber flare with signs of iris inflammation bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Asymmetric arthritis that lasts > 6 weeks and involves ≤ 4 joints in combination with chronic bilateral anterior uveitis and positive antinuclear antibodies is typical of a specific type of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA).

A. Psoriatic juvenile arthritis
B. Postinfectious arthritis
C. Seronegative polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis
D. Acute lymphocytic leukemia
E. Enthesitis-related arthritis
F. Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis
G. Oligoarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent lower back pain for 1 week. His symptoms began shortly after lifting heavy boxes at work. He has not had any fever, chills, or weight loss. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild paraspinal lumbar tenderness. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An x-ray of the spine shows no abnormalities. The pharmacotherapy for this patient's condition should include which of the following agents? Conservative management with analgesics and physical therapy is recommended for acute, mild musculoskeletal back pain, but the appropriate pharmacotherapy should not exacerbate preexisting comorbidities.

A. Aspirin
B. Cyclobenzaprine
C. Oxycodone
D. Acetaminophen
E. Ibuprofen

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of acne on her face and chest. She has no itching or scaling. She is concerned about the possibility of facial scarring and has never sought treatment. She has no history of serious illness. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (130 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several open comedones on the face and chest. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment? Open comedones (also known as blackheads) on the face and chest are characteristic of mild noninflammatory acne vulgaris.

A. Oral antibiotics
B. Topical benzoyl peroxide
C. Combined oral contraceptive
D. Topical antibiotic
Oral isotretinoin
Correct Answer: B

Question
A 66-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue for 6 months. He says that he wakes up every morning feeling tired. Most days of the week he feels sleepy during the day and often takes an afternoon nap for an hour. His wife says he snores in the middle of the night. He has a history of heart failure and atrial fibrillation. His medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and warfarin. He drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily with dinner; he does not smoke. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 96 kg (212 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His pulse is 98/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a low-lying palate. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and no murmurs. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient with symptoms of daytime sleepiness and snoring likely has obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Standardized questionnaires and third-party reports identify risk factors like the ones seen here, such as male sex, obesity, alcohol consumption, and a low-lying palate, which can impair respiratory flow.

A. ENT evaluation
B. Overnight pulse oximetry
C. Home sleep apnea testing
D. In-laboratory polysomnography
E. Echocardiography

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother 30 minutes after reporting intense pain in both hands. The patient has sickle cell anemia and has been to the emergency department 2 times over the past year because of similar symptoms. Her mother gave her acetaminophen, but the pain continued. Physical examination shows swelling and severe tenderness in her fingers and hands. The diagnosis of an acute sickle cell crisis is established and intranasal fentanyl is ordered for pain control. When the physician informs the patient's mother, she refuses to give consent for the treatment. She says, “My daughter already has this awful illness, she can't get addicted to opiates too. I'm a social worker and have seen so many people get hooked on morphine and then overdose. Most of the time they got it from their doctor first!” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? In situations like this one, it is important to balance the ethical principles of beneficence and nonmaleficence with maintaining respect for parental autonomy.“You must have seen a lot as a social worker. Please tell me more about the cases of morphine addiction that you have seen.”10%
“I urge you to reconsider. I know you don't want your daughter to be in pain and this is her best treatment option.”3%
"I am sorry, but in emergency situations like this, I have the authority to treat your daughter without your consent."3%
“If you don't consent to treatment with morphine, we can try to give her a different nonopioid medication and see if that helps.”14%
"I understand your concern. Would you mind if I shared some information about the chances of addiction in this situation? "70%

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 5-day-old breast-fed male newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin. He was born at term following a vaginal delivery at home. The mother states that, initially, the newborn fed well every 2–3 hours but developed poor feeding and irritability over the past 24 hours. The mother received no prenatal care during her pregnancy. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 35th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin. His serum unconjugated bilirubin concentration is 31.5 mg/dL. The physician explains to the parents that the newborn must receive an exchange transfusion and phototherapy. The parents refuse to consent to the treatment and request immediate discharge, stating that they want to try "natural” treatment options such as ginger tea and sunbathing. Despite counseling about the consequences of not treating the child, the parents do not change their decision. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician? This newborn's severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (> 30 mg/dL) puts him at increased risk of bilirubin encephalopathy (i.e., kernicterus), which leads to permanent neurological damage and potentially death.

A. Seek a court order to override the parents' decision
B. Admit the patient and initiate appropriate treatment
C. Discharge the patient and notify child protective services
D. Discharge the patient after the parents sign an "against medical advice" form

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has one sexual partner with whom she had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. She does not wish to become pregnant at this time and is interested in a reliable and long-term contraceptive method. She has read in detail about the reliability, adverse effects, health risks, and effective duration of intrauterine devices (IUD) as a birth control method. She requests the physician to prescribe and place an IUD for her. The physician feels that providing contraception would be a violation of her own religious beliefs. Which of the following responses by the physician is most appropriate? In determining the best course of action, both the patient's preferences for their treatment as well as the physician's misgivings are valid and should be taken into account.“Prescribing any means of contraception is against my religious beliefs, but as a doctor, I am obliged to place the IUD for you.”2%
“I need to discuss this with my pastor before I decide whether to insert an IUD, as this is against my religious beliefs.”0%
“I can understand your need for the IUD, but I cannot place it for you due to my religious beliefs. I would be happy to refer you to a colleague who could do it.”93%
“I understand your concerns, but I cannot place the IUD for you due to my religious beliefs. I recommend you use condoms instead.0%
“First, I would like to perform an STD panel since you are sexually active.”4%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, malaise, and severe right knee joint pain and swelling for 3 days. He has also had episodes of abdominal pain and epistaxis during this period. Five days ago, he had swelling and pain in his left ankle joint which has since resolved. He reports having a sore throat 3 weeks ago while he was camping in the woods, for which he received symptomatic treatment. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 119/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, tender right knee; range of motion is limited. There are painless 3 to 4-mm nodules over the elbow. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 11,800/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 63 mm/h. Arthrocentesis of the right knee joint yields clear, straw-colored fluid. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 1350/mm3 with 17% neutrophils; no organisms are identified on Gram stain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Migratory polyarthritis, subcutaneous nodules, and fever following an upper respiratory tract infection are suggestive of an immune-mediated sequela of an infectious disease.

A. Acute rheumatic fever
B. Septic arthritis
C. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
D. Infective endocarditis
E. Lyme disease
F. Kawasaki disease
G. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well but is unhappy about being overweight. She reports that she feels out of breath when walking for more than one block and while climbing stairs. She has tried to lose weight for several years without success. She goes for a walk 3 times a week but she has difficulty following a low-calorie diet. During the past 12 months, she has had two urinary tract infections that were treated with fosfomycin. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis. Her only current medication is metformin. She has never smoked. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 39 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows cracking in both knees on passive movement. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show an HbA1c of 9.5%, and a fasting serum glucose concentration of 158 mg/dL. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? This patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with recurrent urinary tract infections, and a hemoglobin A1c of 9.5%, both of which suggest insufficient glycemic control with her current medication regimen. The patient's desire to lose weight should also be considered when adjusting her treatment.

A. Exenatide
B. Pioglitazone
C. Glyburide
D. Acarbose
E. Dapagliflozin
F. Phentermine
G. Saxagliptin

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 35-year-old soldier is rescued from a helicopter crash in the Arctic Circle and brought back to a treatment facility at a nearby military base. On arrival, the patient's wet clothes are removed. He appears pale and is not shivering. He is unresponsive to verbal and painful stimuli. His temperature is 27.4°C (81.3°F), pulse is 30/min and irregular, respirations are 7/min, and blood pressure is 83/52 mm Hg. Examination shows fixed, dilated pupils and diffuse rigidity. The fingers and toes are white in color and hard to the touch. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. In addition to emergent intubation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's pallor, hypotension, fixed pupils, arrhythmia, and core body temperature < 28°C (82°F) indicate a diagnosis of severe hypothermia.

A. Increasing the temperature of the room
B. Intravenous administration of tissue plasminogen activator
C. Intravenous administration of diltiazem
D. Application of heating pads to the extremities
E. Intravenous administration of warmed normal saline
F. Emergent electrical cardioversion

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive numbness and weakness in her right arm and right leg for 1 day. Two months ago, she had blurry vision and headache for a week, which resolved without treatment. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/71 mm Hg. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the right arm and leg and 5/5 on the left side. MRI of the brain shows gadolinium-enhancing lesions in the left central sulcus, cervical spinal cord, and optic nerve. Intravenous methylprednisolone therapy is started. This drug is most likely to result in which of the following laboratory changes? This woman has multiple sclerosis and is being treated with a potent glucocorticoid. Glucocorticoids influence the numbers of circulating immune cells. They increase the number of neutrophils but have an opposite effect on other immune cell populations.

A. Basophilia
B. Anemia
C. Monocytosis
D. Lymphocytosis
E. Eosinopenia
F. Granulocytopenia

Correct Answer: E

Question
Ten days after admission to the hospital for the management of right middle lobe aspiration pneumonia, a 75-year-old man develops a gradual decrease in his oxygen saturation. He had a vertebrobasilar stroke 3 years ago and had been living in a nursing home since the stroke. In the emergency department, rapid sequence intubation was performed, the patient was mechanically ventilated, and empirical antibiotic therapy was initiated. Currently, his temperature is 38.7°C (101.7° F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85% with an FiO2 of 0.6. On pulmonary examination, scattered crackles are heard bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral opacities in all lung fields. This patient's current condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathophysiologic changes? The presence of worsening respiratory distress, pulmonary crackles, persistent hypoxemia despite high FiO2 on invasive ventilation, and normal cardiac exam are consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), probably caused by aspiration pneumonia.

A. Decreased alveolar dead space
B. Increased pulmonary wedge pressure
C. Decreased pulmonary artery pressure
D. Decreased pulmonary compliance
E. Increased mixed venous oxygen saturation
F. Decreased shunt fraction

Correct Answer: D

Question
An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he has vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk-based formula. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and platelet count is 118,000/mm3. A nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? The x-ray shows gas within the wall of the intestine (i.e., pneumatosis intestinalis) and evidence of portal venous gas, which is diagnostic of this condition.

A. Hirschsprung disease
B. Meckel diverticulum
C. Meconium ileus
D. Malrotation with volvulus
E. Cow milk protein allergy
F. Intussusception
G. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
H. Duodenal atresia
. Necrotizing enterocolitis

Correct Answer: I

Question
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of fever and a non-itchy rash. The mother reports that he has had difficulty eating since yesterday. He has not had a cough, nausea, or vomiting. He was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Question
A surgeon who is on-call for the weekend is called in to perform an emergency appendectomy on a 19-year-old man who was diagnosed with perforated appendicitis and generalized peritonitis in the emergency department. The patient retained decision-making capacity at the time of diagnosis and a surgical resident obtained informed consent from the patient for the procedure. The on-call surgeon is 30 minutes late and the operating room staff is unable to reach her by telephone to confirm the instruments and materials she requires for the procedure. When she arrives, the scrub technician smells alcohol on the surgeon's breath and then confirms this suspicion with the nurse anesthetist present for the case. If the on-call surgeon performs the procedure in her current state, which of the following principles of patient care would most likely be violated? A physician who is impaired (e.g., an intoxicated surgeon) has a higher risk of committing a medical error that causes injury to the patient.

A. Beneficience
B. Justice
C. Autonomy
D. Nonmaleficience

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of a cough and shortness of breath. He also noted several episodes of blood-tinged sputum over the last 4 days. He has a 3-month history of progressive fatigue. His temperature is 37.5°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/93 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Laboratory studies show:He is started on prednisone and cyclophosphamide. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Fatigue, cough with hemoptysis, elevated creatinine and urea nitrogen, and nephritic sediment (hematuria, red blood cell casts, proteinuria) on urinalysis indicate pulmonary-renal syndrome. Evidence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM) is diagnostic for Goodpasture syndrome.

A. Administer inhalative fluticasone
B. Administer moxifloxacin
C. Perform hemodialysis
D. Administer immune globulins
E. Administer rituximab
F. Perform plasmapheresis
G. Administer enalapril

Correct Answer: F

Question

Question

Question

Question

Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 3-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department 6 hours after the onset of fever and persistent irritability. He had been well until 2 days ago, when he started feeding poorly and sleeping more than usual. He appears lethargic and irritable when roused for examination. His temperature is 39.0°C (102°F). His total serum bilirubin is 6.3 mg/dL. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:Gram stain results of the cerebrospinal fluid are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic regimen for this patient? The presence of fever, lethargy, and irritability in a neonate with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings of neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose concentration, increased opening pressure, and protein concentration is highly suggestive of late-onset bacterial neonatal meningitis. The pathogens that most commonly cause this disease are group B streptococcus, gram-negative bacilli (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species), and Listeria monocytogenes.

Question

Question

B. Penile prosthesis placement
C. Extracorporeal shockwave therapy

Question
Immediately after undergoing a right total knee replacement, a 69-year-old woman has severe abdominal pain, nonbloody vomiting, and confusion. She has a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis that is well-controlled with levothyroxine and hyperlipidemia that is controlled by diet. She underwent bunion removal surgery from her right foot 10 years ago. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a diffusely tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. The patient is confused and oriented to person but not place or time. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's history of an autoimmune disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis) and clinical presentation (shock, abdominal pain, and fever) directly after surgery should raise concern for adrenal crisis, a life-threatening complication of adrenal insufficiency. Primary adrenal insufficiency (i.e., Addison disease) due to autoimmune adrenalitis is often associated with other autoimmune endocrinopathies and is commonly subclinical until an adrenal crisis is triggered by a stressful event.

B. Noncontrast CT of the head
C. Intravenous hypotonic saline infusion
D. Exploratory laparotomy
E. CT angiography of the abdomen

Question
A 28-year-old Marine comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of a 3-week history of pain on urination. He returned from a deployment to Egypt 3 months ago, where he spent 6 months on a mission on the Nile. He has no personal history of serious illness. His father died of metastatic prostate cancer at 82 years of age. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. This patient's urine microscopy shows parasitic eggs with a prominent terminal spine, a distinctive feature of Schistosoma haematobium, which is endemic to Africa and the Middle East. B. Metronidazole
C. Prednisolone
D. Ivermectin
E. Ciprofloxacin

Question
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-sided abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104.0°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The ultrasound shows a multiseptated hepatic lesion with an anechoic fluid center with enhancement of the septae and surrounding parenchyma on contrast-enhanced ultrasound. In conjunction with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, high fever, neutrophilic leukocytosis, and elevated liver enzymes, this patient most likely has a multiloculated pyogenic liver abscess (PLA).

C. Measure serum alpha-fetoprotein levels

E. Resect the left liver lobe

G. Administer metronidazole

Question
A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department 35 minutes after the sudden onset of dizziness and palpitations. He says his symptoms began while watching TV and resolved spontaneously after 10 minutes. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He had two myocardial infarctions over the past year. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 6 months ago. His medications are aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, ramipril, and atorvastatin. While the nurse is recording an ECG, his symptoms suddenly start again. The patient appears in mild distress but is alert and fully oriented. His pulse is 160/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG is shown. One minute later, a repeat ECG shows the same findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's ECG shows two normal sinus beats followed by continuous wide (∼ 140 ms) monomorphic QRS complexes with a heart rate of ∼ 160/min, and atrioventricular dissociation, which is consistent with sustained (> 30 seconds) monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). He has no features of unstable tachycardia (e.g., altered mental status or loss of consciousness, hypotension, respiratory distress, ischemic chest pain).

A. Intravenous procainamide
B. Intravenous magnesium sulfate
C. Synchronized cardioversion
D. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator
E. Defibrillation

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of 2 episodes of loss of consciousness over the past week. She recovered immediately and was not confused following the episodes. During the past 5 months, she has also had increased shortness of breath and palpitations. She has been unable to carry out her daily activities. She also reports some chest tightness that resolves with rest. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She immigrated with her family from India 10 years ago. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 115/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention and pitting edema below the knees. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows accentuation and splitting of S2. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur in the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation and right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these findings? This patient has features of mitral stenosis (opening snap and diastolic murmur along with atrial fibrillation) that has progressed and caused further hemodynamic changes. Mitral stenosis commonly occurs as a late complication of rheumatic fever, which is more common in developing countries where patients may not have been adequately treated.

A. Increased left ventricular end diastolic pressure
B. Left-to-right shunting
C. Decreased left ventricular contractility
D. Increased systemic arterial resistance
E. Increased preload
F. Increased left atrial pressure

Correct Answer: F

Question

Question
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Question
An otherwise healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations. He says that he can feel his heartbeat in his chest all the time. For the past 3 weeks, he has had shortness of breath on exertion. He has not had chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at the age of 25 years. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? VIDEOThe peak of the carotid pulse upstroke occurs immediately after S1. In this patient, there is a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse upstroke, which is consistent with a diastolic timing. With early diastolic murmurs, the S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation, as is the case here.

A. Mitral valve regurgitation
B. Pulmonary valve stenosis
C. Aortic valve regurgitation
D. Tricuspid valve regurgitation
E. Aortic valve stenosis
F. Mitral valve stenosis
G. Mitral valve prolapse

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 43-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe central chest pain, mild shortness of breath, and one episode of coughing up blood since waking up that morning. The pain worsens on inspiration, and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. Three months ago, she underwent a left modified radical mastectomy for invasive ductal carcinoma. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0 °F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The left lower extremity is swollen and erythematous. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count, serum creatinine concentration of 1.0 mg/dL, and a creatinine clearance of 81 mL/min (N = 75–115). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management? Acute dyspnea, hemoptysis, and pleuritic chest pain raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism (PE). This patient's Wells score for PE is 9.5 (1.5 points for HR > 100/min, 1 for hemoptysis, 1 for malignancy, 3 for clinical features of deep venous thrombosis, and 3 for no diagnosis that better explains the symptoms), which indicates a high pretest probability of PE (a modified Wells score of > 4 indicates that PE is likely; an original Wells score of > 6 indicates that there is a high probability of PE).

A. CT pulmonary angiography
B. D-dimer measurement
C. Catheter embolectomy
D. Compression ultrasonography scan
E. Alteplase therapy
F. Low molecular weight heparin therapy
G. Echocardiography

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of nocturia. He wakes up twice each night to urinate. He has no involuntary leakage of urine and no history of serious illness. He takes no medication. His younger brother was diagnosed with testicular cancer at the age of 35 years. Rectal examination shows a smooth, symmetrical prostate without nodules. The remainder of the examination and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Bladder ultrasonography discloses a postvoid residual volume of 10 mL (N < 50). The physician offers to discuss the advantages and limitations of the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test in screening for prostate cancer. He mentions that a serum PSA of 4 ng/mL is generally used as a cutoff value. At this cutoff, the test has a sensitivity of 21% for detecting any prostate cancer and 51% for detecting high-risk prostate cancer, with a specificity of 91%. In patients without urinary retention, hematuria, back pain, or incontinence, the positive predictive value (PPV) for PSA > 4 ng/mL is estimated at 30%, and the negative predictive value (NPV) for PSA ≤ 4 ng/mL at 85%. Based on this information, what is the probability that this patient does not have prostate cancer if his PSA is 4.3 ng/mL? In this scenario, PSA values are used as a test for prostate cancer with a value above the cutoff of 4 ng/mL being considered a positive test and a value ≤ 4 ng/mL considered a negative test. The positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a patient who tests positive truly does have the disease of interest, i.e., P (disease | positive test) when expressed as a conditional probability.21%
2%
79%
5%
85%
7%
15%
7%
30%
9%
70%
62%
9%
8%

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right shoulder pain. He landed on his shoulder after falling off a bike 1 hour ago.
