There is swelling and tenderness over the superior, anterior aspect of the shoulder; active range of motion is intact. When the patient's arm is adducted across his body, the pain becomes worse. The remainder of the examination, including cervical spine examination and neurovascular examination of the right arm, shows no abnormalities. In addition to ice application and analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? A positive cross-arm adduction test and tenderness over the acromioclavicular (AC) joint following direct trauma to the shoulder is suggestive of an AC joint injury.

A. Perform immediate closed reduction
B. Perform an x-ray of the shoulder
C. Perform an MRI of the shoulder
D. Administer intraarticular glucocorticoids
E. Place a shoulder slingNo further intervention is necessary

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of gradually worsening pain in his right groin. The pain increases during and after physical exercise, especially when climbing stairs. After waking up in the morning, the right hip feels stiff for up to 20 minutes. He has not sustained any recent trauma. His father died of lung cancer at the age of 78 years. He has hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. He drinks one 12-oz beer daily. Current medications are valsartan and tamsulosin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg. Examination of the right hip shows a limited internal rotation; there is crepitus, and pain with full flexion and extension. The right inguinal area is soft without any palpable masses. Muscle strength is 5/5 bilaterally. Leukocyte count is 4,500/mm3, erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 16 mm/h, and serum uric acid concentration is 7.3 mg/dL. An x-ray of this patient's right hip is most likely to show which of the following findings? The combination of chronic joint pain that worsens with movement and is associated with limited range of motion, morning stiffness lasting < 30 minutes, and crepitus suggest osteoarthritis (OA). Risk factors for OA include age > 55 years and obesity.

A. Marginal bone erosions and opaque periarticular soft tissue
B. Cartilage calcification
C. Joint-space narrowing and subchondral sclerosis
D. Cartilage erosions and bone demineralization
E. Diffuse lytic bone lesions

Correct Answer: C

Question

B. Pituitary adenoma

Question

Question
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past 4 months. Initially, his symptoms occurred only while climbing stairs, but now they are also present at rest. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He was diagnosed with gastric cancer 11 months ago and was treated with chemotherapy and surgery. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His respirations are 22/min; other vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows a well-healed midline laparotomy scar, jugular venous distension, mild hepatomegaly, and bilateral 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Cardiac examination shows a loud P2 and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur best heard in the fourth left intercostal space near the sternal border. Bruits that become louder with inspiration are heard diffusely over both lung fields. Serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows enlargement of the central pulmonary trunk, a prominent right heart border, and decreased vascular markings. Echocardiography shows dilation and hypertrophy of the right ventricle, dilation of the right atrium, and regurgitant flow across the tricuspid valve during systole. Spirometry shows no abnormalities. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg at rest (N = 10–20) and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg (N = 5–16). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's cardiac catheterization findings? This patient's clinical features (pedal edema, jugular venous distention, tricuspid regurgitation, loud P2) and cardiac catheterization findings (increased mean pulmonary arterial pressure) indicate that the patient has developed pulmonary hypertension (PH) and right heart failure, (i.e., cor pulmonale), without left heart failure (normal pulmonary capillary wedge pressure).

A. Hereditary proliferative vasculopathy
B. Recurrent pulmonary embolism
C. Serotonin-producing hepatic metastases
D. Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction
E. Chemotherapy-induced cardiomyopathy

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

She goes shopping, cooks her own meals, and plays bridge with her friends every weekend. She is not anxious about her memory lapses. Question

Question
A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after having fallen from the balcony of his fifth-floor apartment. Emergency medical technicians arrived at the scene of injury 10 minutes after the fall and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) en route to the hospital. On arrival, he is unconscious and has a Glasgow coma score of 3. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F) and he has nonpalpable pulses with asystole on ECG. CPR is continued and the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Chest auscultation discloses clear lung fields with bilateral air entry and absent heart sounds. Point of care ultrasound shows visible sliding of the pleura and no cardiac wall motion. There is no evidence of fluid in the pericardium, ventricular dilation, or inferior vena cava collapse. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen shows a pH of 7.36 and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Despite continuing CPR for another 20 minutes, the ECG recordings persistently show asystole. The pupils are 9 mm and nonreactive to light. End-tidal carbon dioxide is 8 mm Hg (N = 35–45) and serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Two emergency medicine residents in their first postgraduate year ask the attending physician if they can practice femoral vein catheterization and scalpel cricothyroidotomy on the patient. There are no advanced directives or emergency medical contacts in the patient's electronic health record. At this time, which of the following is the most appropriate directive by the attending physician to the team treating the patient? In this patient, reversible causes of posttraumatic cardiac arrest (e.g., tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, exsanguination, asphyxiation) have been excluded. Before making a decision, the attending physician must consider the following scenario-specific features: high-energy trauma, out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, late initiation of CPR, a cumulative CPR time > 30 minutes without return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) or a rhythm change at any point, end-tidal CO2< 10 mmHg, and an examination finding suggestive of brainstem areflexia.

A. Continue CPR and attempt to contact the patient's family
B. Pronounce death and attempt to contact the patient's family
C. Pronounce death and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision
D. Pronounce death and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
E. Continue CPR and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
F. Continue CPR and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 32-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of recurrent episodes of vomiting. He has had over 15 episodes of bilious vomiting. During this period he has had cramping abdominal pain but has not had a bowel movement or passed flatus. He does not have fever or diarrhea. He was diagnosed with Crohn disease at the age of 28 years which has been well controlled with oral mesalamine. He underwent a partial small bowel resection for midgut volvulus at birth. His other medications include vitamin B12, folic acid, loperamide, ferrous sulfate, and vitamin D3. He appears uncomfortable and his lips are parched. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. The abdomen is distended, tympanitic, and tender to palpation over the periumbilical area and the right lower quadrant. Rectal examination is unremarkable. A CT scan of the abdomen shows multiple dilated loops of small bowel with a transition zone in the mid to distal ileum. After 24 hours of conservative management with IV fluid resuscitation, nasogastric bowel decompression, promethazine, and analgesia, his condition does not improve and a laparotomy is scheduled. During the laparotomy, two discrete strictures are noted mid-ileum, around 20 cm apart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's symptoms (abdominal pain, vomiting, obstipation), CT scan, and laparotomy findings are consistent with small bowel obstruction (SBO). Surgical treatment is indicated because conservative measures have failed. Given this patient's history of Crohn disease and a previous small bowel resection, any abdominal surgical procedure should focus on bowel preservation and minimize further complications (e.g., short bowel syndrome, postoperative adhesions and fistulas).

A. Ileocolectomy
B. Strictureplasty of individual strictures
C. Small bowel resection and primary anastomosis
D. Discontinue surgery and start palliative care
E. Small bowel resection with ileostomy

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
The chief medical officer at an obstetrics and gynecology clinic has noticed an increased refusal rate for the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine among teenage girls over the past 6 months. The chief medical officer meets with all physicians who provide vaccination counseling and performs mock consultations for training. In response to a simulated patient query about the risk of syncope from the quadrivalent HPV vaccine, an attending physician who has experienced very low rates of vaccination refusal says, “More than 99.99% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine did not report any adverse effects and only 0.008% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine had significant lightheadedness.” In response to the same query, an intern who has experienced comparatively higher rates of vaccination refusal says, “Approximately 50 in 100,000 patients who receive the quadrivalent vaccine report at least one adverse effect, and approximately 15% of those who reported an adverse effect had significant lightheadedness as one of the adverse effects.” When compared to the attending physician's response, which of the following types of cognitive bias is most likely to affect a patient who hears the intern's response? Both the attending physician and the intern present the same information. However, the intern's phrasing of the response, which focuses more on the vaccine's negative outcomes, might influence patients' decision-making process and lead to vaccination refusal.

A. Framing
B. Anchoring
C. Visceral
D. Confirmation
E. Availability

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of palpitations and loose stools. She has had a 2.3-kg (5-lb) weight loss over the past month. Question

Correct Answer: H

Question
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following? The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.

A. Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
B. Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
C. Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
D. Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
E. Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of increasing confusion and lethargy. He reports decreased urine output and abdominal pain for the past month. Two months ago, he was hospitalized for pyelonephritis and treated with ceftriaxone. He has a history of chronic hepatitis C. He does not take any medications. He appears pale and irritable. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person but not to time or place. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave. Laboratory studies show:Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. FENa is < 1%. Ultrasound of the kidneys is unremarkable. Intravenous fluids are administered for 36 hours but do not improve urine output. Which of the following is the most likely cause of kidney dysfunction in this patient? Ascites, jaundice, and laboratory results showing impaired liver function, prolonged prothrombin time, and hematologic abnormalities in a patient with untreated hepatitis C infection is highly suggestive of decompensated liver cirrhosis. Thrombocytopenia and leukopenia in patients with cirrhosis are typically due to hypersplenism from portal hypertension, while the cause of anemia is often multifactorial (e.g., hypersplenism, blood loss, vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency).

A. Renal interstitial inflammation
B. Immune-mediated mesangial proliferation
C. Renal vein thrombosis
D. Decreased renal perfusion
E. Renal tubular injury
F. Renal microvascular thrombi

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the office because of poor performance in school since he started first grade 6 months ago. His teacher says he is not learning at the same pace as his classmates and that he often has temper tantrums, especially when he does not get enough attention. The mother reports that her son has been “chubby” since he was a toddler and that he has had a 10-kg weight gain over the last year. He had cryptorchidism requiring orchiopexy at 2 years of age. He started walking at 27 months of age. He speaks using 2-word sentences. He is at the 8th percentile for height and 90th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows central obesity. Eyes are almond-shaped and deviate inward in primary gaze position. Hands and feet are small for his age. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications? This patient has excessive weight gain (likely due to hyperphagia), short stature (due to growth hormone deficiency), behavioral problems, developmental delay, intellectual disability, small hands and feet, and facial dysmorphia, all of which suggest Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).

A. Hyperthyroidism
B. Type 1 diabetes mellitus
C. Precocious puberty
D. Choking episodes
E. Conduct disorder

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fatigue over the past 6 months. During this period, the patient has also had a 5 kg (11-lb) weight loss. Laboratory studies show a serum alanine aminotransferase level of 190 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase level of 250 U/L, and serum total bilirubin level of 0.6 mg/dL. B. Positive antismooth muscle antibodies
C. Positive antimitochondrial antibodies
D. Decreased serum ceruloplasmin concentration
E. Positive HBV surface antigen
F. Elevated serum transferrin saturation
G. Positive perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

Question

She has told her father that aliens are trying to infiltrate her mind and that she has to continuously listen to the radio to monitor these activities. She appears anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Mental status examination shows psychomotor agitation. She says: “I can describe how the aliens chase me except for my car which is parked in the garage. You know, the sky is beautiful today. Why does my mother have a cat? ” Which of the following best describes this patient's thought process? A. Circumstantial speech
B. Thought-blocking
C. Loose associations
D. Flight of ideas
E. Clang associations
F. Word salad

Question
A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 6-week history of sleeping difficulties because she thinks that someone is watching her through security cameras. She avoids going outside whenever possible and refuses to take the subway. Whenever she needs to leave the house she wears large hats or hooded sweaters so that she cannot be recognized by the cameras. As soon as she arrives at her office or at home she feels safer. She was recently promoted to the team manager of a small advertising agency. She takes no medications. On mental status examination, she is alert, oriented, and shows a normal range of affect. B. Agoraphobia

Question
A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 2-day history of nonbloody diarrhea. The patient has had 8–10 bowel movements daily and has not vomited. She has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metoprolol, metformin, and dapagliflozin. She appears ill and sleepy. She is 157 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 109 kg (240 lb); BMI is 44 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2 °F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. A fingerstick glucose test shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Which of the following is the most likely acid-base abnormality in this patient? Using the Winter formula, i.e., expected pCO2 = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (+/- 2), the expected pCO2 for an HCO3- concentration of 16 mEq/L is between 30 and 34 mm Hg.

A. Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
B. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
C. Respiratory acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
D. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
E. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of redness, swelling, and pain of the right leg. During this time, he also has had fever, chills, and nausea. He reports seeing liquid oozing from the affected area on his right leg. He has hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Three months ago, he was hospitalized for treatment of a hip fracture. His current medications include metoprolol, enalapril, and omeprazole. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 142/94 mm Hg. Examination of the right lower leg shows a large area of erythema with poorly-demarcated borders and purulent drainage. The area is fluctuant, warm, and tender to touch. Examination of the right groin shows several enlarged, tender lymph nodes. There is mild edema of the ankles bilaterally. In addition to incision, drainage, and taking cultures from the wound, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Tender, erythematous skin with diffuse borders that is draining pus is most likely the result of purulent cellulitis, which is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to incision and drainage, systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated for purulent cellulitis with systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever, tachycardia) and/or immunosuppression.

A. Oral clindamycin
B. Intravenous vancomycin
C. Surgical debridement
D. Oral dicloxacillin
E. Oral cephalexin
F. Intravenous ciprofloxacin

Correct Answer: B

Question
A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of intermittent double vision and a tremor of the fingers. He is a physician doing his residency in general surgery; the tremor and periods of double vision have kept him from participating in surgeries during the past month. During this time, he has also had difficulty sleeping, increased frequency of bowel movements, and a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss despite an increased appetite. He has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. He has been drinking 3 to 4 cups of coffee daily for the past 9 years. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), pulse is 105/min and regular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 145/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a fine, low-amplitude tremor of the fingers when he extends his arms in front of his body. There is retraction of the upper eye lids, anterior protrusion of both eyeballs, and restricted convergence during accommodation reflex testing. Neurologic examination shows normal muscle strength, bulk, and tone. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperactive. There is no dysmetria and sensation is intact. Serum studies show a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.03 μU/mL, thyroxine concentration of 19 μg/dL, and antibodies against the TSH receptor. Thyroid scintigraphy shows diffusely increased iodine uptake. Treatment with propranolol is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? Thyrotoxicosis with elevated serum antibodies against the TSH receptor (TRAbs) is diagnostic of Graves disease (GD), which in this patient is complicated by moderate Graves orbitopathy (GO), as indicated by intermittent diplopia and exophthalmos. This complication should be taken into account when addressing this patient's hyperthyroidism.

A. Thyroid lobectomy
B. Near-total thyroidectomy
C. Oral methimazole therapy
D. Radioactive iodine ablation
E. Tocilizumab therapy

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, lethargy, and swelling of the lower legs for 2 months. She reports recurrent episodes of pain in both wrists, her right knee, and her right ankle in the past year. She has had skin problems that are aggravated by exposure to sunlight for the past 18 months. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 13 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally and periorbital edema. There are erythematous patches with scaling on both cheeks. Laboratory studies show:A renal biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following? Edema, massive proteinuria, fatty casts, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is most commonly caused by membranous nephropathy in adults of European, Middle Eastern, or North African descent. Recurrent arthralgia, fatigue, photosensitivity, and a discoid rash suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) as an underlying cause.

A. Thickened capillary loops
B. Nodular glomerulosclerosis
C. Segmental sclerosis
D. Crescent formation
E. Apple-green birefringence
F. Splitting of basement membrane

Question
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He did not lose consciousness. He has pain in his right arm, forehead, and pelvis. He also has an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. He appears uncomfortable. There are abrasions over his scalp and face and a 1 x 3 cm area of ecchymosis above his right eye. His pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. Musculoskeletal examination shows tenderness and ecchymosis over the right distal forearm with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill. There is no tenderness of the cervical spine. B. Intravenous pyelography
C. Retrograde cystography
D. Foley catheterization

Question

She occasionally becomes confused in the evenings. Her blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg when supine and 124/80 mm Hg while standing. Muscle tone is increased in the upper extremities. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. There is conjugate limitation of both eyes when looking down. Mental status examination shows apathy. The patient responds to questions with 1–2 words after a delay of several seconds. MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A. Multiple system atrophy
B. Alzheimer disease
C. Progressive supranuclear palsy
D. Dementia with Lewy bodies
E. Normal pressure hydrocephalus
F. Parkinson disease

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 23-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1 is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 5-day history of anxiety and tearfulness. According to her mother, the patient “has not been herself” since the delivery of her 1-week-old son. “She spends hours sitting next to the crib to make sure the baby is still breathing and barely gets any sleep. She also doesn't let me hold the baby because she thinks I might drop him.” The patient has a good appetite and is breastfeeding without any issues. The patient's sister has a history of bipolar disorder. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an involuting uterus consistent in size with her postpartum date. Mental status examination shows no evidence of homicidal or suicidal ideation. During the examination, the patient asks the physician if there is anything wrong with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? This patient presents with anxiety, tearfulness, and insomnia without changes in appetite or breastfeeding. These symptoms have developed within 1 week of delivery."You most likely have the postpartum blues, which are very common after delivery. Let's schedule a follow-up appointment in 10 days."84%
"You most likely have the postpartum blues, which are very common after delivery. It takes some time to adjust to this new responsibilty, but you will feel better soon."8%
"You most likely have postpartum depression, which affects almost 1 in 10 women after delivery. I recommend we initiate antidepressant therapy."3%
"You most likely have postpartum depression, which affects almost 1 in 10 women after delivery. I recommend we initiate cognitive behavioral therapy."3%
"Given your family history, you most likely have postpartum psychosis. I'm afraid we will have to hospitalize you."1%

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 108/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather face mask shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Examination shows multiple bruises on the left anterior thoracic wall. Jugular venous pulsation is measured at 3 cm above the sternal angle with the head of the bed elevated at 30 degrees. The trachea is at the midline. On inspiration, his left chest wall moves inwards while his right chest wall is expanding. There is pain to palpation and crepitus over his left anterior ribs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? A. Needle thoracostomy
B. Positive pressure ventilation
C. Bedside thoracotomy
D. Pericardiocentesis
E. Surgical fixation

Question

Question

B. Serotonin syndrome
C. Increased BMI
D. Abnormal liver function
E. Decreased perspiration

Question

Question
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of progressive fatigue. His symptoms were preceded by a 3-day history of diarrheal illness with bloody stools and abdominal cramping that subsided 3 days ago. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He appears pale and is fully oriented. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Arterial blood gas analysis shows no abnormalities. A peripheral blood smear shows abundant helmet cells. Test of the stool for Shiga toxin is positive. ADAMTS13 activity is normal. The patient is admitted to the hospital, and intravenous fluid therapy is initiated. In addition to repeat blood counts and serum studies, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time? Thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin, helmet cells on peripheral blood smear), and acute kidney injury (increased creatinine and urea nitrogen) compose the classic triad of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This patient has positive stool testing for Shiga toxin, which confirms the diagnosis of Shiga toxin-associated HUS (ST-HUS).

A. Initiate plasma exchange therapy
B. No further management is indicated
C. Perform a renal biopsy
D. Administer ciprofloxacin
E. Administer prednisone and intravenous immune globulin

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 2-hour history of swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 30 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He appears distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, prothrombin time of 11 seconds, partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? This young man presents with deep vein thrombosis (swollen, tender leg with positive Homan sign, positive D-dimer, positive ultrasonography signs). Despite receiving a therapeutic dose of heparin, his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) hardly increases and remains within normal limits, suggesting a defect in the protein targeted by heparin.

A. Hyperhomocysteinemia
B. Antithrombin III deficiency
C. Factor V Leiden
D. Protein C deficiency
E. Antiphospholipid syndrome

Correct Answer: B

Question

A. Dislocated lens
B. Hearing impairment
C. Widely spaced permanent teeth
D. Cerebral berry aneurysm
E. Prominence of the costochondral junctions
F. Increased head circumference
G. Intellectual disability

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 64-year-old woman has progressively worsening abdominal pain 5 hours after an open valve replacement with cardiopulmonary bypass. The pain is crampy and associated with an urge to defecate. The patient reports having had 2 bloody bowel movements in the last hour. Her operation was complicated by significant intraoperative blood loss, which prolonged the operation and necessitated 2 transfusions of red blood cells. She has hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient received prophylactic perioperative antibiotics and opioid pain management during recovery. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 115/69 mm Hg. Rectal examination shows blood on the examining finger. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? C. Decreased blood flow to the splenic flexure

Question
A 69-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower back pain and right-sided chest pain for the past month. The pain is aggravated by movement. Over the past 2 months, she has had increasing fatigue. She has hypertension and reflux disease. Her mother died of breast cancer. Current medications include metoprolol and omeprazole. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows full muscle strength. There is tenderness to palpation over the lower spine and the right lateral chest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:An ECG shows no evidence of ischemia. An x-ray of the chest shows lytic lesions in 2 ribs. Blood smear shows aggregations of erythrocytes. Protein electrophoresis of the serum with immunofixation shows an M-protein spike. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings? This patient presents with bone pain, anemia, elevated creatinine, rouleaux formation (aggregation of erythrocytes) on peripheral blood smear, an M-protein spike on serum protein electrophoresis, and lytic bone lesions on x-ray, making multiple myeloma (MM) the most likely diagnosis.

A. Urinary tract infection
B. Leukemic hiatus
C. Splenomegaly
D. Jaundice
E. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
F. Richter transformation

Correct Answer: A

Question

The patient's vertical midline scar indicates that she has previously undergone a classical cesarean incision."Given your previous cesarean birth, I recommend scheduling a cesarean delivery for 37 weeks' gestation."49%
"We usually perform a cesarean delivery if the baby is in breech presentation at the time of labor, but we can try assisted vaginal delivery first if you wish to avoid surgery."5%
"Most fetuses spontaneously convert to cephalic presentation as they get closer to term. If that happens, a vaginal delivery will be possible."38%
"The baby is in breech presentation, and given your history, I recommend performing an external cephalic version."4%
"Because you had only one cesarean delivery in the past, the risk of uterine rupture during vaginal birth is low. Therefore, we can attempt a trial of labor."2%

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:Measurement of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? An arterial blood gas analysis with a pH of 7.56, pCO2 of 40 mm Hg, and HCO3- of 30 mEq/L is consistent with primary metabolic alkalosis. Question
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination, accompanied by his daughter. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with localized prostate cancer, for which he underwent radiation therapy. He moved to the area 1 month ago to be closer to his daughter but continues to live independently. He was recently diagnosed with osteoblastic metastases to the spine and is scheduled to initiate therapy next week. In private, the patient’s daughter says that he has been losing weight and wetting the bed, and she tearfully asks the physician if his prostate cancer has returned. She says that her father has not spoken with her about his health recently. The patient has previously expressed to the physician that he does not want his family members to know about his condition because they “would worry too much.” Which of the following initial statements by the physician is most appropriate? Physicians have an obligation to maintain patient confidentiality, which requires verbal or written consent from the patient before releasing medical information.“As your father's physician, I think that it's important that you know that his prostate cancer has returned. However, we are confident that he will respond well to treatment.”0%
“It’s difficult to deal with parents aging, but I have experience helping families cope. We should sit down with your father and discuss this situation together.”8%
“I'm sorry, I can't discuss any information with you without his permission. I recommend that you have an open discussion with your father.”82%
“It concerns me that he's not speaking openly with you. I recommend that you seek medical power of attorney for your father. Then, we can legally discuss his diagnosis and treatment options together.”0%
“Sorry, but because your father’s condition is not classified as a notifiable disease, I’m not permitted to discuss his medical information with you without first obtaining his consent.”7%
“Your father is very ill and may not want you to know the details. I can imagine it's frustrating for you, but you have to respect his discretion.”3%

Correct Answer: C

Question
Seven days after undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery, a 51-year-old man has continued sternal chest pain. The pain is sharp and does not worsen with deep inspirations or when he is walking up and down the hospital hallway. He has mild shortness of breath. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease, coronary artery disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin, metformin, aspirin, and clopidogrel. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/72 mm Hg. There is edema of the chest wall. The surgical incision site shows erythema. Cardiac examination discloses a crunching sound in synchronization with the heartbeat. Mildly decreased breath sounds are heard at the lung bases. His leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3. Preoperative nasal swabs were positive for methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus. Blood cultures are pending. ECG shows low voltage and wide Q waves and T wave inversions in leads V1 through V3. Chest x-ray shows small bilateral effusions and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Chest pain, fever, leukocytosis, and local signs of inflammation at the sternotomy incision in combination with findings that indicate pneumomediastinum (i.e., a Hamman crunch on cardiac auscultation, widened mediastinum on chest x-ray, and low voltage QRS complexes) suggest postoperative mediastinitis. B. Surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics
C. CT pulmonary angiography
D. Wound irrigation and packing
E. NSAIDs and creation of pericardial windowPercutaneous coronary intervention

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 51-year-old man is admitted to the hospital on the evening before a scheduled laparoscopic hernioplasty. He was diagnosed with a left direct inguinal hernia 4 months ago and requested a day-care surgery because he does not wish to stay in the hospital longer than is necessary. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. The on-call anesthetist completed his preoperative assessment on the day of admission and cleared the patient for surgery. On the day of the surgery, the anesthesiology resident, who is part of the team performing the procedure, reviews the patient's records, determines that the patient needs echocardiography, and informs the surgical resident responsible for the patient's care. The surgical resident believes that the patient does not require any further preoperative cardiac evaluation and that performing the evaluation would necessitate postponing the surgery to the next day. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the surgical resident to the request for preoperative echocardiography? The anesthetist and surgeon work in a team but they have different processes, priorities, and knowledge based on their training. These differences can lead to interpersonal disagreement/conflict. There are five common strategies for dealing with disagreement/conflict: forcing (competing), accommodating, avoiding, compromising, and collaborating. In health care, collaboration should be used whenever possible."I do not understand why the patient requires echocardiography. Would it be possible for you to discuss the case with my attending surgeon? "10%
"If we send the patient for echocardiography, his surgery will be delayed by at least one day. Can you please explain to me why you think this patient requires this test? "72%
"Based on my assessment of the patient's cardiac risk score, I believe that echocardiography is unnecessary in this situation. An argument could, however, be made for an ECG."5%
"I trust your professional judgment in this situation. If the echocardiography is important, we can delay the surgery and inform the patient."13%
"This patient does not want to stay in the hospital longer than necessary. Since he has already received preoperative clearance by an anesthetist, we must proceed with the surgery."0%

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A critical care fellow is interested in whether the auscultatory finding of pulmonary rales can accurately predict hypervolemic state. He conducts a study in 100 patients with a volume overloaded state confirmed by a Swan Ganz catheter in his hospital's cardiac critical care unit. He also recruits 100 patients with euvolemic state confirmed by Swan Ganz catheter. He subsequently examines all patients in the unit for rales and finds that 80 patients in the hypervolemic group have rales in comparison to 50 patients in the euvolemic group. Which of the following is the probability that a patient in the study with rales on auscultation truly has hypervolemia? It may help to create a two-by-two table with the values mentioned in the stem and then calculate the number of true positives (TP), true negatives (TN), false positives (FP), and false negatives (FN). The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that a patient with a positive test result (i.e., presence of rales on auscultation) truly has the condition (i.e., hypervolemia).80/10018%
50/1001%
80/13080%
50/701%
100/2000%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She is alert, awake, and oriented. There is no family history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen. A FAST scan of the abdomen is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows no fractures. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows a 4-cm sharply defined liver mass with a hypoattenuated central scar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has a 4-cm liver mass with a central hypoattenuated scar on a CT scan, which is diagnostic of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

A. Reassurance and observation
B. Biopsy of the mass
C. Avoid contact sports
D. Discontinue the oral contraceptive
E. Percutaneous aspiration of the mass
F. Surgical resection of the mass

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Over the past 6 months, she has had a 5.4-kg (12-lb) weight loss. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Weight loss, fatigue, splenomegaly, anemia, and thrombocytosis combined with leukocytosis with the presence of immature cells (left shift), increased numbers of granulocytes, and a higher number of immature myelocytes compared to more mature metamyelocytes on CBC, are highly suspicious for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

D. Flow cytometry
E. All-trans retinoic acid therapy

Question

Question
The chief medical officer of a health maintenance organization (HMO) receives reports from numerous healthcare providers at her organization that an increasing number of patients presenting with lower back pain receive CT and MRI scans unnecessarily and subsequently undergo follow-up workup for incidental findings. She observes that these referrals for imaging and the subsequent follow-up take up a large amount of the HMO's annual budget, which is primarily financed by a capitation reimbursement model. With the aim of decreasing the number of imaging referrals, she decides to purchase a validated computerized clinical decision support system (CDSS) that uses evidence-based clinical decision rules to assist physicians in determining whether a patient with low back pain requires imaging. A failure mode and effects analysis is conducted for the CDSS and anticipated barriers to using the CDSS are addressed. According to the Plan-Do-Study-Act (PDSA) paradigm, which of the following is the most appropriate subsequent action? The first phase (i.e., the "Plan" phase) of the PDSA cycle consists of preparing a new process or tool (e.g., a CDSS), identifying a quality improvement (QI) measure (e.g., the number of imaging referrals), and establishing a goal for the effect of the new process or tool (e.g., a decrease in the number of imaging referrals).

A. Obtain informed consent from patients presenting with low back pain
B. Prepare a backup plan to decrease the number of imaging referrals
C. Implement the CDSS for a specified time frame
D. Establish control limits for the number of imaging referrals
E. Modify the CDSS to remove unanticipated failure modes

Correct Answer: C

Question
A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of a new mRNA vaccine in preventing a viral infection. They conducted a pilot phase II study in which participants were randomized to receive either the new vaccine or a placebo vaccine. After one month of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators conclude that the study lacks statistical power because their study design was flawed. Assuming the investigators intended to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following factors most likely contributed to the low statistical power of the study? Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).

A. Large difference between the mean immune responses
B. Low probability of a type 2 error
C. Inadequate number of participants in the study
D. High precision of the tests used to measure the immune response
E. High probability of a type 1 error

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 23-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for an initial prenatal visit at 13 weeks' gestation. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 138/95 mm Hg. A repeated reading four hours later shows 142/93 mm Hg. Serum AST is 17 U/L and ALT is 19 U/L. Results of the urinalysis are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? A few, mild headaches are quite common during the first trimester because of changes in maternal hormones and are not of significant concern if they respond well to treatment. B. Eclampsia

Question

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 3-day history of face and foot swelling, dark urine, and a rash on her hands and feet. The mother reports that her daughter has had a low-grade fever, shortness of breath, and a dry cough for the past 8 days. She has had generalized weakness and pain in her right knee and ankle. She has a ventricular septum defect that was diagnosed at birth. The patient appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows small, nonblanching, purple lesions on her palms, soles, and under her fingernails. There is edema of the eyelids and feet. Fundoscopic examination shows retinal hemorrhages. Holosystolic and early diastolic murmurs are heard. Laboratory studies show:Transthoracic echocardiography shows a small outlet ventricular septum defect and a mild right ventricular enlargement. There are no wall motion abnormalities, valvular heart disease, or deficits in the pump function of the heart. Blood cultures grow Streptococcus pyogenes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Children with congenital heart disease are at increased risk of developing this condition.

A. Pneumonia
B. Infective endocarditis
C. Acute rheumatic fever
D. Hand, foot, and mouth disease
E. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
F. Systemic lupus erythematosus
G. Myocarditis
H. Kawasaki disease

Correct Answer: B

Question

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: C

Question

B. Klebsiella granulomatis
C. Herpes simplex virus

Question
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past 2 months, she has had increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago; she was happy to tell him last week that she is pregnant. B. Pseudocyesis
C. Malingering
D. Pregnancy
E. Couvade syndrome
F. Incomplete abortion
G. Ectopic pregnancy

Question
A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Severe ipsilateral head and neck pain and partial Horner syndrome (ptosis and miosis) in combination with duplex ultrasonography findings of absent flow in the left internal carotid artery indicate a carotid artery dissection. This patient also likely experienced the complication of a transient ischemic attack (TIA), characterized by extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax.

A. 100% oxygen
B. Sumatriptan
C. Mannitol
D. Heparin
E. Alteplase

Correct Answer: D

Question
One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition? This patient has clinical features of a stroke (e.g., facial droop, right-sided hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, headache) and a CT scan of the head that shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH; hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema) in the left hemisphere.

A. Degree of carotid stenosis
B. Aspirin therapy
C. Perioperative heparin
D. Hypertension
E. Smoking

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of multiple episodes of coughing up blood over the past 2 hours. He says that he has coughed up approximately half a cup of bright-red blood each time. He has had progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion and a productive cough with occasionally blood-tinged sputum for the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He drinks 2 to 3 beers every evening. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His medications include amlodipine, tiotropium, and an albuterol inhaler as needed. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 97/63 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. He appears anxious and cachectic. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the patient coughs up copious amounts of blood. His hemoglobin concentration is 11.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8800/mm3, and platelet count is 160,000/mm3. His coagulation parameters are within normal limits. A. Radionuclide scan
B. CT scan of the chest
C. Upper endoscopy
D. Surgery
E. Arteriography
F. Bronchoscopy

Correct Answer: F

B. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

Question
A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after falling from her bicycle 1 hour ago. The patient was on her way to work as she lost her balance, hitting her head on the sidewalk. She had an initial loss of consciousness for a couple of minutes following the accident. She currently has nausea and a headache. She has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. She has no history of a serious illness. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise on the right temporal side of the head. While the remainder of the physical examination is being performed, the patient starts having a seizure. Intravenous lorazepam is administered and she is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient? This patient had a brief recovery of consciousness (lucid interval) after experiencing head trauma, but now has signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), including nausea, headache, vomiting, seizure, and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea). All of these features suggest intracranial hemorrhage most likely due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery.

A. Ischemic stroke
B. Subdural hematoma
C. Intracerebral hemorrhage
D. Subarachnoidal hemorrhage
E. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
F. Epidural hematoma

Correct Answer: F

Question

Three days ago, she had a seizure but has not seen a physician. She is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is more than 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hypernatremia? This patient's features of dehydration (agitation, confusion, lethargy, prolonged capillary refill time) and hypernatremia with a low urine osmolality indicate severe diabetes insipidus (DI). Additionally, her recurring headaches, visual impairment, and recent seizure raise suspicion of a brain tumor.

B. Increased antidiuretic hormone secretion
C. Decreased antidiuretic hormone receptor activity
D. Increased adrenocorticotropin hormone secretion
E. Decreased antidiuretic hormone secretion

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of progressive difficulty swallowing solid foods. The patient reports feeling like food gets stuck in her throat, and that she has to drink a lot of water to swallow her meals. Over the past 3 months, she has had progressive fatigue and occasional dyspnea while performing her daily activities. Her pulse is 104/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor, erythema around the corners of the mouth, and dry, scaly lips. Her fingernails appear spoon-shaped and brittle. Auscultation of the heart shows a grade 1/6 systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows thin membranes that are protruding into the upper third of the esophagus. Further evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following? This patient presents with Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of dysphagia, upper esophageal webs, and iron deficiency anemia (indicated by fatigue, dyspnea, angular cheilitis, koilonychia, brittle nails, pallor, tachycardia, and systolic murmur).

B. Hair loss
C. Thickening of the skin
D. Loss of vibratory sense in the lower limbs
E. Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus
F. Craving for non-nutritive substances

Correct Answer: F

Question

She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with her husband and uses a copper intrauterine device (IUD) for contraception. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows a well-positioned IUD and a 3.5-cm, concentric, hypoechoic, heterogeneous mass in the posterior myometrial wall. B. Repeat ultrasonography in 6 months
C. Remove copper IUD and prescribe oral contraceptive therapy
D. Perform hysteroscopy with endometrial biopsy
E. Obtain MRI of the pelvis

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

He experiences severe ear pain when the right auricle is pulled superiorly. Question

This patient's ECG shows a slow ventricular rhythm (∼ 27/min) with complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. These findings are consistent with a third-degree atrioventricular block (complete AV block). Her hypotension and confusion should raise concern for inadequate perfusion and impending shock.

B. Adminstration of adenosine

D. Implantation of cardiac defibrillator

Question
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of severe right-sided flank pain, fever, and vomiting. He has a history of gout, benign prostate hyperplasia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with allopurinol, tamsulosin, and metformin. Urinalysis shows pyuria, leukocyturia, and WBC casts. Results of blood and urine cultures are pending. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and admitted for empiric treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics. After 4 days, his symptoms have continued to worsen. He is somnolent and not oriented to person, place, or time. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. He is transferred to the intensive care unit and vasopressor therapy is initiated. The physician informs the patient's wife that her husband has developed urosepsis as a complication of his urinary tract infection and that advanced life support may become necessary. A written advance directive provided by the patient's primary care physician includes a do-not-intubate (DNI) order, which was verbally confirmed by the patient upon admission. There is no medical power of attorney. The patient's wife says she wants full life support in case of cardiorespiratory arrest. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? A DNI order expresses a patient's wish to decline the placement of a breathing tube in the event of cardiac or respiratory arrest.”If you can confirm that this decision is in your husband's best interest, I will provide full life support.”1%
”I can only intubate your husband if you obtain a court order to revoke his advance directive.”1%
“I will perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation if needed, but I cannot intubate your husband.”83%
“This may be difficult for you, but your request is unethical. You should respect your husband's wishes.”3%
”I have to respect your husband's wishes and will only provide comfort measures.”11%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for sudden leakage of clear vaginal fluid. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her first child was born at term by vaginal delivery. She has no history of serious illness. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Current medications include vitamin supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Speculum examination demonstrates clear fluid in the cervical canal. The fetal heart rate is reactive at 160/min with no decelerations. Tocometry shows uterine contractions. Nitrazine testing is positive. She is started on nifedipine. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's presentation is consistent with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), which is diagnosed by detection of clear fluid in the cervix and vagina on sterile speculum examination. A positive nitrazine test confirms the presence of amniotic fluid.

A. Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with cesarean section
B. Administer ampicillin and perform amnioinfusion
C. Administer ampicillin and test amniotic fluid for fetal lung maturity
D. Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and azithromycin
E. Administer ampicillin and progesterone
F. Administer betamethasone, ampicillin, and proceed with induction of labor

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain over the past 2 months. The father reports that the pain typically occurs in the morning before she goes to kindergarten. He has also had to bring her home early from kindergarten several times because of similar episodes. He says that her symptoms are not related to any specific type of food and he has not noticed any change in her appetite, toilet use frequency, or stool and urine appearance. He also reports that she often has nightmares of him dying and frequently asks him to stay in her bedroom until she falls asleep. There is no personal history of serious illness and she takes no medications. Her mother died four months ago in a motor vehicle collision. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 50th percentile for weight and 75th percentile for height. There is no decline in the percentiles of her anthropometric measurements since her previous well-child visit. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, her mood and affect are normal. She confirms a history of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain when interviewed separately. A serum test for IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Stool test for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician to the father regarding the management of his daughter's condition? This patient has repeated nightmares, difficulties going to sleep if her father is not near her, and physical symptoms (abdominal pain) that cannot be attributed to a somatic condition."Your child's symptoms are suggestive of somatic symptom disorder. I need to schedule regular follow-up visits with her."4%
"Your child's symptoms are suggestive of pathological grief. I would recommend a specific form of psychotherapy called cognitive behavioral therapy."13%
"Your child's symptoms do not appear to have a clear cause. I would recommend additional investigations including a complete blood count and an abdominal ultrasound."1%
"Your child's symptoms are a normal reaction to her mother's death. Her symptoms will most likely subside over time and she does not require any treatment."28%
"Your child's symptoms are considered normal for her age. Her symptoms will most likely subside over time and she does not require any treatment."3%
"Your child's symptoms are suggestive of separation anxiety disorder. I would recommend a specific form of psychotherapy called parent-child interaction therapy."51%

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing swelling and pain of his right knee for the past month. He has not had any trauma to the knee or previous problems with his joints. He has hypertension. His only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. He works as a carpet installer. He drinks two to three beers daily. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 97 kg (214 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination of the right knee shows swelling and erythema; there is fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. The range of flexion is limited because of the pain. The skin over the site of his pain is not warm. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella; there is no joint line tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A. Gout
B. Septic arthritis
C. Prepatellar bursitis
D. Osteoarthritis
E. Osgood-Schlatter disease

Correct Answer: C

Question
A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of intranasal ketamine in decreasing acute suicidality in teenagers admitted to inpatient psychiatric units. They conducted a pilot study in which 15 participants were randomized to receive intranasal ketamine while 15 participants were randomized to receive a placebo. The investigators ultimately found no statistically significant difference in suicidality after 30 days of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%. They suspect inadequate statistical power. Assuming the investigators intend to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following changes would be most effective to increase the statistical power? Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).

A. Decrease alpha
B. Decrease the sample size
C. Decrease the type II error rate
D. Increase beta
E. Increase the type I error rate

Correct Answer: C

Question

Laboratory studies today show a PSA level of 0.9 ng/mL. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient? Pneumonia together with this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, diarrhea) and CNS symptoms (confusion) suggest Legionnaires' disease, which is caused by infection with Legionella pneumophila. B. Contamination of reheated hospital food

Question
A group of researchers conducted a study to determine whether there is an association between folic acid supplementation before pregnancy and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in offspring. The researchers retrospectively surveyed 200 mothers of children diagnosed with ASD during the first 4 years of life and 200 mothers of children without developmental disorders. All participants were interviewed about their prenatal consumption of folic acid using standardized questionnaires. A 94% response rate was obtained from the surveys. The study ultimately found that folic acid supplementation was associated with lower rates of ASD in offspring (OR = 0.3, p < 0.01). Which of the following type of bias is most likely to have influenced these results? A significant period of time (4 years) has passed between the prenatal exposure being studied here and the administration of the questionnaire.

A. Non-response bias
B. Interviewer bias
C. Latency period
D. Recall bias
E. Survival bias
F. Length-time bias

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question
A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of sharp retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the neck and worsens on inspiration. Last night, he had difficulty sleeping because lying down exacerbated the pain. He was on sick leave last week because of a sore throat and a nonproductive cough. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Cardiac auscultation discloses a regular rate and rhythm and a high-pitched squeaking sound over the left sternal border; no murmurs are heard. There is no jugular vein distention. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Complete blood count and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. Serum troponin I concentration is 0.04 ng/mL and creatine kinase activity is 20 U/L. ECG is shown. Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? ECG shows concave ST elevations in multiple leads (I, II, aVL, V2–V6) with ST depression in lead aVR. These findings suggest pericarditis. The diagnosis of acute pericarditis requires at least two of the following four criteria: characteristic chest pain (pleuritic), pericardial friction rub, typical ECG changes (diffuse, concave, upward-sloping ST segment elevations), and new or worsening pericardial effusion on echocardiography. This patient meets the first three clinical criteria.

A. CT pulmonary angiography
B. Ibuprofen and colchicine therapy
C. Blood cultures
D. Chest x-ray
E. Pericardiocentesis
F. Clopidogrel and aspirin therapy

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Abdominal distention, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, and a dilated large bowel loop suggest lower intestinal obstruction. The delayed passage of meconium, absence of air in the rectum, and a narrow sigmoid colon with a dilated segment on x-ray support the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease.
