Question
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening weakness in his right arm. His symptoms started 5 days ago when he was powerlifting and felt an intense shooting pain in his right elbow that radiated to his shoulder. The pain improved with ice packs, over-the-counter ibuprofen, and rest. He has weakness in his right arm and trouble lifting everyday objects, such as eating utensils. He is eager to return to lifting and is concerned about his ability to participate in sports. Four years ago, he fell off his bike during a triathlon and injured his right shoulder and neck; he finished the race and the pain resolved with ibuprofen. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Inspection of the right arm shows no abnormalities. Active range of motion of the right arm is normal at the shoulder, elbow, and wrist joints. Muscle strength is 3/5 on flexion of the right elbow and on forearm supination but normal elsewhere. Sensation is intact. When the right bicep is squeezed with the elbow flexed, the forearm remains still. Examination of the left arm shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right elbow shows no abnormalities. MRI confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has a history of elbow pain and arm weakness after powerlifting and an abnormal biceps squeeze test, all of which strongly suggest a distal biceps tendon rupture.

A. Splinting in flexion
B. Referral for surgical repair
C. Nerve conduction studies
D. Subacromial glucocorticoid injections
E. Reassurance and follow-up in three weeks

Correct Answer: B

Question
The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result? Sensitivity = (true positives) / (true positives + false negatives)1551%
1520%
1951%
6070%
1403%
1354%

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasonography of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient's effusion will likely improve over the next couple of weeks.

A. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis
B. Transient synovitis
C. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
D. Developmental dysplasia of the hip
E. Septic arthritis
F. Osteomyelitis

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 23-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with acute respiratory distress syndrome due to influenza A. He has no history of serious illness and does not smoke. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Two weeks later, his symptoms have improved. Pulmonary examination shows fewer inspiratory crackles than at the time of admission. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following long-term complications? This long-term complication typically manifests with ground-glass opacities and thickening of the interlobular septa on CT scan.

A. Pulmonary embolism
B. Interstitial lung disease
C. Spontaneous pneumothorax
D. Panacinar emphysema
E. Asthma

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a cough, dyspnea, and fever for 1 day. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. He has metastatic colon cancer and has received three cycles of chemotherapy with 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, and oxaliplatin; his last chemotherapy session was 2.5 months ago. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has been treated with antibiotics and prednisolone for acute exacerbations three times in the past year. His medications include a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. His temperature is 39.1°C (103.1°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 88/69 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods. Two large-bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? The presence of fever, productive cough, crackles, and an infiltrate on the chest x-ray indicate community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). As this patient is hypoxic and has a CURB-65 score of 3 (respiratory rate ≥ 30/min, systolic blood pressure ≤ 90 mm Hg, age ≥ 65 years), he should be hospitalized. Given the patient's history of prior antibiotic treatments, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, possible immunosuppression due to chemotherapy, greenish sputum, and gram-negative rods on Gram stain, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely causal organism.

A. Ceftriaxone and azithromycin
B. Ertapenem
C. Vancomycin
D. Colistin
E. Cefepime and levofloxacin
F. Clarithromycin and amoxicillin/clavulanate

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of frontal throbbing headaches for 3 weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and a brief episode of double vision. She has been taking ibuprofen with only mild improvement of her symptoms. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Medical history is remarkable for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. Her current medications include metformin and vitamin A. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision. Fundoscopic examination of both eyes is shown. An MRI of the brain with contrast shows an empty sella but no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Recurrent headaches and visual changes in a young woman with obesity and a history of vitamin A use raise concern for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Papilledema (a sign of intracranial hypertension) and an empty sella on MRI support the diagnosis.

A. Emergency craniotomy
B. Acetazolamide therapy
C. Cerebral shunt
D. Lumbar puncture
E. Sumatriptan therapy
F. Alteplase therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after she was found yelling at a bookshelf in a public library 30 minutes ago. The patient appears unkempt and restless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. On mental status examination, she talks very fast with occasional abrupt interruptions and frequent changes of topic. She is cooperative but requires continuous redirection. She is disoriented to time and repeatedly tells the physician, “I hear the sun telling me that I was chosen to save the universe.” The remainder of the examination, including cardiopulmonary and neurological examination, shows no abnormalities. The results of routine serum studies show no abnormalities and urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? Auditory hallucinations without a positive toxicology screening or features to suggest an organic medical disease indicate that patient has psychosis due to psychiatric disease.

A. Intravenous haloperidol
B. Oral lorazepam
C. Intravenous ketamine
D. Oral valproic acid
E. Oral risperidone

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a worsening tremor that began 1 year ago. The tremor affects his left hand and improves when he uses his hand to complete a task. He also reports feeling stiffer throughout the day, and he has fallen twice in the past year. He has not noticed any changes in his cognition or mood. He has not had difficulty sleeping, but his wife says that he would kick and punch while dreaming for almost a decade. His mother has Alzheimer disease. He drinks two cans of beer daily. He takes no medications. He appears well-nourished. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient maintains a blank stare throughout the visit. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following? This patient's asymmetrical resting tremor, rigidity, and reduced facial expression (hypomimia) should raise concern for idiopathic Parkinson disease (PD), which is commonly associated with sleep disturbances (e.g., REM sleep behavior disorder) during early stages of the disease.

A. Reduced amplitude on foot tapping
B. Startle myoclonus
C. Impaired vertical eye movements
D. Horizontal gaze nystagmus
E. Extensor plantar response
F. Choreiform movements
G. No abnormalities

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of fever for 3 days. During this period, he has had fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and severe burning with urination. The patient reports that his urine is red and has a strange odor. He has taken acetaminophen twice a day for the past two days with no improvement in his symptoms. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medication is metformin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F). Examination shows right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 40 mm/hr. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites. Urinalysis shows:Results of initial urine cultures are pending. Damage to which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's hematuria? The combination of fever, leukocytosis, urinary symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency, dysuria), and costovertebral angle tenderness in a male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus aged > 60 years is consistent with complicated pyelonephritis (PN). This patient has developed a complication of PN that characteristically manifests with gross hematuria (urine with red streaks) without RBC casts.

A. Renal tubules
B. Renal papilla
C. Urethral epithelium
D. Renal glomerular basement membrane
E. Mucosa of the bladder

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and cough. He has been feeding normally and has not had vomiting or diarrhea. The infant was born at term via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immunizations are up-to-date. Eight months ago, he was treated for a urinary tract infection. Four months ago, he had an uncomplicated upper respiratory infection. He is alert and well-appearing. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 90/56 mm Hg. Examination shows erythematous nasal mucosa. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. After administration of an antipyretic, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient’s presentation suggests uncomplicated bronchiolitis. His chest x-ray shows a thymic sail sign.

A. Provide reassurance
B. Begin oral antibiotic therapy
C. Obtain a CT scan of the chest
D. Measure serum immunoglobulin levels
E. Measure T cell count
F. Perform bronchoscopy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, has back pain and numbness in her lower extremities after an emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy 3856-g (8-lb, 8-oz) newborn male. She had a placental abruption and lost approximately 2000 mL of blood. During the procedure, she received two units of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensation to temperature and pinprick below her waist. She feels the vibrations of a tuning fork placed on both of her great toes. Muscle strength is 0/5 in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in the lower extremities and 2+ in the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? The dorsal columns, which are located posteromedially within the spinal cord, transmit ipsilateral proprioceptive, vibratory, and some light-touch sensation, while the anterolateral spinothalamic tracts transmit contralateral pain and temperature sensations. The anterior corticospinal tracts transmit ipsilateral motor impulses.

A. Tabes dorsalis
B. Anterior spinal artery syndrome
C. Guillain-Barré Syndrome
D. Brown-Séquard syndrome
E. Posterior spinal artery syndrome

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of early morning headaches for the past 6 months. During this period, he has had severe nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting. For the past month, he has had difficulty walking and intermittent double vision. He was born at term and has been healthy apart from an episode of sinusitis 8 months ago that resolved spontaneously. He is at the 60th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mm Hg. Examination shows normal muscle strength and 2+ deep tendon reflexes bilaterally. He has a broad-based gait and impaired tandem gait. Fundoscopy shows bilateral swelling of the optic disc. B. Schwannoma
C. Pituitary adenoma
D. Craniopharyngioma
E. Hemangioblastoma
F. Meningioma
G. Medulloblastoma

Question
A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in her right index finger. She does not recall injuring her finger but the pain has become progressively worse and over the past 4 days, the painful area has become slightly swollen and red. She works as a bartender at a local bar. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Examination of the right index finger shows an erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold; the nail plate and nail bed appear normal. When light pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the fingertip, a well-demarcated, fluctuating area of blanching appears in the lateral nail fold. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's clinical features and the duration of symptoms (< 6 weeks) are consistent with acute paronychia. A positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess.

A. Soaks with warm water and 1% acetic acid
B. Incision and drainage
C. Eponychial marsupialization
D. Topical mupirocin and betamethasone therapy
Oral dicloxacillin therapy
Correct Answer: B

Question
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for shortness of breath and chest pain. Pulmonary angiography shows a large saddle embolus in the pulmonary arteries. Emergency drug therapy is administered and she is admitted to the hospital for observation. A follow-up CT scan of the chest shortly after admission shows that the thrombus has disappeared. Five hours later, the patient is found to be lethargic with slurred speech. Physical examination shows decreased consciousness, dysarthria, and optic disc swelling bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her neurological symptoms? This patient has most likely been given a thrombolytic agent for a massive pulmonary embolism.

A. Acute metabolic encephalopathy
B. Internal carotid artery dissection
C. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
D. Drug-induced hypotension
E. Embolic cerebrovascular accident
F. Intracerebral hemorrhage

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 3-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 3-day history of progressive lethargy and difficulty feeding. He was born at term and did not have difficulty feeding previously. His temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 220/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 50/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows dry mucous membranes, delayed capillary refill time, and cool skin with poor turgor. Despite multiple attempts by the nursing staff, they are unable to establish peripheral intravenous access. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This infant's poor feeding, lethargy, high fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension should raise concern for septic shock.

A. Rapid sequence intubation
B. Intramuscular epinephrine
C. Femoral vein cannulation
D. Internal jugular vein cannulation
E. Intraosseous cannulation
F. Ultrasound-guided antecubital vein cannulation
G. Umbilical vein cannulation

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of episodic stabbing chest pain. She currently feels well. The pain is unrelated to exercise or rest and does not radiate. The episodes typically last less than 15 minutes and lead to feelings of anxiety. She has not had dyspnea, cough, or lightheadedness. She has no history of serious illness. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. At this visit, which of the following is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for coronary artery disease in this patient? Episodic chest pain that is unrelated to exertion, not increasing in frequency, and described as “stabbing” is consistent with possible cardiac chest pain due to stable coronary artery disease (CAD). However, stable chest pain in women < 60 years or men < 40 years of age without additional risk factors or concerning findings on the initial ECG indicates low pretest probability (PTP) of CAD.

A. Coronary CT angiogram
B. Nuclear exercise stress test
C. Troponin I measurement
D. No further testing at this visit
E. Regadenoson cardiac MRI
F. Dobutamine stress echocardiography

Correct Answer: D

Question

The study shows that 180 patients with tuberculosis and 40 patients without tuberculosis have a positive result with the new test. Which of the following is the specificity of this new test? Question
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his sister for the evaluation of progressive drowsiness and confusion over the past 6 hours. The patient is lethargic and unable to answer questions. His sister says that he has a history of illicit drug use. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, dry skin and dry mucous membranes. The pupils are dilated. The abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are hypoactive. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. ECG shows no abnormalities. B. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor
C. Cannabis
D. Cocaine
E. Opioid

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for coughing, nasal congestion, and intermittent wheezing for the past 2 months. The child has a history of eczema. Since birth, he has had three upper respiratory tract infections that resolved without treatment, and one episode of acute otitis media treated with antibiotics. His family moved into affordable housing 3 months ago. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. B. Spirometry
C. Skin prick testing
D. Throat culture
E. Serum IgA levels

Question
A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of headaches and vision difficulties. She reports mild diffuse headaches during the majority of the day and intermittent blurry vision as well as double vision when she is tired. She sometimes sees flashes of light in her vision. She is in her senior year of high school and feels a lot of pressure to perform well, but has been otherwise healthy. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F). Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Common risk factors are obesity, female sex, tetracycline use, and excessive vitamin A intake.

A. Idiopathic intracranial hypertension
B. Migraine headaches
C. Giant cell arteritis
D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis
E. Multiple sclerosis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of progressively worsening right calf pain. She reports that the pain occurs after walking for about 10 minutes and resolves when she rests. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Her pulse is 78/min and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. Femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Left pedal pulses are 1+; right pedal pulses are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following? This patient presents with intermittent claudication (pain on exertion that is relieved on rest) of her right calf with diminished pedal pulses and decreased ABI (normal range: 1–1.3). These features are characteristic of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Her risk factors include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.

A. Abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring open surgical repair
B. Lower extremity lymphedema
C. Critical limb ischemia requiring amputation
D. Deep vein thrombosis
E. Acute mesenteric ischemia
F. Acute myocardial infarction

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening double vision and drooping of the right eyelid for 2 days. He has also had frequent headaches over the past month. Physical examination shows right eye deviation laterally and inferiorly at rest. The right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or with accommodation. The patient's diplopia improves slightly on looking to the right. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s findings? Double vision, eyelid droop, lateral and inferior eye deviation at rest, and a dilated pupil that does not react to light point to oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy, with both somatic and parasympathetic involvement.

A. Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus
B. Ischemic damage to intraneural arterioles
C. Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery
D. Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
E. Enlarging pituitary adenoma
F. Infarction of the midbrain

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease. She recently moved to a new city. Her father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 46 years. Her paternal uncle died because of small bowel cancer. Her paternal grandfather died because of stomach cancer. Current medications include esomeprazole and a multivitamin. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 6 years but quit 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy is unremarkable. Germline testing via DNA sequencing in this patient shows mutations in DNA repair genes MLH1 and MSH2. Which of the following will this patient most likely require at some point in her life? This woman has three family members with gastrointestinal cancers in two different generations, and one relative was under the age of 50 when diagnosed (3-2-1 rule). These findings fulfill the Amsterdam II criteria for Lynch syndrome, which is caused by mutations in various DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2).

A. Hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy
B. Surgical removal of a desmoid tumor
C. Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy
D. Bilateral prophylactic mastectomy
E. Prophylactic proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis
Annual measurement of carcinoembryonic antigen and CA 19-914%

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of episodic pelvic pain radiating to her back and thighs for 4 months. The pain occurs a few hours before her menstrual period and lasts for 2 days. She has been taking ibuprofen, which has provided some relief. Menses have occurred at regular 28-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years and last for 5 to 6 days. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? Episodic lower abdominal pain shortly before menstruation in an adolescent with a normal physical exam suggests primary dysmenorrhea.

A. Endometrial sloughing and uterine contractions mediated by prostaglandin
B. Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or cervix
C. Activation of lymphatic cells in the intestinal walls and local tissue damage
D. Ascending infection of the uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, or surrounding tissue
E. Fluid-filled sac within the ovary
F. Pregnancy
G. Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall
H. Ascending infection of the urinary tract
. Hormone-sensitive smooth muscle tumor of the myometrium

Correct Answer: A

Question
A clinical trial is conducted to determine the role of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) beta-amyloid levels as a biomarker in the early detection and prognosis of Alzheimer disease. A total of 100 participants are enrolled and separated into three groups according to their Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score: mild dementia (20–24 points), moderate dementia (13–20 points), and severe dementia (< 13 points). Participants' CSF level of beta-amyloid 42 is measured using an immunoassay. The researchers find out that there is a statistically significant difference in CSF levels of beta-amyloid 42 between the groups of dementia severity. Which of the following statistical tests was most likely used to compare the study groups? The statistical test was conducted to determine if there are statistically significant differences in the mean of a continuous variable (CSF beta-amyloid 42 level) between three categories of individuals (mild, moderate, and severe dementia).

A. Chi-square test
B. Fishers exact test
C. Two-sample t-test
D. Pearson correlation analysis
E. Analysis of variance

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-week history of fever and pain in his right thigh that is causing him to limp. She thinks he may have hurt himself during soccer practice. He has no history of rash or joint pain. His older sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient appears well. He is at the 40th percentile for height and 45th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling, tenderness, warmth, and mild erythema over the right upper thigh; range of motion is limited by pain. He has a right-sided antalgic gait. His leukocyte count is 12,300/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 40 mm/h. X-rays of the hips and lower extremities are unremarkable. An MRI of the right lower extremity shows increased T2 and decreased T1 signals over the right femur with periosteal elevation, multiple osteolytic areas in the femoral metaphysis, and bone marrow edema. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This child presents with fever, increased inflammatory markers, and pain in a long bone that is associated with swelling, warmth, erythema, and limited range of motion. This presentation in combination with the MRI findings (periosteal reaction, osteolysis in the metaphysis, bone marrow edema) indicates acute osteomyelitis. Treatment can be initiated after further diagnostic steps are complete.

A. Nafcillin therapy
B. Nuclear scan of the right upper leg
C. CT scan of the right upper leg
D. Femoral osteotomy
E. Antinuclear antibody testing
F. Arthrocentesis
G. Bone biopsy of the right femur
H. In situ fixation of the femoral head

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of mild fatigue and weakness. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 74 μm3. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows 10% HbA2 (N < 3.5). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? In addition to the significant elevation in HbA2, this patient's hemoglobin electrophoresis would most likely show a decreased HbA concentration and increased HbF concentration.

A. Beta thalassemia minor
B. Hemoglobin Barts disease
C. Alpha thalassemia minima
D. Hemoglobin H disease
E. Sickle cell trait

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of persistent dry cough and shortness of breath with mild exertion. She reports feeling too weak to leave the house on most days. She has rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. She used to work as a hotel receptionist but quit her job a year ago because of worsening joint pain. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years but quit 2 years ago. Her medications include methotrexate, folic acid, and enalapril. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows an enlargement of the fingertips with increased curving of the nails and bilaterally enlarged metacarpophalangeal joints. Inspiratory crackles are heard over both lung bases. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown. The diffusing capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? The CT scan shows multiple cystic lesions within the lung parenchyma (honeycomb pattern) and few areas of bronchiectasis.

A. Caplan syndrome
B. Emphysema
C. Pleural effusion
D. Pulmonary edema
E. Pulmonary hypertension
F. Interstitial lung disease

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for 3 days. He has had fever and malaise for the past 5 days. He had a sore throat 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 98/min and blood pressure is 84/62 mm Hg. B. Viral myocarditis
C. Systemic lupus erythematosus
D. Infection with Borrelia burgdorferi
E. Kawasaki disease

Question
A 15-year-old girl with bronchial asthma is brought to the physician by her parents for a follow-up examination. She received a diagnosis of asthma 6 years ago. Her current medications include daily inhaled budesonide-formoterol and a rescue albuterol inhaler as needed. Her parents say that she is doing well in school and is very social. Vital signs are within normal limits. Diffuse end-expiratory wheezes are heard on pulmonary auscultation. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 75% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. Upon checking the patient's records, the physician notices that the patient's spirometry results have been worsening over time. Question

One month ago, she had a 3-day episode of high fever and sore throat that subsided without medical treatment. She appears weak. The abdomen is diffusely tender with no peritoneal signs. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.05. Urine dipstick is positive for blood and protein. A blood smear shows schistocytes and normochromic, normocytic cells. In addition to supportive treatment, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This child presents with thrombocytopenia, findings of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (e.g., schistocytes), and intrinsic acute kidney injury, which is a triad indicating hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). Typical HUS is often preceded by a prodromal gastrointestinal illness; over 90% of pediatric cases of HUS are due to a Shiga-like toxin from enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157:H7.

B. Platelet transfusion
C. Levofloxacin therapy
D. Hemodialysis
E. Eculizumab therapy
F. Unfractionated heparin therapy
G. Plasma exchange therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 10-year-old boy with bronchial asthma is brought to the physician by his mother because of a generalized rash for 2 days. He has also had a fever and sore throat for 3 days. The rash involves his whole body and is not pruritic. His only medication is a fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F) and pulse is 102/min. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and a flushed face except around his mouth. A diffuse, maculopapular, erythematous rash that blanches with pressure is seen over the trunk with a linear, petechial appearance in the axilla and groin. Oropharyngeal examination shows pharyngeal erythema with a red beefy tongue. His hemoglobin is 13.5 mg/dL, leukocyte count is 13,200/mm3 (75% segmented neutrophils, 22% lymphocytes), and platelet count is 220,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely sequela of this condition? Sore throat and fever followed by a diffuse, maculopapular, blanching rash with perioral pallor and a strawberry tongue indicate scarlet fever. The rash of scarlet fever is typically more marked in skin creases (e.g., axilla, groin) and has a linear, petechial appearance known as Pastia lines.

A. Coronary artery aneurysm
B. Hemolytic anemia
C. Hodgkin lymphoma
D. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
E. Encephalitis

Correct Answer: D

Question
A previously healthy 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening jaundice, generalized itching, and epigastric discomfort. He also has nausea and loss of appetite. His stools have looked like clay for the past week. He has returned from a vacation in Thailand one week ago, where he got a new tattoo. Superficial excoriations are seen on all limbs. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. An elevation of which of the following serum findings is most specific for this patient's condition? This patient most likely has a malignant biliary obstruction, as indicated by signs of painless jaundice, pruritus, pale stools, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase. The solitary pancreatic head mass is likely obstructing the biliary and pancreatic ducts and causing subsequent dilation (double duct sign). B. Elevated anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

C. Glucagon
D. Alpha-fetoprotein

Correct Answer: D

Question

Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? The echocardiography findings confirm the diagnosis.

Question
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of epigastric pain, fever, nausea, and malaise. Five weeks ago she had acute biliary pancreatitis and was treated with endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and subsequent cholecystectomy. Her maternal grandfather died of pancreatic cancer. She does not smoke. She drinks 1–2 beers daily. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), respirations are 18/min, pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows epigastric tenderness and three well-healed laparoscopy scars. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Abdominal ultrasound shows a complex cystic fluid collection with irregular walls and septations in the pancreas. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This symptomatic patient (fever, malaise, tender abdomen) previously treated for acute pancreatitis has a complex cyst and elevated levels of amylase and lipase.

A. Pancreatic abscess
B. Pancreatic pseudocyst
C. Pancreatic cancer
D. Acute cholangitis
E. ERCP-induced pancreatitis

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of easy bruising and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past month. He has not changed his diet significantly. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a palm-sized hematoma on his right arm. B symptoms, cytopenias (e.g., anemia, thrombocytopenia), and hepatosplenomegaly are suggestive of a hematological malignancy. B. Cyclophosphamide
C. All-trans retinoic acid

E. Cryoprecipitate transfusion
F. Imatinib

Question
A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained driver. His pulse is 58/min, respirations are 17/min and regular, and blood pressure is 89/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Rectal examination discloses no discernable resting tone and squeezing of the glans penis does not elicit anal sphincter contraction. The remainder of the examination, including a focused assessment with sonography for trauma, shows no abnormalities. B. Intravenous dexamethasone therapy
C. Surgical stabilization of the spine
D. Myelography
E. Phenylephrine therapy
F. Rapid sequence intubation with manual inline stabilization

Question

Question
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful nonhealing lesion that developed on his left toes 2 weeks ago after he accidentally hit them at work. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic retinopathy. His medications include insulin, ramipril, and metoprolol but he often does not take them because he cannot afford to refill his prescriptions. He smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks 2–3 beers daily. He works as a car mechanic. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 89/min, blood pressure is 146/90 mm Hg, and BMI is 29 kg/m2. Question

Question
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has nontremor-dominant Parkinson disease that was diagnosed at the age of 68 after developing progressive bradykinesia and rigidity. He lives alone following the death of his wife 2 years ago. The patient's son, daughter-in-law, and grandchildren live nearby and help him with daily activities. Current medications include levodopa, carbidopa, and entacapone. He appears well. Neurologic examination shows mild hypomimia, bradydiadochokinesia, shortened steps, and mild gait shuffling. During the examination, the patient mentions that he drove himself to his appointment today because he does not want to feel like a burden on his son. The physician is concerned that the patient's illness and medications potentially impair his driving skills. The patient stresses that he has never had an accident in his life and is a very safe driver. He also states that he has felt isolated since his wife's passing and likes to meet up with old friends at a local bar. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction by the physician? The physician must balance responsibility to public safety with the welfare of the individual patient."You should not feel that you are a burden on your son. I'm sure he will be happy to drive you."6%
“I understand that you need your car to stay mobile, but without an official evaluation of your driving capacity, you should not be driving anywhere.”84%
"I have a duty to public safety and unfortunately, I must inform the police that you are still driving."3%
"I would advise you to stop driving, but I cannot tell you what to do. Just be aware that it is solely your responsibility if something bad happens."4%
"I understand this is a difficult situation for you, but I have to ask you to surrender your driver's license now."4%

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
Six days after being admitted to the hospital for cholecystectomy, a 56-year-old woman has high-grade fevers, chills, malaise, and generalized weakness. She has been hospitalized twice in the last year for acute cholecystitis. She had a molar extraction around 2 weeks ago. Her last colonoscopy was 8 months ago and showed a benign polyp that was removed. She has mitral valve prolapse, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, and hypothyroidism. Current medications include metformin, rituximab, levothyroxine, and enalapril. Her temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 138/90 mm Hg. Examination shows painless macules over her palms and soles and linear hemorrhages under her nail beds. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the apex. Blood is drawn and she is started on intravenous antibiotic therapy. Two sets of blood cultures grow coagulase-negative staphylococci. Echocardiography shows a large oscillating vegetation on the mitral valve and moderate mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition? Acute onset of high-grade fever, chills, splinter hemorrhages, and Janeway lesions (painless macules on palms and soles) in combination with a valvular vegetation on echocardiography and two positive blood cultures suggest acute infective endocarditis (IE). The coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species most commonly associated with IE is Staphylococcus epidermidis.

A. Predamaged heart valve
B. Colonic polyp
C. Recent dental procedure
D. Immunosuppression
E. Infected peripheral venous catheter

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of bed-wetting during the past 3 weeks. The mother is concerned because she has received phone calls from the school that her daughter has been acting out in class and making inappropriate jokes. Physical examination shows a thin female body habitus with no axillary or pubic hair. A few pink, fleshy papules measuring 3–5 mm in size are present on the vulva. B. Interview the patient and mother separately
C. Recommend scheduled voiding and fluid restriction at night
D. Contact hospital social workers
E. Perform a urine dipstick test and measure serum glucose
F. Recommend desmopressin therapy

Correct Answer: B

91/10086%

She has no personal or family history of serious illness. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill. Question

Question
A 43-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of fever and night sweats over the past 15 days. During this period, he has also had headaches and generalized weakness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and drinks one to two beers on weekends. He is a known user of intravenous drugs. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left lower sternal border. D. Hematuria
E. Retinal hemorrhages
F. Asymptomatic hemorrhages on palms and soles

Question

Question

Delayed meconium passage, constipation, lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, failure to thrive (with length affected more than weight), abdominal distention, prolonged unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, hypothermia, bradycardia (heart rate < 100/minute in neonates), and macrocytic nonmegaloblastic anemia are features of a condition for which screening is routinely performed 1–2 days after term births.

B. Thyroid function tests
C. Liver biopsy
D. Sweat chloride measurement
E. Stool analysis

Question
A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful left ear with discharge for the past 5 days. The ear pain is constant and slightly improves with over-the-counter ibuprofen. He has no personal history of serious illnesses. He works as a sound technician for a rock band and uses earplugs almost the entire day. He smokes two packs of cigarettes and drinks three to four beers daily. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Examination of the left ear discloses a swollen pinna and a malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a swollen ear canal. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Severe ear pain, otorrhea, ear canal edema, and a tragus tender to touch are suggestive of acute otitis externa (AOE), which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Using earplugs can cause injury to the skin and increase moisture in the external auditory canal, which increases the risk of AOE.

A. Ear swabs, blood cultures, CT scan of the temporal bone, and systemic therapy with intravenous ciprofloxacin
B. Ear swabs and topical therapy with clotrimazole and acetic acid
C. Systemic therapy with oral amoxicillin-clavulanate
D. Topical therapy with betamethasone and acetic acid, and systemic therapy with oral ciprofloxacin
E. Topical therapy with gentamicin, prednisolone, and acetic acid

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe shortness of breath and worsening of her chronic cough. B. Increased pulmonary vasoconstriction

D. Increased arterial pCO

Question
An attending physician in internal medicine publishes an important study about the efficacy of a new drug used to treat Crohn disease. She is currently treating many patients with inflammatory bowel disease who would benefit greatly from this new treatment. After the study is published, the physician receives a letter from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the medication. The company offers her sponsorship of travel, lodging, and registration to present her research at an important international conference on inflammatory bowel disease. The company also offers her funding for a phase III trial with the new drug at the hospital where she is currently working. The company reserves the right to withhold the publication of the physician's research findings after the trial. The physician is very interested in both the drug trial and the conference, where many potential collaborators would be present that could help assist in her research. Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the attending physician? Patients can benefit from collaboration between pharmaceutical companies and physicians. However, clinical research guidelines should be followed to protect the integrity of research, objectivity of the physician's judgment, and general welfare of patients.Reject the trial funding and accept the conference sponsorship but properly disclose the financial support.36%
Accept trial funding and conference sponsorship if the institutional review board gives permission.17%
Accept the trial funding and reject the conference sponsorship.6%
Reject both the offer for the trial funding and the conference sponsorship.39%
To avoid a potential conflict of interest, recommend that a senior resident attend the conference and lead the trial.2%

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes for a prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She was successfully treated with fosfomycin for asymptomatic group B Streptococcus bacteriuria in the first trimester. She has since moved to a different state and has not attended any further routine prenatal visits. Last year, while she was being treated with amoxicillin for bacterial sinusitis, she developed a rash on her chest that resolved spontaneously. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus that is consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation? Indications for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis include positive screening culture for group B Streptococcus (GBS), previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, and GBS bacteriuria at any time during pregnancy.

A. Administration of intrapartum cefazolin
B. Administration of intrapartum penicillin
C. Collection of rectovaginal swab for culture
D. Administration of penicillin to the newborn after delivery
E. Collection of urine culture

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of an unsteady gait that started after waking up that morning. He has no fever, chills, headache, or myalgia. He works as a logger in Washington. He has hypertension and asthma. Current medications include ramipril and inhaled albuterol. His younger sister has multiple sclerosis. The patient appears pale. He is alert and responsive. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 11/min, and blood pressure is 136/86 mm Hg. Examination shows intact cranial nerves. D. Perform lumbar puncture
E. Locate and remove tick

Question

She has used over-the-counter emollients to decrease the intensity of the rash, but they have not had any notable effect. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Question
A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of fatigue and bloody stools. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/65 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. The abdomen is soft, and bowel sounds are normal. Rectal examination shows bright red blood. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8000/mm3, and platelet count is 305,000/mm3. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is begun, blood is sent for type and crossmatch, and a transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells is planned. She is admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of diverticular bleeding and a gastroenterology consult is requested. To facilitate claims payment, a person with a verified health plan identification number from the patient's health insurance company contacts the physician supervising the patient's care and asks, “How long do you think this patient will be in the hospital? ” The patient records include a note by the gastroenterologist that the patient should remain in the hospital for at least 3 days. Which of the following responses by the physician is most appropriate? When a covered entity (e.g., health plan, health care clearinghouse) requests access to protected health information (PHI), the minimum necessary requirement of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) requires hospitals and health care providers to limit access to and disclosure of PHI to what is necessary to accomplish a particular task.

A. "Could you send in a request via electronic mail? I am not allowed to share patient information with you on the telephone."
B. "She will be receiving at least one blood transfusion. It is too early to know how long she will be in the hospital."
C. "I anticipate that the patient will be in the hospital for at least 3 days."
D. "I need a consent release form signed by the patient before I can disclose any information."

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of dyspnea and left-sided chest pain that is worse when she breathes deeply. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 28/min and slightly labored, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. The uterus is consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Left-sided pleuritic pain with decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung field indicate left-sided pleuritis and pleural effusion. B. Decreased fibrinogen levels on serum studies

Question
A 39-year-old woman is evaluated for persistent right-sided flank pain 3 days after admission to the hospital for treatment of acute pyelonephritis. The patient is concerned that “the infection is still there” and asks the physician if this is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? This patient with uncomplicated pyelonephritis has not responded to antibiotic therapy and requires further management."I would have expected your symptoms to have improved by now, so we should perform an abdominal CT scan."27%
"It may take a few days for the antibiotic to have an effect. Let's continue this antibiotic and I will prescribe you more analgesics for the pain."15%
“I am concerned that the infection has entered your bloodstream. I will draw some blood for cultures and start you on fluids."2%
"This may not be the most appropriate antibiotic but the results of the urine culture will tell us more. We will change the antibiotics according to the results."48%
"This antibiotic does not seem to be effective, so we need to try a different one. Let's start you on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole."8%

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 39-year-old woman is examined in the intensive care unit 45 minutes after she sustained a head injury in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. CT scan of the head shows a massive intracranial bleed. After a brain death examination and an apnea test, the patient is declared brain dead. The patient has no living will or advance directives regarding organ donation and was legally competent before her death. She is survived by her 17-year-old son, elder brother, and parents. Her son is currently on a camping trip outside the country. The physician informs the local organ procurement organization, and a representative from the organization inquires with the family about donating the deceased's organs. The patient's brother permits organ donation, whereas her parents strongly disagree. The physician and the representative encourage a family meeting but the family cannot reach an agreement on the patient's most likely wish regarding organ donation. The hospital ethics committee is convened and recommends adhering to the state law in this case. In most states, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding organ donation? In the absence of an oral or written advance directive for a deceased individual, a surrogate decision-maker (SDM) should be designated to act in their best interest. An SDM may be designated by a patient prior to loss of capacity (e.g., durable medical power of attorney), legally appointed (a court-appointed guardian), or appointed via default sequence among the next of kin.

A. Encourage another family meeting with a social worker
B. Initiate organ procurement procedures
C. Request a court-appointed guardian
D. Do not proceed with organ donation
E. Request the patient’s son to intercede and make a decision

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of the gradual onset of fatigue over the past 4 months. He also reports shortness of breath and difficulty concentrating. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears pale. His vital signs are within normal limits. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the toes bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:An oral dose of radiolabeled vitamin B12 is administered, followed by an intramuscular injection of nonradioactive vitamin B12. A 24-hour urine sample is collected and urine vitamin B12 levels are unchanged. The procedure is repeated with the addition of oral intrinsic factor, and 24-hour urine vitamin B12 levels increase. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following? Macrocytic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and decreased vitamin B12 levels are consistent with vitamin B12 deficiency. The Schilling test results are consistent with intrinsic factor deficiency, which suggests pernicious anemia.

A. Type 2 diabetes mellitus
B. Colorectal carcinoma
C. Celiac disease
D. De Quervain thyroiditis
E. Gastric carcinoma
F. Pancreatic carcinoma

Correct Answer: E

Question
A previously healthy 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend after briefly losing consciousness. He passed out while moving furniture into her apartment. She said that he was unresponsive for a minute but regained consciousness and was not confused. The patient did not have any chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing before or after the episode. He has had episodes of dizziness when exercising at the gym. His blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg while supine and 120/70 mm Hg while standing. Pulse is 70/min while supine and 75/min while standing. On examination, there is a grade 3/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a systolic murmur at the apex, both of which disappear with passive leg elevation. A. Prolonged QT interval
B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
C. Bicuspid aortic valve
D. Mitral valve prolapse
E. Orthostatic syncopeVasovagal syncope
F. Carotid sinus syndrome
G. Mitral valve stenosis

Question
A previously healthy 36-year-old man is brought to the physician by a friend because of fatigue and a depressed mood since his wife left him 4 weeks ago. Since then, the patient has stopped participating in weekly bowling nights with his friends and also missed his friend's bachelor's party. He spends his evenings alone at home watching television on the couch. The patient's friend is concerned that he may lose his job because he feels “tired of everything all the time, including work.” He has not missed any work days and has been able to meet all important deadlines. Nearly every night, he wakes up frequently and sometimes takes 20 minutes to go back to sleep. The patient says that he avoids bowling nights because he does not want to see his wife's mutual friends. He also says that he felt too depressed for the bachelor party, which “just did not feel like the right thing at this point in time.” He says that he needs some time to himself in the evening and enjoys watching TV, especially a recent documentary on wildlife in Wyoming. He says that he is planning a trip there to stay alone in a cabin and have some time to think. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He has a flat affect and says that he is going through a difficult phase and does not know how to live without his wife. He denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Emotional or behavioral disturbances that occur within 3 months of an identifiable stressor may indicate an adjustment disorder.

A. Prescribe a short course of alprazolam
B. Initiate cognitive behavioral therapy
C. Prescribe a short course of sertraline
D. Issue a sick note for time off from work
E. Hospitalize the patient

Correct Answer: B

Question

B. Expectant management
C. Methotrexate therapy
D. Cervical cerclage
E. Serial beta-hCG measurement
F. Oxytocin therapy

Question

Question
A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 1 hour after being tackled by a bull on his ranch. Immediately after being knocked over, he had pain in his right lower thoracic region. Twenty minutes later, he became dizzy. His wife says he has no history of previous illness and takes no medications. On arrival, he barely responds to painful stimuli. His temperature is 36ºC (96.8ºF), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 76/62 mm Hg. No source of bleeding is seen besides small lacerations on his extremities. There is a significant ecchymosis in the right lower thoracic region and the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Chest auscultation shows no abnormalities. Peripheral venous access is established, blood samples for crossmatching and blood gas analysis are drawn, and rapid infusion of Ringer lactate (RL) solution is initiated. The patient is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. A FAST scan of the abdomen discloses blood in the hepatorenal recess. After the administration of 500 mL of RL solution, the patient's blood pressure is 80/64 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has a history of blunt trauma and presents with tachycardia, hypotension with decreased pulse pressure, tachypnea, and intraperitoneal blood, the combination of which indicates hypovolemic shock as a result of internal hemorrhage. The bleeding most likely comes from liver laceration caused by a rib fracture (as suggested by ecchymosis on the right lower chest). The next step in management should increase blood pressure and ensure oxygen delivery to the tissue.

A. Perform diagnostic peritoneal lavage
B. Initiate fluid resuscitation with hydroxyethyl starch solution
C. Transfuse O group, Rh negative packed red blood cells
D. Perform CT scan of the abdomen
E. Initiate norepinephrine infusion
F. Administer recombinant activated factor VII

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 78-year-old man with stage IV non-small cell lung cancer is admitted to the hospital for palliative care because of a 2-day history of severe bone pain and insomnia. He has not received opioid medications in the past. Treatment with intravenous morphine via a patient-controlled pump is initiated. Twelve hours later, the patient says, “The pain is still unbearable, please do something or help me sleep forever. I can't do this anymore.” His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 142/72 mm Hg. Examination shows shallow breathing. The patient-controlled analgesia system is checked and found to be functioning properly. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The shallow but rapid breathing, insomnia, and features of sympathetic activation (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension) are most likely due to pain. For terminally ill patients, pain relief is prioritized over the potential adverse effects of pain medication (i.e., the principle of double effect).

A. Increase morphine dosage as needed for pain control
B. Change morphine to a nonopioid analgesic and add zolpidem for insomnia
C. Remove the patient-controlled pump immediately to prevent intentional morphine overdose
D. Continue morphine therapy at the same dosage to avoid respiratory depression
E. Request psychiatric evaluation to assess for suicidal ideation

Correct Answer: A

Question

This drug primarily works via activation of dopaminergic neurons and NMDA antagonism, but whether this has a stimulant or depressive effect depends on the dose. C. Marijuana
D. Cocaine

Question
A 41-year-old woman comes to the office because of burning pain in her right foot for the past month. The pain mostly affects her heel, sole, and toes, but sometimes she can feel it in her calf as well. She has been taking acetaminophen without any relief in her pain. The symptoms are worse at night and after prolonged standing. She needs to wear a uniform at her job at a local restaurant. Her shoes are tight-fitting and, because of the pain, she regularly feels an urge to take them off. Three years ago, she had a right ankle fracture, for which she required surgery. She takes no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right foot shows loss of sensation on the plantar surface; range of motion of the right ankle is normal but going from dorsiflexion to eversion of the right foot causes pain on the medial plantar surface of the foot. Tapping behind the medial malleolus reproduces the burning sensation in the toes and the entire plantar surface of her foot. Compression of the foot at the heel or the forefoot is not painful. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? B. Retrocalcaneal bursitis
C. Achilles tendinitis
D. Morton metatarsalgia
E. Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Question

Question
One week after admission for an acute manic episode with psychotic features, a 27-year-old woman is found sitting on a chair in her hospital room and staring blindly at the ceiling with her head bent backwards. The nurse states that the patient has not changed her position since she first saw her several hours ago this morning. The day before, the patient participated actively in a group psychotherapy session and took a yoga class offered in the psychiatric unit. She has a history of bipolar disorder and has been hospitalized for multiple episodes of acute mania and major depression in the past 5 years. She takes lithium for long-term maintenance treatment. Since admission, she has received several doses of haloperidol, which has gradually reduced her manic symptoms. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. The patient does not react to the physician when she is called by her name or asked to stand up from the chair. Examination shows resistance to passive limb movement. After repositioning, the limbs remain in their new locations. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? This patient shows akinesis, posturing, mutism, negativism, stupor, staring, and waxy flexibility, all of which are classic signs of retarded catatonia. Catatonia can occur in a number of psychiatric diseases (e.g., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, major depressive disorder) as well as organic conditions (e.g., encephalopathy).

A. Hemodialysis
B. Intravenous lorazepam
C. Intravenous benztropine
D. Intramuscular aripiprazole
E. Intravenous dantrolene
F. Oral cyproheptadine

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Over the past 6 months, she has had a 13-kg (28.6-lb) weight loss and intermittent episodes of watery diarrhea. She has generalized anxiety disorder and hypothyroidism. She has a severe allergy to sulfa drugs. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks 2–3 beers daily. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include paroxetine, levothyroxine, and an etonogestrel implant. She is 162.5 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 50.3 kg (110.2 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. She appears pale. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. E. Intravenous trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and oral prednisone

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 6 months. She is a competitive runner and has been training heavily for the past year in preparation for upcoming races. She has no family or personal history of serious illness. She has not been sexually active for the past 9 months. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4° F), pulse is 51/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 106/67 mm Hg. Her BMI is 18 kg/m2. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea? Competitive female athletes often present with amenorrhea, which forms part of the “female athlete triad.”

A. Autoimmune destruction of thyroid cells
B. Poor synthetic response of ovarian cells to circulating LH and FSH
C. Increased prolactin secretion
D. Decreased frequency of GnRH release from the hypothalamus
E. Intrauterine adhesions
F. Increased LH release and increased ovarian androgen production

Question

B. Erythema multiforme
C. Urticaria
D. Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Question
A research group designs a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. By reviewing medical records, the investigators identify a group of patients who were active cocaine users and did not have a history of syphilis as of one year ago. Another group of patients with no history of cocaine use and no history of syphilis infection as of one year ago is also identified. The researchers examine the medical records to determine whether the patients who were actively using cocaine were more likely to have developed syphilis over a 6-month period. The study ultimately finds that the rate of syphilis was 30% higher in patients who actively used cocaine compared to patients who had never used cocaine. This study is best described as which of the following? In this research design, both the exposure (cocaine use) and outcome (syphilis) have occurred before the start of the study.

A. Prospective cohort study
B. Metaanalysis
C. Ecological study
D. Case series
E. Single-blind clinical trial
F. Double-blind clinical trial
G. Retrospective cohort study
H. Cross-sectional study
. Case-control study

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up care. One year ago, she was diagnosed with a 3.8-cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm found incidentally on abdominal ultrasound. She has no complaints. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and COPD. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, glyburide, and an albuterol inhaler. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. B. Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up CT in 6 months
C. Elective endovascular aneurysm repair
D. Elective open aneurysm repair
E. Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 6 months
F. Adjustment of cardiovascular risk factors and follow-up ultrasound in 12 months

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 69-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and fever. He also noticed air bubbles in his urine during this period. He has had three similar episodes of lower abdominal pain and fever with lesser intensity during the past 2 years. The patient says he is worried because “I never saw air in my urine before.” Medical history is remarkable for chronic constipation, hypercholesterolemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He underwent a colonoscopy 1 year ago, which showed focal outpouchings of the colonic wall in the sigmoid colon. Current medications include atorvastatin, metformin, and polyethylene glycol. Temperature is 38.3ºC (101.0ºF). Abdominal examination shows a tender palpable mass in the left lower quadrant. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following? This patient's history of recurrent episodes of fever and lower abdominal pain suggests diverticular disease complicated by diverticulitis. The presence of pneumaturia in a patient with diverticular disease indicates the formation of a colovesical fistula (CVF).

A. Inflammation of the uvea
B. Recurrent urinary tract infections
C. Megaloblastic anemia
D. Metastatic liver disease
E. Chronic inflammation of the bile ducts

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 31-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of increasing restlessness over the past 2 weeks. She reports that she continuously paces around the house and is unable to sit still for more than 10 minutes at a time. During this period, she has had multiple episodes of anxiety with chest tightness and shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with a psychotic illness 2 months ago. Her current medications include haloperidol and a multivitamin. She appears agitated. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The examination was interrupted multiple times when she became restless and began to walk around the room. To reduce the likelihood of the patient developing her current symptoms, a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action should have been prescribed instead of her current medication? A. H2 receptor antagonism
B. NMDA receptor antagonism
C. GABA receptor antagonism
D. 5-HT2A receptor antagonism
αE. 2 receptor antagonism
F. D1 receptor antagonism

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 49-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of recurrent abdominal pain for 1 week. The pain is worse after eating and he has vomited twice during this period. He was hospitalized twice for acute pancreatitis during the past year, most recently 2 months ago. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is a vitamin supplement. He used to drink five beers a day for several years but quit 1 month ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min and blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg. He appears uncomfortable. Examination shows epigastric tenderness to palpation; there is no guarding or rebound. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a 6-cm low attenuation oval collection with a well-defined wall contiguous with the body of the pancreas. In this patient with epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and a history of multiple episodes of acute pancreatitis, the collection of walled-off pancreatic fluid on CT suggests the presence of a pancreatic pseudocyst.

A. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
B. Endoscopic drainage
C. Distal pancreatectomy
D. Laparoscopic surgical drainage
E. Observation and reimaging in 6 weeks

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of shortness of breath. He has also had decreased urine output for the past 2 days. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat treated with over-the-counter gargles and licorice lozenges. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only current medication is metformin. His temperature is 37.2ºC (99ºF) and blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Diffuse bilateral crackles are heard on pulmonary examination. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Serum studies show a creatinine concentration of 2.6 mg/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 32 mg/dL, and positive antistreptolysin O antibody titers. This patient's urinalysis is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings? This patient has oliguria, hypertension, a BUN:creatinine ratio < 15, and features of fluid overload (peripheral edema, dyspnea and crackles indicating pulmonary edema). These findings suggest intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI), most likely due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) secondary to streptococcal pharyngitis that occurred 3 weeks ago (indicated by the positive antistreptolysin O antibody titers).

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E
F. F

Correct Answer: D

Question
A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in the United States using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of US citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This study is best described as which of the following? This study design is analyzing prevalence data in individuals collected at a single point in time.

A. Meta-analysis
B. Single-blind clinical trial
C. Double-blind clinical trial
D. Ecological study
E. Cross-sectional study
F. Case-control study
G. Prospective cohort study
H. Case series
. Retrospective cohort study

Correct Answer: E

Question

B. Abdominal ultrasonography

D. Flexible sigmoidoscopy

Question

Question

Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic presentation. Fetal monitoring shows a heart rate of 145/min with variable decelerations. Five minutes later, after spontaneous rupture of membranes, the fetal heart rate is 60/min. Vaginal palpation shows a thick, pulsating cord. The patient is placed in a knee-chest position and the midwife continuously elevates the fetal head. The bladder is filled with 500 mL normal saline and the patient receives supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Fetal heart rate monitoring now shows a fetal heart rate of 80/min. B. Assisted vaginal delivery
C. Intravenous oxytocin
D. Cesarean delivery
E. Manual replacement of the umblical cord

Correct Answer: D

Question

She is currently unemployed and lives in a low-income neighborhood with her 3 children. For the past 3 years, her HIV RNA viral load was undetectable, but last week, her viral load was 8,391 copies/mL (N < 50). Current medications include dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. On questioning, she says that she misses her medications every other day. Which of the following responses by the physician is most appropriate? An appropriate response should explore the reasons for medication nonadherence in a nonjudgmental manner."Let's talk about what makes it difficult for you to take your medications."97%
"I would like to check whether the virus has become resistant to your drugs."0%
"Are you aware that it is essential to take your medications every day? "1%
"You should know that skipping doses will make your HIV harder to treat."0%
"The social worker can help subsidize next month's medications."0%
"We should go over the instructions on how to take your medications again."1%

Correct Answer: A

Question

She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Question

She has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. Question

This patient's symptoms of renal failure (fatigue, anorexia, nausea, oliguria, hypertension, peripheral edema) are most likely caused by long-standing bilateral hydronephrosis due to upper urinary tract obstruction (as evidenced by bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis, calyces, and proximal ureter).

B. Ureteropelvic junction obstruction
