D. Nephrolithiasis

Question

Question

Question
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of chest pain and rapid heart beating over the past two months. During this period, he has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss, malaise, pain in both knees, and diffuse muscle pain. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection and was started on tenofovir. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities except for tachycardia. There are several ulcerations around the ankle and calves bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms (fever, arthralgia, malaise, weight loss), cutaneous symptoms (ulcerations), cardiac symptoms (chest pain, palpitations), and renal manifestations (proteinuria, hematuria), as well as elevated ESR and leukocytosis, all of which are findings consistent with a multisystemic vasculitis. A. Takayasu arteritis
B. Giant cell arteritis
C. Churg-Strauss syndrome
D. Polyarteritis nodosa
E. Thromboangiitis obliterans
F. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
G. Microscopic polyangiitis

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 74-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue as well as joint pain and stiffness in her shoulders and hips. She says that the stiffness is especially bad in the morning and after having sat on the couch for long periods of time, watching TV or doing crosswords. She has difficulty climbing stairs in the evening because her legs feel “very weak.” She has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and dyslipidemia. She immigrated from South Korea 35 years ago. She worked as a typist for 30 years until her retirement 5 years ago. Her medications include venlafaxine and atorvastatin. She has smoked a half-pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. B. Statin use
C. Age
D. History of psychiatric disease
E. Smoking history

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of fatigue, dry mouth, blurry vision, and a persistent nonproductive cough. She does not have shortness of breath, a rash, or joint pain. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcoholic beverages. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows injected conjunctivae and swollen parotid glands. Examination of the oral cavity shows dry mucous membranes and prominent tongue fissures. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. On slit-lamp examination, tear film break-up time is decreased. The results of a complete blood count show no abnormalities. Serum studies show positive antinuclear antibody titers, negative anti-Smith and anti-dsDNA antibody titers, and IgG4 antibody titers that are within the reference range. An ECG and a CT scan of the chest show no abnormalities. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications? Features of sicca syndrome (e.g., dry mouth and tongue fissures due to xerostomia; blurred vision, injected conjunctiva, and decreased tear film break-up time due to keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and positive antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) in a patient without a history of another autoimmune disorder are consistent with primary Sjogren syndrome (SS).

A. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
B. Lofgren syndrome
C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
D. Retroperitoneal fibrosis
E. Libman-Sacks endocarditis

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for evaluation of several bruises on her lower extremities. She has had these bruises for about 6 weeks, and her mother is concerned that she might be being bullied at school. The patient has had increasing fatigue and pallor over the past several days. She has a history of recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures treated with carbamazepine. She appears pale and ill. There are several subcutaneous purple spots on her legs bilaterally. C. Sickle cell disease
D. Systemic lupus erythematosus
E. Adverse effect of medication
F. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
A 32-year-old woman is evaluated by the physician 3 days after a high-speed motorcycle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. A neurologic examination performed by a resident at the time of admission showed nonreactive pupils and absent brainstem and deep tendon reflexes; a CT scan of the head showed a massive epidural hematoma. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. She does not respond to painful stimuli applied to the shins, sternum, and temporomandibular joint. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right ankle and 2+ in the left biceps. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. Urinary toxicology screening is negative. The apnea test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? The absence of the pupillary reflex, vestibuloocular reflex, corneal reflex, gag reflex, and cough reflex indicate brainstem areflexia, which is one of the criteria for brain death. The presence of cardiac activity and spontaneous or reflex motor responses as a result of bioelectrical activity restricted to the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and muscles (e.g., deep tendon reflexes, Babinski sign, fasciculations, myoclonus) should not be interpreted as evidence against brain death.

A. Somatosensory evoked potentials test
B. No further workup is indicated
C. Nerve conduction test
D. Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
E. Electroencephalography

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 5-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty breathing for the past hour. The parents report noisy breathing and bluish discoloration of their son's lips. Crackles are heard over both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Intubation is performed and methylprednisolone is administered. Methenamine silver staining of bronchial lavage fluid shows aggregates of 2 to 8 cysts with central spores. Serum IgA titers are decreased. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition? This patient's current infection is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (cysts with central spores on methenamine silver staining), which suggests a defect in cell-mediated immunity. A decreased serum IgA level suggests an additional defect in humoral immunity. The diagnosis is therefore a mixed congenital immunodeficiency disorder, most likely hyper-IgM syndrome.

A. Defective WAS gene
B. Defective CD40 ligand
C. Impaired lysosomal trafficking regulator gene
D. Tyrosine kinase gene mutation
E. Chromosome 22 microdeletion
F. Impaired NADPH oxidase

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 22-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 41 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. At the beginning of the second stage of labor, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. Fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the fetal heart tracing findings? This patient's cardiotocograph (CTG) shows short (< 3 minutes), gradual decelerations with an onset, nadir, and recovery that correspond with the onset, peak, and end of uterine contractions, which is characteristic of early decelerations.

A. Maternal hypotension
B. Placental insufficiency
C. Umbilical cord compression
D. Fetal myocardial depression
E. Fetal head compression

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of photophobia and pruritus on the periocular area of the right eye. He also had crusts over the eyelashes of the right eye that morning. The boy has a history of asthma and atopic dermatitis. His medications include inhaled steroids and salbutamol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival injection and redness of the affected eye with watery discharge. There are multiple vesicles with an erythematous base located on the upper and lower eyelids. Visual acuity test shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause? What infection associated with multiple vesicles are patients with atopic dermatitis prone to? 

A. Molluscum contagiosum virus
B. Chlamydia trachomatis
C. Adenovirus
Enterovirus 701%
D. Varicella-zoster virus
E. Staphylococcus aureus
F. Herpes simplex virus
G. Allergens

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. On questioning, she has had occasional morning dizziness and palpitations during the past year. She is a graduate student. She does not smoke and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine on the weekends. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an irregular pulse. On auscultation of the chest, S1 and S2 are normal and there are no murmurs. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The ECG shows several extrasystoles preceded by deformed P waves and no full compensatory pause (RR interval between the preceding and the following QRS complexes is less than twice the normal RR interval). These findings are diagnostic for atrial premature beats (APBs).

A. Reassurance
B. Event recorder implantation
C. Valsalva maneuver
D. Stress echocardiography
E. Administration of metoprolol
F. Administration of flecainide

Correct Answer: A

Question
A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a new antidiabetic drug in decreasing serum glucose concentration. A total of 500 participants are enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. After 6 months, the mean glucose concentration is 121 mg/dL in the new drug group and 124 mg/dL in the placebo group, with a p-value of 0.02 for the observation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the study result? Implementation of research results in clinical practice requires appropriate interpretation.

A. There is a 2% probability that the observed effect is due to chance alone
B. The new drug is unlikely to have a clinically significant impact on patient outcome
C. There is a 98% probability that the new antidiabetic drug is better than placebo
D. The 95% confidence intervals of each group's serum glucose concentration do not overlap

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 59-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of progressively worsening back pain that began about 2 months ago. It started as a dull pain that has now developed into a constant throbbing pain that makes falling asleep difficult. Ibuprofen and acetaminophen do not provide relief. The patient has not had any bowel incontinence, limb weakness, or paresthesias. He has metastatic prostate cancer with known metastasis to the sacrum and left ilium, but has had minimal pain related to these sites. He underwent bilateral orchiectomy two years ago, which was complicated by urinary incontinence. He currently takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is midline tenderness to palpation over the lower lumbar spine. MRI of the spine shows a new sclerotic lesion at the L5 vertebral body. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has new lower back pain secondary to vertebral body metastasis. Treatment is aimed at slowing the growth of the sclerotic lesion and preventing complications such as spinal cord compression.

A. Zoledronic acid
B. Flutamide
C. Spinal surgery
D. Prostatectomy
E. Local radiation
F. Denosumab

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 72-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of right-sided weakness and dysphagia. He is diagnosed with a thrombotic stroke and treatment with aspirin is initiated. A videofluoroscopic swallowing study is performed to determine his ability to swallow safely; he is found to be at increased risk of aspiration. Consequently, he is ordered not to have any food or liquids by mouth. A Dobhoff feeding tube is placed, tube feedings are ordered, and the patient starts receiving tube feedings. Shortly after, he develops a cough and dyspnea. An x-ray of the chest shows opacification of the right lower lobe and that the end of the Dobhoff tube is in his right lung instead of his stomach. Which of the following would most likely have prevented this medical error from occurring? There is a standardized procedure for Dobhoff feeding tube insertion.

A. Two patient identifiers
B. Closed-loop communication
C. Checklist
D. Mortality and morbidity review
E. Computerized physician order entry
F. Fishbone diagram

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 59-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One week ago he had a routine health maintenance examination, during which his blood pressure was 156/94 mm Hg. He has gout, hypercholesterolemia, and peripheral artery disease. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 35 years. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Current medications include aspirin, allopurinol, and atorvastatin. He is 172 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. At the current visit, his temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 162/96 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased lower extremity pulses bilaterally. Serum studies show:An ECG shows no abnormalities. The ratio of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity is within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's newly-diagnosed hypertension, hypokalemia, increased creatinine, elevated BUN/Cr ratio, and history of atherosclerotic disease raise suspicion for renal artery stenosis.

A. Abdominal duplex ultrasonography
B. 24-hour measurement of ambulatory blood pressure
C. Polysomnography
D. Measurement of 24-hour urinary metanephrines excretion
E. Fludrocortisone suppression test
F. Renal arteriography

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 43-year-old woman is evaluated for worsening epigastric pain 2 days after admission to the hospital for gallstone removal via endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. There were no complications during the procedure. The pain is constant and radiates to the back. She has vomited twice since yesterday. She has hypertriglyceridemia treated with gemfibrozil. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears ill. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 129/80 mm Hg. There is tenderness to palpation and abdominal guarding in the epigastric area. Bowel sounds are present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm. Laboratory studies show:Treatment with intravenous fluids is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Epigastric pain that radiates to the back, vomiting, abdominal guarding, leukocytosis, and increased serum amylase and lipase concentrations suggest acute pancreatitis. In this patient who recently underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), the most likely underlying cause is post-ERCP pancreatitis.

A. Intravenous calcium gluconate therapy
B. Intravenous imipenem therapy
C. Repeat endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
D. Intravenous prednisone therapy
E. Intravenous fentanyl therapy
F. Surgical exploration of the abdomen

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 61-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police, who found him in an old campervan in the desert. He is agitated and excessively scratches his arms. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with locally-advanced lung cancer. He has completed several rounds of polychemotherapy and is currently in remission. He is a retired high school chemistry teacher. He reports that his wife, son, and daughter recently left him, and he now lives by himself. He appears disheveled and is sweating profusely. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry oral mucous membranes and severe tooth damage. There are multiple excoriations on the arms. Pupils are 8 mm in diameter and minimally reactive to light. A routine urine toxicology screen shows evidence of substance use. Intoxication with which of the following substances is most likely seen on this patient's urine toxicology screen? This patient's clinical features of agitation, diaphoresis, tachypnea, hyperthermia, tachycardia, hypertension, and pupillary dilation indicate intoxication with a sympathomimetic recreational drug. The excoriations on the skin are suggestive of chronic use of the drug, which can cause formication. It could very well be that this patient lives in Albuquerque, New Mexico. He is the one who knocks.

A. Bath salts
B. Cocaine
C. Methamphetamine
D. Heroin
E. Lysergic acid diethylamide
F. Phencyclidine

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of fatigue, palpitations, nausea, and diaphoresis. The episodes have become more frequent over the past 2 weeks and he has missed work several times because of them. His symptoms usually improve after he drinks some juice and rests. He has had a 2-kg (4.5-lb) weight gain in the past 6 months. He has a history of hypertension and asthma. His sister has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and a budesonide inhaler. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 92/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis? This patient's episodes of palpitations, nausea, fatigue, and diaphoresis that improve with the consumption of sugar (e.g., by drinking juice) should raise concern for episodic hypoglycemia.

A. Oral glucose tolerance test
B. 24-hour urine catecholamine test
C. Dexamethasone suppression test
D. 72-hour fasting test
E. Corticotropin stimulation test

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of weakness, agitation, and slurred speech. She speaks slowly with frequent breaks and has difficulty keeping her eyes open. Over the past three days, she has had a sore throat, runny nose, and low-grade fever. She says her eyes and tongue have been “heavy” for the past year. She goes to bed early because she feels too tired to talk or watch TV after dinner. She appears pale and anxious. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 118/65 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is bluish discoloration of her lips and around the mouth. Her nostrils dilate with every breath. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is generalized weakness of the proximal muscles. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with generalized muscle weakness, agitation, tachycardia, signs of respiratory distress (i.e., tachypnea, cyanosis), and a one-year history of weakness of the eye and bulbar muscles. This constellation of symptoms suggests myasthenia gravis (MG) complicated by acute myasthenic crisis.

B. Pyridostigmine therapy
C. Prednisone therapy
D. Plasmapheresis
E. Thymectomy
F. Endotracheal intubation
G. Administration of edrophonium

Correct Answer: F

Question

Medical history is remarkable for exercise-induced asthma controlled with a metered-dose albuterol inhaler. He works as a hairdresser and says, “My boss told me yesterday to stop working because the customers are scared it might be contagious.” He lives with a roommate who has not had any similar skin symptoms. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms regularly. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows macular erythema, xerosis, and fine, white scaling on the dorsum of the left hand. There are linear fissures in several of the flexural creases of the interphalangeal joints. A. Atopic dermatitis
B. Psoriasis
C. Seborrheic dermatitis
D. Irritant contact dermatitis
E. Scabies

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because he is concerned that she appears sickly and lethargic. She has always had a pale complexion, but it has been getting worse over the past month. She was delivered at home at 36 weeks to a 26-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has not yet been examined by a physician. She is at the 10th percentile for length, 8th percentile for weight, and 2nd percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows a pale infant with facial features of micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, and microopthalmos. The eyes are set widely apart and strabismus is present. She has a high arched palate and there is fusion of the cervical vertebrae with flaring of the skin around the neck. A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best on the left chest. Laboratory studies show:This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings? This infant has Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) based on a pronounced normochromic, macrocytic anemia with normal leukocytes and platelets. She also has many nonspecific dysmorphic features that are typical of the disease, including microcephaly, micrognathia, hypertelorism, microphthalmia, a webbed neck, and a VSD.

B. Spherocytes
C. Triphalangeal thumb
D. Target cells
E. Cafe-au-lait spots
F. Exocrine pancreatic dysfunction
G. Blueberry muffin rash
H. Hypersegmented neutrophils

Correct Answer: C

Question

Her son says that she frequently stumbles into the nightstand when she gets up to go to the bathroom at night. She has a history of celiac disease and frequent bouts of diarrhea. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. B. Retinol
C. Zinc

Question
An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. She lives in a senior living facility in the Midwestern United States. There have been several cases of heavy metal poisoning through drinking water in her state, and she is concerned about potential exposure to toxic substances. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 153 cm (5 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Pulse is 76/min and regular, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. A. High-frequency hearing loss
B. Vertical nystagmus
C. Decreased vibration sensation in the great toe
D. Decreased sense of smell

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 17-year-old boy comes to the office because of a 1-year history of a slow-growing, painless lump on his forehead. He is concerned about the cosmetic appearance of the lesion and asks for it to be removed. He lives alone, supports himself financially without assistance, and has not had any contact with his parents in over a year. Physical examination shows a single, well-circumscribed, soft, rubbery, and mobile mass 1 cm above the right supraorbital ridge. A preliminary diagnosis of lipoma is made. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the doctor? Emancipated minors have legal adulthood before reaching the age of majority. Common ways to attain emancipation include marriage, military service, and living separately from parents while supporting oneself financially.

A. Obtain consent for treatment from the patient's mother
B. Offer surgical removal of the mass to the patient
C. Provide only nonsurgical treatment options to the patient
D. Request a legal competence evaluation
E. Reassure the patient that no treatment is necessary because the mass is unlikely to be cancerous

Correct Answer: B

Question
Three days after an elective total knee replacement surgery for severe osteoarthritis, a hospitalized 66-year-old woman has difficulties sleeping because of knee pain. The physician on call for the night shift enters an order for ketorolac in the patient's electronic health record. Two hours later, a nurse notifies the physician that the drug was mistakenly administered to a patient in the room next door. The physician reviews the electronic records and notices that he had inadvertently entered the order for the wrong patient. The patient to whom ketorolac was administered feels “fine” and does not develop any side effects or require a prolonged hospital stay. Which of the following terms best describes the physician's action? The physician's actions constitute a medical error even though no harm occurred from administering ketorolac.

A. Latent error
B. Ameliorable adverse event
C. Alert fatigue
D. Medical malpractice
E. Sharp end error

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of early satiety and intermittent nausea for the past 3 months. During this period she has also felt uncomfortably full after meals and has vomited occasionally. She has not had retrosternal or epigastric pain. She has longstanding type 1 diabetes mellitus, diabetic nephropathy, and generalized anxiety disorder. Current medications include insulin, ramipril, and escitalopram. B. Exenatide
C. Clarithromycin
D. Metoclopramide
E. Ondansetron

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy since. There is no family history of serious illness. She can write her own name, is able to tie a knot, and can hop on one foot. Her father says that she has started watching television and often plays with his cell phone. She attends school regularly. She has been at the 50th percentile for both height and weight for the last 2 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The father is concerned about the effects of media exposure on his child. The physician recommends limiting screen time to approximately 1 hour daily, content monitoring by parents, and the use of a family media plan with child safety filters. At this visit, it is most appropriate for the physician to provide the father with which of the following additional health maintenance recommendations regarding the child? This guidance should also have been provided during the well-child visit at 3 years of age when toddlers can begin to perform the relevant activity.

A. Prepare separate meals for the child and fix the portion sizes of each meal
B. Ensure that the child is wearing a helmet and knee pads when cycling
C. Include a compulsory daytime nap for the child in her daily routine
D. Set expectations for child's academic performance at school
E. Use a rear-facing seat for the child when she is in a car

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 25-year-old man is brought to the physician because of fatigue, lethargy, and lower leg swelling for 2 weeks. He also noticed that his urine appeared darker than usual and for the last 2 days he has passed only small amounts of urine. His temperature is 37.5°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 154/98 mm Hg. Examination shows 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:Renal biopsy specimen shows a crescent formation in the glomeruli with extracapillary cell proliferation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with nephritic syndrome (oliguria, hypertension, edema, mild proteinuria, hematuria with dysmorphic RBCs). The renal biopsy shows a “crescent-moon shape”, making rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) the most likely diagnosis.

A. Administer rituximab
B. Administer lisinopril
C. Perform hemodialysis
D. Perform plasmapheresis
E. Administer methylprednisolone
F. Administer cyclosporine A

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 58-year-old woman comes to an orthopedic surgeon after referral from her primary care physician because of a 10-year history of right knee osteoarthritis. She has not been able to walk her dog for the past 6 months because of severe pain that worsens with movement; during the past couple of weeks, she has also had pain without movement at night. Medical history is remarkable for several knee injuries from playing soccer in college. Previous treatment with physical therapy, diclofenac, and intraarticular glucocorticoid injections has not provided significant pain relief. She has no other history of serious illness. She is 164 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Range of motion of the right knee is limited; there is palpable crepitus and moderate swelling. X-ray of the right knee joint shows marked osteophyte formation and irregular joint space narrowing. The surgeon wants to schedule the patient for total knee arthroplasty. She has a health maintenance organization (HMO) insurance plan, and the surgeon is an in-network provider. The patient is concerned about potential out-of-pocket costs for this treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate administrative action by the orthopedic surgeon? This strategy, which is also considered when prescribing biological immunosuppressants, aims to control costs and provide only the necessary care.

A. Defer knee surgery until a request for reimbursement is approved by the HMO
B. Inform the patient that she has to pay out of pocket because HMOs do not cover elective orthopedic surgeries
C. Perform the knee surgery and ask the primary care physician to submit a pre-claim review to the HMO
D. Perform the knee surgery and then submit a reimbursement claim to the HMO
E. Ask the patient to seek approval from the HMO for reimbursement prior to surgery

Correct Answer: A

Question

Question
A 67-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He does not take any medications. He drinks 6 to 7 bottles of beer every night, and says he often has a shot of whiskey in the morning “for my headache.” He was recently fired from his job for arriving late. He says there is nothing wrong with his drinking but expresses frustration at his best friend for no longer returning his calls. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician? When addressing substance use with patients who are in the precontemplation stage (i.e., denies the problem and its consequences), it is often helpful to employ strategies that guide the patient toward realizing there is a discrepancy between their goals/values and their current behavior."I'm sorry that your friend no longer returns your calls. It seems like your drinking is affecting your close relationships."1%
"I'm sorry to hear you lost your job. Drinking the amount of alcohol that you do can have very negative effects on your health."0%
"I'm sorry that your friend no longer returns your calls. Why do you think this is the case? "85%
"I'm sorry that your friend no longer returns your calls. Do you feel that your drinking has affected your relationship with your friend? "13%
"I'm sorry to hear you lost your job. I am concerned about the amount of alcohol you are drinking."1%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past 6 months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. He has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. He attends high school and is on the swim team. He also states that he lifts weights on a regular basis. His father has a disk herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Two adjacent vertebrae that are displaced and at different levels on palpation constitute a positive step-off sign.

A. Ankylosing spondylitis
B. Spondylolisthesis
C. Scheuermann disease
D. Facet joint syndrome
E. Disk herniation
F. Overuse injury

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 69-year-old man comes to the physician with a 9-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and need to urinate at night. He occasionally has palpitations but does not have chest pain. The patient had a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago for which he underwent right-sided carotid endarterectomy. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, aspirin, and simvastatin. He appears fatigued. His pulse is 61/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows cold extremities. There are no murmurs or rubs on cardiac auscultation. Fine, bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. There is 2+ lower extremity edema. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and T wave inversions in leads V1 to V4. Which of the following agents is most likely to improve the patient's long-term survival? This patient shows clinical signs of congestive heart failure (CHF), including progressively worsening exertional dyspnea, nocturia, cold extremities, and edema. The patient has had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago, which is a strong risk factor for ischemic heart disease.

A. Eplerenone
B. Amlodipine
C. Ivabradine
D. Dobutamine
E. Furosemide
F. Verapamil
G. Digoxin

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of heavy bleeding and severe pelvic cramping during her menstrual period. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5–6 days, during which she needs to use 6–8 pads daily. The pelvic cramps usually begin 2 days before the onset of bleeding. Naproxen provides only mild pain relief. She worked as a janitor until 2 weeks ago when she was fired for missing several shifts in 1 week because of her symptoms. Medical history is remarkable for tubal sterilization 1 year ago. Both of her children were delivered via uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with her husband. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies, are within the reference ranges. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Her history of tubal ligation indicates that she does not want to have more children.

A. Combined oral contraceptives
B. Reassurance and follow-up
C. Endometrial ablation
D. Hysterectomy
E. Copper intrauterine device

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 75-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for the evaluation of occasional epigastric pain, nausea, and weight loss for the past 2 months. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and a history of recurrent episodes of pancreatitis. Ten years ago, the patient was diagnosed with brief psychotic disorder after the death of his wife. Since then, his mental status has been stable. He lives alone and takes care of all his activities of daily living. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years and drinks two glasses of wine daily. His current medication is metformin. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a pancreatic mass. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a suspicious mass in the head of the pancreas that is classified as unresectable. A needle biopsy specimen of the mass confirms a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. When the doctor wants to enter the patient's room to reveal the diagnosis to the patient, he is approached by the son who says, “If it's cancer, please don't tell him.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response from the physician? A patient with decision-making capacity has the right to full medical disclosure unless there is a good reason to withhold information."I will respect your wish to withhold the diagnosis from your father."0%
"I can help you disclose the diagnosis to your father. He has a right to know."1%
"Can you tell me why you don't want your father to know about the diagnosis? "88%
"As his physician, I cannot withhold any information about your father's health from him."10%
"I propose a psychiatric consultation to assess your father's mental competence."0%

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, depressed mood, insomnia due to vivid dreams, and fatigue. Since yesterday, she has also had nausea and has noticed an unusual “electric shock-like” sensation on her skin. She has had major depression for 6 years and multiple sclerosis for 4 years. Her medications are natalizumab and paroxetine, which she stopped taking 1 week ago after having a positive pregnancy test. She appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows flat affect, gait instability, tremor, and muscle pain. Muscle strength is normal. An MRI of the brain shows multiple old periventricular white matter lesions. A. Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome
B. Serotonin syndrome
C. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
D. Major depression relapse
E. Multiple sclerosis relapse
F. Bipolar disorder

Correct Answer: A

Question

The palpitations are intermittent in nature, with each episode lasting 5–10 seconds. She states that during each episode she feels as if her heart is going to “spin out of control.” She has recently been staying up late to study for her final examinations. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. A. Echocardiography
B. Observation and rest
C. Electrical cardioversion
D. Pharmacologic cardioversion
E. Beta blockers
F. Cardiac catheter ablation

Question

Three weeks ago, an abdominal CT scan showed ovarian metastases surrounding her superior rectum. At the time, she declined a proximal colostomy and provided a written advance directive that designated medical power of attorney to her eldest daughter in the event that she lacked the capacity to make medical decisions. Today, an abdominal x-ray shows a large bowel obstruction. The patient appears lethargic and thin. On mental status examination, she is alert and cooperative. She expresses that she does not want to receive any lifesaving procedures. She accurately describes her medical history and understands the consequences of her decision. The patient's eldest daughter, who is in the emergency department, says that she wants her mother to receive all necessary measures to stay alive. A. Follow the eldest daughter's wishes
B. Ask the patient to reconsider her decision
C. Discharge the patient against medical advice
D. Obtain a psychiatric consultation
E. Follow the patient's orally expressed wishes

Correct Answer: E

Question

B. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

Question
Urinalysis shows:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Question

Question
A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of an episode of syncope 2 hours ago. He reports sudden onset of palpitations followed by loss of consciousness while carrying his groceries to his car. He is unable to recall any further details and does not have any chest pain or dizziness. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastroparesis, and osteoarthritis of the knees. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and ondansetron as needed for nausea. He also takes methadone daily for chronic pain. Apart from an abrasion on his forehead, he appears well. His temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 F), pulse is 104/min and regular, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. While he is in the emergency department, he loses consciousness again. Telemetry shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis that spontaneously resolves after 30 seconds. Results of a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and serum thyroid studies show no abnormalities. Cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope? Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis (sinusoidal waveform) is referred to as torsades de pointes (TdP) and can progress to life-threatening ventricular fibrillation.

A. Prolonged QT interval
B. Acute myocardial ischemia
C. Shortened PR interval
D. Fast accessory conduction pathway
E. Prinzmetal angina
F. Brugada syndrome
G. Hypomagnesemia

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of increasing abdominal pain and distention for 3 days. The pain is diffuse and colicky, and he describes it as 4 out of 10 in intensity. His last bowel movement was 5 days ago. He has not undergone any previous abdominal surgeries. He has hypertension, chronic lower back pain, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Prior to admission, his medications were enalapril, gabapentin, oxycodone, metoprolol, aspirin, and simvastatin. He appears uncomfortable. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast shows a cecal diameter of 11 cm. The patient is kept NPO and intravenous fluids with electrolytes are administered. A nasogastric tube and rectal tube are inserted. Thirty-six hours later, he still has abdominal pain. Examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen. B. Neostigmine therapy
C. Laparotomy
D. Metronidazole therapy
E. Colonoscopy

Correct Answer: B

Question

She recalls being bitten several times by mosquitoes. She has a history of atopic dermatitis. She lives in Massachusetts with both parents and her 4-year-old sister. This patient's circular red rash with central clearing (erythema migrans) and flu-like symptoms (headaches, myalgias) following a recent camping trip to an endemic area (Northeast and Upper Midwest of the US) should raise concern for early localized Lyme disease, which typically occurs 7–14 days after a tick bite. B. Ceftriaxone
C. Clotrimazole
D. Penicillin G
E. Tetracycline

Question

When the resident attempts to talk to the patient, he stares silently at the resident and clenches his fists. In addition to removing potentially dangerous objects from the patient's vicinity and requesting for the presence of additional personnel close by, which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident? This patient's behavior and posture indicates a risk of impending violence. When confronted with an aggressive or violent patient, the health care provider (HCP)'s first priority is to ensure personal safety and attempt to deescalate the situation.

B. Stand between the patient and the ED exit and request that the patient take a sedative medication orally
C. Take turns speaking to the patient with another health care provider
D. Step two arm lengths away from the patient and offer the patient food and water
E. Sit next to the patient and maintain eye contact in silence until the patient calms down

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician for an adolescent wellness examination. She feels well. She plays on her high school's softball team, performs well in school, and gets along with her friends and family. Medical history is unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is not sexually active. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Growth and development are appropriate for age. Vital signs are within normal limits. During physical examination, the physician notices a 1-cm sized hypopigmented macule on the dorsal surface of the left forearm. When the physician inquires about the lesion, the patient says that she burnt herself using a friend's cigarette butt 2 months ago. She says that she does not know why she did it and that her parents do not know about the lesion because she has been covering it with long-sleeved clothing. She says that she has not harmed herself before this incident or since then. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation, hallucinations, or delusions. Her thought process and speech are organized. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient asks the physician not to tell her parents about the skin lesion. In addition to exploring the reasons for the patient's request, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Nonsuicidal self-injury (NSSI) is defined as intentional self-injury to the surface of the body (e.g., cutting, burning, scratching) without suicidal intent and is commonly seen in adolescents. The severity and frequency of the self-injury and the presence or absence of suicidal ideation or other psychiatric comorbidities determine how NSSI is managed.

A. Review with the patient which information will be disclosed to her parents
B. Respect the patient's wishes and provide anticipatory guidance
C. Admit the patient to the hospital for further evaluation
D. Recommend sessions of dialectical behavioral therapy

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Question
A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 35 minutes after an episode of loss of consciousness. He was having dinner with a client when his left arm suddenly became weak and numb. A few minutes later he became tense and his arms and legs began jerking violently, following which he lost consciousness. He has no recollection of this event. He works as a business consultant. He has a history of asthma and major depressive disorder. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and doxepin. He increased the dose of doxepin one week ago because he felt the medication was not helping. He drinks two to three beers on the weekend. He says he uses cocaine 4–5 times per week. On arrival, he is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. His speech is slurred. His temperature is 37°C (98.6F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Neurological examination shows left facial droop. There is 3/5 strength in the left arm. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms? This patient had an episode of focal neurological deficits (weakness and numbness of his left arm) followed by a grand mal seizure (with post-ictal loss of consciousness), making a stroke with a complicating seizure the most likely diagnosis. Due to his relatively young age and the lack of classic risk factors, the stroke most likely occurred secondary to his regular use of cocaine.

A. Antagonism on M3 receptor
B. Ruptured berry aneurysm
C. Tear in the carotid artery
D. Patent foramen ovale
E. Lowered seizure threshold
F. Vasospasm of cerebral vessels

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient? His back pain and neurologic symptoms are suggestive of compressive myelopathy due to metastases.

A. Surgical decompression
B. Surgical stabilization of the spine
C. Radiation therapy
D. Intravenous dexamethasone therapy
E. Intravenous acyclovir therapy
F. Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin therapy
G. Oral ibuprofen therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue and a 9-kg (20-lb) weight gain over the past 12 months. She also has irregular menstrual cycles and difficulty sleeping. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Menarche was at age of 13 years and her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has 1-year history of hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. She drinks a glass of wine daily. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mm Hg. Examination shows acne on the face and hair on the chin and around the umbilicus. The face has a rounded shape and is reddened. There are several smaller bruises on both forearms. This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings? Hirsutism, thin, easily bruisable skin (ecchymoses), moon facies (rounded facial shape), flushing of the face, acne, weight gain, irregular menstrual cycles, hypertension, and fatigue can all be explained by excess production of cortisol, making Cushing syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

A. Decreased serum sodium
B. Periorbital myxedema
C. Increased serum erythropoietin
D. Decreased bone mineral density
E. Discoloration of the corneal margin
F. Enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles

Correct Answer: D

Question

C. Oral albendazole therapy
D. Topical nystatin therapy

Question

The increase in cortisol levels after the ACTH stimulation test suggests secondary adrenal insufficiency, most likely due to her medication nonadherence.

D. D
E. E
F. F

Question
A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass and weight loss. He first noticed the growing mass 2 months ago. The mass is not painful. He also has decreased appetite and intermittent abdominal pain. He has lost 10 kg (22 lb) of weight over the past 3 months. Sometimes, he wakes up in the morning drenched in sweat. He takes daily over-the-counter multivitamins. He appears pale. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a painless, golf ball-sized mass in the anterior triangle of the neck. A biopsy shows large cells with a bilobed nucleus that are CD15 and CD30 positive. Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 14.5 mg/dL and a parathyroid hormone concentration of 4 pg/mL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's serum findings? This patient's B symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever, night sweats), lymphadenopathy, biopsy findings of CD15/CD30 antigens and large cells with a bilobed nucleus (Reed-Sternberg cells) indicate that the patient has Hodgkin lymphoma, which typically causes hypercalcemia by a paraneoplastic mechanism.

A. Osteoblastic metastasis
B. Increased 1α-hydroxylase activity
C. Ectopic PTH-related protein production
D. Multivitamin overdose
E. Osteolytic metastasis

Correct Answer: B

Question

She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Current medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, metformin, and glyburide. She appears ill and is not able to say more than a sentence without resting for a while. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 35/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. On pulmonary examination, crackles and decreased breath sounds are heard at the left lung base. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows an oxygen partial pressure of 50 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest shows consolidation of the left lower lobe. A vaccine against the capsulated strain of this pathogen is a part of the routine childhood immunization schedule and is also indicated for asplenic patients.

B. Mycoplasma pneumoniae
C. Klebsiella pneumoniae
D. Escherichia coli
E. Moraxella catarrhalis

Question

Question
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields? This patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, digital clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, and restrictive pattern of lung disease on spirometry (normal to increased FEV1:FVC ratio, decreased VC) raises concern for interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, which indicate carbon-laden macrophages, and imaging findings are characteristic of exposure to a noxious agent in this field of work.

B. Sandblasting
C. Uranium processing
D. Aerospace manufacturing
E. Farming
F. Coal mining

Correct Answer: F

Question

B. Increased direct bilirubin level
C. Decreased haptoglobin level

Question

Question
A 2-month study is conducted to assess the relationship between the consumption of natural licorice and the development of hypokalemia. A total of 100 otherwise healthy volunteers are enrolled. Half of the volunteers are asked to avoid licorice and the other half are asked to consume licorice daily, along with their regular diet. All volunteers are monitored for the duration of the study and their serum potassium concentration is measured each week. No statistically significant difference in mean serum potassium concentrations is found between the volunteers who consumed licorice regularly and those avoiding licorice. The serum potassium concentrations remained within the range of 3.5–5.0 mEq/L in all volunteers from both groups. Two patients were excluded from the study after their baseline serum potassium concentrations were found to be 3.1 mEq/L and 3.3 mEq/L. If these patients had been included in the analysis, which of the following values would most likely have been unaffected? The two excluded values are outliers, which would cause a negative skew of the sample distribution.

A. Median
B. Mode
C. Standard error
D. Variance
E. Mean

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question
A 66-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 2-day history of vomiting and abdominal pain that radiates to his back. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medication includes enalapril and tamsulosin. Treatment with intravenous fluids and ketorolac is initiated. One day after admission, the patient becomes restless and insists on leaving the hospital to “run some errands” against the advice of his treating physician. When a resident tries to talk to him, the patient suddenly approaches her and screams, “I need to leave now!” A nearby nurse who heard the screaming calls the rapid response team. The arriving psychiatrist slowly approaches the patient without blocking the exit, introduces herself, and calmly asks why he would like to leave the hospital. The patient begins to shout at the psychiatrist and pulls out his intravenous catheter. The psychiatrist asks the patient to sit down and have a glass of water. The patient does not respond and starts mumbling and banging his head against the wall. The psychiatrist says, “I would also like for you to leave this hospital when it is possible.” The patient abruptly turns and throws one of his slippers at the psychiatrist. A. Leave the patient alone and reevaluate him after 15 minutes
B. Administer a sedative medication intramuscularly
C. Ask the patient about his feelings
D. Offer the patient an oral sedative
E. Discharge the patient against medical advice

Correct Answer: B

Question

Question

Question
A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of a urethral discharge and painful urination. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are metformin and amlodipine. He is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife and does not use condoms. He reports that his wife does not have similar symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Genital examination shows purulent discharge from the urethral meatus. B. Oral cefixime for the patient and his wife

D. Oral doxycycline for the patient and his wife
E. Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime and doxycycline for his wife

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain during intercourse and vaginal dryness. The patient has also had intermittent hot flashes and fatigue during this time. Over the past year, her periods have become irregular. Her last menstrual period was over 6 months ago. She is sexually active with one partner and does not use protection or contraception. She has a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia during childhood, which has remained in remission. Pelvic examination shows an atrophic cervix and vagina. A urinary pregnancy test is negative. B. Decreased LH levels

D. Increased FSH:LH ratio

Question
A group of bariatric surgeons are investigating a novel surgically-placed tube that drains a portion of the stomach following each meal. They are interested in studying its efficacy in facilitating weight loss in obese adults with BMIs > 40 kg/m2 who have failed to lose weight through nonsurgical options. After randomizing 150 patients to undergoing the surgical tube procedure and 150 patients to nonsurgical weight loss options (e.g., diet, exercise), the surgeons found that, on average, participants in the surgical treatment group lost 15% of their total body weight in comparison to 4% in the nonsurgical group. Which of the following statistical tests is an appropriate initial test to evaluate if this difference in weight loss between the two groups is statistically significant? The surgeons are comparing two groups (surgical treatment versus nonsurgical treatment) with regard to a numeric outcome variable (amount of weight loss).

A. Chi-square test
B. Paired two-sample t-test
C. Analysis of variance
D. Kaplan-Meier analysis
E. Multiple linear regression
F. Pearson correlation coefficient
G. Unpaired two-sample t-test

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of a 9-month history of progressive difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection during sexual intercourse. He says that his erections are weak, both when he wakes up in the morning and at night. The patient reports that his mood is good overall, but he is upset that his desire for sexual intercourse has decreased since he developed erectile dysfunction. He is in a monogamous relationship with his wife. His inability to engage in sexual intercourse has led to intramarital tension, which is making him feel increasingly anxious and stressed. They have two children who are in college. The patient works as a janitor; every day, he walks 2 miles to work but has to pause intermittently because of pain in his thighs. He has hypertension, peripheral arterial disease, and occasional tension headaches. His medications are enalapril, aspirin, pravastatin, and ibuprofen. He smoked cigarettes for 24 years but quit 3 years ago when his granddaughter was born. He does not drink alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, bilateral pedal pulses are decreased; hair growth on the lower extremity is sparse. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's erectile dysfunction? This patient has hypertension, peripheral artery disease, and increased total cholesterol, glucose, and HbA1c levels. Given that he has difficulty attaining and maintaining an erection both during sexual intercourse and upon waking up, the cause of his erectile dysfunction (ED) is most likely organic.

A. Prescribe oral tadalafil
B. Start testosterone replacement
C. Recommend vacuum pump and penis ring
D. Prescribe injectable prostaglandin E
E. Discontinue enalapril therapy
F. Refer for psychotherapy

Correct Answer: A

Question
One week after an aortic valve replacement surgery, a 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 30 minutes after the onset of severe, sharp chest pain. Question

Question
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of watery diarrhea and episodic crampy abdominal pain. He has no fever, nausea, or vomiting. His wife has noticed that sometimes his face and neck become red after meals or when he is in distress. A year ago, he was diagnosed with asthma. He has hypertension. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and enalapril. He drinks one beer daily. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the left sternal border and fourth intercostal space. B. Achlorhydria
C. T-cell lymphoma
D. Megaloblastic anemia
E. Dementia
F. Intestinal fistula

Question
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, night sweats, and a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss over the past 4 months despite having a good appetite. He takes lisinopril, atorvastatin, and tiotropium. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. B. Acute myelogenous leukemia

Question

Question
A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of recurring chest discomfort. The symptoms occur when walking up the stairs to her apartment or when walking quickly for 5 minutes on level terrain. She has not had shortness of breath, palpitations, or dizziness. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include estrogen replacement therapy, metoprolol, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and rosuvastatin. She drinks 3–4 cups of coffee per day. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her pulse is 65/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A resting ECG shows normal sinus rhythm and the results of routine serum studies show no abnormalities. She is scheduled for a cardiac exercise stress test in 2 days. Which of the following is most appropriate to discontinue before the procedure? The goal of cardiac stress testing is to evaluate for stress-induced ischemic changes on ECG and/or imaging. The stress is created by increasing heart rate and contractility (using exercise or dobutamine) or by inducing a coronary steal phenomenon (using vasodilators). Certain medications or substances may have to be withheld prior to testing in order to obtain reliable results.

A. Metoprolol and estrogen
B. Metoprolol and coffee consumption
C. Rosuvastatin and hydrochlorothiazide
D. Rosuvastatin and coffee consumption
E. Lisinopril and estrogen
F. Lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide

Correct Answer: B

Question

Her temperature is 34.2°C (93.5°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. E. Administer exogenous surfactant
F. Place cervical collar

Question

Question
An investigator is conducting a retrospective study on the effects of ivermectin on the treatment of adult patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) during hospitalization. 315 patients are enrolled in the study and categorized further into three treatment groups; the trial period is 3 months. One group receives 6 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, one group receives 12 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, and one control group receives a placebo once daily. The primary endpoint is viral clearance measured as the mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test. The confidence level is set at 95%. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate to compare the results from the different treatment groups? A. Pearson correlation analysis
B. Unpaired t-test
C. Paired t-test
D. Analysis of variance
E. Chi-square test

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

B. Fever

Question

Question
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of an episode of loss of consciousness while he was playing soccer earlier that morning. He was unconscious for about 15 seconds and did not shake, bite his tongue, or lose bowel or bladder control. He has been healthy except for 1 episode of simple febrile seizure. His father died suddenly at the age of 34 of an unknown heart condition. The patient does not take any medications. He is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min and regular, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and a QT interval corrected for heart rate (QTc) of 470 milliseconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? This patient with a family history of sudden death presents with syncope associated with exercise and a prolonged QTc (> 440 milliseconds) on ECG, both of which indicate the diagnosis of long QT syndrome (LQTS). Since there is no indication of a medication adverse effect (e.g., macrolide ingestion) or electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia) that could explain this patient's prolonged QT interval, a congenital rather than acquired LQTS is the most likely diagnosis.

A. Propranolol therapy
B. Implantable cardioverter defibrillator
C. Adenosine therapy
D. Procainamide therapy
E. Cardiac pacemaker
F. Magnesium sulfate therapy
G. Amiodarone therapy
H. Stellectomy

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for 45 minutes. He has dyslipidemia, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, metformin, and atorvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He appears pale and diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy with ST-segment elevation in leads I, aVL, and V1–V6. High-dose aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, sublingual nitroglycerin, and unfractionated heparin are administered. As the patient awaits transport to the nearest emergency room, he collapses and becomes unresponsive. His pulse and blood pressure cannot be detected. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death in this patient? ST-segment elevations on ECG in leads I, aVL, and V1–V6 are consistent with a left anterior descending artery myocardial infarction (MI). The patient's subsequent death within an hour of symptom onset is known as sudden cardiac death (SCD).

A. Papillary muscle rupture
B. Left ventricular failure
C. Ventricular fibrillation
D. Pericarditis
E. Free wall rupture
F. Septal wall rupture
G. Pulmonary embolism

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening rhythmic movements of his right hand for the past 5 months. His symptoms worsen when he is in a meeting and he is concerned that people are noticing it. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient recalls that his father developed bobbing of the head at an older age. He takes no medications. Neurologic examination shows tremor of the right hand with a frequency of approximately 5 Hz when the limbs are relaxed. When the patient is asked to move his arm the tremor decreases. There is reduced arm swing while walking. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? A unilateral resting tremor with a frequency of 4–6 Hz that worsens with stress and improves with voluntary movements, as well as signs of mild bradykinesia (decreased arm swing), are features consistent with Parkinson disease (PD).

A. Donepezil
B. Trihexyphenidyl
C. Clonazepam
D. Topiramate
E. Methimazole
F. Propranolol

Correct Answer: B

Question
A 74-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after he fell from the top of the staircase at home. He reports pain in the neck as well as weakness of the upper extremities. He has hypertension well-controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. He is alert and immobilized in a cervical collar. His pulse is 90/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg. Examination shows bruising and midline cervical tenderness. Neurologic examination shows diminished strength and sensation to pain and temperature in the upper extremities, particularly in the hands. Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes are absent. Strength, sensation, and reflexes in the lower extremities are intact. Anal sensation and tone are present. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the cause of this patient's neurologic examination findings? Bilateral upper extremity weakness with diminished pain and temperature sensation (particularly in the hands) is characteristic of a central cord syndrome at the level of the cervical spine. Strength and reflexes are intact in the lower extremities because the motor fibers supplying the legs run more laterally in the corticospinal tract than the motor fibers supplying the arms. The acute onset of symptoms following trauma indicates that traumatic myelopathy is the underlying etiology.

A. MR angiography of the neck
B. CT angiography of the neck
C. CT of the cervical spine with contrast
D. Cervical myelography
E. X-ray of the cervical spine
F. MRI of the cervical spine without contrast

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash that began 3 days ago. She has low-grade fever and muscle aches. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has had 5 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with a low-grade fever, myalgias, diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles, and a positive VDRL test, all of which suggest secondary syphilis due to an infection with Treponema pallidum. Following a positive VDRL test, confirmation is required to establish the definite diagnosis.

A. Rapid plasma reagin test
B. Treponemal culture
C. Intravenous penicillin G
D. Dark-field microscopy
E. Intramuscular penicillin G
F. Oral doxycycline
G. Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test

Correct Answer: G

Question
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office as a new patient. He has not seen a physician since immigrating from South Africa with his family 1 year ago. His parents report that he has been healthy except for occasional episodes of nasal discharge and sneezing when playing outside. Medical history is remarkable for infantile atopic dermatitis treated with emollients. He received all appropriate childhood vaccinations, including oral polio and the BCG vaccine in South Africa. His mother says that the family has had no known contact with anyone infected with tuberculosis. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient recently immigrated from a country with a high burden of tuberculosis (TB) and should be screened for latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI).

A. Tuberculin skin test
B. No further evaluation is necessary
C. X-ray of the chest
D. Sputum microscopy and culture
E. Interferon-gamma release assay

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 62-year-old man with a 5-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had episodic palpitations over the past week. His only medication is a tiotropium-formoterol inhaler. His pulse is 140/min and irregular, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 116/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and cardiac troponins are within the reference range. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The ECG shows absent P waves, an irregularly irregular tachycardic rhythm, and narrow QRS complexes (indicating supraventricular tachycardia). These are all signs of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Some pulmonary diseases, such as COPD, pulmonary embolism, and pneumonia, are risk factors for developing Afib. Although this patient has palpitations, he has no ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or altered mental status, which means he has stable Afib.

A. Synchronized cardioversion
B. Radiofrequency ablation
C. Procainamide therapy
D. Verapamil therapy
E. Transesophageal echocardiography
F. Propranolol therapy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 20-year-old woman is being prepared to undergo orthodontic bracket placement for a dental overbite. She feels well. Three years ago, she underwent splenectomy for traumatic splenic rupture. She does not have any known allergies and has no family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her only medication is a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac auscultation shows a normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs. The patient is concerned about her asplenic state and asks the physician if she needs to take any antibiotics to decrease her risk of infection. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician? This would also be the most appropriate recommendation for this patient if she did not have asplenia.

A. Administration of oral amoxicillin 60 minutes prior to the procedure
B. Following the procedure, daily administration of oral penicillin V for one year
C. Administration of intravenous cefazolin 30 minutes prior to the procedure
D. Administration of intramuscular clindamycin 60 minutes prior to the procedure
E. No antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated
F. Following the procedure, monthly administration of intramuscular penicillin G for 5 years

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and shortness of breath. Eight months ago, he was treated for bacterial pneumonia. Over the past 2 years, he has also had 7 episodes of fever and purulent nasal discharge, each lasting for 5 to 7 days.
