Question
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of pain in his left hip. The pain started suddenly and has worsened over the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the thigh and is aggravated by movement. He had a fall while cycling around a month ago. He had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago that resolved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. There is no family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Flexing the hip causes external rotation and abduction. His leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and his erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This obese adolescent male has left hip pain, a positive Drehmann sign (passive flexion causes external rotation and abduction), and x-ray findings (widening of the left hip joint, cranial displacement of the femoral neck in relation to the femoral head) suggestive of a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

A. Conservative management
B. Long leg cast
C. Intravenous antibiotic therapy
D. Surgical pinning of femoral head
E. Intraarticular lidocaine
F. Proximal femoral osteotomy

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 36-year-old internal medicine resident at a teaching hospital notices that the head of her department has frequently been tired and irritable over the past 6 months. The physician in question has been known for his unorthodox teaching methods. His colleagues describe him as misanthropic and eccentric, but a brilliant diagnostician of rare diseases. One year ago, he had a vascular infarction of his right quadriceps femoris muscle while playing golf, and ever since has a limp and uses a cane to walk. He is recently divorced and does not have any children. Over the past 3 months, the resident has observed the physician secretly taking pills on several occasions. During this period, he has also stopped attending rounds and charting. He often meets his patients at odd hours and has a tendency to be absent for a prolonged duration without telling anyone of his whereabouts or answering his phone, which has led to numerous complaints by his colleagues. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the resident? The physician in question shows signs of substance use disorder and therefore presents a potential threat to patient safety. B. Notify law enforcement authorities
C. Report the colleague to the local Physician Health Program
D. Contact the state medical licensing board
E. Confront the colleague directly about his behavior

Correct Answer: C

Question

B. Intravenous epinephrine therapy
C. Chest compressions
D. Intravenous amiodarone therapy
E. Mild hypothermia therapy

Question
A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of fever for the past 3 days. They also state that he has been less active and has been refusing to eat. The patient has had two episodes of bilateral otitis media since birth. He was born at term and had severe respiratory distress and sepsis shortly after birth that was treated with antibiotics. Umbilical cord separation occurred at the age of 33 days. The patient appears pale. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 195/min, and blood pressure is 60/40 mm Hg. He is at the 25th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Examination shows a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Oral examination shows white mucosal patches that bleed when they are scraped off. There is bilateral mucoid, nonpurulent ear discharge. Several scaly erythematous skin lesions are seen on the chest. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 38,700/mm3 with 90% neutrophils and a platelet count of 200,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient presents with signs of septic shock (fever, hypotension, tachycardia, decreased peripheral perfusion), bilateral nonpurulent otitis media, mucocutaneous candidiasis (white mucosal patches that bleed when scraped), and a history of recurrent bacterial infections. This presentation in combination with delayed umbilical cord separation (> 30 days postpartum) suggests a specific congenital phagocyte disorder.

B. Defective CD40 ligand
C. Defective IL-2R gamma chain
D. Defective beta-2 integrin
E. Defective NADPH oxidase
F. Defective lysosomal trafficking regulator gene
G. WAS gene mutation

Correct Answer: D

Question
An otherwise healthy 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 14-day history of painful red nodules on her legs associated with malaise and mild joint pains. There is no preceding history of fever, trauma, or insect bites. Her vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the tender lesions on her shins is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Complete blood count and antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are within the reference range. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 30 mm/h. Question

Question

Question

Question

Question

Question
An investigator conducts a case-control study to evaluate the relationship between benzodiazepine use among the elderly population (older than 65 years of age) and Alzheimer dementia. Three hundred elderly patients with Alzheimer dementia are recruited from assisted-living facilities throughout the New York City metropolitan area, and their rates of benzodiazepine use are compared to 300 controls. Which of the following describes a patient who would be appropriate for the study's control group? In this case-control study, patients with Alzheimer dementia (AD), i.e., cases, and those without AD, i.e., controls, are studied to compare the odds of benzodiazepine use between the two groups. In analytical observational studies (e.g., case-control study), a specific step should be performed during the study design phase to avoid selection bias and confounding bias.

A. An 80-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an independent-living community
B. A 64-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an assisted-living facility
C. A 73-year-old woman with coronary artery disease who was recently discharged to an assisted-living facility from the hospital after a middle cerebral artery stroke
D. An 86-year-old man with well-controlled hypertension and mild benign prostate hyperplasia who lives in an assisted-living facility
E. A 68-year-old man with hypercholesterolemia, mild benign prostate hyperplasia, and poorly-controlled diabetes who is hospitalized for pneumonia

Question
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a cough and mild shortness of breath for the past 12 hours. He has not had fever. He has been to the emergency department 4 times during the past 6 months for treatment of asthma exacerbations. His 9-month-old sister was treated for bronchiolitis a week ago. His father has allergic rhinitis. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and a formoterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears in mild distress. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 86/60 mm Hg. Examination shows mild intercostal and subcostal retractions. This child presents with acute onset cough and shortness of breath and has unilateral wheezing and reduced air entry along with hyperlucency of the lung fields, which indicate a foreign body aspiration (FBA) with ball-valve foreign body obstruction. B. Bronchoscopy
C. Albuterol nebulization
D. Racemic epinephrine
E. CT of the lung

Question
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressive fatigue and joint pain. She has a 1-year history of skin changes and a 4-month history of episodic pallor of her fingers. She reports that the skin of her face, neck, and hands is always dry and itchy; there are also numerous “red spots” on her face. She has become more “clumsy” and often drops objects. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with lansoprazole. She does not smoke. She occasionally drinks a beer or a glass of wine. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 154/98 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min. Examination shows hardening and thickening of the skin of face, neck, and hands. There are small dilated blood vessels around her mouth and on her oral mucosa. Mouth opening is reduced. Active and passive range of motion of the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints is limited. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum creatinine concentration is 1.4 mg/dL. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications? This patient presents with fatigue, joint pain and reduced range of motion of her finger joints, Raynaud phenomenon, hardening and thickening of the skin, telangiectasia, and reduced mouth opening (due to perioral skin tightening), the combination of which suggests systemic sclerosis (SSc). The presence of gastroesophageal reflux disease, elevated serum creatinine, and hypertension indicates extracutaneous organ involvement.

A. Dental caries
B. Antiphospholipid syndrome
C. Interstitial lung disease
D. Urolithiasis
E. Dactylitis
F. Swan neck deformity

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 32 weeks' gestation is evaluated for vaginal bleeding. Five days ago, she was admitted to the hospital and started on treatment for a deep vein thrombosis in the right leg. Her pulse is 125/min and blood pressure is 95/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows large hematomas on the upper limbs and swelling in the right calf. There is a large amount of bright red blood in the vaginal vault. Heparin is most commonly used in pregnant women who require anticoagulation since it does not cross the placenta.

A. Protamine sulfate
B. Prothrombin complex concentrate
C. Vitamin K
D. Alteplase
E. Fresh frozen plasma

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital because of a 1-month history of fatigue, intermittent fever, and weakness. Results from a peripheral blood smear taken during his evaluation are indicative of possible acute myeloid leukemia. Bone marrow aspiration and subsequent cytogenetic studies confirm the diagnosis. The physician sets aside an appointed time-slot and arranges a meeting in a quiet office to inform the patient about the diagnosis and discuss his options. He has been encouraged to bring someone along to the appointment if he wanted. He comes to the office at the appointed time with his daughter. He appears relaxed, with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate opening statement in this situation? When delivering bad news, physicians should follow the SPIKES protocol."I may need to refer you to a blood cancer specialist because of your diagnosis. You may need chemotherapy or radiotherapy, which we are not equipped for.”0%
"Your lab reports show that you have an acute myeloid leukemia"3%
"What is your understanding of the reasons we did bone marrow aspiration and cytogenetic studies? "86%
"Would you like to know all the details of your diagnosis, or would you prefer I just explain to you what our options are? "4%
"You must be curious and maybe even anxious about the results of your tests."7%

Correct Answer: C

Question

This patient's alcohol use disorder, epigastric pain, and Cullen sign (periumbilical hematoma) suggest acute pancreatitis, which can also cause respiratory symptoms by triggering a massive release of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-1, TNF-α).

B. Aspiration pneumonia

Question

Today, he feels well but still wakes up frequently at night and cannot sleep through the night. He lives alone in his apartment and has no children. B. Mood disorder
C. Lack of social support

Question
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for an annual well-child examination. Her mother complains that the patient has a poor diet and spends most of the evening at home texting her friends instead of doing homework. She has been caught smoking cigarettes in the school bathroom several times and appears indifferent to the dean's threats of suspension. Two weeks ago, the patient allowed a friend to pierce her ears with unsterilized safety pins. The mother appeals to the physician to lecture the patient about her behavior and “set her straight.” The patient appears aloof and does not make eye contact. Her grooming is poor. Upon questioning the daughter about her mood, the mother responds “She acts like a rebel. I can't wait until puberty is over.” Which of the following is the most appropriate response? A principled approach to caring for a teenage patient must take into account that the teen years are a time of transition from full dependence to (ideally) full autonomy.

A. "What do you think of your mother's version of events? How does it make you feel?"
B. "I am very concerned that your daughter is displaying signs of depression, and I'd suggest that she is seen by a psychiatrist."
C. "Let's run a routine urine toxicology screen to make sure your daughter is not doing drugs."0%
"Would it be possible for you to step out for a few moments so that I can interview your daughter alone?"
D. "I sympathize with you, but I'm afraid if you want to change your daughter's behavior you would have to change her peer group."
E. "Your daughter displays normal signs of puberty. Being overly critical of your daughter is not helpful."

Correct Answer: D

Question

Question

She has experienced similar episodes intermittently over the past 12 months. The episodes began shortly after she started a new job, occur 1 day per month, and last for 4–8 hours. She has no history of serious illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Manual palpation of the pericranial muscles shows tenderness in the neck and shoulders. The remainder of the examination, including neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Once-monthly episodes of nonpulsating, pressing, band-like headache accompanied by a singular autonomic symptom (e.g., phonophobia) and pericranial muscle tenderness lasting 30 minutes to 7 days in conjunction with a normal neurologic examination are characteristic of episodic tension-type headaches (TTHs).

B. Amitriptyline therapy
C. Sumatriptan therapy
D. Ibuprofen therapy
E. Oxygen therapy

Question

His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is mildly distended, and there is mild tenderness to palpation diffusely. There are palpable masses in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination shows hard stool. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Diffuse abdominal pain and distention, palpable masses in the lower abdomen, and hard stool on digital rectal examination are consistent with fecal impaction. B. Begin a physical therapy regimen
C. Place a nasogastric tube and administer polyethylene glycol
D. Perform colonoscopy
E. Perform manual disimpaction

Question
A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after sustaining a stab wound to the right chest. First responders found the patient sitting on the curb experiencing pain where he had been stabbed. On arrival at the hospital, he is alert. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 112/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows several 1–2 cm lacerations and ecchymoses over the face and trunk. There is no neck crepitus. A pocket knife is lodged in the fourth parasternal intercostal space and there is a small amount of blood oozing out of the wound. There is no bubbling of the blood at the wound. The lungs are clear to auscultation with equal breath sounds. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows the knife in situ extending into the right thorax. Both lungs appear normal; they are homogeneously aerated and have no abnormal opacities. Size and shape of the heart are within normal limits. No fractures or tracheal deviation are visible. Both hemidiaphragms and costophrenic angles are sharply demarcated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment? Further diagnostic workup in a hemodynamically stable patient with penetrating chest trauma usually includes a CT scan of the chest and often echocardiography, ultrasonography, or angiography to better visualize intrathoracic structures. The knife that caused this patient's stab wound is still in situ.

A. Right needle thoracostomy
B. Right tube thoracostomy
C. Surgical exploration in the operating room
D. Cricothyroidotomy
E. Emergency department thoracotomy

Correct Answer: C

Question
Three days after undergoing cardiac catheterization and coronary angioplasty for acute myocardial infarction, a 70-year-old man develops shortness of breath at rest. C. Ventricular septal rupture
D. Postmyocardial infarction syndrome
E. Coronary artery dissection

G. Papillary muscle rupture

Question

Question

Question
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after the sudden onset of weakness in his legs and upper arms. He explains that he has been under a lot of stress lately preparing for a set of important exams. He had a similar episode 7 months ago the first night after finishing a football tournament with his high school. At the time, the weakness lasted 5 hours and resolved completely without treatment. At follow-up examination, the results of a complete blood count, routine serum studies, and an MRI of the brain and spine showed no abnormalities. Medical and family history is otherwise unremarkable. He is not sexually active. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. He smokes 2–3 cigarettes daily and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears to be in mild distress. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the hip flexors and knee extensors, 3/5 in the shoulder abductors, and 4/5 in all other muscle groups. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout. Sensation is intact. Examination of the cranial nerves shows no abnormalities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is normal. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? This ECG shows T wave flattening and inversion, prominent U waves, a prolonged PR interval, and ST segment depression.

A. Myasthenia gravis
B. Becker muscular dystrophy
C. Embolic stroke
D. Conversion disorder
E. Periodic paralysis

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 27-year-old-man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a motorcycle accident. He lost control at high speed and was thrown forward onto the handlebars. On arrival, he is alert and responsive. He has abdominal pain and superficial lacerations on his left arm. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, erythematous area over his epigastrium. The abdomen is soft and non-distended. A CT scan of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Treatment with analgesics is begun, the lacerations are cleaned and dressed, and the patient is discharged home after 2 hours of observation. B. Liver hematoma
C. Aortic dissection
D. Abdominal compartment syndrome
E. Diaphragmatic rupture
F. Splenic rupture

Question

Question

Question

He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 37 years. Current medications include metformin and sitagliptin. Temperature is 37.5˚C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. The left lower extremity is swollen and erythematous. Auscultation of the lungs discloses mild bibasilar crackles. Arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia and decreased PCO2. This patient's presentation with sudden-onset pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, hypoxemia, hypocapnia, signs of right heart strain (right bundle branch block on ECG), and features of deep venous thrombosis (asymmetric lower extremity swelling) is concerning for pulmonary embolism (PE). B. Increased PaO2/FiO2 ratio

Question

He has asthma and eczema. He uses a glucocorticoid inhaler and an albuterol inhaler but has missed his medications for the past week while on vacation. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Expiratory and inspiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. There are moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions and a decreased inspiratory to expiratory ratio. Nebulized albuterol and ipratropium treatments and intravenous methylprednisolone are given in the emergency department for a presumed asthma exacerbation. One hour later, the child is limp and lethargic. Magnesium sulfate is administered. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. No wheezing is heard on repeat pulmonary examination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has status asthmaticus, a type of severe asthma exacerbation. Question

This patient's features are highly suggestive of sacroiliitis, likely secondary to underlying ankylosing spondylitis (AS). Question

Question
A 16-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department because of palpitations and lightheadedness that began 16 hours ago. He had been binge drinking the night before. He was sedated and electrically cardioverted. An ECG that was recorded following cardioversion showed a regular rhythm with a heart rate of 80/min, a shortened PR interval, and wide QRS complexes with a slurred upstroke. After regaining consciousness, he was admitted for observation. Serum concentration of creatinine and electrolytes were measured to be within the reference range. Twelve hours after cardioversion, the patient again develops palpitations. He does not have lightheadedness or chest pain. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 220/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 112/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A newly recorded ECG shows a regular rhythm, a shortened PR interval, and wide, monomorphic QRS complexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? The slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave) in the ECG obtained following cardioversion indicates preexcitation due to an aberrant pathway. In conjunction with this finding, the shortened PR interval and wide QRS complexes during tachycardia are consistent with antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia. Symptomatic tachycardia in a patient with an aberrant pathway is referred to as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW syndrome).

A. Perform synchronized electrical cardioversion
B. Administer magnesium sulfate
C. Administer verapamil
D. Administer atenolol
E. Administer procainamide
F. Administer adenosine

Correct Answer: E

Question
A previously healthy 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend 1 hour after having a seizure. Earlier that day, he also experienced a nosebleed that took 30 minutes to stop when applying pressure. He has had no sick contacts or history of epilepsy or other seizure disorder. He does not take any medications. He is confused and disoriented. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 128/70 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor and scattered petechiae over the trunk and arms. The neck is supple, and neurological examination is otherwise normal. Laboratory studies show:A peripheral blood smear shows numerous schistocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient presents with symptomatic thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 150,000/mm3, epistaxis, petechiae), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes, elevated LDH, elevated indirect bilirubin, decreased hemoglobin), neurological abnormalities (seizure, confusion), and impaired renal function (elevated creatinine). These findings are consistent with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

A. Electroencephalography
B. Packed red blood cells transfusion
C. Plasma exchange therapy
D. Fresh frozen plasma transfusion
E. MRI of the head
F. Platelet transfusion
G. Intravenous tranexamic acid

Correct Answer: C

Question

Question

Vital signs are within normal limits. Range of motion is normal in the left wrist and left digits. There is numbness in the palmar surface of the left thumb and the left index finger. Question
A 55-year-old man who works as an account manager in the hospital comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of severe pain and swelling of the penis. Initially, the patient is reluctant to disclose the mechanism of injury but then admits that it occurred during penetrative sexual intercourse at a swinger party. He says that he heard a cracking sound, which was followed by intense pain and an immediate loss of erection. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows hematoma and curving of the penis. He is diagnosed with a penile fracture and undergoes uncomplicated surgical repair. After surgery, the patient asks the physician if they could change the diagnosis in his medical records because he is ashamed that his colleagues may read them. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician? Medical records describe a patient's medical history and the care or services provided by health care professionals and facilities, document communication between patients and providers, ensure compliance with regulations and quality standards, and serve as a business record and resource for health care reimbursement.

A. Reject the patient's request
B. Request the patient to submit a formal application to the medical records department
C. Accept the patient's request and make a time-stamped note that the record was modified
D. Accept the patient's request, but inform him that the alteration will result in out-of-pocket expenses for the care provided
E. Reject the patient's request and report it to the hospital ethics committee

Correct Answer: A

Question
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 33 weeks’ gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband 1 hour after the onset of painful contractions. The contractions occur once every 20–30 minutes, last 30–40 seconds, and are associated with an increase in fetal movements. She reports that the pain is not getting worse and that the contractions have been consistent in duration. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she attended all prenatal appointments. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows clear cervical mucus and a firm uterus consistent in size with a 33-week gestation. The cervix is 0% effaced and undilated; the vertex is at -3 station. The fetal heart rate is reassuring. After 2 hours of monitoring in the emergency department, the character of the contractions and pelvic examination findings remain unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Consider the diagnostic criteria of labor contractions, which include the nature of uterine contractions, cervical changes, and descent of fetal presenting part.

A. Administer intravenous magnesium sulfate
B. Admit for continuous monitoring
C. No further action is indicated at this time
D. Administer intramuscular betamethasone
E. Administer oral nifedipine
F. Administer intravenous oxytocin

Correct Answer: C

Question
A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 10-day history of high-grade fever and diffuse joint pain. The mother says her symptoms initially included red, puffy palms, which resolved 3 days ago, followed by a rash on the abdomen. Two weeks ago, she was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection and was treated with amoxicillin. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her immunization records are not available. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a polymorphous truncal rash and injected conjunctivae. Oral examination shows several fissures on the lips and a shiny, red tongue. There is anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Both knees are swollen and tender. Laboratory studies show:This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications? Fever ≥ 5 days, bilateral conjunctivitis, oropharyngeal mucositis (strawberry tongue, cracked and red lips), lymphadenopathy, polymorphous truncal rash, and history of erythematous palms are consistent with Kawasaki disease. Arthralgias, elevated ESR, leukocytosis with left shift, thrombocytosis, elevated transaminases, and normocytic anemia are commonly seen in patients with this condition.

A. Splenic rupture
B. Aplastic crisis
C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
D. Coronary artery aneurysm
E. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

Correct Answer: D

Question

There is 3+ pedal edema and reddening of the palms bilaterally. Breast tissue appears enlarged, and several telangiectasias are visible over the chest and back. Question
A 32-year-old man is brought to the operating room to undergo a hip procedure. Experience has shown that they are all willing and able to voice any concerns they may have to other members of the team. The anesthesiologist verifies the patient's name and date of birth. After general anesthesia is administered, the circulating nurse initiates a discussion among the surgeon, surgical physician assistant, anesthesiologist, and operating room technician. Each person actively communicates and agrees on the patient's identity, the surgical site, and the procedure. The circulating nurse then documents their conversation, and the surgeon marks the surgical site with his initials. The initial incision is made and the surgery is performed. In the recovery room, the patient's wife asks the recovery room nurse why the bandaging is on her husband's left hip when his right hip was supposed to be operated on. The occurrence of wrong-site surgery can be decreased through active participation by all involved parties and consideration of all risk factors.

A. Engaging in interprofessional communication
B. Marking an "X" on the left hip
C. Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery
D. Involving the patient in the site verification process

Question
A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Four weeks ago, she had increased blood pressure readings of 145/95 mm Hg on both arms. She reports a blood pressure reading of 116/82 mmHg that she measured with a neighbor's home blood pressure monitor 1 week ago. The patient sleeps well and has no history of headaches, palpitations, or epistaxis. She is physically active and walks her dog for 45 minutes every day. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease for which she takes pantoprazole. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She is 162 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 64 kg (141.1 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 148/94 mm Hg on the right arm and 145/91 mm Hg on the left arm. Blood pressure measured 10 minutes later is 144/92 mm Hg on the right arm and 141/89 mm Hg on the left arm. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. B. Duplex ultrasonography
C. Lisinopril therapy
D. Ambulatory blood pressure measurement
E. Reassurance and follow-up at the office in 6 months

Question

Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took on an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Question

The birth weight of the second infant was 2580 g (5 lb 11oz); her current weight is 6500 g (14 lb 5 oz) and she is at the 25th percentile. Both of the twins can raise their head and chest in the prone position, reach for objects, localize sounds, and smile at sounds and sights. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician? "I will refer you to a developmental pediatrician for further assessment."1%
"We will set up examinations at shorter intervals until both children have achieved the same milestones."4%
"I will order a detailed neurological assessment to further investigate your child's developmental delay."0%
"There is no need to worry because differences between twins reaching milestones are normal."94%

Correct Answer: E

Question

Which of the following actions by the hospital staff would most likely have been a HIPAA violation? HIPAA requires covered entities (i.e., health plans, health care clearinghouses, and health care providers) to take all measures necessary to protect the privacy, integrity, and security of both electronic and paper-based protected health information (PHI).

A. Charging a patient for copies of their protected health information
B. Hiring a vendor to destroy protected health information outside the hospital premises
C. Sending protected health information from a personal electronic mail address
D. Calling a patient by their full name in the waiting room

Question

A. Acute myeloid leukemia
B. Sarcoidosis
C. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
D. Chronic myeloid leukemia

Question
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his neighbor 2 hours after ingesting an unknown substance in a suicide attempt. He is confused and unable to provide further history. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/92 mm Hg. His skin is dry. Pupils are 12 mm and minimally reactive to light. An ECG shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy? The symptoms of anticholinergic syndrome can be remembered as: "Blind as a bat (mydriasis), mad as a hatter (delirium), red as a beet (flushing), hot as a hare (hyperthermia), dry as a bone (decreased secretions and dry skin), the bowel and bladder lose their tone (urinary retention and paralytic ileus), and the heart runs alone (tachycardia).”

A. Sodium bicarbonate
B. Naloxone
C. Physostigmine
D. N-acetylcysteine
E. Glucagon
F. Flumazenil

Correct Answer: C

Question
Six days after completing a course of chemotherapy for metastatic colon cancer, a 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of persistent vomiting. This patient presents with persistent vomiting and dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, increased serum osmolality) following chemotherapy. His blood gas analysis is consistent with metabolic alkalosis (increased pH and HCO3-) with respiratory compensation (increased pCO2). The metabolic alkalosis is the result of volume depletion (contraction alkalosis) and loss of gastric H+.

A. Hyponatremia
B. Hypermagnesemia
C. Hypercalcemia
D. Hyperchloremia
E. Hypokalemia

Correct Answer: D

Question
A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 2-day history of malaise and new-onset confusion. The patient has been hemiplegic and bedridden following an ischemic stroke 4 months ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She is oriented to person but not to place or time. Her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 88/59 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Examination of the sacrum reveals an ulcer with exposed subcutaneous tissue and necrotic areas. The skin is warm and well-perfused. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.25, pCO2 of 30 mm Hg, and HCO3- of 14 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient with a necrotic decubitus ulcer presents with altered mental status, subfebrile temperature, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis, which suggests sepsis.

A. CT scan of the head
B. Surgical debridement of the ulcer
C. Intravenous vasopressin therapy
D. Superficial swab of the wound
E. Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 76-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up visit 8 months after undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Medical history is otherwise remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has been on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with clopidogrel and aspirin since TAVR. Other medications include lisinopril and metformin. The patient feels well but is concerned about the number of pills she is taking. She asks about the benefit of taking “two blood clot pills” and wants to know whether she can discontinue one of them. The physician informs the patient that one important indication for antiplatelet therapy after TAVR is the risk of stroke. The physician reviews a recent metaanalysis comparing the effects of single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) to DAPT on the risk of disabling ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR. The graph shows the results of the study. Based on the graph, which of the following conclusions about the metaanalysis is most appropriate? The graph shown is a forest plot that summarizes the findings of a metaanalysis. Squares and horizontal lines represent the results from individual studies, and the combined results are represented by a diamond.

A. The results indicate publication bias and should not be used to make a clinical decision
B. The sample sizes of the individual studies were too small to compare the overall risks of ischemic stroke
C. Ischemic stroke was more common in patients receiving DAPT than in patients receiving SAPT
D. None of the included studies showed a statistically significant increase in risk of ischemic stroke of SAPT compared to DAPT
E. Patients on SAPT appeared to have no statistically significant difference in the risk of ischemic stroke compared to patients on DAPT

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician because she has not yet attained menarche. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Examination shows normal breast development. Scant axillary hair is present. Abdominal examination shows a firm, nontender left inguinal mass. Pelvic examination shows a blind vaginal pouch. Ultrasonography does not show a uterus or ovaries. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms? This patient's serum luteinizing hormone (LH) and testosterone levels will both be elevated.

A. SRY gene defect
B. Mullerian duct agenesis
C. 5α-reductase deficiency
D. Sex chromosome mosaicism
E. Sex chromosome monosomy
F. Androgen insensitivity

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with chest pain. She describes the pain as a squeezing sensation in her chest with radiation to the left shoulder. The episode began about 15 minutes ago when she was sitting reading a book. She has had this pain before, typically in the evenings, though prior episodes usually resolved after a couple of minutes. Her pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 121/87 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 21/min. An ECG shows ST-segment elevations in the inferior leads. Serum troponins are negative on two successive blood draws and the ECG shows no abnormalities 30 minutes later. Which of the following is the best long-term treatment for this patient's symptoms? Angina with reversible ST elevation and the negative troponin is typical for vasospastic angina (Prinzmetal angina).

A. Clopidogrel
B. Diltiazem
C. Aspirin
D. Enalapril
E. Metoprolol

Correct Answer: B

Question
Two days after undergoing surgical aortic valve replacement with a porcine valve, a 59-year-old man develops yellow discoloration of his eyes. He had a similar episode 40 years ago after running a marathon but the discoloration resolved spontaneously. He has a history of calcific aortic stenosis. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's laboratory findings? Asymptomatic jaundice induced by physical stress (e.g., surgery) along with laboratory studies showing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, normal lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and normal liver enzyme levels is consistent with Gilbert syndrome.

A. Impaired bilirubin conjugation
B. Mechanical erythrocyte damage
C. Drug-induced toxicity
D. Absent hepatic glucuronosyltransferase
E. Impaired bilirubin excretion

Correct Answer: A

Question
A group of gastroenterologists is concerned about low colonoscopy screening rates in their region. They decide to implement a free patient navigation program to encourage more individuals to obtain colonoscopies in accordance with US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) guidelines. Individuals were recruited at a community center and randomly assigned into two groups. The first group was enrolled in a patient navigation program and attended monthly meetings, where they were given regular reminders that their adherence to screening guidelines was being evaluated. The second group did not participate in the patient navigation program. Colonoscopy rates were assessed via chart review and showed that 90% of participants in the first group and 34% of people in the second group adhered to screening guidelines. Which of the following most likely contributed to the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates? The frequent reminders given to participants in the first group likely influenced their behavior.

A. Confirmation bias
B. Reporting bias
C. Hawthorne effect
D. Berkson bias
E. Sampling bias
F. Recall bias

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (groans = 2; opens eyes to pain = 2; withdraws extremities to pain = 4).Focused assessment sonography for trauma (FAST)24%

A. Pelvic binder
B. Insertion of intercostal chest tube
C. CT scan of the head and neck
D. X-rays of the extremities
E. Intubation and mechanical ventilation

Correct Answer: F

Question
A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a 5-month history of progressive bilateral ankle swelling and shortness of breath on exertion. He can no longer walk up the stairs to his bedroom without taking a break. He also constantly feels tired during the day. His wife reports that he snores at night and that he sometimes chokes in his sleep. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He has a history of hypertension treated with enalapril. His pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. There is jugular venous distention. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The extremities are warm and well perfused. There is 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. ECG shows right axis deviation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition? The physical examination findings (bilateral ankle swelling, exertional dyspnea, increased jugular venous pressure) and right axis deviation on ECG suggest right ventricular dysfunction.

A. Left ventricular hypertrophy
B. Ischemic heart disease
C. Chronic hypoxia
D. Chronic kidney damage
E. Pulmonary neoplasia
F. Alveolar destruction

Correct Answer: C

Question
A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after the onset of severe nausea and vomiting. He also has cramping abdominal pain and feels fatigued. Two months ago, he injured his lumbar spine in a car accident and lost complete motor and sensory function below the level of injury. He has been bedridden ever since and is cared for at home. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and renal insufficiency. Examination shows dry mucosal membranes and sensory impairment with flaccid paralysis in both lower limbs that is consistent with prior examinations. Laboratory studies show:In addition to administration of intravenous 0.9% saline and calcitonin, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient has symptomatic hypercalcemia, as evidenced by his nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, and elevated serum calcium. His history of prolonged immobilization from his recent accident, decreased parathyroid hormone (PTH), and increased urinary calcium excretion suggest his hypercalcemia is due to increased bone resorption.

A. Reduced calcium intake
B. Parathyroidectomy
C. Thiazide diuretics
D. Hemodialysis
E. Bisphosphonates
F. Glucocorticoids

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue for 4 months. She is unable to do her chores and complains of excessive sleepiness during the day. She has generalized itching. She has not had abdominal pain, fever, or weight loss. She has had chronic low back pain for 6 years. Her current medications include acetaminophen and vitamin supplements. Examination shows scratch marks over the trunk. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows gallbladder sludge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? Fatigue, generalized itching, elevated cholestatic parameters (bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, γ-glutamyl transferase), and normal or slightly elevated aminotransferases are suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), an autoimmune liver disease that occurs mostly among women. Positive ANA and AMA confirm the diagnosis.

A. Liver biopsy
B. Obeticholic acid
C. Atorvastatin
D. Cholestyramine
E. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
F. Ursodeoxycholic acid
G. Budesonide

Correct Answer: F

Question
Two weeks after undergoing below-knee amputation of the left leg, a 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of several episodes of sharp, shooting, and burning pain in her left lower leg for the past 3 days. She is in the military reserve and was involved in active combat 2 weeks ago, during which she sustained multiple gunshot wounds to her left lower leg resulting in irreversible limb ischemia. She is currently taking oral paracetamol, which has provided minimal pain relief. The patient has a history of bronchial asthma for which she uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 123/75 mm Hg. Physical examination of the residual limb shows mild erythema and warmth of the overlying skin with discrete, nonpurulent fluid draining from the suture, and mild tenderness to palpation. Muscle strength in the hip and upper leg is normal bilaterally. Sensation to pain and temperature is normal in the left upper leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? This patient's reporting of new-onset neuropathic pain in her left lower limb despite having undergone left-sided below-knee amputation two weeks ago suggests phantom limb pain.

A. Surgical revision
B. Ibuprofen therapy
C. Spinal cord stimulation
D. Oxycodone therapy
E. Gabapentin therapy

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 2-week history of worsening intermittent headaches, double vision, nausea, fatigue, and a low-grade fever. He has not been able to go to work since then. His wife says that he “was acting weird” last night. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 years ago. His current medications include lamivudine, abacavir, and efavirenz. His wife reports that he has a stressful job and sometimes forgets to take his medications. He appears lethargic. He is oriented to time and person but not to place. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/77 mm Hg. There is nuchal rigidity. On neurologic examination, there is an abduction deficit of both eyes. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,000/mm3, CD4+ lymphocyte count is 95/mm3, and platelet count is 300,000/mm3. Cranial CT scan shows basilar meningeal thickening; there is no evidence of increased intracranial pressure. A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:Results of blood and cerebrospinal fluid cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely infectious agent? This patient's 2-week history of low-grade fever and headaches in combination with altered mental status and nuchal rigidity on physical examination raises concern for subacute meningitis. The presence of a cranial nerve palsy (abducens nerve palsy), bibasilar meningeal thickening on cranial CT scan, and increased adenosine deaminase (ADA) on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis suggest a particular causal organism.

A. Streptococcus pneumoniae
B. Listeria monocytogenes
C. Herpes simplex virus
D. Toxoplasma gondii
E. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
F. Coxsackievirus

Correct Answer: E

Question
A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency and pain on urination for two days. She has had three similar episodes over the past year that resolved with antibiotic treatment. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with one male partner; they do not use barrier contraception. Upon questioning, she reports that she always urinates and cleans herself after sexual intercourse. She drinks 2–3 liters of fluid daily. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. Examination shows mild tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows WBCs and rare gram-positive cocci; a urine pregnancy test is negative. Results of a urine culture are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent similar episodes in the future? In combination with WBCs and gram-positive cocci (likely S. saprophyticus) on urinalysis, urinary frequency and dysuria suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). This patient is experiencing the fourth UTI in one year.

A. Daily intake of cranberry juice
B. Self-treatment at the onset of symptoms with oral cefpodoxime
C. Postcoital vaginal probiotics
D. Treatment of the partner with intramuscular ceftriaxone
E. Postcoital oral amoxicillin/clavulanate
F. Daily oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 3 months

Correct Answer: F

Question
Two days after undergoing a left hemicolectomy for diverticulitis, a 61-year-old man reports increasing sharp lower chest pain and shortness of breath over the past 24 hours. The pain worsens when he takes a deep breath. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. His current medications include lisinopril, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydromorphone for pain control. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, decreased breath sounds are heard over the right lower lung field. Tactile fremitus is decreased. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows elevation of the right diaphragm and opacification of the right lower lung zone. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient? This patient's recent history of abdominal surgery, examination findings (diminished breath sounds and decreased tactile fremitus over the affected lung), and chest x-ray findings (opacification of the right lower lung zone with ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm) indicate postoperative atelectasis.

A. A
B. B
C. C
D. D
E. E

Correct Answer: E
